<p>PREFACE</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-can-mosby-s-review-series-be-used">HOW CAN MOSBY'S REVIEW SERIES BE USED?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-can-mosby-s-review-series-be-used" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mosby's Review Series is designed to help you obtain the most from your preparation and study time for your nursing exams. These books should be used to review essential concepts, theory, and content prior to nursing courses, challenge, certification, or licensing examinations. The review series can be used to prepare for clinical experiences and as a quick reference when providing care of clients. Mosby's Review Series consists of five books:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maternity Nursing</li>
<li>Medical-Surgical Nursing</li>
<li>Mental Health Nursing</li>
<li>Pediatric Nursing</li>
<li>Nursing Pharmacology</li>
</ul>
<p>The series is designed to highlight important information related to the specific content. It is not meant to provide a comprehensive, in-depth coverage of the selected area of nursing. The reference list at the end of each book is a compilation of resources used to develop these books. These references as well as other texts should be consulted when a more comprehensive discussion of a particular topic is desired. Use these books to jog your memory, to reinforce what you know, to guide you to identify what you don't know, and to lead you to appropriate sources for more details. If you are in a formal education setting, these books are not intended to be considered as a substitute for attending classes or completing required reading assignments.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="used-correctly-these-books-can-help-you">Used correctly these books can help you:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#used-correctly-these-books-can-help-you" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Increase your ability to prioritize in clinical situations while using the nursing process.</li>
<li>Increase your ability to remember essential content.</li>
<li>Increase your productivity in studying to leave some time for you and your family.</li>
<li>Apply new behaviors for improvement of your testing skills.</li>
<li>Evaluate your strengths and weakness related to content areas or testing situations.</li>
</ol>
<p>ix</p>
<p>x
▼
PREFACE</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="what-is-unique-about-mosby-s-review-series">WHAT IS UNIQUE ABOUT MOSBY'S REVIEW SERIES?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-is-unique-about-mosby-s-review-series" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Computer disks of exams</li>
<li>Comprehensive rationales</li>
<li>Test-taking tips</li>
<li>Chapter format</li>
<li>References for further reading</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="computer-disk">Computer Disk<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#computer-disk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each book in the series has a comprehensive exam on computer disk. For your convenience, the exam is also included in the book. The answers for the comprehensive exams, like the end of the chapter questions, include the answers, comprehensive rationales, and test-taking tips.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="comprehensive-rationales">Comprehensive Rationales<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#comprehensive-rationales" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include answers and rationales for each option in each test question.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="test-taking-tips">Test-Taking Tips<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These tips aid in your decision-making and facilitate the development of your logical thinking for the selection of the correct answers, especially if you have narrowed your choice to two options.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chapter-format">Chapter Format<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-format" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each chapter contains an easy-to-follow format divided into five sections:</p>
<p><strong>Study Outcomes:</strong> provides an advanced organizer approach to what is in each chapter</p>
<p><strong>Key Terms:</strong> includes the most common difficult terms to recall</p>
<p><strong>Content Review:</strong> is organized and structured by the nursing process to help you identify what is most important</p>
<ul>
<li>All information within each heading is prioritized</li>
<li>Nursing diagnoses are prioritized</li>
<li>Goals are client-centered</li>
<li>Client teaching content is focused for in-hospital and at-home clinical settings</li>
<li>Home care content is included</li>
<li>Older adult alerts are included where applicable</li>
<li>Evaluation criteria includes decision-making tools concerning which actions to take when client's clinical status shows improvement or deterioration</li>
<li>Many tables, charts, and figures contrast, cluster, and simplify information for ease of remembering</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Review Questions:</strong> stand-alone, 4-option multiple choice</p>
<p><strong>Answers, Rationales, and Test-Taking Tips:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Comprehensive rationales: given for each option to explain why it is correct or incorrect</li>
</ul>
<p>PREFACE ▼ xi</p>
<p>▼ Test-taking tips: give strategies to use in situations such as when options are narrowed to two or when you have no idea of a correct answer</p>
<p><strong>References</strong></p>
<p>Current references are suggested for further study if more in-depth discussion is needed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="what-s-in-mosby-s-review-series-nursing-pharmacology">WHAT'S IN MOSBY'S REVIEW SERIES: NURSING PHARMACOLOGY?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-s-in-mosby-s-review-series-nursing-pharmacology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><em>Mosby's Review Series: Nursing Pharmacology</em> includes basic principles of pharmacology and content about medications. The focus is on essentials needed by nurses. Within the initial four chapters, essential content such as fundamentals and principles of pharmacology, and drug therapy provide a basis for the remaining chapters. The remaining chapters are organized by major systems with the most common drug classifications as the building block within each chapter. The content is developed with priorities and most common elements written in order to meet your need for studying, reviewing, and referencing in an expedient manner.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>I express my heartfelt gratitude to those who have endured with me throughout this publication opportunity for a nursing review series: an adventure from idea to reality.</p>
<p>I especially want to thank the following people:</p>
<p><em>Beverly Copland</em>, who thought that I had the potential to complete this project and who eagerly gave me tons of strong support in the initial and ongoing book development phases.</p>
<p><em>Laurie Muench</em>, who picked up the ball in the middle of manuscript preparation and persisted with me through the process to completion of book publication. The response “OK . . . when can I expect it?” provided silent encouragement and sometimes comic relief when my mental and physical energies ran quite low. Laurie’s thoughtfulness and guidance to help me set priorities were invaluable! I am very grateful and fortunate to work with Laurie.</p>
<p><em>Suzi Epstein</em>, who was full of enthusiasm and total support from the birth of the idea for a nursing review series to the final publication of the books. Suzi’s creativity and suggestions provided essential building blocks in the overall development of the series.</p>
<p>My coauthors, for their enormous efforts to produce manuscript content in a short period of time. Their nursing expertise was helpful for the development of the unique aspects of each book.</p>
<p>My wonderful husband, Dan, for his patience, humor, support, and love. His faith in my abilities has sustained my energies and maintained my sense of self.</p>
<p>My parents, Joseph and Mildred Demaske, for their love, encouragement, and prayers.</p>
<p>Paulette D. Rollant</p>
<p>Thanks to Bobby, B.J., and Kristopher for their love and support.</p>
<p>Karen Hill</p>

<p>INTRODUCTION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="how-can-i-use-this-book">HOW CAN I USE THIS BOOK?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-can-i-use-this-book" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This book is designed to work for you—at your convenience. Read the following guidelines first to help save you time and energy during test preparation. The chapters are designed for short, quick intervals of review. Carry this book with you to catch the times when you are stuck and have nothing to do.</p>
<p>The directions will help you to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maximize your individual performance in review and testing situations.</li>
<li>Identify your personal priorities in preparation for testing.</li>
<li>Sharpen your thinking and discrimination skills for testing.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="directions-on-how-to-review">DIRECTIONS ON HOW TO REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#directions-on-how-to-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. Identify your routine for reviewing: the best days, the best time of day</p>
<p>A. Write the days and times on the inside front cover of this book and on your personal calendar and the calendar at home. This communicates to your family or support systems that you will be unavailable to them at these times. It is also a nice reminder every week to yourself that this is important to you.
B. Refer to section V for specific directions on how to develop your routine</p>
<p>II. Scan the table of contents</p>
<p>A. Put a check mark in front of the content with which you are comfortable
B. Circle the content in which you think you are weak
C. Prioritize the weak content with #1 being the weakest content area. Put these numbers in front of your circles.
D. Prioritize the strongest content areas in the same manner</p>
<p>III. When you are feeling a high-energy day</p>
<p>A. Go to the #1 chapter of the weakest content area for review</p>
<p>IV. When you are having a low-energy day</p>
<p>A. Go to the #1 chapter of the strongest content area for review</p>
<p>XXV</p>
<p>xxvi ▼ INTRODUCTION</p>
<p>V. General guidelines for the development of a routine for reviewing
A. Develop a system of review that meets your needs
B. Set aside time when you are least tired or stressed both mentally and physically
C. Limit your review time to a maximum of 90 minutes for the most effective, efficient retention of reviewed content
D. If possible, relax and take a nap after reviewing to further place the information into long term memory. Some research reveals that sleeping for 2 to 3 hours after studying results in a 70 to 80% retention rate of content into long term memory in contrast to 30 to 40% retention when you are active after studying.
E. Use at least one relaxation technique <em>at the onset</em> and <em>at the end</em> of your review time. Deep breathing that is slow with a concentration on the air movement going in and out is one of the best ways to relax physically and mentally.
F. Use at least one relaxation technique <em>during</em> the time you review.
G. If your time is limited, use 10 to 15 minute intervals to review small portions of the content. For example, you may want to review the different aspects of hypertension in one study session.
H. Use a theme per week or per day approach. For example, if there is enough time between your test and when you begin to study, every Monday review something on sodium from the book. Then at work find clients with sodium imbalances, review their charts, and discuss their situations with colleagues or with the clients’ physicians.</p>
<p>Continue with themes for the day such as:</p>
<ol>
<li>Tuesdays are potassium</li>
<li>Wednesdays are calcium</li>
<li>Thursdays are magnesium</li>
<li>Fridays are acidosis situations</li>
<li>Saturdays are alkalosis days</li>
<li>Sundays are fun days. Don’t forget to keep one day to relax and have fun. This allows your mind to work for retention and reorganization of the content that you reviewed during the week.</li>
<li>Weekly themes also might be of help. Do one system per week such as pulmonary, endocrine and so forth.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="directions-on-how-to-use-this-book-for-success">DIRECTIONS ON HOW TO USE THIS BOOK FOR SUCCESS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#directions-on-how-to-use-this-book-for-success" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. Suggested study sequence #1 for each chapter
A. Read the objectives
B. Complete the key terms</p>
<p>INTRODUCTION ▼ xxvii</p>
<p>C. Complete the content review
D. Complete the review questions
E. Review the answers, rationales, test-taking tips</p>
<p>II. Suggested study sequence #2 for each chapter
A. Complete the review questions
B. Review the answers, rationales, test-taking tips
C. Review the missed content areas
D. Review the unfamiliar and the familiar content areas
E. Complete the key terms
F. Complete the objectives to evaluate your level of understanding</p>
<p>III. Suggested study sequence #3 after doing #1 or #2 suggested sequence
A. Complete the comprehensive exam in the book
B. Correct comprehensive exam answers with review of the rationales and test-taking tips
C. List content areas missed, then cluster them in terms of similar content
D. Prioritize these clusters with #1 being the least familiar content
E. Review additional content as directed by the questions you missed</p>
<p>IV. Suggested study sequence #4 before doing #1 or #2 suggested sequence
A. Complete the comprehensive exam in the book
B. Correct comprehensive exam answers with review of the rationales and test-taking tips
C. List content areas missed, then cluster them in terms of similar content
D. Prioritize these clusters with #1 being the least familiar content
E. Implement either sequence #1 or #2
F. Complete the computer comprehensive exam. Note that even though the questions are the same as in the book, you should evaluate how your reading of the questions and options differed as related to perception and consistent ability to identify key words, terms, age, and developmental needs.
G. Review content as needed and directed from your missed questions on your exam</p>
<p>V. Suggested techniques for use of the objectives during your review
A. Read the objectives to have them guide you where to start
B. Put a check next to the ones in which you feel the weakest
C. Prioritize them with #1 being the weakest
D. Review the weakest content first or on high-energy days
E. Review the most familiar content last or on low-energy days</p>
<p>VI. Suggested techniques for the use of the key terms, the content review section, and the exams
A. Key terms—suggested study techniques</p>
<ol>
<li>Use a 3 x 5 index card to cover the definitions of the key terms</li>
<li>State your definition out loud</li>
</ol>
<p>xxviii ▼ INTRODUCTION</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Uncover the definition and read the given definition out loud (speaking the content as well as seeing the content will enhance your retention)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Write key notes in terms of a few words on a 3 x 5 card for the information you have difficulty recalling</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carry the card with you for a few days to review this content again. Suggestion: put the card on your survivor in the car and review it at the stoplight or if stopped in traffic.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Content review—suggested study techniques</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Use a 3 x 5 card to cover the content under a major heading</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>State out loud what 3 or 4 important aspects of the content under the major heading might be or ask yourself a few questions about that content heading. Try to state the items in order of priority.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Uncover the content under the major heading. Check your information against that given in the book. See what you forgot or added that may or may not be important.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Write key notes in terms of a few words on a 3 x 5 card for the information you have difficulty recalling</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carry the card with you for a few days to review this content again. Suggestion: carry the card with you to review whenever you get 5 to 10 minutes free.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When you practice prioritizing the content you will enhance your critical thinking skills</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Exam review—suggested study techniques</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>For all tests read all the rationales and test-taking tips for missed and correct questions. These often contain pearls of wisdom on how to remember or get a better understanding of the content.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember to do a relaxation exercise before you begin your questions and repeat the exercise about every 25 questions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When you miss a question ask yourself
a. Did I not know the content?
b. Did I misread the question or option(s)?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If you miss questions because of a knowledge deficit
a. Make a list on a 3 x 5 card for 3 to 4 days
b. Group or cluster the content according to the steps in the nursing process, the content area, or a system
c. Look up that content
d. Do not look up content after every practice test. A better approach is to cluster the content and look it all up every</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>INTRODUCTION</p>
<p>3 to 4 days. With this approach you will have better retention into long term memory and the best recall at a later time.</p>
<p>e. Try to identify new ways to approach reading questions and their options</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>If you misread the question or the option(s)</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Try to identify what key words, timeframes, ages, and developmental stages that you may have overlooked</p>
<p>b. Try to identify new ways to approach reading the questions and their options</p>
<p>c. Practice, practice and practice doing questions</p>
<p>d. Practice, practice, and practice doing relaxation before you begin the practice exam, after every 10 to 20 questions, and then at the end of the exam to refresh your thinking and diminish your tenseness or tiredness.</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>
<p>Be sure to do a practice exam with the exact number of questions as your real exam. Note after this exam when you were the most tired, anxious, or nervous. Plan to do a relaxation exercise at these times during the real exam.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Your success is directly correlated to your degree of effort to review content as well as relax during the review and exam processes.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="summary">SUMMARY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is hoped that after you have completed your review with the use of this book as your major tool that you have:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maximized your individual performance in review and testing situations.</li>
<li>Identified your personal priorities in preparation for testing.</li>
<li>Sharpened your thinking and discrimination skills for testing.</li>
</ul>
<p>Let this book work for you to make it easy, enjoyable, and effective to review at times that are convenient for you. The short, condensed, and prioritized chapter content may spark new ways to develop your skills in critical thinking and content recall.</p>
<p>It is feedback from students, graduates, and practitioners in nursing that prompted the development and publication of this book. We welcome your comments. We wish you a successful career in the nursing profession and hope that Mosby's Nursing Review Series has made that success a little easier to obtain!</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>CHAPTER 1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="essential-elements-for-nursing">Essential Elements for Nursing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#essential-elements-for-nursing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify essential elements common to all nursing specialties.</li>
<li>Discuss the priority content for each essential element.</li>
<li>Incorporate the essential elements into nursing practice.</li>
</ul>
<p>CHAPTER 1 ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR NURSING</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="client-education">Client education<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#client-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Process of meeting the client's needs for the acquisition of skills, knowledge, or attitudes to deal with a pathological condition in the arenas of primary, secondary, or tertiary health promotion as based on the prior skills, knowledge, and attitudes of the client.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="nursing-process">Nursing process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Process used as the basis of nursing practice. It includes five steps: (1) assess, (2) select nursing diagnosis, (3) plan, (4) intervene, and (5) evaluate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="essential-elements-in-nursing">ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS IN NURSING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#essential-elements-in-nursing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>I. The two essential elements
A. Nursing process
B. Client education</p>
<p>II. Nursing incorporates these common essential elements irrespective of the level, environment, or client population</p>
<p>III. The nursing process is the priority common thread throughout nursing practice</p>
<p>IV. Client education facilitates clients' behavior changes in areas of primary (preventive), secondary (early diagnosis), and tertiary (restorative, rehabilitative) health promotion</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="nursing-process">NURSING PROCESS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>I. The nursing process has five steps
A. Assess
B. Select nursing diagnosis
C. Plan
D. Intervene
E. Evaluate</p>
<p>THE NURSING PROCESS, ASSESSMENT ▼ 3</p>
<ol>
<li>Nurses follow the nursing process sequence in any initial client contact</li>
<li>Evaluation of the interventions occurs to determine effectiveness or ineffectiveness</li>
<li>If effective results, the client-nurse relationship either terminates or new priorities are set for new client problems</li>
<li>If ineffective results, nurses select the appropriate step(s); at this point in the evaluation process, the sequence of steps is a creative process by nurses as dictated by client need</li>
<li>If a client has unexpected changes during care, nurses typically do further assessment of the situation before implementing actions</li>
<li>Use of these steps is a dynamic, client-centered process</li>
<li>Communication is essential in all phases of the nursing process</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-the-initial-assessment-process">II. The initial assessment process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-the-initial-assessment-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-includes-subjective-and-objective-information">A. Includes subjective and objective information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-includes-subjective-and-objective-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-subjective-information-elicited-by-questions-such-as">B. Subjective information: elicited by questions such as<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-subjective-information-elicited-by-questions-such-as" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>What is the one item that made you decide to seek help?</li>
<li>What is your major problem today?</li>
<li>When did this start? How long did it last? What relieved it?</li>
<li>Do I need to know any other information that can help me better care for you?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-objective-information-elicited-through-the-senses">C. Objective information: elicited through the senses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-objective-information-elicited-through-the-senses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Inspection: done initially for the client's respiratory rate, breathing effort, color, and position</li>
<li>Inspection and touch: a handshake of the client elicits
a. Demonstration of respect for the client; reduction of client's anxiety
b. Level of consciousness and the motor ability/strength of client to initiate an appropriate response
c. Pulse assessment for rate and regularity if two-handed technique is used
d. Skin assessment for temperature, color, texture, and moisture</li>
<li>Smell for odors: done simultaneously with inspection</li>
<li>Hearing: asking the initial questions, then auscultating elicits
a. Specific information about the client's perception of the problem
b. Information about the client's emotional reaction to the situation by noting the tone and inflection of the speech</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 1 ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR NURSING</p>
<p>c. Degree of influence from others based on whether they answer or clarify client's answers to questions
d. Auscultation typically includes the lungs, heart sounds, bowel sounds, and then any vascular sounds such as the carotid arteries or arterio-venous (A-V) fistulas</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Touch: commonly the approaches to other touch techniques such as percussion or palpation are completed by starting with the problem system then moving to the respiratory, cardiac, and neurological systems followed by the other systems</li>
</ol>
<p>D. In emergency situations, objective information may take precedent over subjective information</p>
<ol>
<li>Airway, breathing, and circulation, the ABCs, may dictate assessment priorities</li>
<li>Deferment of the history and physical assessment of all body systems may take a secondary focus, with priority actions aiming to support the cardiac and respiratory systems</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Subjective information is best obtained from the client, the primary source, or from secondary sources such as the caretaker, family, or friends
F. History can be obtained from prior documentation to expedite the initial contact and conserve client energy
G. Results of the client's assessment act as the foundation for selecting priority nursing diagnoses and the development of an appropriate plan of care
H. In acute- and home-care settings, nurses may limit priorities to two nursing diagnoses for a more realistic, attainable, efficient, and effective approach to client care</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-the-selection-of-nursing-diagnoses">III. The selection of nursing diagnoses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-the-selection-of-nursing-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-nursing-diagnoses">A. Nursing diagnoses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-nursing-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Are clinical judgments about responses of an individual or family to actual or a risk for threats to health or life situations</li>
<li>Provide the basis for the selection of nursing interventions or referrals to achieve positive outcomes for evaluation</li>
<li>Are designed with a three-part statement; however, in clinical practice the first part is consistently used, but the other parts may not be required as part of the documentation</li>
</ol>
<p>a. The three parts, also referred to as the PES format, are</p>
<p>(1) P = health problem, stated as a nursing problem
(2) E = etiological or related factors
(3) S = the defining characteristics or cluster of signs/symptoms as identified from the assessment data</p>
<p>ASSESSMENT, NURSING DIAGNOSES SELECTION ▼ 5</p>
<p>b. The words <em>related to</em> connect the health problem and the etiological factors
c. The words <em>as manifested by</em> connect the etiological factors and the signs/symptoms
d. Example: urinary elimination—altered <em>related to</em> loss of muscle tone <em>as manifested by</em> incontinence, nocturia, dribbling.
e. A health problem may be an actual or a risk for (formerly potential or high-risk) problem</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-process-to-the-selection-of-nursing-diagnoses">B. Process to the selection of nursing diagnoses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-process-to-the-selection-of-nursing-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Assessment data are analyzed and interpreted for priorities in relation to time, for an actual or high-risk problem with respect to what interventions are accountable by nursing
a. In acute care: what needs to be accomplished
(1) In the next 30 to 60 minutes?
(2) In the next 8 hours?
(3) In the next 24 hours?
(4) By discharge from the facility?
b. In other settings such as clinic, home, and outpatient care
(1) What was the priority in the last few visits?
(2) What necessitated this visit?
(3) What has changed to require a reorganization of the priorities?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A diagnostic label is selected with or without the phrases <em>related to</em> and <em>as manifested by</em>; institutional documentation policies guide the specific format for each agency</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In most situations, one or two priority nursing diagnoses are appropriate</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The ABCs are appropriate to use as a guide for setting priorities</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-the-planning-process">IV. The planning process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-the-planning-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-blueprint-for-nursing-actions-also-called-nursing-orders-or-planned-nursing-interventions-which-are">A. Blueprint for nursing actions, also called nursing orders or planned nursing interventions, which are<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-blueprint-for-nursing-actions-also-called-nursing-orders-or-planned-nursing-interventions-which-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Based on the priorities collected or clustered from the assessment data</li>
<li>Selected in reference to time and resources available</li>
<li>Safe for the client and the nurse</li>
<li>Commonly a combination of independent, interdependent, and dependent actions</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-involves-goal-setting-for-achievement-of-client-outcomes">B. Involves goal setting for achievement of client outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-involves-goal-setting-for-achievement-of-client-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>CHAPTER 1 ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR NURSING</p>
<p>C. May be done cooperatively if client is able to participate
D. Commonly involves some component of education for a client knowledge deficit
E. Commonly dictates client outcomes, which need to be</p>
<ol>
<li>Achieved in a set amount of time</li>
<li>Objective</li>
<li>Realistic</li>
<li>Observable or measurable for changes in client's activity, behavior, or physical state</li>
<li>Used as a standard of measure in the evaluation process</li>
<li>Examples
a. Client outcome: within 48 hours the client will sleep through the night without the need to void
b. Planned interventions
(1) Provide use of the bedside commode before bedtime
(2) Give no liquids after 8:00 P.M.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-the-intervention-process">V. The intervention process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-the-intervention-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actual execution of the planned nursing actions
B. Incorporates supervision, coordination, or evaluation of the delivery of care
C. Includes the recording and exchange of information among different disciplines</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-the-evaluation-process">VI. The evaluation process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-the-evaluation-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Based on client outcomes as identified from the planning process
B. Determination of the degree of effectiveness or ineffectiveness of the interventions taken to achieve the stated outcomes
C. Ongoing throughout the client-nurse relationship
D. Often performed concurrently with other phases of the nursing process rather than as a distinctly individual step
E. May result in the client's reassessment to reorder priorities and set new outcomes, especially if the stated time frame has been exceeded
F. Requires documentation of the date when revisement or resolution of the health problem occurred; may be documented as ongoing
G. Requires timely, accurate, and objective documentation and communication</p>
<p>PLANNING, INTERVENTION, EVALUATION; CLIENT EDUCATION ▼ 7</p>
<p>H. Includes identification of the client’s level of knowledge and degree of willingness to change behaviors, skills, knowledge, or attitudes in any of these areas</p>
<ol>
<li>Diet</li>
<li>Activity</li>
<li>Environment</li>
<li>Equipment</li>
<li>Medications: knowledge of
a. Expected side effects
b. Side effects that are treatable
c. Side effects to report to the physician and within what time frame
d. Length for the course of treatment</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="client-education">CLIENT EDUCATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#client-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. Client education: the process
A. Integral part of nursing care on either a formal or informal basis
B. Incorporates the use of the nursing process
C. Requires the use of teaching and learning principles
D. Varies with clients according to their life experiences, present situation, and age
E. Includes six main steps</p>
<ol>
<li>Assessment of client education needs or wants</li>
<li>Identification of priorities</li>
<li>Identification of client goals or outcomes: what is needed
a. Behavior changes
b. Skill acquisition
c. Cognitive or attitude changes</li>
<li>Development of a teaching plan
a. Development of learner objectives
b. Determination of the content required for the given situation
c. Determination of the resources and how to use them
(1) Identify the available referral support agencies
(2) Identify the materials available for teaching/learning activities
(3) Investigate whether there is money available for materials, courses, transportation to and from education classes
(4) Estimate the amount of time available versus the amount of time needed to implement the teaching plan</li>
</ol>
<p>8 ▼ CHAPTER 1 ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR NURSING</p>
<p>(5) Decide whether the nurse will initiate and complete the education or refer to another support service for the education</p>
<p>d. Determination of sequence and presentation approach of the content</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>
<p>Implementation of the teaching plan over a stated time frame</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Evaluation of outcomes with revisions or reteaching as needed</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-client-assessments-for-education">II. Client assessments for education<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-client-assessments-for-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1d460449">A. Client’s knowledge base. What does the client know? What does he or she want to know? Respect that some clients desire no information and document that response.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1d460449" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-readiness">B. Readiness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-readiness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Emotional</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Which stage of loss does client exhibit?</p>
<p>(1) Denial
(2) Anger
(3) Bargaining
(4) Depression
(5) Acceptance</p>
<p>b. If clients are in denial or anger, education will probably be ineffective; document stage of loss</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Motivational: intrinsic motivation, stimulated from within the learner, is preferred to extrinsic motivation, stimulated from outside the learner</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Experiential climate</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Values associated with social roles
b. Personal resources and support systems</p>
<p>(1) Family, friends
(2) Finances for medications, equipment
(3) Environmental factors: indoor plumbing, electricity
(4) Prior and current exposure to interactions with the healthcare system and providers
(5) Availability of healthcare services, time versus distance with available transportation</p>
<p>c. Developmental stage</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Physical</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Clinical status is stable or improved
b. Functional abilities</p>
<p>(1) Hearing, attention span, listening
(2) Vision
(3) Touch and manual dexterity</p>
<p>CLIENT ASSESSMENTS FOR EDUCATION ▼ 9</p>
<p>(4) Reading, level of highest education
(5) Endurance
(6) Short-term memory
(a) Limited in its capacity
(b) Enhanced if distractions are avoided
(c) Enhanced if opportunities are given for repeating or rehearsing the information
(7) Long-term memory
(a) Unlimited in its capacity and duration
(b) Influenced by the rate at which new information is introduced: the best approach is to introduce one new item every 4 to 5 seconds
(c) Enhanced by 20% to 90% if material is incorporated into a story or real-life situation</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Signs of client’s readiness
a. Beginning behaviors of adaption to the original problem
b. Exhibits awareness of the health problem and its implications
c. Asks direct questions
d. Presents clues that suggest client is seeking information
e. Begins to ask questions about how to handle situations at home
f. Indicators during a teaching session
(1) Client is physically comfortable; basic needs are met
(2) Client readily gives attention; eye contact is made
(3) Client turns off television or asks visitors to leave</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-special-needs-of-clients-for-their-education">III. Special needs of clients for their education<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-special-needs-of-clients-for-their-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-interventions-for-low-literacy-clients">A. Interventions for low-literacy clients<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-interventions-for-low-literacy-clients" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Give only simple (basic) information</li>
<li>Present no more than three new points at a given time</li>
<li>Give the most important information first and last</li>
<li>Sequence information in the way the client will use it</li>
<li>Give information the client can use immediately</li>
<li>Use the same words when meanings are the same (e.g., medicine or drug, not both words)</li>
<li>Use small, simple words and short sentences; introduce no more than five new words in one session</li>
<li>Present information at the fifth-grade level or lower</li>
<li>Be concrete and time specific. Example: take two pills at 4:00 P.M.</li>
<li>Ask the client to repeat the information or the skill</li>
<li>Use humor appropriately; be creative</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 1 ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR NURSING</p>
<ol start="12">
<li>Avoid long explanations</li>
<li>Reward frequently—even for small accomplishments</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-interventions-for-older-clients">B. Interventions for older clients<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-interventions-for-older-clients" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Priority evaluations
a. Establish the degree of functional losses
b. Identify the degree of social support; lack of social support may be an important determinant in the decreased compliance of older adults
c. Identify their habit structures
d. Have an evaluation completed by social services or the business office for the availability of monies</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clients with impaired hearing
a. Use low-pitched voice
b. Face client when speaking
c. Use clear, concise terms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clients with impaired vision
a. Use large print and a magnifying glass
b. Black on white or black on yellow paper may be easier for the older clients to read
c. Provide adequate lighting
d. Have client use prescription glasses</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clients with limited endurance
a. Keep sessions short (10 to 15 minutes)
b. Schedule the teaching session at a time of day when clients are comfortable and their energy levels are higher
c. Break down the information into small steps
d. The initial session should have only survival-level information</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clients with memory loss
a. Provide repeated exposure to same message
b. Provide cues: visual, verbal, written
c. Question frequently
d. Use advanced organizers: "I'm going to tell you 2 ways to give your insulin," "I've told you how to give your insulin by using two methods."</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-learning-theory">IV. Learning theory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-learning-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-learning-theory-for-adults">A. Learning theory for adults<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-learning-theory-for-adults" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Adult learner is defined as a self-directed, independent person who becomes ready to learn when the need to know or perform is experienced</li>
<li>Adult education is learner centered</li>
<li>Adult education is dynamic, interactive, and cooperative</li>
</ol>
<p>EDUCATION NEEDS; LOW-LITERACY, OLDER ADULTS; LEARNING THEORY ▼ 11</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>The responsibility for success of adult learners is shared by all participants</li>
<li>Adult learners
a. Like to participate in identification of their learning needs, formulation of learning objectives, and evaluation of learning
b. Expect a climate of mutual respect
c. Enter the learning situation with a life-centered, task-centered, or problem-centered approach
d. Are motivated internally to learn in order to increase self-esteem, self-confidence, or seek a better quality of life
e. See the educator as a facilitator rather than a director of the activity</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Learning theory for children</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Learning programs for children are more subject centered</li>
<li>Design of learning experiences is topic centered</li>
<li>Learning may be more of an external process with emphasis on externally sanctioned approvals for learning such as stars, happy-face stickers</li>
<li>Objective, content development, and evaluation process are teacher controlled</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Factors that interfere with learning</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Nervousness, anxiety, fear</li>
<li>Too much content at one session</li>
<li>Unfamiliar terms</li>
<li>Complexity of the task</li>
<li>Limited time with too much content, results in rushing</li>
<li>Background noise or other distractions</li>
<li>Fear of the task or information</li>
<li>Frequent interruptions</li>
<li>Inability of an educator to listen to the client</li>
<li>Absence of silence</li>
<li>Left-handed student’s learning skills with right-handed educator</li>
<li>Client is not healthcare oriented; healthcare educator is</li>
<li>Stage of development; older adults may have the attitude that they have lived more or less successfully with their present habits and there is no reason to change now</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>V. Tools for teaching</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Types of teaching</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>One to one</li>
<li>Group</li>
</ol>
<p>12 ▼ CHAPTER 1 ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR NURSING</p>
<p>a. Homogeneous clients for a topic
b. Heterogeneous clients for a topic</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Programmed instruction</li>
<li>Guided independent study</li>
<li>Lecture</li>
<li>Role playing</li>
<li>Simulation</li>
<li>Case method</li>
<li>Demonstration/return demonstration</li>
<li>Computerized instruction</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Media for teaching</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Printed materials: pamphlets, books, crossword puzzles, study guides</li>
<li>Pictorial materials: coloring books, videotapes, cartoons, flowcharts, slides, posters, overhead transparencies, computer simulations</li>
<li>Visual representations: models, actual equipment</li>
<li>Auditory: lectures, paired and small-group discussion, one-to-one interaction, role playing, cassette tapes, simulations</li>
<li>Tactile, kinesthetic: practice with real or simulated items, manipulating or constructing models, playing games, completing worksheets, drawing, preparing charts, bulletin boards, developing a calendar of activities</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Factors to consider in the selection of media/support materials</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Items readily available within acceptable costs</li>
<li>Suitability: for the purpose of the teaching, to the environment in which the teaching will take place, for the availability of ancillary equipment</li>
<li>Language: appropriate, understandable, and useful to the audience</li>
<li>Materials: accurate and relevant to the intended age group and culture</li>
<li>Print size: readable for the intended age group</li>
<li>Illustrations: accurate and related to the intended audience</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nurse as a tool of teaching: the nursing professional should</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Show interest, empathy, and enthusiasm</li>
<li>Practice expert listening skills; listen between the lines not only to what clients say, but how they say it</li>
<li>Note clients’ verbal and nonverbal communication that occurs; be aware of your own communication style</li>
<li>Take a break when the client indicates a need; vary the schedule</li>
<li>Be creative</li>
</ol>
<p>TOOLS FOR TEACHING ▼ 13</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>Keep language simple</li>
<li>Allow enough time for demonstrations and return demonstrations</li>
<li>Summarize at the end with encouragement for any progress, no matter how small</li>
</ol>
<p>E. <strong>Evaluation tips for achievement of education outcomes</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Evaluation is an ongoing process throughout the entire teaching session</li>
<li>If periodic reassessment of learning indicates no progress, try a different approach</li>
<li>Ask open-ended questions along with specific questions</li>
<li>Ask clients to evaluate themselves</li>
</ol>
<p>F. <strong>Intervention tips for different age groups</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Pediatrics: the play approach works best with dolls or models; coloring, comic, or storybooks</li>
<li>Teenagers and persons in their 20s: use peer speakers, entertainment, and peer groups and keep in mind that body image and independence are a priority for these age groups</li>
<li>Persons in their 30s to mid-40s: written materials work well with follow-up time to answer questions or clarify information</li>
<li>Persons from mid-40s to early 60s: a few long, single sessions to discuss how the effects of the health problem will interfere with attainment of or plans for lifelong goals</li>
<li>Persons over mid-60s: use short, frequent, one-to-one meetings with material in larger print and keep in mind that maintaining functional abilities is a priority</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="summary">SUMMARY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A working knowledge of the content in Chapter 1, the essential elements for nursing, will enhance the application of the remainder of the content in the review series. Most nursing professionals incorporate the two elements into their practice, which is based on the changing needs of clients who pursue the acquisition of healthcare services and actions to prevent pathological deterioration of the body. The nursing process and client education are intertwined in the areas of primary (preventive), secondary (early diagnosis), and tertiary (restorative, rehabilitative) health promotion.</p>
<p>14 ▼ CHAPTER 1 ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR NURSING</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nanda-approved-nursing-diagnoses">NANDA-APPROVED NURSING DIAGNOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nanda-approved-nursing-diagnoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Activity intolerance</li>
<li>Activity intolerance, risk for</li>
<li>Adaptive capacity, decreased: intracranial</li>
<li>Adjustment, impaired</li>
<li>Airway clearance, ineffective</li>
<li>Anxiety</li>
<li>Aspiration, risk for</li>
<li>Body-image disturbance</li>
<li>Body temperature, altered, risk for</li>
<li>Bowel incontinence</li>
<li>Breastfeeding, effective</li>
<li>Breastfeeding, ineffective</li>
<li>Breastfeeding, interrupted</li>
<li>Breathing pattern, ineffective</li>
<li>Cardiac output, decreased</li>
<li>Caregiver role strain</li>
<li>Caregiver role strain, risk for</li>
<li>Communication, impaired verbal</li>
<li>Community coping, ineffective</li>
<li>Community coping, potential for enhanced</li>
<li>Confusion, acute</li>
<li>Confusion, chronic</li>
<li>Constipation</li>
<li>Constipation, colonic</li>
<li>Constipation, perceived</li>
<li>Coping, defensive</li>
<li>Coping, family: potential for growth</li>
<li>Coping, ineffective family: compromised</li>
<li>Coping, ineffective family: disabling</li>
<li>Coping, ineffective individual</li>
<li>Decisional conflict (specify)</li>
<li>Denial, ineffective</li>
<li>Diarrhea</li>
<li>Disuse syndrome, risk for</li>
<li>Diversional activity deficit</li>
<li>Dysreflexia</li>
<li>Energy field disturbance</li>
<li>Environmental interpretation syndrome: impaired</li>
<li>Family processes, altered</li>
<li>Family processes, altered: alcoholism</li>
</ul>
<p>NANDA-APPROVED NURSING DIAGNOSES ▼ 15</p>
<p>Fatigue
Fear
Fluid volume deficit
Fluid volume deficit, risk for
Fluid volume excess
Gas exchange, impaired
Grieving, anticipatory
Grieving, dysfunctional
Growth and development, altered
Health maintenance, altered
Health-seeking behaviors (specify)
Home maintenance management, impaired
Hopelessness
Hyperthermia
Hypothermia
Incontinence, functional
Incontinence, reflex
Incontinence, stress
Incontinence, total
Incontinence, urge
Infant behavior, disorganized
Infant behavior, disorganized: risk for
Infant feeding pattern, ineffective
Infection, risk for
Injury, perioperative positioning: risk for
Injury, risk for
Knowledge deficit (specify)
Loneliness, risk for
Management of therapeutic regimen, community: ineffective
Management of therapeutic regimen, families: ineffective
Management of therapeutic regimen, individuals: effective
Management of therapeutic regimen, individuals: ineffective
Memory, impaired
Mobility, impaired physical
Noncompliance (specify)
Nutrition, altered: less than body requirements
Nutrition, altered: more than body requirements
Nutrition, altered: risk for more than body requirements
Oral mucous membrane, altered
Pain
Pain, chronic
Parent/infant/child attachment altered, risk for</p>
<p>CHAPTER 1 ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR NURSING</p>
<p>Parental role conflict
Parenting, altered
Parenting, altered, risk for
Peripheral neurovascular dysfunction, risk for
Personal identity disturbance
Poisoning, risk for
Posttrauma response
Powerlessness
Protection, altered
Rape-trauma syndrome
Rape-trauma syndrome: compound reaction
Rape-trauma syndrome: silent reaction
Relocation stress syndrome
Role performance, altered
Self-care deficit, bathing/hygiene
Self-care deficit, dressing/grooming
Self-care deficit, feeding
Self-care deficit, toileting
Self-esteem, chronic low
Self-esteem disturbance
Self-esteem, situational low
Self-mutilation, risk for
Sensory/perceptual alterations (specify) (visual, auditory, kinesthetic, gustatory, tactile, olfactory)
Sexual dysfunction
Sexuality patterns, altered
Skin integrity, impaired
Skin integrity, impaired, risk for
Sleep pattern disturbance
Social interaction, impaired
Social isolation
Spiritual distress (distress of the human spirit)
Spiritual well-being, potential for enhanced
Suffocation, risk for
Swallowing, impaired
Thermoregulation, ineffective
Thought processes, altered
Tissue integrity, impaired
Tissue perfusion, altered (specify type) (renal, cerebral, cardiopulmonary, gastrointestinal, peripheral)
Trauma, risk for
Unilateral neglect</p>
<p>NANDA-APPROVED NURSING DIAGNOSES ▼ 17</p>
<ul>
<li>Urinary elimination, altered</li>
<li>Urinary retention</li>
<li>Ventilation, inability to sustain spontaneous</li>
<li>Ventilatory weaning process, dysfunctional</li>
<li>Violence, risk for: self-directed or directed at others</li>
</ul>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>CHAPTER 2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fundamentals-of-pharmacology">Fundamentals of Pharmacology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fundamentals-of-pharmacology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Discuss the use of the nursing process in drug administration.</li>
<li>Describe drug legislation within the United States.</li>
<li>Describe controlled substances with the categories for controlled agents.</li>
<li>Identify the three types of names for a given drug.</li>
<li>Discuss the various preparations of drugs.</li>
</ul>
<p>19</p>
<p>20 ▼ CHAPTER 2 FUNDAMENTALS OF PHARMACOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Brand or trade name</strong>
The proprietary name assigned by the manufacturing company. Example: Tylenol.</p>
<p><strong>Chemical name</strong>
The chemical nomenclature. Example: N-acetyl-para-aminopenol.</p>
<p><strong>Controlled substance</strong>
Drugs that have the potential for physical or psychological dependence.</p>
<p><strong>Enteral route</strong>
By way of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract.</p>
<p><strong>Generic name</strong>
The nonproprietary name assigned by the United States Adopted Names Council. Example: acetaminophen.</p>
<p><strong>Inhalation route</strong>
By way of the respiratory tract with inspired air.</p>
<p><strong>Parenteral route</strong>
By way of any route other than in or through the digestive tract.</p>
<p><strong>Topical route</strong>
By way of a body surface part such as the skin, mucous membranes, or cornea.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-nursing-process">I. Nursing process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-nursing-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-assessment">A. Assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Obtain a drug history. Include each of the following
a. Prescription drugs
b. Over-the-counter (OTC) drugs
c. Drug specifics
(1) Name
(2) Amount
(3) Route
(4) Frequency
d. Allergies to drugs
Ask: What exactly does the medicine do?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Identify diseases in the body system that may affect the following
a. Drug absorption through the gastrointestinal tract, lungs, mucous membranes
b. Distribution by the circulatory system
c. Metabolism by the hepatic system
d. Excretion by the renal system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assess the use of illegal drugs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Identify special considerations for the older adult, pediatric, and pregnant client</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>DRUG ADMINISTRATION AND THE NURSING PROCESS ▼ 21</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-diagnosis">B.
