Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Identify nursing diagnosis related to the medications currently in use</li>
<li>Begin a plan of care related to the client's drug regimen, considering side effects, dietary factors, and compliance</li>
<li>Apply nursing diagnoses taken from the North American Nursing Diagnoses Association (NANDA) specific to drug therapy
a. Knowledge deficit related to drug treatment regimen
b. Noncompliance related to side effects of medication or financial difficulty
c. Risk for injury related to side effects of medication
d. Alteration in bowel elimination: constipation related to narcotic use secondary to pain</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-planning">C. Planning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-planning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Identify outcome criteria to document patient responses to the drug therapy</li>
<li>Determine the best schedule to administer the prescribed drugs
a. Consider drugs to be administered with and without meals
b. Plan diuretics and laxatives early in the morning to avoid unnecessary interruptions in sleep during the night
c. Identify potential drug interactions and schedule accordingly</li>
<li>Establish nursing observations and interventions for safe drug therapy</li>
<li>Identify necessary client teaching for safe drug administration at home</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-implementation">D. Implementation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-implementation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Provide drug therapy as directed on the plan of care</li>
<li>Prepare the medication with consideration to the proper technique for the ordered route and drug calculation</li>
<li>Consider the five rights of drug administration (Box 2-1)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-2-1-five-rights-of-drug-administration">Box 2-1. Five Rights of Drug Administration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-2-1-five-rights-of-drug-administration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Right Drug</li>
<li>Right Dose</li>
<li>Right Route</li>
<li>Right Time</li>
<li>Right Client</li>
</ul>
<p>CHAPTER 2 FUNDAMENTALS OF PHARMACOLOGY</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Monitor for the effectiveness of the drug and for adverse side effects</li>
<li>Teach appropriate information for home drug therapy</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Evaluation</p>
<ol>
<li>Document the effectiveness of the drug</li>
<li>Document any side effects and the actions taken to relieve them</li>
<li>Determine the client's knowledge of the drug regimen</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-drug-legislation-within-the-united-states-table-2-1">II. Drug legislation within the United States (Table 2-1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-drug-legislation-within-the-united-states-table-2-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-controlled-substances">III. Controlled substances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-controlled-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Defined as drugs that have the potential for physical or psychological dependence
B. The nurse's responsibility is to maintain accurate records of controlled-substance use in health care agencies</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-drug-names">IV. Drug names<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-drug-names" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Chemical name is the chemical nomenclature {N-Acetyl-para-aminopenol}
B. Generic name is the nonproprietary name assigned by the United States Adopted Names Council {acetaminophen}
C. Brand name is the proprietary name assigned by the manufacturing company {Tylenol}
D. Nurses should know both the generic and brand name of a drug in clinical practice and for nursing exams</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-forms-of-medications">V. Forms of medications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-forms-of-medications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Preparations</p>
<ol>
<li>Oral: solids
a. Tablets that are compressed: may be scored
b. Capsules with a dissolvable gelatin sheath
(1) Time-release or sustained-release tablets or capsules have several doses of specially coated medications that dissolve at different times. May have the suffix SA, SR, or extentab. (Box 2-2)
(2) Enteric-coated tablets or capsules dissolve in the intestine instead of in the stomach
(3) Time-release and enteric-coated tablets should not be crushed (Box 2-2)</li>
</ol>
<p>DRUG NAMES, FORMS, LEGISLATION ▼ 23</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="table-2-1-federal-drug-legislation-in-the-united-states">Table 2-1. Federal Drug Legislation in the United States<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-2-1-federal-drug-legislation-in-the-united-states" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Date</th><th>Title of Law</th><th>Major Provisions</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1906</td><td>Pure Food and Drug Act</td><td>Established USP and NP as official standards</td></tr><tr><td>Set standards for proper drug labeling</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1912</td><td>Sherley Amendment</td><td>Prohibited fraudulent claims for therapeutic effects of drugs</td></tr><tr><td>1914</td><td>Harrison Narcotic Act</td><td>Legally defined term narcotic</td></tr><tr><td>Regulated and restricted importation, manufacture, sale, or use of opium, cocaine, marijuana, and other drugs likely to produce dependence</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1938</td><td>Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act</td><td>Maintained major provisions of previous laws</td></tr><tr><td>Required that a drug be demonstrated to be safe before it was marketed</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Added Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States as a third standard for drugs</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1941-1945</td><td>Amendments to Pure Food and Drug Act</td><td>Required that biologic products used as drugs (e.g., insulin or antibiotics) be certified on a batch-by-batch basis by a government agency</td></tr><tr><td>1952</td><td>Durham-Humphrey Amendment</td><td>Designated certain drugs as legend drugs (must be marked “Caution: Federal Law prohibits dispensing without prescription”)</td></tr><tr><td>Restricted right of pharmacist to distribute legend drugs</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1962</td><td>Kefauver-Harris Amendment</td><td>Required proof of efficacy for a drug to remain on market</td></tr><tr><td>Authorized FDA to establish official names for drugs</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Continued.</p>
<p>CHAPTER 2 FUNDAMENTALS OF PHARMACOLOGY</p>
<p>Table 2-1. Federal Drug Legislation in the United States—cont'd</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Date</th><th>Title of Law</th><th>Major Provisions</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1970</td><td>Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act (or Controlled Substances Act)</td><td>Defined drug dependency and drug addiction</td></tr><tr><td>Classified drugs according to abuse potential and medical usefulness</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Established methods for regulating the manufacture, distribution, and sale of controlled substances</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Established education and treatment programs for drug abuse</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1983</td><td>Orphan Drug Act</td><td>Offered tax relief to companies marketing orphan drugs</td></tr><tr><td>Protected companies for 7 years against competition on nonpatentable orphan drugs</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1984</td><td>Drug Price Competition and Patent Term Restoration Act</td><td>Drugs first marketed after 1962 are eligible for abbreviated new drug application</td></tr><tr><td>Generic drugs are more easily introduced</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Established guidelines for bioequivalence</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Restored up to 5 years of patent protection for time used in drug development</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1986, 1988</td><td>National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act</td><td>Private health care providers are required to keep records on adverse events following immunization</td></tr><tr><td>Covers diphtheria, measles, mumps, pertussis, poliomyelitis, rubella, and tetanus toxoids or vaccines</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1987</td><td>Prescription Drug Marketing Act</td><td>Bans diversion of prescription drugs from legitimate channels</td></tr><tr><td>Restricts reimportation of drugs from other countries</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1988</td><td>Food and Drug Administration Act</td><td>Establishes the FDA within the Department of Health and Human Services</td></tr><tr><td>Sets mechanism for appointing the Commissioner of Food and Drugs</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>GUIDELINES FOR DRUG ADMINISTRATION ▼ 25</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="box-2-2-drug-forms-that-should-not-be-crushed-or-chewed">Box 2-2. Drug Forms That Should Not Be Crushed or Chewed<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-2-2-drug-forms-that-should-not-be-crushed-or-chewed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Enteric-coated tablets</li>
<li>Sustained-release forms. These often have the following suffixes attached to the drug name:</li>
<li>Dur (Duration)</li>
<li>SR (Sustained Release)</li>
<li>CR (Controlled or Continuous Release)</li>
<li>SA (Sustained Action)</li>
<li>Contin (Continuous)</li>
<li>LA (Long Acting)</li>
<li>Trade names that imply sustained release such as spansules, extentabs, extencaps</li>
<li>Trade names with the b.i.d. (twice a day) abbreviation in the name, such as Theobid, Cardabid</li>
<li>Liquid-containing capsules, although occasionally it may be acceptable to puncture the capsule and squeeze out the contents; consult the pharmacist or manufacturer</li>
</ul>
<p>The name alone may not provide enough information. Consult the pharmacist if in doubt. Some forms that look like sustained forms are not and vice versa. Some capsules containing small, slow-release pellets may be opened, and the pellets sprinkled on applesauce, or gently mixed into liquid or food, but they should not be crushed or dissolved.</p>
<p>Scored tablets may be broken along the scored line but should not be chewed or crushed.</p>
<p>Clark J, Queener S, and Karb, V: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.</p>
<p>c. Lozenges or troches: dissolve in the mouth
d. Powders: must be dissolved in liquid prior to use</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Oral: liquids
a. Elixirs, spirits, and extracts: contain alcohol
b. Syrups: contain much sugar
c. Suspensions such as emulsions, gels, and magmas are mixtures that are not dissolved. These must be shaken well before use.
d. Tinctures: portions of drugs mixed in solutions with alcohol
e. Sprays</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Topical
a. Creams, lotions, and ointments
b. Sprays</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>26 ▼ CHAPTER 2 FUNDAMENTALS OF PHARMACOLOGY</p>
<p>c. Transdermal disks: medicated; allow for slow absorption of the medication through the skin, usually over a period of 3 to 7 days</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Injectable
a. Powders: must be mixed with a diluent
b. Single-dose and multi-dose vials
c. Intravenous fluids</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vaginal and rectal
a. Creams and tablets: both
b. Suppositories: both
c. Douches: usually vaginal
d. Enemas: usually rectal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Eye and ear
a. Drops
b. Ointments</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other
a. Nose drops
b. Inhalation drugs
c. Implanted capsules
d. Insulin pumps</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Routes of administration</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Enteral: by way of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract
a. Oral preparations (PO)
b. Nasogastric tubes
c. Gastrostomy tubes
d. Intestinal tubes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parenteral: by injection
a. Intradermal (ID)
b. Subcutaneous (SC or SQ)
c. Intramuscular (IM)
d. Intravenous (IV)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Topical: through the skin
a. Transdermal drug delivery system (TDDS)
b. Skin ointments, creams, gels</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inhalation: absorbed through the lungs
a. Oxygen by nasal cannula (NC) or mask in liters/min (L/m) or %
b. Aerosols</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mucous membranes: absorbed through the mucous membranes of various parts of the body
a. Eye and ear ointments and drops (gtt)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>ROUTES OF ADMINISTRATION ▼ 27</p>
<p>b. Vaginal applications: creams and tablets
c. Rectal suppositories
d. Buccal (BC): in the cheek or mouth
e. Inhalants: nasal drops (gtt)
f. Sublingual (SL): under the tongue</p>
<p>A client with abdominal pain reports to the emergency department. A brief history reveals an allergy to the analgesic morphine sulfate (morphine HP). The nurse should follow through by first asking which of the following questions? a. What other analgesics are you allergic to? b. Have you had this allergy long? c. Exactly what does the morphine do to you? d. Does the morphine make you nauseated?</p>
<p>A client reports to a cardiac rehabilitation session complaining of not feeling well. The nurse questions what is wrong and is told, “I've been having angina for several days.” During further assessment, the client reports that she has not been taking her nitrate because she gets a terrible headache. Which of the following nursing diagnoses is most appropriate? a. Knowledge deficit related to the side effects of nitroglycerin b. Knowledge deficit related to the need for nitrates c. Alteration in comfort: headache related to the side effects of the analgesic d. Noncompliance related to the side effects of nitroglycerin</p>
<p>A nurse's neighbor calls, concerned that the medicine prescribed for her daughter is too big to swallow. After a brief discussion, the nurse discovers that the capsule the child is having trouble swallowing is a sustained-release capsule. The nurse should a. Encourage her to open the capsule and mix it with ice cream b. Explain to her how to crush the medicine and then give it with plenty of liquid c. Explain that sustained-release capsules cannot be crushed; she should call her physician to report that the pills are too difficult to swallow d. Explain that sustained-release capsules cannot be crushed; she should stop the medication and inform her physician at the follow-up visit</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 29</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Determining the exact nature of the allergic reaction will best help the nurse distinguish an allergy from a common side effect. A listing of all medications the client is allergic to would be more appropriate. The length of time of the allergy is irrelevant. Nausea is a common side effect, not an allergic reaction.</td><td>One strategy is to eliminate responses that are false or not the best. Responses <em>b</em> and <em>d</em> offer little information, since they are yes/no-phrased questions. The question in response <em>a</em> ignores the issue of the morphine allergy. It is a good question but is not the best for the “first” next question, given the situation in the stem. Thus, select response <em>c</em>.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Headache is a common side effect of NTG and can lead to noncompliance. There is not enough information to determine if responses <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are true. Nitroglycerin is not an analgesic.</td><td>Responses <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> can be eliminated, since there is no data in the stem to support a knowledge problem. If you read response <em>c</em> too quickly and give the first part of the answer too much emphasis, you may overlook the word “analgesics”; the headache is related to the nitrates, which are not analgesics. Thus, response <em>d</em> is correct. This error of reading too quickly is common for this type of question, especially if you are tired or tense.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>A different medication or a liquid form of the drug needs to be ordered by the physician. Opening the capsule can alter absorption and cause toxicity. Crushing alters the absorption and</td><td>A medication should never be discontinued without notification of the physician. Key words in the stem are “sustained-release capsule.” Responses <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> can be immediately eliminated because of the word clues “open</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>CHAPTER 2 FUNDAMENTALS OF PHARMACOLOGY</p>
<p>destroys the sustained-released action of the medication.</p>
<p>the capsule" and "crush the medicine." These are never used on time-released or enteric-coated medications. If you have difficulty deciding between responses  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> , a clue exists in response  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> — "inform . . . physician at the follow-up visit"; notifying the physician about the medication should be done the day the client decides to stop and no later.</p>
<p>31</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="principles-of-drug-therapy">Principles of Drug Therapy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principles-of-drug-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Define the three essential phases of drug action.</li>
<li>Define absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination.</li>
<li>Identify factors affecting absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination.</li>
<li>Identify factors affecting absorption with each route of medication administration.</li>
<li>Identify factors affecting a client’s response to drug therapy.</li>
<li>Describe the various effects and interactions of drugs.</li>
<li>Describe ways to monitor drug therapy.</li>
</ul>
<p>CHAPTER 3</p>
<p>32 ▼ CHAPTER 3 PRINCIPLES OF DRUG THERAPY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Agonist</strong>
Drug with a certain affinity for a receptor to produce a predictable response. Example: morphine sulfate (Astramorph).</p>
<p><strong>Antagonists</strong>
Drugs that exert opposite actions to others or compete for the same receptor sites. Example: naloxone hydrochloride (Narcan).</p>
<p><strong>Extrapyramidal effect</strong>
Exhibiting movement disorders, especially postural, supporting, static, and locomotor mechanisms similar to those of Parkinson’s disease. Examples: dystonia: impaired muscle tone; akathisia: restlessness, agitation, inability to sit still; akinesia: hypoactivity or nonmovement as in muscular paralysis.</p>
<p><strong>Half-life</strong>
Amount of time required to reduce the plasma drug value to one half of its initial value.</p>
<p><strong>Iatrogenic effect</strong>
Caused by treatment or diagnostic procedures.</p>
<p><strong>Idiosyncracy</strong>
An individual sensitivity to effects of a drug caused by inherited or other bodily constitution factors.</p>
<p><strong>Loading dose</strong>
Dose that may be required to obtain a therapeutic blood level.</p>
<p><strong>Maintenance dose</strong>
Daily dose to maintain a therapeutic blood level.</p>
<p><strong>Side effect</strong>
Also called <strong>adverse effect</strong>—an undesirable or unintended effect of a drug.</p>
<p><strong>Therapeutic dose</strong>
Dose that may be required to produce a desired effect.</p>
<p><strong>Toxic effect</strong>
Undesirable or unintended effect of a drug when the drug’s blood levels are above the therapeutic range. Examples: lanoxin toxicity: serum levels &gt;2.0 ng/ml; lithium toxicity: serum levels &gt;1.5 or 2.0 mEq/L; theophylline toxicity: serum levels &gt;20 µg/ml.</p>
<p><strong>Toxicity</strong>
Blood level above the therapeutic range.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-three-reasons-for-medication-administration">I. Three reasons for medication administration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-three-reasons-for-medication-administration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) for fever, digoxin (Lanoxin) for heart failure
B. Cure: antibiotic for infection</p>
<p>PHARMACOKINETICS ▼ 33</p>
<p>C. Maintenance: insulin for diabetes
D. Support: IV fluids, potassium supplements</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-the-study-of-pharmacology-includes-three-areas">II. The study of pharmacology includes three areas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-the-study-of-pharmacology-includes-three-areas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Pharmacokinetics: the study of how drugs are absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and excreted within the body; think about transport
B. Pharmacodynamics: the study of how the medicine exerts an effect once it reaches the target cell; think about action
C. Pharmacotherapeutics: the study of the use of drugs to treat various illnesses, and the clients’ responses; think about barriers for specific drugs to meet specific needs</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-pharmacokinetics-transport-of-drug">III. Pharmacokinetics: transport of drug<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-pharmacokinetics-transport-of-drug" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Four Steps</p>
<ol>
<li>Absorption</li>
<li>Distribution</li>
<li>Metabolism</li>
<li>Excretion</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Absorption: what happens to a drug from the time it enters the body until it enters the circulating fluid</p>
<ol>
<li>Mechanisms of absorption
a. Active transport: carriers + energy source
b. Passive transport: without an energy source
c. Pinocytosis: engulfing of the molecule to move it across the cell wall</li>
<li>Variables affecting absorption
a. Absorption surface: irritation to the lining of the stomach, abrasion to the skin
b. Drug formulation: enteric-coated, time-release, liquid versus solid
c. Route of administration: linked to blood flow; IV usually absorbed quicker than IM
d. Circulation: more blood flow increases absorption; less blood flow decreases absorption
e. Pain and stress: can decrease absorption; may be linked to blood flow
f. Hepatic first-pass effect: inactivation of drug by enzymes in the liver before the drug reaches the systemic circulation for distribution
g. Enterohepatic recycling: absorption of drug from the bile into the small bowel and then into the circulating system</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 3 PRINCIPLES OF DRUG THERAPY</p>
<p>h. Effects of pH in the stomach and small intestines: may increase or decrease absorption rate
i. Drug solubility: drugs must become liquid to be absorbed
j. Motility of the GI tract: may increase or decrease absorption rate
k. Drug interactions: drug to drug and drug to food</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>The different routes of medicine administration affect absorption in various ways (Table 3-1)</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Distribution: ways in which drugs are transported by body fluids to their sites of action</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Factors affecting distribution
a. Drug's affinity for
(1) Fatty tissue
(2) Bone
(3) Certain body tissue
b. Amount of blood flow to specific organs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors related to plasma protein binding
a. Drugs bound to protein albumin are transported and cannot be used until unbound or free
b. Situations that alter protein binding
(1) Hypoalbuminemia: decreased albumin level; in this situation more of a drug may be available with a result of toxic effects, i.e., digoxin
(2) Competition for protein</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blood-brain barrier: protects brain by preventing many medications from penetrating. Agents that can penetrate
a. Anesthetics
b. Barbiturates
c. Penicillin G
d. Atropine sulfate (Atropair)
e. Scopolamine hydrobromide (Hyoscine Hydrobromide)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Metabolism: the breaking down or detoxification of medications</p>
<ol>
<li>Occurs primarily in the liver</li>
<li>Other sites of metabolism: kidneys, lungs, blood, and intestinal mucosa</li>
<li>Results of metabolism on a drug
a. Converted into a harmless substance
b. Converted into metabolites capable of exerting a therapeutic effect
c. Unchanged
d. Competition resulting in toxicity</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Excretion: process of elimination from the body</p>
<ol>
<li>Occurs primarily in the kidneys</li>
</ol>
<p>DRUG ROUTES AND EFFECTS ON ABSORPTION ▼ 35</p>
<p>Table 3-1. Comparison of Drug Administration Routes and their Effects on Absorption</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Route</th><th>Effects on Absorption</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Enteral</td><td>Rapid absorption in small intestine</td></tr><tr><td>Presence of food diminishes absorption</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Absence of food increases absorption</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Liquids absorb more rapidly than solids</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Absorption occurs within 3 to 5 minutes with SL or buccal</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Increased intestinal motility decreases available time for absorption</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Absorption through the GI tract may be undependable</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Parenteral</td><td>IM injection has effects within 10 to 15 minutes</td></tr><tr><td>SQ injection can have effects within 10 to 15 minutes</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IV requires no absorption and has immediate effects</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Poor circulation may hinder IM or SQ absorption</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Shock, edema, trauma, and coolness to tissue slow absorption</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Massage and heat to tissue increase absorption</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Topical</td><td>Local application of drugs can have a systemic effect: lidocaine (Xylocaine) + epinephrine (Adrenalin)</td></tr><tr><td>Some medications may be applied locally for a systemic effect: nitrol paste or patch (Nitroglycerin)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Scarred or burned skin can hinder absorption</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Damaged or irritated skin can enhance absorption systemically</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Inhalation</td><td>May be absorbed systemically: anesthetic agents.</td></tr><tr><td>May be absorbed locally: corticosteroids</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Absorption is enhanced because of the large surface area</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Mucous Membranes</td><td>May produce either local or systemic effect</td></tr><tr><td>Rectal route may result in incomplete absorption if feces is present in sigmoid or there are numerous internal hemorrhoids</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Absorption is rapid through the rectal route because of the large vascularity—acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Absorption by the vaginal route is usually enhanced because of the high vascularity</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Other excretory sites: sweat glands, feces, saliva, bile, maternal milk, lungs</li>
<li>"Steady State": obtained when absorption equals elimination</li>
</ol>
<p>36 ▼ CHAPTER 3 PRINCIPLES OF DRUG THERAPY</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>"Half-Life": the amount of time to reduce the plasma concentration by half. Usually takes five half-lives to completely eliminate a drug.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors affecting elimination
a. Urine pH can enhance or delay excretion
b. Kidney diseases may interfere with drug clearance from the body</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-pharmacodynamics-therapeutic-effect-or-action">IV. Pharmacodynamics: therapeutic effect or action<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-pharmacodynamics-therapeutic-effect-or-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Alteration in the cell environment by drugs occurs as follows</p>
<ol>
<li>Physical modification of the cell environment by alteration of the surface tension (stool softeners) or by osmosis (osmotic diuretics)</li>
<li>Chemical modification of the cell environment such as changing the pH of stomach contents (antacids)</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Alteration in the cell function may occur when drugs interact to alter the cellular process. For example, insulin facilitates glucose into the cell.</p>
<p>C. Drug-Receptor Theory is the most commonly accepted mechanism for the action of drugs. Receptors attract drug molecules that attach and fit into the receptor (Lock and Key).</p>
<ol>
<li>Agonist: a drug with a certain affinity for a receptor. Example: morphine sulfate (Astramorph).</li>
<li>Antagonists: drugs that form a complex with the receptor, prohibiting a pharmacologic action or counteracting the effect of other drugs. Example: naloxone hydrochloride (Narcan).</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Effects of drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Local: usually affecting one body part; effect occurs at the site of application. Example: acyclovir (Zovirax) cream for herpes simplex.</li>
<li>Systemic: may affect more than one body part; effect may not occur at the site of administration. Example: promethazine hydrochloride (Phenergan).</li>
<li>Local and systemic: an agent may be given for its local effect but produce a systemic effect also. Example: lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine) with adrenalin chloride (Epinephrine) SQ.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-pharmacotherapeutic-phase-target-of-medications-and-response-by-clients">V. Pharmacotherapeutic phase: target of medications and response by clients<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-pharmacotherapeutic-phase-target-of-medications-and-response-by-clients" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Factors influencing therapeutic response</p>
<ol>
<li>Decreased muscle mass, total body weight, and fat (20% below or above ideal weight) can affect the dosage. The average adult dose is calculated on half the population weighing 150 pounds between the ages of 16 and 65.</li>
</ol>
<p>PHARMACODYNAMICS, PHARMACOTHERAPEUTICS ▼ 37</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Age: clients more prone to drug effects (Table 3-2)
a. Neonates and infants because of immature organs
b. Older adults because of a decrease in the function of organs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disease states or dysfunction of the following systems
a. Circulatory. Example: congestive heart failure.
b. Hepatic. Example: cirrhosis.
c. Renal. Example: renal failure.
d. Gastrointestinal (GI). Example: bowel inflammation or resection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Immunological state: body's ability to form antibodies against medications can result in adverse effects</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Psychological factors: a client's belief in the effects of the drug (such as a placebo)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Environmental factors: temperature and climate can affect dosage</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sex of client: females have proportionately less water owing to greater body fat. This is due to the low water content of fat cells; while most body cells are 70% to 80% water, fat cells are primarily composed of triglycerides.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Genetics: enzymes and acetylation rates are determined genetically, and alterations can cause toxicity</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Drug effects and interactions</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Primary effect: that which is intended</li>
<li>Secondary effect: any effect other than those intended
a. Drug allergy
(1) Unique tissue response. Example: dermatitis.
(2) Anaphylaxis: reaction within minutes that requires immediate attention
(3) Serum sickness: reaction one week after administration of a drug
b. Idiosyncracy: an individual sensitivity to effects of a drug caused by inherited or other bodily constitution factors. Example: malignant hyperthermia after receiving general anesthetics.
c. Side effect (also called adverse effect): an undesirable or unintended effect of a drug. Examples: nausea or insomnia.
d. Blood dyscrasias: anemias, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia
e. Photosensitivity: an abnormal reaction to light, particularly sunlight. Example: sunburn or puritus after a short time in the sun.
f. Extrapyramidal effect: exhibiting movement disorders similar to Parkinson's disease. Example: dystonia, akathisia, and akinesia.
g. Toxicity: blood level above the therapeutic range. Example: digitalis (Lanoxin) toxicity.</li>
</ol>
<p>38</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Obstetrician</th><th>Obstetrician</th><th>Other Adult</th><th>Pediatric</th><th>Pregnant</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Absorption</td><td>Delayed, but more complete</td><td>Disposition</td><td>Exaggerated as a result of lack of gastric acidity and to shorter intestines</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Impeded somewhat from a larger body surface</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IM delayed</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Enteral route unpredictable</td><td>Delayed because of decreased motility and prolonged gastric emptying</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Distribution</td><td>Low albumin could create problem with plasma protein binding</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Could cause toxicity</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Altered because of less lean mass, less body water, greater body fat</td><td>Distribution</td><td>Protein binding may be a problem—greater chance of toxicity because of low albumin levels</td><td>Decreased protein binding because of decreased protein level</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Metabolism</td><td>Decreased because of diseases and changes due to age, higher blood concentration and less excretion causes greater chances of toxicity</td><td>Metabolism</td><td>Immature liver and metabolism may be altered—best to give drugs based on body weight to avoid toxicity</td><td>Lower because of decreased blood flow to liver</td></tr><tr><td>Excretion</td><td>Less excretion from decreased glomerular filtration rate</td><td>Excretion</td><td>Delayed as a result of immature kidneys</td><td>Greater excretion from greater renal perfusion</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>39</p>
<p>Considerations</p>
<ul>
<li>Polypharmacy: the use of a number of different drugs by a patient who may have one or several health problems</li>
<li>Multiple medications can cause many problems in absorption, distribution, metabolism and/or excretion</li>
<li>Higher chance of drug-to-drug interactions</li>
<li>Compliance may be a problem due to forgetfulness, cost, ability to manipulate lids of medication bottles or equipment such as syringes, aerosols, and inability to see clearly</li>
</ul>
<p>Calculate dosage by body surface area (BSA) or mg/kg
Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Be honest about pain</li>
<li>Allow choice of bandage</li>
<li>Assure that crying is all right</li>
<li>Tell how long procedure should last or if it will hurt</li>
<li>Offer comfort (pacifier, bottle, favorite toy)</li>
<li>Use age-appropriate words and a brief explanation</li>
<li>Prepare all medication in advance</li>
<li>Keep needle out of sight</li>
<li>Solicit parents' help</li>
<li>Act quickly—do not be nervous</li>
<li>Position child correctly</li>
</ol>
<p>FDA rating of drugs for effects on pregnancy
A—No risk
B—No risk evident in human studies or animal studies
C—Risk cannot be ruled out
D—Positive evidence of risk exists
X—Contraindicated in pregnancy</p>
<p>Many drugs pass to infants through maternal milk
Teratogenes is the major concern
1st trimester
Placental barrier is not a protective mechanism
Common ingestants such as alcohol, caffeine, and illegal drugs can cause serious complications.
Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) can be a side effect of alcohol consumption: a set of congenital psychological, behavioral, cognitive, and physical abnormalities; typical are limb, cardiovascular defects, and retarded development and craniofacial defects</p>
<p>CHAPTER 3 PRINCIPLES OF DRUG THERAPY</p>
<p>h. Teratogenic: causing harm to the fetus. Example: fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS).</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Drug and food interactions occur. Example: penicillin G potassium (Pentids) is destroyed by food in the stomach.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drugs may interact with other drugs</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Synergistic effect: a substance that augments or adds to the activity of another substance or agent. Example: ethanol (alcohol) and diazepam (Valium).</p>
<p>b. Additive effect: the combined effect of drugs that produces an enhanced effect greater than the sum of their separately measured individual effects. Example: acetaminophen (Tylenol) + codeine (Tylenol no. 3).</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>
<p>Placebo effect: a physical or emotional change occurring after a substance is taken or administered that is not the result of any special property of the substance. Example: sodium chloride (normal saline) in place of a narcotic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dependency</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Physical: the need for continued use of a substance to avoid abstinence symptoms. Example: ethanol (alcohol) used to avoid delirium tremors (DTs).</p>
<p>b. Psychological: the craving or desire to continue use of a substance in order to meet the demands of everyday life. Example: diazepam (Valium).</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Tolerance: the need for increasing amounts of a substance to produce the same effect. Example: caffeine.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-monitoring-drug-therapy">VI. Monitoring drug therapy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-monitoring-drug-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Drug therapy goal is to maintain a therapeutic drug level. Examples:</p>
<ol>
<li>Digoxin (Lanoxin) level of 0.8 to 2.0 ug/ml</li>
<li>Theophylline ethylenediamide (Aminophylline) level of 10 to 20 ug/ml</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Loading dose may be required to obtain a therapeutic blood level. Most common with the following</p>
<ol>
<li>Initial digitalization</li>
<li>Urinary antiseptics</li>
<li>Anticonvulsants</li>
<li>Antidysrhythmics</li>
<li>Antibiotics</li>
<li>Bronchodilators—especially aminophylline</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Maintenance dose is the daily dose to maintain a therapeutic blood level</p>
<p>LEVELS: THERAPEUTIC, LOADING, TOXIC, PEAK, TROUGH ▼ 41</p>
<p>D. Toxicity occurs when the drug dose is greater than what is needed for a therapeutic level. Low plasma protein levels and hepatic and renal dysfunction may contribute to drug toxicities. Clients usually exhibit specific findings.</p>
<ol>
<li>For theophylline, first nausea then tremors</li>
<li>For digoxin, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting as initial findings</li>
</ol>
<p>E. The smallest drug dose needed to produce an effect is measured as the Minimal Concentration Level (MCL)</p>
<p>F. A blood test may be ordered to measure the following</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Plasma concentration level
a. Digoxin (Lanoxin)
b. Theophylline (Aminophylline)
c. Lithium carbonate (Lithium)
d. Gentamicin sulfate (Garamycin) or any aminoglycoside</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Peak level: when drug exerts its greatest concentration; usually obtained for IV antibiotics one hour after dose is completely infused; insulin depends on specific type: fast acting is 2 to 4 hours, intermediate acting is 6 to 12 hours</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Trough level: when drug is at its lowest concentration before next dose; usually antibiotics</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>G. The relationship of various concentration levels is demonstrated in Figure 3-1</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-7ce36d62.jpeg" alt="img-1.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3-1. Onset, peak, and trough levels in relation to minimal, therapeutic, and toxic blood levels. (Adapted from Baer C., and Williams B: Clinical pharmacology and nursing, ed 2, St Louis, 1992, Mosby.)</p>
<p>CHAPTER 3 PRINCIPLES OF DRUG THERAPY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>A nurse applies a medication in the form of an ointment to a client's rash. Shortly after applying the ointment, the nurse begins to feel a burning sensation on the hand and notices that it has a reddened area. The nurse then sees some ointment next to the reddened area and realizes that this drug reaction is a (an)</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Systemic effect
b. Local effect
c. Idiosyncrasy
d. Synergistic effect</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>The nurse must monitor factors affecting drug action. Which of the following clients has physiologic factors that most significantly determine and modify drug activity?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Mr. Carver, age 45, an alcoholic with an ulcer
b. John, age 18, a large boy who fractured his leg and wrist in an accident
c. Mr. Cannon, age 89, who is a frail, underweight man with high blood pressure and heart disease
d. Susie, age 12, who has just been diagnosed with leukemia</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>A client who has received an initial dose of an antibiotic shows signs of acute respiratory distress within minutes. Which is the most appropriate documentation to describe the situation?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Idiosyncratic reaction
b. Anaphylactic reaction
c. Serum sickness
d. Cumulative effect</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>The normal therapeutic range for the drug theophylline is 10 to 20 mcg/dl. A client has a serum level of 24. This level would be considered</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Tolerance
b. A high trough level
c. Exaggerated peak
d. Toxic</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>The nurse is caring for a client who has hypoalbuminemia. The nurse is concerned for which of the following reasons?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. There may be difficulty with elimination of a drug
b. Excess free drug may result in toxicity
c. A reduction in a drug effect may occur
d. Excess bound drug may result in toxicity</p>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 43</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>
<p>A client has had most of the small intestine removed. The nurse would be most concerned about drug
a. Excretion
b. Absorption
c. Metabolism
d. Distribution</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client is currently maintained on a medication that is protein bound. A second drug that is more highly protein bound has been prescribed. What is likely to be the effect if these medications are administered?
a. The second drug will produce a greater effect than the first
b. The first medication will be inactivated
c. Toxic effects may occur from the first drug
d. The second drug will have a synergistic effect on the first</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which variable will decrease the absorption of an oral drug?
a. Increased surface area of the small intestine
b. Reduced surface area of the small intestine
c. Reduced stress
d. Increased splanchnic blood flow</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>44 ▼ CHAPTER 3 PRINCIPLES OF DRUG THERAPY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The burning indicates a reaction from contact with the skin and a local reaction. A systemic effect would require absorption through the circulatory system and may be exhibited by a headache or nausea. An idiosyncracy is an unusual response, usually more on an individual basis. A synergistic effect involves the combination of two drugs.</td><td>Use a common sense approach—“ointment next to the reddened site” is a local effect. Don’t select terms that you can’t recall such as options c or d. Go with what you know!</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>His hypertension, heart disease, and weight greatly influence drug activity. In option a, the alcohol and ulcer can affect absorption, but more information is needed. In option b, the client has no significant factors that will modify drug activity. Leukemia could lower the resistance, but more information is needed in option d.</td><td>A common sense approach would also work here; the very young and the very old are more at risk for complications. The youngest given age is 12 and the oldest is 89. Look at the number of variables given for each; the young person has one and the older client has four, so c is the best choice.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The description of “acute” and “within minutes” signals this answer as anaphylactic. Respiratory distress as an anaphylactic response is not unusual to antibiotics,</td><td>Refer to rationale under response b. Be cautious to avoid an emotional response that may block your thinking process since you might not document the situation with terms of this type.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 45</p>
<p>especially penicillins. The response may occur with an initial dose or with later doses. Idiosyncratic means unusual and specific to an individual. Serum sickness usually manifests within a week after a medication administration. The “initial” dose indicates that the medication is being administered for the first time. A cumulative effect needs multiple doses.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Correct answer: d</li>
</ol>
<p>Toxicity occurs when the level is greater than the highest number indicated. (See Figure 3-1.) An increased dose is not indicated from the information in the stem. The trough level is the amount in the circulatory system before the next dose; it may be below the minimal dose. No peak time is indicated from the information to determine if it is exaggerated.</p>
<p>Remember that Toxic levels are above the Therapeutic’s maximum number. With theophylline the clinical findings would first be nausea, and later, Tremors. Another approach, if you have no idea of the correct response, is to cluster the first three responses under “normal.” In response d “toxic” indicates abnormal, so select it.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Correct answer: b</li>
</ol>
<p>A low albumin level allows more unbound drug to circulate in the body and leads to toxicity. A low albumin level does not indicate elimination problems. An increase in the drug effect would be seen. Excess bound drug would result in a reduction in the drug effect.</p>
<p>Eliminate responses a and c because of the key words “elimination” and “effect”; note that the remaining responses have the similar words, “excess . . . result in toxicity.” To decide between responses b and d, use common sense: if free drug is available, there will be more action than with the bound drug. Thus response b is best.</p>
<p>46 ▼ CHAPTER 3 PRINCIPLES OF DRUG THERAPY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-correct-answer-b">6. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many drugs are absorbed through the small intestine. The kidney is the main organ involved in elimination. The liver is the main organ involved in metabolism. Plasma protein and the circulatory system are the main elements of concern for drug distribution.</p>
<p>Recall the normal sequence of medication delivery from external and internal: 1. absorption, 2. distribution, 3. metabolism, 4. excretion. The first three steps can be remembered in alphabetical order. Common sense dictates that excretion occurs last. Refer to the rationale.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-correct-answer-c">7. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>More of the first drug will remain free, or unbound, and therefore can produce toxic effects. The second drug will compete to bind more with the protein and produce a lesser effect if it is more highly bound since less of the second drug will be free or unbound. Competition does not necessarily cause inactivation. Response <em>d</em> does not provide enough information.</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct answer, select the severest or most detrimental situation. The situations are, in option <em>a</em>—a greater effect, in option <em>b</em>—inactivated, in option <em>c</em>—toxic effects and in option <em>d</em>—synergistic effect. Select option <em>c</em>, toxic effects are the worst in the given choices.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-correct-answer-b">8. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Less intestinal surface area or time in the small intestine will decrease absorption. Example: diarrhea. Increased surface area will increase absorption. Increased stress will most likely decrease absorption. Increased blood flow will increase absorption.</p>
<p>Use common sense; decreased surface area results in decreased absorption. If you had no idea of a correct response, try matching the theme in the stem “decreased absorption” with the same in the responses—responses <em>b</em> and <em>c</em>. Then make an educated guess that reduced stress means the body is relaxed and more absorption would occur; thus, select response <em>b</em>.</p>
<p>CHAPTER 4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administration-of-medications">Administration of Medications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administration-of-medications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify general principles in the administration of medications.</li>
<li>Describe nursing practices that help the nurse achieve the “five rights” of administration of medications.</li>
<li>Identify key principles for giving medications by oral, injectable, nasogastric, intravenous, and topical routes.</li>
<li>Identify the size of needle or cannula and type of syringe for injections.</li>
<li>Locate different sites for giving intramuscular injections.</li>
<li>Calculate medication dosages using various formulas.</li>
</ul>
<p>47</p>
<p>CHAPTER 4 ADMINISTRATION OF MEDICATIONS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Airlock</strong>
Small amount of air, 0.2 to 0.5 cc, added to the syringe after the medication is accurately measured; it enables the clearing of all of the drug from the needle after the medication is injected.</p>
<p><strong>Extravasation or infiltration</strong>
The process whereby a fluid or drug passes into the tissues with findings of pain, swelling, coolness, and a pale color at the infiltration site.</p>
<p><strong>Phlebitis or thrombophlebitis</strong>
Inflammation of a vein, often accompanied by a clot, with findings of pain, swelling, redness, and warmth along the inflamed vein.</p>
<p><strong>Tissue necrosis</strong>
Localized tissue death that occurs in groups of cells in response to disease or injury, for example, from an infiltrated, highly caustic, or vasoconstrictive drug such as norepinephrine (Levophed).</p>
<p><strong>Z-track</strong>
Technique for injecting preparations into the muscle without tracking residual medication through sensitive tissue (Figure 4-6).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-general-principles-for-medication-administration">I. General principles for medication administration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-general-principles-for-medication-administration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Remember the five rights of medication administration</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Right drug</li>
<li>Right dose</li>
<li>Right route</li>
<li>Right time</li>
<li>Right client</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Always check for client allergies</strong></p>
<p><strong>C. Check all medications three times</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>When locating in the cart or on the shelf</li>
<li>When pouring or preparing</li>
<li>Before returning to cart or shelf (or before giving a unit dose)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Check all medications listed on the Medication Administration Record (MAR) against the chart orders at least once per shift</strong></p>
<p><strong>E. Never give medication another staff member has prepared</strong></p>
<p><strong>F. Sign controlled substance wastage that has been witnessed</strong></p>
<p><strong>G. Give medications within 30 minutes before or after the time scheduled if unable to give at the scheduled time</strong></p>
<p>GENERAL PRINCIPLES; DRUG ADMINISTRATION BY INJECTION ▼ 49</p>
<p>H. Identify clients by checking their identification bands and, if possible, ask them to speak their names. Ask parents to state children’s names.</p>
<p>I. Always double-check medications questioned by clients. (They are often right!)</p>
<p>J. Wash your hands prior to medication preparation and between clients</p>
<p>K. Use gloves when necessary to protect self from contamination or to avoid absorbing the medication through the skin</p>
<p>L. Assess the client according to the medication administered</p>
<p>M. Never give an unfamiliar medication. Question any unusual route, dosage, or combination of medications.</p>
<p>N. Sign out all controlled substances</p>
<p>O. In the narrative, document all prn drugs, any necessary assessments, unusual findings, the evaluation of the drug’s effectiveness, and the degree of the desired effect</p>
<p>P. Discard needles, gloves, and alcohol preps in containers clearly marked hazardous waste</p>
<p>Q. Check expiration dates of medications and IV fluids</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-administration-by-injection">II. Administration by injection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-administration-by-injection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Three sites include the following</p>
<ol>
<li>Intramuscular (IM): into a muscle</li>
<li>Subcutaneous (SC or SQ): into the subcutaneous or fatty tissue</li>
<li>Intradermal (ID): into the dermis</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Locating sites (Figures 4-1 to 4-5)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-507e6bf9.jpeg" alt="img-2.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 4-1. To define vastus lateralis and rectus femoris muscle sites, place one hand below patient’s greater trochanter and one hand above knee. Space between two hands declines middle third of underlying muscle. Rectus femoris is on anterior thigh; vastus lateralis is on lateral thigh. (From Clark J et al: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.)</p>
<p>CHAPTER 4 ADMINISTRATION OF MEDICATIONS</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-829f865d.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg">
Figure 4-2. To locate ventrogluteal muscle injection site, place palm of hand on greater trochanter of femur. Make V with fingers, with one side running from greater trochanter to anterosuperior iliac spine and other side running from greater trochanter to iliac crest. (From Clark J et al: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-42432798.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg">
Figure 4-3. Deltoid muscle injection site roughly forms inverted triangle, with acromion process as base. Muscle may be visible in muscular patients. (From Clark J et al: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.)</p>
<p>KEY PRINCIPLES—INJECTIONS ▼ 51</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-6f75aaf7.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-f0a9d495.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg">
Figure 4-4. Two accepted methods for defining dorsogluteal injection site. A, Client's buttocks can be divided on one side into imaginary quadrants. Center of upper outer quadrant should be used as injection site. B, Nurse locates by palpation posterior superior iliac spine and greater trochanter, then draws imaginary line between them. Injection site up and out from that line should be used. (From Clark J et al: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-b5c9d659.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg">
Figure 4-5. Commonly used subcutaneous injection sites. (From Clark J et al: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-f989bc7a.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg"></p>
<p>CHAPTER 4 ADMINISTRATION OF MEDICATIONS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-angles-of-injections">C. Angles of injections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-angles-of-injections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Intradermal: 15 degrees</li>
<li>Subcutaneous: 45 or 90 degrees</li>
<li>Intramuscular: 90 degrees</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-key-principles">III. Key principles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-key-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-oral-route">A. Oral route<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-oral-route" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Avoid touching tablets when transferring into a cup</li>
<li>Do not crush sustained-release or enteric-coated tablets</li>
<li>Assess the client’s ability to swallow and the presence of a gag reflex</li>
<li>Assess whether client has swallowed the tablet</li>
<li>Elevate the head of the bed at least 60 degrees to administer</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-injections">B. Injections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-injections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Know which medications should be given Z-track, usually oil-based, irritating, or large amounts of medications. This is a technique to prevent medication from leaking into the subcutaneous tissue (Figure 4-6).</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>a. Use 0.5 cc airlock: small amount of air added to the syringe after the medication is accurately measured to clear all of the drug from the injecting needle</li>
<li>b. Change the needle after drawing up the medication</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Recommended for children not yet walking is the vastus lateralis site</li>
<li>Always aspirate before injecting medications. If blood returns, remove the needle and discard the medication. For SQ</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-ef254477.jpeg" alt="img-9.jpeg">
Figure 4-6. A, In Z-track intramuscular injection, skin is pulled laterally, then injection is administered. B, After needle is withdrawn, skin is released. Technique helps prevent medication from leaking. Clark J, Queener S, &amp; Karb V: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.</p>
<p>KEY PRINCIPLES—ALL ROUTES ▼ 53</p>
<p>medications such as heparin sodium (Heparin), aspiration is not recommended.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Use an airlock 0.2 cc for injections that are not Z-track. No airlock is needed for intradermal. The use of an airlock 0.2 cc for SQ is the decision of the nurse. However, consistency should be maintained in the use of the airlock so that the dosage given to the client is not altered. Examples: insulin, heparin sodium (Heparin).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Must produce a bleb for intradermal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use the deltoid for 1 cc or less. The dorsal gluteal can tolerate a maximum of 5 cc per one site of injection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Massage increases the absorption of medication. Heparin sodium (Heparin) SQ should not be massaged to prevent bruising.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Know which medications (usually oil-based) cannot be mixed IM. Example: diazepam (Valium).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Change the needle for irritating medications. Example: iron dextran (Imferon).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Penicillin IM is given Z-track, measured in “million units,” and given with no. 16 or no. 18 gauge, 2- to 3-inch needle</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Nasogastric (NG): a tube passed through the nose into the stomach; gastrostomy (G-tube): tube inserted into the stomach</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Wear gloves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Be sure medication can be crushed to mix with water for instilling in an NG tube. Liquid forms are available for some medications.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Check placement of the tube before instillation of any medications</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Follow the medication with 30 to 60 cc of tap water to flush tube</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Other routes</p>
<ol>
<li>Vaginal</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Wear gloves</p>
<p>b. Offer the client a sanitary pad for comfort after application</p>
<p>c. Wash the applicator with warm water and soap. Applicators can be reused.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Rectal</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Wear gloves</p>
<p>b. Use a water-soluable lubricant such as K-Y Jelly</p>
<p>c. Instruct the client not to expel the suppository immediately after application and to try to retain for at least 30 minutes</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Ear drops</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Pull pinna back and down for children under age 5, pull pinna back and up for adults—remember, “grow-up” and “pull-up”</p>
<p>CHAPTER 4 ADMINISTRATION OF MEDICATIONS</p>
<p>b. Keep the dropper aseptic; avoid touching the ear
c. Allow the drop to slide down the wall of the ear canal to decrease sudden discomfort of medication falling on eardrum
d. Instruct clients to lie on their sides or keep their heads tilted to the side for 5 to-10 minutes
e. Cotton may or may not be recommended after instillation of the drops</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Eye drops and ointments</li>
</ol>
