Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Provide comfort measures for side effects</li>
<li>Encourage the use of ice chips and good oral care to relieve dry mouth</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 5 DRUGS AFFECTING THE AUTONOMIC NERVOUS SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Encourage fluids to decrease risk of constipation</li>
<li>Carefully monitor older-adult clients to prevent severe complications from the side effects</li>
<li>Use the agent 30 minutes to 1 hour prior to traveling in order to relieve motion sickness</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs routinely and if side effects occur</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>F. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Atropine sulfate (Isopto Atropine)</li>
<li>Scopolamine hydrobromide (Hyoscine)</li>
<li>Hyoscyamine sulfate (Levsin)</li>
<li>Propantheline bromide (Pro-Banthine)</li>
<li>Benztropine mesylate (Cogentin)—for Parkinson’s disease symptoms; extra-pyramidal symptoms associated with neuroleptic drugs</li>
</ol>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 73</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>While being admitted through the emergency department for signs of congestive heart failure, a client experiences extreme hypotension, BP 78/50. The client is placed on a dopamine hydrochloride (Intropin) drip. The nurse would assess which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Glucose level
b. Heart sounds
c. Neuromuscular status
d. Mental status</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Which one of these drugs is indicated for a client who is experiencing respiratory distress as an anaphylactic reaction to a first dose of cephalexin (Keflex)?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Atropine sulfate
b. Albuterol (Ventolin)
c. Ergotamine tartrate and caffeine (Cafergot)
d. Epinephrine hydrochloride (Adrenalin)</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>A client, age 5, enters the clinic with wheezing, shortness of breath, and a history of severe asthma. The physician orders epinephrine hydrochloride (Adrenalin) SC stat. After the epinephrine is given, the client should be monitored for which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Heart rate of 140, BP 90/50
b. Severe tremors, heart rate of 99
c. Heart rate of 160, BP 130/80
d. Glucose level of 32 mg/dL, severe tremors</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>A client, age 3, was sent home on albuterol (Ventolin) treatments BID for bronchitis due to severe allergies. His mother phones complaining of her child's inability to sleep at night. The mother should be instructed to do what?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Skip the evening treatment unless absolutely necessary
b. Give the second treatment at noon instead of in the afternoon
c. Give the second treatment around 4 P.M. instead of 8 P.M.
d. Divide the evening dose and give half at 4 P.M. and the other half at 8 P.M.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>A client, age 22, diagnosed with migraine headaches, should be given which of these instructions while taking ergotamine tartrate (Cafergot)?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Take 1 tablet when the headache is just beginning and every 4 hours until the headache is gone
b. Take 1 tablet at the first sign of the headache, then every hour until relieved, not to exceed 5 tablets</p>
<p>74 ▼ CHAPTER 5 DRUGS AFFECTING THE AUTONOMIC NERVOUS SYSTEM</p>
<p>c. Take 1 tablet at the first sign of the headache, then every hour until relieved, not to exceed 10 tablets
d. Take 1 tablet once the headache occurs, then every hour thereafter</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>
<p>Important information from a nursing history for the client taking metoprolol tartrate (Lopressor) would be a history of which of the following?
a. Hypertension
b. Asthma
c. Myasthenia gravis
d. Myocardial infarction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Atropine sulfate is more commonly used for which of the following?
a. Cardiovascular complications
b. Glaucoma
c. Hypertension
d. Reduction of salivation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hyoscyamine sulfate (Levsin) is ordered for a 4-month-old client who is experiencing extreme episodes of colic during the early morning hours. The client's parent should be instructed to monitor the infant for which of the following?
a. Diarrhea
b. Constipation
c. Polyuria
d. Hypothermia</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 75</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: a</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Adrenergic agonists can cause hyperglycemia. These agents cause tachycardia; therefore the vital signs, not the heart sounds, should be monitored. These agents do not affect neuromuscular status. These agents do not directly affect mental status.</td><td>If you have no idea of the correct answer, cluster responses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> under “bedside assessment.” Response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> is correct.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Epinephrine is used in anaphylactic reactions and shock; it results in overall clinical improvement during an emergency because of the positive inotropic, chronotropic, and dromotropic effects. It is given IV or SQ in anaphalactic situations. Atropine increases the heart rate. Ventolin is used to treat asthma and hypotension. Cafergot is used for hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, and headaches; it is usually given PO or by suppository.</td><td>Remember Epinephrine for Emergencies.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Side effects of epinephrine include both hypertension and tachycardia. Epinephrine causes hyperglycemia; 32 mg/dL is hypoglycemia, which is defined as a serum glucose of &lt;50 mg/dL.</td><td>Read the responses with a vertical technique; it clarifies and helps to eliminate responses without your reading all the information. Read down: HR 140—yes; tremors—not typical, so eliminate this answer; HR 160—yes; glucose 32—no, so</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>CHAPTER 5 DRUGS AFFECTING THE AUTONOMIC NERVOUS SYSTEM</p>
<p>eliminate this answer. Then read the second series down for the responses left: BP 90/50—no and BP 130/80—yes. The correct response is c.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-correct-answer-c">4. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Taking the drug earlier may decrease the irritability and insomnia and still allow the child to sleep. Skipping the dose could cause increased symptoms from the bronchitis. A dose at noon would be too soon after a morning dose and too long before the next morning dose. Giving half the dose could lower the agents therapeutic effects.</p>
<p>The key words in the stem are the BID frequency and his “severe” allergies—he “needs” the medication; so eliminate responses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>. Use common sense to choose option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> since 4 P.M. is later in the day for a second dose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-b">5. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Taking the drug every hour until the headache is relieved should prevent it from developing to maximum severity. The recommended dose should not exceed five tablets with one headache episode. Cafergot is to be taken to prevent a full-blown, severe headache; every 4 hours would have a minimal effect. Ten tablets would exceed the recommended dose for an attack. Cafergot is to be taken “before” the full attack of a migraine headache. Benefits of the drug cannot be experienced if the client waits until the headache has reached a maximum pain.</p>
<p>The major action with migraine headaches is “preventive,” not to treat after the fact. Usually, the responses are narrowed to either <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>. Be conservative and make an educated selection: choose response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> with the lesser number for a maximum.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 77</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-correct-answer-b">6. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lopressor can cause bronchospasm and could cause respiratory problems for a client with asthma. Lopressor would decrease hypertension. This agent should not interfere with mysthenia gravis. These agents, beta blockers, may be recommended for clients with myocardial infarctions.</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct response, use what you know and go with the ABCs—airway, breathing, circulation—and select response b. Also, remember that with beta blockers—bb—the major complications are bb—bronchospasm and bradycardia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-correct-answer-d">7. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It has an antisecretory action that decreases salivation, mucosal secretions, and peristalsis of the GI and GU tracts. This action helps prevent intraoperative complications. Atropine is used preoperatively to limit potential side effects of aspiration during surgery. Atropine is contraindicated in glaucoma because of the effects of the agent: the mydriasis, pupillary dilation, and cycloplegia—paralysis of the ciliary muscle. Atropine affects heart rate, not the blood pressure.</p>
<p>Recall that atropine is an anticholinergic and therefore acts against the normal, day-to-day processes of the body (moist mucous membranes, peristalsis, pupillary response to light and visual gaze, and a heart rate within normal limits of 60 to 100). Thus, these findings will change after administration of a dose of atropine for a period of time.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-correct-answer-b">8. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Constipation is common with Levsin because of the anticholinergic effect, so fluids should be encouraged. Urinary retention, not polyuria, is a side effect of the drug. A last side effect of this drug is intolerance to heat, but not hypothermia.</p>
<p>Approach the responses to the situation in the stem in mind: colic = spasms of the GI tract, so treatment would be guided to decrease the motility of the GI tract. The only answer that suggests the end result or problem of slowing down the bowel is b, constipation.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>79
CHAPTER 6</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-neuromuscular-system">Drugs Affecting the Neuromuscular System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-neuromuscular-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the classifications and actions of drugs used as anticonvulsants.</li>
<li>Describe the difference between dopaminergic and cholinergic blocking agents used for Parkinson's disease.</li>
<li>Describe the mechanism of action of anticholinesterase inhibitors for treatment of myasthenia gravis.</li>
<li>Describe the action of neuromuscular blocking agents.</li>
<li>List common side effects of anticonvulsants, antiparkinsonism drugs, antimyastthenic agents, and neuromuscular blocking agents.</li>
<li>Identify nursing implications for anticonvulsants, antiparkinsonism drugs, antimyastthenic agents, and neuromuscular blocking agents.</li>
</ul>
<p>CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Anticonvulsant</strong>
A substance that prevents, reduces, or stops the severity of epileptic or other convulsive seizures.</p>
<p><strong>End-of-dose deterioration</strong>
Return of symptoms before the next dose.</p>
<p><strong>Extrapyramidal effect</strong>
Exhibiting movement disorders, especially postural, supporting, static, and locomotor mechanisms similar to those of Parkinson’s disease. Examples: dystonia: impaired muscle tone; akathisia: restlessness, agitation, inability to sit still; and akinesia: hypoactivity or nonmovement as in muscular paralysis.</p>
<p><strong>Gamma-amino-butyric acid (GABA)</strong>
An amino acid with neurotransmitter activity found in the brain, heart, lungs, and kidneys.</p>
<p><strong>On-off phenomenon</strong>
Alteration in the control of symptoms from day to day or within each day.</p>
<p><strong>Status epilepticus</strong>
A medical emergency characterized by continual, uninterrupted seizures; commonly treated with IV Valium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="anticonvulsants">ANTICONVULSANTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anticonvulsants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>I. Agents used to prevent or treat the severity of epilepsy or other convulsive seizures</strong></p>
<p><strong>II. General information</strong></p>
<p>A. There is no ideal drug to control seizures; therefore a trial period of evaluating the effects of a drug is needed
B. Abrupt withdrawal of these agents may precipitate seizures
C. Close supervision is needed to monitor the effects and serum levels of the drug
D. Safety measures should be taken by the nurse and taught to the client due to the sedative effect of these agents
E. Dosage is highly individualized and may require titrating the dose with several dosage adjustments
F. Many drug interactions may occur while a client is on anticonvulsants and other medications
G. Compliance is a major factor in the control of this disease</p>
<p>GENERAL INFORMATION, DILANTIN, PHENOBARBITOL ▼ 81</p>
<p>H. The therapeutic goal is to control the seizure activity without hindering the client's ability to perform normal daily activities
I. All use of alcohol should be eliminated while the client is on these agents because alcohol may cause an additive effect and increase sedation
J. A baseline neurologic assessment should be made by the nurse before beginning the anticonvulsant therapy, then made every shift thereafter</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-hydantoin-derivatives">III. Hydantoin derivatives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-hydantoin-derivatives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Actions: decrease the focal activity in the CNS, decrease the spread of the seizure process, and decrease abnormal hyperactivity
B. Use: first line drug therapy for all types of seizures except absence (petit mal) seizures
C. Major side effects: minimal at therapeutic levels. Common effects related to the dose prescribed include the following</p>
<ol>
<li>Gingival hyperplasia: overgrowth of the gingival tissue</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal effects: nausea, vomiting, anorexia</li>
<li>Hypersensitivity</li>
<li>Hematologic reactions</li>
<li>Dysrhythmias and hypotension
D. Interactions: may occur with enzyme inhibitors, folic acid, oral contraceptives, and other agents that are highly protein bound
E. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Require careful monitoring of the therapeutic level</li>
<li>Require careful monitoring in a pregnant/lactating client; teratogenicity is possible</li>
<li>Should be given intravenous (IV) slowly because hypotension and dysrhythmias may occur; given only through a saline line, at the most proximal port to the insertion site</li>
<li>Should not be mixed with other agents when given IV; validate a good blood return; extravasation causes tissue death
F. Common drug: phenytoin (Dilantin) is the primary drug within this group</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iv-barbiturates">IV. Barbiturates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-barbiturates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: limit the spread of seizures by increasing the seizure threshold</p>
<p>82 ▼ CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>All types of seizures except absence seizures</li>
<li>Status epilepticus</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Sedation (most common)</li>
<li>Agitation, confusion (especially in older adults)</li>
<li>Physical dependence</li>
<li>Congenital abnormalities to the fetus</li>
<li>Toxicity</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions: may occur with oral contraceptives, oral anticoagulants (decreased effect), and other CNS depressants (additive effect)</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Slow withdrawal may occur</li>
<li>A loading dose may be required</li>
<li>Tolerance may develop, so symptoms should be monitored; dosage may need to be increased</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drug: phenobarbital sodium (Luminal Sodium)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-iminostilbenes">V. Iminostilbenes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-iminostilbenes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Action: similar to phenytoin (Dilantin); used in cases refractory to first line drugs because of side effects</p>
<p>B. Uses: effective in tonic-clonic, simple partial, and complex partial seizures</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Vertigo, dizziness</li>
<li>Drowsiness</li>
<li>Nausea or vomiting</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions: decreased effects with phenobarbital, phenytoin; toxicity potential with cimetidine, isoniazid, lithium, erythromycin</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor blood studies: CBB, hepatic and renal</li>
<li>Know that urine may turn pink or brown</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drug: carbamazepine (Tegretol)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-oxazolidinediones">VI. Oxazolidinediones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-oxazolidinediones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: decrease seizures in cortex, basal, ganglia; decrease synaptic stimulation to low-frequency impulses</p>
<p>B. Use: most effective against absence seizures</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Extremely toxic</li>
</ol>
<p>TEGRETOL, ZARONTIN, VALPORIC ACID ▼ 83</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Limited use because of toxicity</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor blood studies, CBC, hepatic and renal</li>
<li>Teach that drug may take 1 to 4 weeks to work</li>
<li>Teach that if rash develops, to notify physician promptly</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drugs: trimethadione (Tridione), paramethadione (Paradione)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-succinimides">VII. Succinimides<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-succinimides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit spike, wave formation in absence seizures; decrease amplitude, frequency, duration, spread of discharge in minor motor seizures
B. Use: primarily in absence seizures
C. Major side effects: mostly gastrointestinal including epigastric pain and hiccups
D. Interactions: decrease effects of estrogens, oral contraceptives; antagonist effect with tricyclic antidepressants
E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Teach clients to avoid alcohol ingestion and CNS depressants; may result in increased sedation</li>
<li>Monitor blood studies: CBC, hepatic and renal</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drug: ethosuximide (Zarontin)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-valporic-acid">VIII. Valporic acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-valporic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: similar to succinimides
B. Use: primarily in absence seizures
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Tremors</li>
<li>Gastric distress, diarrhea</li>
<li>Weight gain</li>
<li>Irregular menses</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions: increase effects with CNS depressants; increase toxicity with salicylates, warfarin, phenytoin</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Give elixir alone; do not dilute</li>
<li>Teach client that physical dependency may result if used long term</li>
<li>Monitor blood studies: CBC, hepatic, and renal</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drug: valporic acid (Depakene syrup or Depakene)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-benzodiazepines">IX. Benzodiazepines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-benzodiazepines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: facilitate GABA and inhibit nerve impulses</p>
<p>84 ▼ CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>B. Use: primarily for status epilepticus (a medical emergency characterized by uninterrupted seizures)
C. Major side effects: CNS—drowsiness, fatigue, lethargy
D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Administer IV slowly and in titrated dosages to most proximal IV site</li>
<li>Drugs may precipitate if mixed with any other agents
E. Common drug: diazepam (Valium)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antiparkinsonism-drugs">ANTIPARKINSONISM DRUGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antiparkinsonism-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. Parkinson’s disease: a slowly progressive, degenerative, neurologic disorder characterized by nonintentional tremors, shuffling gait, masklike facial expression, muscle rigidity, and weakness</p>
<p>II. Goals of these agents: to relieve the symptoms of the disease and to aid the client in carrying out normal daily activities. These agents do not cure; they only treat the symptoms.</p>
<p>III. Actions
A. Increase the dopaminergic system in three ways</p>
<ol>
<li>By increasing the release of dopamine in the brain</li>
<li>By stimulating the dopamine receptor sites</li>
<li>By enhancing conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the brain
B. Anticholinergic drugs: used to decrease the cholinergic system by blocking the acetylcholine receptors in the brain. This action lessens the symptoms of the disease.</li>
</ol>
<p>IV. Uses: decrease the rigidity, spasms, and tremors associated with Parkinson’s disease. These agents also control extrapyramidal effects caused by antipsychotic agents.</p>
<p>V. Major side effects: drug effects are dose-dependent
A. Gastrointestinal effects: nausea, vomiting, anorexia, aversion to certain foods
B. Dysrhythmias, orthostatic hypotension
C. Extrapyramidal effects: tremors, tardive dyskinesia (rhythmic movements of the face manifested by active tongue movement, rocking, chewing, grimacing), dystonia (impaired</p>
<p>VALIUM, DRUGS TO TREAT PARKINSONISM ▼ 85</p>
<p>muscle tone), and akathisia (pathologic condition: restlessness, agitation, inability to sit still)</p>
<p>D. Behavioral symptoms: nervousness, agitation, anxiety</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-interactions-pyroidoxine-hydrochloride-hexa-betalin-can-reverse-the-effectiveness-of-levodopa">VI. Interactions: pyroidoxine hydrochloride (Hexa-Betalin) can reverse the effectiveness of levodopa<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-interactions-pyroidoxine-hydrochloride-hexa-betalin-can-reverse-the-effectiveness-of-levodopa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-nursing-implications">VII. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Instruct the client to rise slowly if orthostatic hypotension occurs
B. Administer the medicine with food if GI symptoms occur
C. Monitor for the following</p>
<ol>
<li>On-off phenomenon: alteration in the control of symptoms from day to day or within each day</li>
<li>End-of-dose deterioration: return of symptoms prior to the next dose</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-common-drugs">VIII. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Dopaminergic agents: levodopa (L-dopa is the precursor of dopamine, which enters the brain). The problem with levodopa is that a majority of it is converted to dopamine in the periphery, so it cannot cross the blood-brain barrier. Carbidopa blocks the peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine and allows for more of the drug to enter the brain before it is converted to dopamine.</p>
<ol>
<li>Levodopa or L-dopa (Larodopa)</li>
<li>Carbidopa-levodopa (Sinemet)</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Dopamine receptor agonists</p>
<ol>
<li>Amantadine hydrochloride (Symmetrel)</li>
<li>Bromocriptine mesylate (Parlodel)</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Anticholinergic drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Benztropine (Cogentin)</li>
<li>Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)</li>
<li>Trihexyphenidyl (Artane)</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Selegiline hydrochloride (L-Deprenyl)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antimyasthenic-agents">ANTIMYASTHENIC AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antimyasthenic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. Myasthenia gravis: an abnormal condition characterized by the chronic fatigue and weakness of voluntary muscles. The goal of therapy for clients</p>
<p>CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>with myasthenia gravis is to maintain a normal lifestyle. These drugs do not cure the disease.</p>
<p>II. Action: these agents prevent the breaking down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction so that receptors are activated and the effects of the acetylcholine are prolonged; this improves the symptoms of the disease (Figure 6-1)
III. Uses: to treat myasthenia gravis and to reverse the effects of neuromuscular blocking agents</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-465efd18.jpeg" alt="img-13.jpeg">
Figure 6-1. Acetylcholine is the neurotransmitter released by the nerve to occupy nicotinic receptors on the muscle and thereby initiates biochemical events causing the muscle to contract. Acetylcholine is rapidly degraded by acetylcholinesterase, present throughout the synapse. In myasthenia gravis, the number of receptors is greatly decreased. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors prevent rapid breakdown of acetylcholine. With more acetylcholine present, fewer receptors are needed, and loss of receptors is partially compensated. (From Clark J et al: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.)</p>
<p>DRUGS TO TREAT MYASTHENIA GRAVIS ▼ 87</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-major-side-effects">IV. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Muscle weakness, cramping, contractions
B. Parasympathetic stimulation: excessive salivation, nausea, vomiting, sweating, bronchospasm
C. Cholinergic crisis: a pronounced muscular weakness and respiratory paralysis caused by excessive acetylcholine or an overdose with anticholinesterase drugs, manifested by increased weakness, increased salivation, dyspnea, bradycardia, increased secretions, nausea, and vomiting</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-interactions-taken-concurrently-with-other-drugs-containing-anticholinergic-properties-may-cause-increased-side-effects">V. Interactions: taken concurrently with other drugs containing anticholinergic properties may cause increased side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-interactions-taken-concurrently-with-other-drugs-containing-anticholinergic-properties-may-cause-increased-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-nursing-implications">VI. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. A baseline neuromuscular assessment is necessary
B. Doses are highly individualized. Periods of stress and infection may require an increased dose.
C. Monitor signs of improved ptosis, ability to swallow, and muscle strength for evaluation of drug's effectiveness
D. Teach the patient the signs and symptoms of cholinergic crisis and to report them to physician immediately
E. Administer with food to decrease the GI side effects, and 30 to 60 minutes before a meal to increase strength for chewing and swallowing
F. Too small of a dose can result in myasthenic crisis (sudden return of original clinical findings), and too large of a dose can result in cholinergic crisis. The client should be taught to distinguish between the two and the importance of compliance.
G. The antidote for these drugs is atropine sulfate</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-common-drugs-acetylcholinesterase-inhibitors-are-the-drugs-of-choice-for-this-disease">VII. Common drugs: acetylcholinesterase inhibitors are the drugs of choice for this disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-common-drugs-acetylcholinesterase-inhibitors-are-the-drugs-of-choice-for-this-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Pyridostigmine bromide (Mestinon)
B. Neostigmine methylsulfate (Prostigmin)
C. Edrophonium chloride (Tensilon)—used more in the initial diagnostic process and to differentiate between myasthenic crisis and cholinergic crises; it has a short duration of action</p>
<p>CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="neuromuscular-blocking-agents">NEUROMUSCULAR BLOCKING AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neuromuscular-blocking-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-divided-into-two-groups">I. Divided into two groups<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-divided-into-two-groups" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Nondepolarizing agents
B. Depolarizing agents</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-general-information-about-the-classification">II. General information about the classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-general-information-about-the-classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. These drugs act to relax the skeletal muscles by disrupting the transmission of nerve impulses
B. These drugs do not cross the blood-brain barrier; therefore the client remains conscious and aware of pain
C. Three clinical indications for these drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Relax smooth muscles during surgery</li>
<li>Decrease the intensity of muscle spasms in drug-induced or electrically induced convulsions</li>
<li>Manage clients needing controlled mechanical ventilation</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-nondepolarizing-agents">III. Nondepolarizing agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-nondepolarizing-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: compete with acetylcholine for the receptor sites on the motor end plate or by blocking depolarization
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Facilitate endotracheal intubation</li>
<li>Decrease amount of anesthetic during surgery</li>
<li>Relax skeletal muscles of intubated clients on mechanical assistance to allow for total control of breathing
C. Major side effects</li>
<li>Cardiac: hypotension, tachycardia, dysrhythmias</li>
<li>Respiratory: apnea, depression, bronchospasm, excess bronchial secretions
D. Interactions</li>
<li>Antibiotics intensify the effect of the neuromuscular blocking agents</li>
<li>Some antidysrhythmic agents may potentiate the effects of these drugs
E. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Implement safety measures and instruct the client on safety measures; eyes may need artificial tears and be patched during paralysis</li>
<li>Use suction and intubation equipment as needed</li>
<li>Offer pain medications if indicated</li>
<li>Keep the antidote (anticholinesterase drugs) available, edrophonium chloride (Tensilon)</li>
</ol>
<p>NEUROMUSCULAR BLOCKING AGENTS ▼ 89</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Assess for signs of respiratory depression, if not ventilated</li>
<li>Maintain a calm environment</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs carefully</li>
<li>If client is on a ventilator, bring client out of paralysis once per shift to complete a neuro check</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>F. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Pancuronium bromide (Pavulon)</li>
<li>Gallamine triethiodide (Flaxedil)</li>
<li>Pipecuronium bromide (Arduan)</li>
<li>Vecuronium bromide (Norcuron)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>IV. Depolarizing agents</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Action:</strong> these agents mimic the action of acetylcholine and cause depolarization of the muscle fiber, which makes the muscle incapable of becoming stimulated by another impulse. These agents are not destroyed by cholinesterase and therefore have a prolonged action.</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Short-term relaxation needed in orthopedic procedures</li>
<li>Intubation</li>
<li>Endoscopy</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Hypertension</li>
<li>Increased intraocular pressure</li>
<li>Muscle pain</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Interactions:</strong> same as for nondepolarizing agents</p>
<p><strong>E. Nursing implications:</strong> same as for nondepolarizing agents</p>
<p><strong>F. Common drug:</strong> succinylcholine chloride (Anectine)</p>
<p>90 ▼ CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Nursing implications for the patient on an anticonvulsant include which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. A neurological assessment is essential after the drug regimen begins
b. Administering the medicine around the clock may decrease sedation
c. If toxicity occurs, the drug is abruptly discontinued
d. Compliance in taking the medicine should be stressed to the client</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>A client with status epilepticus might be given which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Oxazolidones
b. Iminostilbenes
c. Valporic acid
d. Benzodiazepine</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>A client is admitted to the hospital for the control of seizures. The physician prescribes a hydantoin derivative—phenytoin (Dilantin). This class of agents helps to treat seizures by</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Limiting the spread of the seizure
b. Facilitating GABA to inhibit nerve impulses
c. Decreasing the focal activity in the CNS
d. Inhibiting nerve impulses</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>While taking the phenytoin (Dilantin), a female client should be advised to do which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Use alcohol conservatively
b. Report for blood monitoring as ordered to avoid toxicity
c. Continue taking her oral contraceptives as ordered
d. Hold one dose if the drug is too sedating</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Which possible adverse reaction to phenytoin (Dilantin) should be reported to the physician?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Cavities
b. Hypertension
c. Agitation, confusion
d. Bleeding of gums</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>The drugs of choice in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease are those that</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Block acetylcholine receptors in the brain
b. Decrease the dopaminergic system
c. Increase the dopaminergic system
d. Increase cholinergic activity</p>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 91</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>When a client on an antiparkinsonism drug, levodopa (L-dopa), is experiencing many side effects, the combination of levodopa/carbidopa (Sinemet) may work better because</li>
</ol>
<p>a. The latter blocks all side effects of levodopa
b. The levodopa is converted to dopamine more quickly after absorption
c. The carbidopa blocks the conversion of the levodopa to dopamine before its entry into the brain
d. The anticholinergic effects block the symptoms of the disease</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>A client is on an antiparkinsonism drug. He receives his dose as scheduled (9-1-5). The nurse notices that from 9 A.M. to 12 noon he seems calm, is without tremors, and walks normally. Between 12:30 P.M. and 4:30 P.M. his symptoms worsen. The nurse should suspect</li>
</ol>
<p>a. End-of-dose deterioration
b. On-off phenomenon
c. Extrapyramidal effects
d. Dawn phenomenon</p>
<ol start="9">
<li>Antimyasthenic agents exert their effects on improving the symptoms of myasthenia gravis by which action?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Deactivating receptors at the neuromuscular junction
b. Decreasing the excitatory effects of the cholinergic system
c. Inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction
d. Increasing the destruction of acetylcholine</p>
<ol start="10">
<li>A client diagnosed with myasthenia gravis is placed on pyridostigmine bromide (Mestinon). She calls the office and complains of severe diarrhea, drooling, and intestinal cramping. What is the best advice for her?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Avoid the next dose and see the doctor tomorrow
b. Report to the emergency room at once for treatment
c. Increase the next dose and report back to the physician
d. Come in to the office for an examination and perhaps an IV tension test</p>
<ol start="11">
<li>Which of the following would be appropriate nursing implications for a client on a nondepolarizing blocking agent?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Monitor vital signs once per shift
b. Assess for the need to suction the client and for indications of pain
c. Instruct the client to ambulate at least twice per shift unless contraindicated by the physician
d. Allow frequent visitors in order to occupy the client during the therapy</p>
<p>CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Compliance is a major teaching effort for clients on these drugs in order to control the seizures. A baseline neurological assessment should be done before administering the agent, then used for comparison purposes later. Sedation is a major side effect. A bedtime (HS) dose is best for eliminating the sedating effect. Abrupt discontinuation could cause the seizures to return.</td><td>Key words in each response help to eliminate it as a choice. Refer to the rationale for further information. In response a the key word is “after;” in response b, “decrease”; and in response c, “abruptly.”</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Diazepam (Valium), a benzodiazepine, is the drug of choice. Barbiturates can also be used. Ativan, an anticonvulsant agent, is also a drug of choice, since it has a longer duration with less respiratory depression for status epilepticus. Oxazolidones are not used for status epilepticus. Iminostilbenes are used for cases refractory to phenytoin (Dilantin). Valporic acid is used in absence seizures.</td><td>Go with what you know. If you cannot recall what the classifications of responses a, b, and c are and identified the classification in response d, then select that with which you are familiar.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>This action of hydantoin derivatives decreases the spread of the seizure by decreasing abnormal</td><td>Go with what you know plus use common sense to match the need to “control” the seizure by “decreasing” activity of the CNS.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 93</p>
<p>hyperactivity. This action in response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> is the action of barbiturates. Responses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> are the actions of benzodiazepines.</p>
<p>“Limiting the spread” in response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> would not control seizures. Avoid selecting option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> when you have no recall what it pertains to.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-correct-answer-b">4. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Maintaining a therapeutic level is absolutely necessary to control seizures. Alcohol should never be taken by a client while on an anticonvulsant because of the additive effect. Interactions can occur with this drug and oral contraceptives. The client should have the physician evaluate the dose of the oral contraceptive being taken. The excess sedation should be reported to the physician. A client should never avoid a dose without first notifying the physician.</p>
<p>Use a true-false approach to select response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>. All the other answers are false. Refer to the rationale.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-d">5. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gingival hyperplasia can cause softening and severe tenderness of the gums. If gums bleed the client probably has an additional problem. Cavities are not a side effect of this medication. Hypotension is a common side effect. Sedation, not agitation is a common side effect.</p>
<p>Use the ABCs if you have no idea of a correct answer. Select the response dealing with circulation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-correct-answer-c">6. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Increasing the dopaminergic system should decrease the symptoms of Parkinson’s. In response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> this is the action of anticholinergic agents, which</p>
<p>A way to remember Parkinson’s is to stutter . . . PDDD . . . Parkinson’s Disease is a Deficiency in Dopamine.</p>
<p>CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>can be used in Parkinson's but are not the drugs of choice. The dopaminergic system is already decreased in this disease. Increasing cholinergic activity will increase the symptoms of the disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-correct-answer-c">7. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Because the brain blocks the entry of dopamine, conversion of levodopa within the brain boosts the dopaminergic system. The combination increases the effectiveness of the agent but does not decrease all side effects. Dopamine does not cross the blood-brain barrier, since with L-dopa, dopamine is mostly converted in the periphery. Clients using Levodopa/ Carbidopa (Sinemet) do not exhibit anticholinergic effects.</p>
<p>A common sense approach here will help guide option selection. Reread the question with each option. The option that makes most sense is c; if conversion of levodopa to dopamine occurs in the brain, common sense tells you the effect will be better.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-correct-answer-b">8. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The control of the symptoms fluctuates with on-off phenomenon despite repeat dosing. End-of-dose deterioration would manifest a return of symptoms before each dose. Extrapyramidal effects may be manifested with a return of symptoms but would not occur for only a short time period. The dawn phenomenon occurs with antidiabetic agents. Dawn phenomena in Type I diabetics may require an increased insulin dose in the</p>
<p>The important item to clarify here is the time of the medication in relation to the abnormal clinical findings. If the client had end-of-dose deterioration the findings would occur mainly between the hours of 12 noon to 1 P.M. and 4 P.M. to 5 P.M., not between 12:30 P.M. and 4:30 P.M.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 95</p>
<p>early morning hours because of an increase in serum glucose; it is treated with extra insulin. In contrast, the Somogyi Phenomenon is a rebound effect where too much insulin induces hypoglycemia around 2 to 3 A.M. with resulting response of the body to break down glucose stores so that by 6 A.M. the fasting glucose is elevated.</p>
<ol start="9">
<li>Correct answer: c</li>
</ol>
<p>The action of these agents prolongs the effects of the acetylcholine, which improves the disease symptoms. The action of these agents involves activating receptors at the neuromuscular junction and slowing the destruction of acetylcholine. This action in response b is describing antiparkinson drugs.</p>
<ol start="10">
<li>Correct answer: d</li>
</ol>
<p>The side effects could be due to the dose being taken; a visit to her physician is necessary for an adjustment in the amount. Cholinergic crisis typically occurs when the dosage is being initiated or increased to determine the correct dose. The medication should not be held without prior notification of the physician. These symptoms do not warrant a cholinergic crisis but do need to be reported. Doses should</p>
<p>Associate acetylcholine is needed for action of voluntary muscles in myasthenic gravis. Cluster options a, b, and d with negative actions—deactivate, decrease and destruction increased. Option c is more neutral; select it.</p>
<p>Eliminate responses a and c, since they break the basic rules of medication administration. Since the findings do not include any threat to the ABCs there is no need for the client to go to the emergency room. The reasonable action is to advise as described in response d.</p>
<p>96 ▼ CHAPTER 6 DRUGS AFFECTING THE NEUROMUSCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>not be changed unless recommended by the physician.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="11-correct-answer-b">11. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These agents do not control pain; therefore pain medication should be offered or routinely given along with these agents. A side effect is excess bronchial secretions for which suctioning may be needed. Vital signs should be monitored more frequently, at least every 30 minutes. Bed rest should be initiated, with side rails raised, while the client is under the influence of these agents. A calm environment would help the client relax and lessen any pain.</p>
<p>Recall that nondepolarizing blocking agents are neuromuscular paralyzers. Thus the client cannot move voluntary and involuntary muscles. Given this, the most reasonable answer is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>7
CHAPTER</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-central-nervous-system">Drugs Affecting the Central Nervous System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-central-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the difference between preanesthetics, general anesthetics, and local anesthetics.</li>
<li>Describe the side effects and nursing implications for anesthetic agents.</li>
<li>Describe the therapeutic uses of stimulants.</li>
<li>Identify the difference between amphetamines, anorexiant agents, and analeptic agents.</li>
<li>Identify the major groups of drugs used as psychotropics and antianxiety agents.</li>
<li>List the major therapeutic uses and side effects of psychotropics and antianxiety agents.</li>
<li>Describe the differences among antidepressant agents.</li>
<li>Identify necessary client teaching of CNS depressants.</li>
<li>Discuss the action of skeletal muscle relaxants.</li>
<li>Identify common uses and side effects of skeletal muscle relaxants.</li>
<li>Identify nursing implications for skeletal muscle relaxants.</li>
</ul>
<p>98 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Amphetamines</strong>
A group of nervous system stimulants that are subject to abuse. Street names and routes: black beauties, lidpoppers, and pep pills, all taken by mouth; speed, an injectable form; and ice, a crystalline form of methamphetamine that is smoked.</p>
<p><strong>Analeptics</strong>
Also called <strong>CNS Stimulants</strong>. Substances that quicken the activity of the CNS by increasing the rate of neuronal discharge or by blocking an inhibitory neurotransmitter such as caffeine and amphetamines.</p>
<p><strong>Anorexiant</strong>
A drug or other agent that suppresses the appetite.</p>
<p><strong>Central nervous system (CNS)</strong>
One of the two main divisions of the nervous systems of the body, consisting of the brain and the spinal cord. The other main division is the peripheral nervous system.</p>
<p><strong>CNS depressant</strong>
Any drug or substance that decreases the function of the CNS, such as alcohol, barbiturates, and hypnotics. Such drugs can produce tolerance, physical dependence, and compulsive drug use. Street names: “reds,” for secobarbital and “yellows,” for pentobarbital.</p>
<p><strong>Monoamine oxidase enzyme (MAO)</strong>
An enzyme that catalyzes the oxidation of amines. The inhibition of this enzyme by MAO inhibitors is used in the treatment of depression. MAO inhibitors interact with foodstuffs and drugs such as ephedrine, a common ingredient in common cold remedies.</p>
<p><strong>Peripheral nervous system</strong>
The motor and sensory nerves and ganglia outside the brain and spinal cord.</p>
<p><strong>Photosensitivity</strong>
A skin reaction requiring the presence of a sensitizing agent, typically a medication such as tetracycline, and exposure to sunlight or its equivalent.</p>
<p><strong>Psychotropic agents</strong>
Substances that affect the mind or modify mental activity.</p>
<p><strong>Serotonin</strong>
Acts as a neurotransmitter in the CNS; found in platelets and the cells of the brain and the intestines. If released in the blood vessels, it is a potent vasoconstrictor; if in the intestines, it stimulates smooth muscles to contract.</p>
<p><strong>Tyramine</strong>
An amino acid synthesized in the body from the essential acid tyrosine. Tyramine stimulates the</p>
<p>PREANESTHETIC DRUGS ▼ 99</p>
<p>release of catecholamines: epinephrine, and norepinephrine. Clients on MAO inhibitors must avoid foods with tyramine, particularly aged cheeses and meats, bananas, yeast-containing products, and alcoholic beverages. If restrictions are not followed, severe hypertensive crisis may result.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-preanesthetics">I.
