Preanesthetics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-preanesthetics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Action: varies according to the classification</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Induce sedation and decrease anxiety</li>
<li>Decrease the risk of bradycardia</li>
<li>Allow for a smoother induction of anesthesia</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Often given IM or IV</li>
<li>May mix two or more drugs to produce the desired effect</li>
<li>May be ordered the night before or 30 to 60 minutes before the surgery</li>
<li>Use the Z-track method if medication is oil-based or more irritating, and chart this technique if applicable</li>
<li>Double-check the dosage, especially if given in a rushed situation</li>
<li>Know which drugs can be mixed together</li>
<li>Check the client’s drug allergies before preparation of medication</li>
<li>Verify the correct client, using the arm band, and ask client to state his/her name if able</li>
<li>Know the correct time to administer the injection, secure the medicine, and prepare the equipment, ahead of time if possible. Many of these drugs may be scheduled drugs and require signing out on a narcotic record.</li>
<li>Practice safety precautions after medication administration: put side rails up, place call light within reach, give instructions to the client not to get up without assistance, and encourage client to void prior to administration</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Common drugs within each classification</p>
<ol>
<li>Narcotics: morphine sulfate (MS)</li>
<li>Anticholinergics: atropine sulfate</li>
<li>Neuromuscular blocking agents: succinylcholine chloride (Anectine), pancuronium bromide (Pavulon)</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Antiemetics: promethazine (Phenergan), droperidol (Inapsine)</li>
<li>Antianxiety agents: diazepam (Valium)</li>
<li>Barbiturates: pentobarbital (Nembutal), secobarbital (Seconal)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-anesthetics">II. Anesthetics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-anesthetics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Anesthesia: the loss of sensation as a result of reversible central nervous system depression
B. Two basic categories</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>General anesthesia: loss of consciousness and loss of sensation
a. Inhalation route
(1) Gases
(2) Volatile liquids
b. Intravenous route</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Local anesthesia: loss of sensation, particularly the inability to detect pain in a selected area</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Balanced anesthesia: the selection of a combination of drugs to produce the desired effect for the type of surgery scheduled. This is required when there is no ideal anesthetic agent.
D. The role of the nurse is not to administer the agents but to know the nursing implications based on the effects of the agent used</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-anesthesia">GENERAL ANESTHESIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-anesthesia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-three-phases-of-anesthesia">I. Three phases of anesthesia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-three-phases-of-anesthesia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Induction: a large amount of anesthetic agent is administered
B. Maintenance: the desired level is maintained
C. Recovery: the anesthetic agent is no longer administered, and it may be reversed</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-anesthesia-requires-that-critical-concentration-levels-occur-in-the-brain-and-that-the-degree-of-effects-is-dose-dependent">II. Anesthesia requires that critical concentration levels occur in the brain and that the degree of effects is dose-dependent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-anesthesia-requires-that-critical-concentration-levels-occur-in-the-brain-and-that-the-degree-of-effects-is-dose-dependent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-anesthetic-agents-are-administered-until-the-client-reaches-the-stage-when-loss-of-consciousness-occurs-and-surgery-may-be-performed">III. Anesthetic agents are administered until the client reaches the stage when loss of consciousness occurs and surgery may be performed<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-anesthetic-agents-are-administered-until-the-client-reaches-the-stage-when-loss-of-consciousness-occurs-and-surgery-may-be-performed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Clients are monitored by assessing respiration, pulse, blood pressure, pupil response, reflexes, and eye movement for maintenance levels during these stages</p>
<p>ANESTHETICS: GENERAL AND INHALATION ▼ 101</p>
<p>B. Diseases such as chronic airway limitation (obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], emphysema), and congestive heart failure (CHF) can increase or decrease the absorption of these agents</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-inhalation-anesthetics">IV. Inhalation anesthetics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-inhalation-anesthetics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: depression of the central nervous system, interference with nerve impulses, and relaxation of skeletal and smooth muscles. Their exact mechanism of action is unknown.</p>
<p>B. Uses: rapid control and depth of anesthesia</p>
<p>C. Administered by open drops, semiclosed method, or closed method</p>
<p>D. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Cardiovascular depression: bradycardia, hypotension, dysrhythmias</li>
<li>Respiratory depression and complications: bradypnea, apnea, decreased oxygen saturation</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Hypothermia</li>
<li>Confusion</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor any turning, coughing, deep breathing, and client use of incentive spirometer to prevent pneumonia after surgery</li>
<li>Obtain a thorough nursing history prior to the surgery; note in particular any client allergies or previous problems with anesthesia</li>
<li>Assess the client's neurological status postoperative and cautiously administer analgesics</li>
<li>Practice and stress safety measures with the client because psychomotor function is impaired. Raise side rails; set bed in low position; assist with ambulation; and place the call light within reach.</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs; administer oxygen if indicated</li>
<li>Assess for problems with elimination; client may have urinary retention as a result of preoperative or intraoperative medication</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common anesthetic gases</p>
<ol>
<li>Nitrous oxide</li>
<li>Halothane (Fluothane)—prototype</li>
<li>Enflurane (Enthrane)</li>
<li>Methoxyflurane (Penthrane)</li>
<li>Isoflurane (Forane)</li>
</ol>
<p>102 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-intravenous-iv-anesthetics">V. Intravenous (IV) anesthetics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-intravenous-iv-anesthetics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-action-based-on-the-individual-agent-group-used">A. Action: based on the individual agent group used<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-based-on-the-individual-agent-group-used" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Before administration of inhalation agents</li>
<li>Diagnostic procedures</li>
<li>Outpatient surgeries</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>“Hangover” effect</li>
<li>Apnea, laryngospasm, bronchospasm, coughing</li>
<li>Depression of the cardiovascular system (however, less with IV anesthetics than with inhalation agents)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Have emergency equipment ready, IV fluids handy</li>
<li>Know each individual drug, since the classification varies</li>
<li>Practice and stress safety measures</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs especially for respiratory depression</li>
<li>Monitor elimination status; first 24 hours, focus on urinary; afterwards, monitor bowel movements</li>
<li>Cautiously administer analgesics for pain in the recovery period while client is in the postanesthetic care unit</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-common-drugs-within-each-classification">E. Common drugs within each classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs-within-each-classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Neuroleptics: droperidol (Inapsine), fentanyl and droperidol (Innovar)</li>
<li>Opoid narcotics: fentanyl citrate (Sublimaze)</li>
<li>Barbiturates: thiopental sodium (Pentothal)</li>
<li>Benzodiazepines and related drugs: diazepam (Valium), midazolam hydrochloride (Versed)—used more in outpatient surgery units</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="local-anesthesia">LOCAL ANESTHESIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#local-anesthesia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-general-information">I. General information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-general-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-these-drugs-are-given-to-affect-either-a-small-area-of-the-body-such-as-a-digit-or-a-larger-area-such-as-an-entire-extremity-they-may-be-applied-topically">A. These drugs are given to affect either a small area of the body such as a digit, or a larger area such as an entire extremity; they may be applied topically<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-these-drugs-are-given-to-affect-either-a-small-area-of-the-body-such-as-a-digit-or-a-larger-area-such-as-an-entire-extremity-they-may-be-applied-topically" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-methods-of-administration">B. Methods of administration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-methods-of-administration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Topical: application of a topical anesthetic in the form of a solution, gel, or ointment to the skin, mucous membrane, or cornea</li>
<li>Infiltration: the process whereby a local anesthetic is administered through the tissue; field block: producing</li>
</ol>
<p>ANESTHETICS: IV AND LOCAL ▼ 103</p>
<p>anesthesia around the entire lesion or incision—used in emergency rooms to repair lacerations</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Regional: anesthesia of an area of the body by injection of a local anesthetic to block a group of sensory nerve fibers
a. Spinal: injection of an analgesic or anesthetic drug into the subarachnoid space of the spinal column to achieve insensitivity to pain in the lower part of the body
b. Epidural: injection into the epidural space of the spinal cord
C. May be combined with epinephrine hydrochloride (Adrenalin) to slow drug absorption, prolong the effect of the anesthetic, and reduce bleeding at site. Caution should be taken in patients with cardiovascular compromise.</li>
</ol>
<p>II. Action: these agents block nerve impulses and decrease the ability of the cell to depolarize, which is necessary for impulse transmission</p>
<p>III. Uses
A. Minor surgery
B. Diagnostic procedures
C. Minor treatments
D. Toothaches</p>
<p>IV. Side effects
A. Toxicity
B. Interference with the organ involved
C. Reversal of the block
D. Cardiovascular effects: bradycardia, hypotension, respiratory failure
E. Frostbite with the topicals
F. Skin irritation</p>
<p>V. Nursing implications
A. Monitor vital signs
B. Use safety measures
C. Properly position the extremity (regional) or body (spinal)
D. Monitor the area anesthetized for return of motor function and sensation
E. Protect the anesthetized area from trauma, since motor function returns before sensory function
F. Caution client to avoid eating if the throat is involved</p>
<p>CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-common-drugs">VI. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-esters">A. Esters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-esters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Procaine (Novocain)</li>
<li>Tetracaine (Pontocaine)</li>
<li>Cocaine hydrochloride (Procaine)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-amides">B. Amides<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-amides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Lidocaine (Xylocaine)</li>
<li>Prilocaine (Citanest)</li>
<li>Mepivacaine (Polocaine)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="central-nervous-system-stimulants">CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM STIMULANTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#central-nervous-system-stimulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-general-information">I. General information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-general-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-central-nervous-system-cns-stimulant-a-substance-that-quickens-the-activity-of-the-cns-by-increasing-the-rate-of-neuronal-discharge-or-by-blocking-an-inhibitory-neurotransmitter">A. Central nervous system (CNS) stimulant: a substance that quickens the activity of the CNS by increasing the rate of neuronal discharge or by blocking an inhibitory neurotransmitter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-central-nervous-system-cns-stimulant-a-substance-that-quickens-the-activity-of-the-cns-by-increasing-the-rate-of-neuronal-discharge-or-by-blocking-an-inhibitory-neurotransmitter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-many-drugs-can-stimulate-although-few-do-so-therapeutically-therapeutic-cns-stimulation-involves">B. Many drugs can stimulate, although few do so therapeutically. Therapeutic CNS stimulation involves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-many-drugs-can-stimulate-although-few-do-so-therapeutically-therapeutic-cns-stimulation-involves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Restoring mental alertness or consciousness</li>
<li>Stimulating the respiratory center, or overcoming respiratory depression</li>
<li>Treating hyperkinetic children by acting as a depressant in a child</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="c-classification-of-agents-that-stimulate-therapeutically">C. Classification of agents that stimulate therapeutically<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-classification-of-agents-that-stimulate-therapeutically" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Amphetamines</li>
<li>Anorexiant agents</li>
<li>Analeptics</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="d-most-of-these-agents-are-controlled-and-highly-abused-substances">D. Most of these agents are controlled (and highly abused) substances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-most-of-these-agents-are-controlled-and-highly-abused-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-amphetamines-and-amphetamine-like-drugs">II. Amphetamines and amphetamine-like drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-amphetamines-and-amphetamine-like-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-action-stimulate-the-release-of-norepinephrine-which-causes-increased-alertness-less-fatigue-and-elevated-mood">A. Action: stimulate the release of norepinephrine, which causes increased alertness, less fatigue, and elevated mood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-stimulate-the-release-of-norepinephrine-which-causes-increased-alertness-less-fatigue-and-elevated-mood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Narcolepsy: syndrome characterized by sudden sleep attacks. Stimulation of the CNS can alleviate these attacks and produce alertness.</li>
<li>Endogenous obesity: obesity resulting from dysfunction of the endocrine or metabolic systems. Amphetamines suppress the appetite.</li>
<li>Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD): childhood condition involving inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity.</li>
</ol>
<p>CNS STIMULANTS ▼ 105</p>
<p>Amphetamines increase attention span while decreasing the hyperactivity.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Mental depression: amphetamines elevate mood, increase motor activity, and promote self-confidence</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Withdrawal syndromes: physical reactions after cessation or severe reduction in intake of a substance that has been used regularly to induce euphoria, intoxication, or relief from pain or distress. Amphetamines can enhance the effects of some narcotics and reduce the symptoms of withdrawing from abusive agents by their ability to increase alertness, decrease fatigue, and elevate mood.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Tolerance, dependence, abuse</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachyphylaxis: repeated administration of some drugs results in a marked decrease in effectiveness</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nervousness, irritability, increased motor activity</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Headaches, dizziness, insomnia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cardiovascular reactions: hypertension, palpitations, dysrhythmias</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Weight loss and fatigue from prolonged use</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions may occur with antidepressants, which increase the effect of the amphetamine, and with urine alkalinizers, which increase the half-life</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A weight-reduction diet and exercise program should accompany the use of these agents for obesity. Short-term use is recommended.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The client and parent should be taught about the use of drug for attention deficit disorder. Teaching concepts include</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Check with a pharmacist about all over-the-counter medications</p>
<p>b. Do not abruptly stop taking the drug</p>
<p>c. Do not try to make up doses if one is skipped</p>
<p>d. If diabetic, check whether insulin or oral hypoglycemic requirements may be reduced</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Avoid other stimulants while on these drugs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Avoid taking the last dose after 4 to 6 P.M. to prevent insomnia</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Methylphenidate (Ritalin)—for ADHD most commonly</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Amphetamine complex (Biphetamine)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Amphetamine sulfate</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dextroamphetamine sulfate (Dexedrine)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>106 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-anorexiant-agents">III. Anorexiant agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-anorexiant-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Classification: sympathomimetic agents
B. Action: suppress appetite by acting on the hypothalamus
C. Use: weight reduction when accompanied by medical complications
D. Side effects and nursing implications: similar to those of amphetamines. Tolerance and abuse are possible.
E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Benzphetamine (Didrex)</li>
<li>Diethylpropion (Tenuate)</li>
<li>Phenmetrazine (Preludin)</li>
<li>Phentermine HCl (Adipex-P)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iv-analeptics-and-methylxanthines">IV. Analeptics and methylxanthines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-analeptics-and-methylxanthines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: stimulate the CNS by acting on the cerebral cortex and medulla
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>In over-the-counter (OTC) drugs such as caffeine (Vivarin, NoDoz) to produce wakefulness and increase alertness. Also used in OTC cold medications and analgesics such as acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) with caffeine (Anacin), acetaminophen and caffeine (Excedrin), Triaminicin.</li>
<li>Overdose of CNS depressants</li>
<li>Migraine headaches</li>
<li>Respiratory stimulation
C. Major side effects</li>
<li>Teratogenesis: fetal abnormalities</li>
<li>Cardiovascular: dysrhythmias, heart attacks, tachycardia, hypertension, tachypnea</li>
<li>Caffeinism: restlessness, insomnia, nervousness, muscle twitching, headache</li>
<li>Seizures</li>
<li>Tolerance and abuse
D. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Monitor the dietary intake of caffeine</li>
<li>Assess respiratory and cardiovascular systems</li>
<li>Watch for withdrawal symptoms that can occur if drugs are abruptly discontinued; manifested as nausea, vomiting, headaches</li>
<li>Avoid other foods and drinks that contain stimulants
E. Common drugs</li>
<li>Methylxanthines
a. Caffeine</li>
</ol>
<p>CNS STIMULANTS, PSYCHOTROPICS ▼ 107</p>
<p>b. Theophylline (various trade names)
c. Theobromide</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Analeptic: doxapram hydrochloride (Dopram)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="psychotropics">PSYCHOTROPICS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#psychotropics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-classifications">I. Classifications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-classifications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Antipsychotic agents (Neuroleptics)
B. Antianxiety or anxiolytic agents
C. Antidepressants and mood stabilizers</p>
<ol>
<li>Tricyclic compounds</li>
<li>Monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors</li>
<li>Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors</li>
<li>Lithium</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-antipsychotic-agents">II. Antipsychotic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-antipsychotic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: block the dopamine receptors in the brain, which inhibits the dopamine response. This action results in improved symptoms in the client with a psychiatric disorder. They also work as antiemetics by inhibiting the chemoreceptor trigger zones in the medulla.
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Psychiatric disorders
a. Schizophrenia: a psychiatric disorder characterized by gross distortion of reality, withdrawal, and disorganization of thought
b. Bipolar disorder: manic-depressive illness
c. Delusional disorders
d. Organic syndromes</li>
<li>Antiemetic: prevention of emesis
C. Major side effects</li>
<li>Serious movement disorders, extrapyramidal effects
a. Tardive dyskinesia: involuntary repetitious movements of the muscles of the face, limbs, and trunk
b. Dystonia: impairment of muscle tone
c. Parkinsonism (see Chapter 6 pp. 84-85)
d. Akathisia: restlessness, agitation, inability to sit still
e. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: a complication of psychotherapy, with neuroleptic drugs given in therapeutic doses
f. Tremors</li>
<li>Addiction and tolerance</li>
</ol>
<p>108 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Sedation</li>
<li>Hypotension and tachycardia</li>
<li>Anticholinergic effects: dry mouth, dilation of pupils, tachycardia, decrease in GI and GU motility</li>
<li>Photosensitivity</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions include additive effect with other CNS depressants, especially alcohol, and delayed or blocked absorption with antacids</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Psychological and physical assessments are necessary as a baseline, and while client is taking the medicine</li>
<li>Monitor any controlled substances</li>
<li>Use safety measures due to the sedation</li>
<li>Carefully document the effects of the drug</li>
<li>Teach the client about compliance and need for skin protection in the sun</li>
<li>Evaluate for effectiveness in treating nausea and vomiting</li>
<li>Teach the client about the side effects, especially how to monitor for extrapyramidal effects and anticholinergic effects</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Phenothiazines
a. Chlorpromazine (Thorazine)
b. Thioridazine hydrochloride (Mellaril)
c. Prochlorperazine (Compazine)</li>
<li>Thioxanthines
a. Chlorprothixene (Taractan)
b. Thiothixene hydrochloride (Navane)</li>
<li>Butyrophenones: haloperidol (Haldol)</li>
<li>Dihydroindolones: molindone hydrochloride (Moban)</li>
<li>Dibenzodiazepines: clozapine (Clozaril)</li>
</ol>
<p>III. Antianxiety or anxiolytic
A. Action: depression of the central nervous system, thereby increasing the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which produces relaxation and may depress the limbic system
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Anxiety states</li>
<li>Depression</li>
<li>Insomnia</li>
<li>Preanesthesia</li>
<li>Withdrawal syndromes</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIANXIETY AGENTS, TRICYCLIC ANTIDEPRESSANTS ▼ 109</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Abuse, dependence, tolerance</li>
<li>Sedation, which causes decreased motor skills</li>
<li>Hypotension</li>
<li>Respiratory depression</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-interactions-will-occur-with-other-cns-depressants-especially-alcohol">D. Interactions: will occur with other CNS depressants, especially alcohol<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-interactions-will-occur-with-other-cns-depressants-especially-alcohol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>These agents do not cure, only treat the symptoms.
Counseling and therapy should accompany treatment.</li>
<li>The amount of the medication taken should be monitored</li>
<li>In higher doses, drugs may be used as sedatives or hypnotics</li>
<li>Most are not recommended in pregnancy (unless absolutely necessary) because of the risk to the fetus</li>
<li>Should be used cautiously with older-adult and debilitated clients, as well as those with pulmonary disorders</li>
<li>Clients should be taught how to avoid effects of orthostatic hypotension</li>
<li>Safety measures should be ensured due to the sedative properties</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-groups-many-groups-of-drugs-have-the-potential-to-lower-anxiety">F. Common groups: many groups of drugs have the potential to lower anxiety<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-groups-many-groups-of-drugs-have-the-potential-to-lower-anxiety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Benzodiazepines
a. Diazepam (Valium)
b. Alprazolam (Xanax)
c. Clorazepate dipotassium (Tranxene)
d. Oxazepam (Serax)</li>
<li>Antihistamines: diphenhydramine hydrochloride (Benadryl)</li>
<li>Other agents
a. Hydroxyzine hydrochloride (Atarax)
b. Hydroxyzine hydrochloride (Vistaril)
c. Buspirone hydrochloride (BuSpar)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-tricyclic-antidepressants">IV. Tricyclic antidepressants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-tricyclic-antidepressants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-action-increase-neurotransmitter-concentration-levels-of-norepinephrine-and-serotonin">A. Action: increase neurotransmitter concentration levels of norepinephrine and serotonin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-increase-neurotransmitter-concentration-levels-of-norepinephrine-and-serotonin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Treat depression</li>
<li>Treat chronic headaches</li>
<li>Treat enuresis</li>
<li>Normalize sleep</li>
<li>Increase appetite</li>
<li>Elevate mood</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Sedation</li>
<li>Orthostatic hypotension</li>
<li>Anticholinergic effects: dry mouth, dilated pupils (results in blurred vision), tachycardia, decreased GI motility</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-interactions-may-occur-with-other-cns-depressants-alcohol-and-many-medications">D. Interactions may occur with other CNS depressants, alcohol, and many medications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-interactions-may-occur-with-other-cns-depressants-alcohol-and-many-medications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>These agents do not cure, only treat symptoms. Other forms of nondrug therapy should be instituted.</li>
<li>Instruct client that the drug will take 1 to 3 weeks before benefits may occur</li>
<li>These drugs can mask suicidal tendencies</li>
<li>Teach client the need for compliance</li>
<li>A single dose at bedtime may be beneficial if sedation is problematic</li>
<li>Institute safety measures</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Amitriptyline hydrochloride (Elavil)</li>
<li>Doxepin hydrochloride (Sinequan)</li>
<li>Imipramine hydrochloride (Tofranil)</li>
<li>Perphenazine and amitriptyline (Triavil)</li>
<li>Chlordiazepoxide and amitriptyline (Limbitrol)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-monoamine-oxidase-mao-inhibitors">V. Monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-monoamine-oxidase-mao-inhibitors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-action-inhibit-monoamine-oxidase-enzyme-present-in-the-brain-blood-platelets-liver-spleen-and-kidneys-which-metabolizes-amines-norepinephrine-and-serotonin-thus-the-concentration-of-these-amines-increases">A. Action: inhibit monoamine oxidase enzyme (present in the brain, blood platelets, liver, spleen, and kidneys), which metabolizes amines, norepinephrine, and serotonin. Thus, the concentration of these amines increases.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-inhibit-monoamine-oxidase-enzyme-present-in-the-brain-blood-platelets-liver-spleen-and-kidneys-which-metabolizes-amines-norepinephrine-and-serotonin-thus-the-concentration-of-these-amines-increases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>As a second-choice antidepressant if tricyclic compounds do not work</li>
<li>When depression is not responsive to tricyclic compounds</li>
<li>When the side effects of tricyclic compounds are intolerable</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Hypertensive crisis, especially if food with tyramine is eaten</li>
<li>Insomnia</li>
<li>CNS stimulation: anxiety, agitation, mania</li>
<li>Orthostatic hypotension</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-interactions-are-numerous-with-otc-drugs-as-well-as-prescription-drugs-all-medications-should-be-approved-by-the-physician-while-the-client-is-on-mao-inhibitors">D. Interactions are numerous with OTC drugs as well as prescription drugs. All medications should be approved by the physician while the client is on MAO inhibitors.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-interactions-are-numerous-with-otc-drugs-as-well-as-prescription-drugs-all-medications-should-be-approved-by-the-physician-while-the-client-is-on-mao-inhibitors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>MAO INHIBITORS, SELECTIVE SEROTONIN REUPTAKE INHIBITORS ▼ 111</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Avoid foods with tyramine, which may cause hypertensive crisis (Box 7-1)</li>
<li>Limit foods and beverages high in caffeine</li>
<li>Teach about compliance and possible side effects</li>
<li>Inform the client that it may take weeks before benefits are experienced</li>
<li>Instruct that if insomnia occurs, the drug should be taken early in the morning</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Phenelzine sulfate (Nardil)</li>
<li>Tranylcypromine sulfate (Parnate)</li>
<li>Isocarboxazid (Marplan)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-selective-serotonin-reuptake-inhibitors-ssri">VI. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-selective-serotonin-reuptake-inhibitors-ssri" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-action-antidepressant-response-is-from-the-inhibition-of-serotonin-uptake">A. Action: antidepressant response is from the inhibition of serotonin uptake<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-antidepressant-response-is-from-the-inhibition-of-serotonin-uptake" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-7-1-dietary-consideration-mao-inhibitors-and-tyramine">Box 7-1. Dietary Consideration: Mao Inhibitors and Tyramine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-7-1-dietary-consideration-mao-inhibitors-and-tyramine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients taking MAO inhibitors may experience a hypertensive crisis if they ingest foods containing a large amount of tyramine. Foods high in tyramine include the following:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>avocadoes</th><th>paté</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>bananas</td><td>pickled and kippered herring</td></tr><tr><td>beer</td><td>pepperoni</td></tr><tr><td>bologna</td><td>pods or broad beans (fava beans)</td></tr><tr><td>canned figs</td><td>raisins</td></tr><tr><td>chocolate</td><td>raw yeast or yeast extracts</td></tr><tr><td>cheese (except cottage cheese)</td><td>salami</td></tr><tr><td>cheese-containing food (e.g., pizza or macaroni and cheese)</td><td>sausage</td></tr><tr><td>liver</td><td>sour cream</td></tr><tr><td>meat extracts (e.g., marmite and bovril)</td><td>soy sauce</td></tr><tr><td>offal</td><td>wine and chianti</td></tr><tr><td>papaya products, including meat tenderizers</td><td>yogurt</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Clark J, Queener S, &amp; Karb V: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.</p>
<p>112 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Depression</li>
<li>Investigational use in obsessive-compulsive disorders and appetite disorders</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Nausea, diarrhea</li>
<li>CNS stimulation: insomnia, headache, nervousness, dizziness</li>
<li>Skin rash</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Administer with meals to reduce the nausea</li>
<li>Teach the client to report the side effects. A rash, especially with fever, should be reported immediately. These together could signal serious complications.</li>
<li>Use cautiously in older adults or those with impaired renal function</li>
<li>Monitor weight, since the agent can cause weight loss</li>
<li>Monitor the suicidal client especially during improved mood and increased energy levels</li>
<li>Teach the client to take a single morning dose to avoid insomnia</li>
<li>Stress safety precautions if dizziness develops</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Fluoxetine hydrochloric (Prozac)</li>
<li>Sertraline hydrochloride (Zoloft)</li>
<li>Paroxetine (Paxil)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>VII. Mood stabilizers</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Action:</strong> normalize the catecholamine response in clients with bipolar, manic-depressive, disorders
<strong>B. Use:</strong> manic-depression illness
<strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Minor toxicity: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fine hand tremors, GI upset, convulsions</li>
<li>Major toxicity: coarse tremors, severe thirst, tinnitus, diluted urine</li>
<li>Renal toxicity</li>
<li>Teratogenesis: physical defects in the embryo</li>
<li>Goiter: pronounced swelling in the neck, usually related to a hypertrophic thyroid gland</li>
<li>Metallic taste in mouth</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Interactions:</strong> include diuretics, sodium chloride, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory (NSAID) drugs</p>
<p>PROZAC, MOOD STABILIZERS: LITHIUM ▼ 113</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Teach the client the side effects and the need for close blood monitoring of lithium levels to prevent side effects and toxicity</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>serum level &gt;2 mEq/L; initially check serum levels weekly, then every two months. Many of the side effects can occur at doses within the therapeutic range, which is 0.6 to 1.2 mEq/L.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Since the half-life is short, administer these agents in divided doses; doses should not be skipped</li>
<li>Instruct the client that benefits may not be seen for 1 to 2 weeks</li>
<li>Assess renal status and serum creatinine, and avoid drugs that alter urinary elimination in any way</li>
<li>Avoid in pregnant or lactating women</li>
<li>Prevent dehydration, which may precipitate toxicity</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drug-lithium-carbonate-lithane">F. Common drug: lithium carbonate (Lithane)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drug-lithium-carbonate-lithane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="skeletal-muscle-relaxants">SKELETAL MUSCLE RELAXANTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skeletal-muscle-relaxants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-classifications">I. Classifications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-classifications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Centrally acting
B. Peripherally acting</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-general-information">II. General information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-general-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Limited in usefulness because of the side effects
B. Relief may be obtained primarily because of the sedative properties
C. These agents do not cause loss of consciousness
D. Objective is to relieve musculoskeletal pain or spasm and severe musculoskeletal spasticity without causing loss of function</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-centrally-acting">III. Centrally acting<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-centrally-acting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: depression of the central nervous system, thereby altering the neurotransmitter function in the spinal cord and depressing selected areas of the brain that control skeletal muscle function
B. Use: relieve spasms associated with trauma, injury, inflammation, postsurgical procedures, anxiety, and pain
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Potential for dependency or addiction</li>
<li>Drowsiness, dizziness</li>
<li>Flaccid muscles</li>
<li>Bradypnea, hypotension</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<p>D. Interactions: with all other CNS depressants and alcohol</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Check allergies before administration</li>
<li>Use safety precautions after administration, including using side rails, instructing the client not to ambulate without assistance, and advising precaution about driving or working around machinery</li>
<li>Assess the amount (and effects) of medication being taken</li>
<li>Instruct the client in the use of heat, rest, and physical therapy as indicated to minimize/treat muscle spasms</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Cyclobenzaprine hydrochloride (Flexeril)</li>
<li>Chlorzoxazone (Parafon Forte)</li>
<li>Diazepam (Valium)</li>
<li>Carisoprodol (Soma)</li>
</ol>
<p>IV. Peripherally or direct-acting agents</p>
<p>A. Action: work directly on the skeletal muscle, decreasing the availability of calcium in the muscle, that thereby decreasing the contractility of the muscles</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Decrease spasticity in chronic conditions such as multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy, spinal cord injuries, and strokes</li>
<li>Rehabilitation</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Muscle weakness in the nonspecific muscles, manifested by slurring of speech and drooling</li>
<li>Drowsiness, dizziness, fatigue, malaise</li>
<li>Severe hepatotoxicity</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions: with other CNS drugs and alcohol to produce an additive effect</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>May be combined with diazepam (Valium) to produce an additive effect. For this reason and because of the sedative potential, safety measures should be taken and instructed to the client.</li>
<li>Liver studies should be monitored; ALT, AST</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drug</p>
<ol>
<li>Dantrolene sodium (Dantrium)</li>
</ol>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 115</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>A client, age 40, enters the emergency department with a laceration to his left shoulder. The fitting from an oxygen tank exploded and is embedded in his arm. The entry is at the elbow, and the fitting can be felt at the shoulder. The physician anticipates a long procedure and will probably desire lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine) with epinephrine because</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Epinephrine stops the bleeding
b. Epinephrine shortens the effect of the analgesia and can be repeated more often
c. Epinephrine lengthens the effect of the analgesia
d. Epinephrine is safe because the client is 40 years old</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Which of the following clients would benefit most from a preanesthetic?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Sally, age 26, who is having her third female operation
b. Joe, age 39, who has never had surgery and is scheduled for open heart surgery
c. John, age 79, who is having his shunt declotted
d. Jimmy, age 2, who is having a tonsillectomy</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Which of the following groups of drugs is more likely to be questioned as a preanesthetic?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Narcotics
b. Anticholinergic agents
c. Long-acting barbiturates
d. Short-acting barbiturates</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Which of the statements is true about amphetamines as a group?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. They have a low abuse potential
b. They cause weight gain if used on long-term basis
c. They are indicated in treatment of narcolepsy
d. They can promote a tired feeling</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>A nursing implication for a client on an MAO inhibitor would include which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Teach client the side effects, especially of a hypertensive crisis
b. Caution client to stop eating foods high in sodium
c. Administer the drug throughout the day if it causes sedation
d. Advise client to call for an appointment if no effect is noticed within a week</p>
<p>116 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>
<p>Which of the following is true about lithium (Lithane)?
a. The lithium (Lithane) concentration level must be monitored
b. It is the drug of choice for depression
c. Toxicity rarely occurs
d. Clients need to call for an appointment if no effect is noticed within a week</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client, age 45, takes an antipsychotic agent. She asks the nurse if she can drink a glass of wine with dinner each night. The nurse should tell her that she
a. Can drink one or two glasses of wine daily
b. Should consult her physician before consuming any alcohol
c. Can drink in moderation because the wine will not interact with her medication
d. Should drink wine because it will increase the drug’s effectiveness</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Amphetamines are potent stimulants that act by
a. Decreasing the release of norepinephrine
b. Increasing the release of norepinephrine
c. Depressing the higher centers of the brain
d. Stimulating the CNS by acting directly on the cerebral cortex</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Why might the anesthetist add an injection anesthetic with an inhalation anesthetic?
a. Injection anesthetics prevent adverse reactions to inhaled anesthetics
b. Injection anesthetics will promote more rapid induction of anesthesia
c. Injection agents are used because of their long duration of action
d. Injection anesthetics offer more precise and control of the depth of anesthesia than inhalation anesthetics do</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which statement is true concerning inhalation and IV anesthetics?
a. Diseases such as emphysema/CHF may increase or decrease the absorption of gases
b. Nitrous oxide is always used alone and is long-acting
c. Barbiturates are seldom used
d. IV anesthetics would be ineffective in outpatient surgeries</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client, age 61, weighs 205 pounds and has a history of respiratory difficulties. The physician tells her to lose at least 50 pounds during the next year to prevent further problems. She tells the nurse that she wants her physician to prescribe an amphetamine to help her lose weight. What should the nurse tell her?</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 117</p>
<p>a. An amphetamine can be used along with a weight-reduction plan for several months
b. She can take the amphetamine as long as she wants
c. Amphetamines are beneficial for a few weeks only, and the client must be on a weight-reduction diet
d. Amphetamines are relatively safe drugs with few side effects</p>
<ol start="12">
<li>
<p>A client is prescribed an MAO inhibitor. Which of the following foods should the nurse advise the client to avoid completely?
a. Beer, aged cheese, sausage
b. Chocolate, soy sauce, oranges
c. White wine, chicken, apples
d. Cottage cheese, yogurt, ham</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Side effects of the tricyclic antidepressants are related to the anticholinergic actions of the drug. A common side effect is
a. Increased salivation
b. Constipation
c. Bradycardia
d. Hypertension</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client, age 32, is suffering from severe anxiety because her young daughter was seriously injured in an automobile accident. Her physician prescribes diazepam (Valium) as an antianxiety agent. Why would the physician be more likely to order a benzodiazepine than a barbiturate?
a. Benzodiazepines are faster acting than barbiturates
b. Benzodiazepines cause mild central nervous system effects
c. Benzodiazepines are not controlled substances
d. Benzodiazepines do not accumulate in the body</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following clients would benefit the most from a local (spinal) anesthetic instead of a general anesthetic?
a. Bobby, age 40, who is anxious about the outcome of his surgery
b. Annie, age 89, who has COPD, hypertension (HTN), and a fractured pelvis
c. Brian, age 4, who is scheduled for a tonsillectomy
d. Joseph, age 56, who is having an open reduction of his arm</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client enters the emergency department complaining of having injured his right ankle during a game of flag football. He is diagnosed as having a sprain and sent home on cyclobenzaprine hydrochloride (Flexeril). He</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>118 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<p>questions his ability to return to work at a chemical plant. The nurse would instruct him to</p>
<p>a. Return to work the next day and use his lunch break to elevate his foot
b. Abstain from work for a week
c. Assess his ability to drive while on the cyclobenzaprine hydrochloride (Flexeril) and report the use of the drug to his immediate supervisor
d. Return to work and speak to his immediate supervisor if questioned about his treatment</p>
<ol start="17">
<li>A 32-year-old cerebral palsy client is taking a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant–dantrolene sodium (Dantrium). Dantrolene (Dantrium) achieves an effect by</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Increasing the release of calcium from muscle cells
b. Decreasing the release of calcium from muscle cells
c. Depressing the CNS
d. Depressing the cerebral cortex</p>
<ol start="18">
<li>Centrally acting skeletal muscle relaxants are commonly used to treat</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Muscle spasm caused by cerebral palsy
b. Chronic musculoskeletal disorders
c. Lower extremity spasticity
d. Severe muscle spasms</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 119</p>

<p>120 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<p>pain and relax the client before surgery. Anticholinergic agents are given to prevent the complication of bradycardia and atelectasis or aspiration. Barbiturates relieve anxiety, sedate, and decrease the complications of anesthetic agents.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Correct answer: c</li>
</ol>
<p>Amphetamines stimulate the CNS and produce wakefulness. Narcolepsy is the clinical condition where the client has sudden sleep attacks. Amphetamines have a high potential for abuse, and tolerance develops quickly. Weight loss usually occurs if they are taken on a long-term basis. Amphetamines increase the energy level unless abused. If abused then stopped, clients feel tired.</p>
<p>If you narrowed the responses to either c or d, reread the question and the two options. The question is a “general question” so select the disease over the specific finding of tired feeling.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Correct answer: a</li>
</ol>
<p>Hypertension is a typical side effect and can be severe. Foods high in tyramine, which can cause hypertensive crisis, should be avoided. Insomnia is the typical side effect. Usually a response is not evident for 1 to 3 weeks.</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct answer, go with what you know in general about teaching clients with drugs: teach the side effects. Select response a.</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>Correct answer: a</li>
</ol>
<p>Toxicity is a common side effect, and a lithium level must be maintained at a</p>
<p>Levels of drug concentration are measured in the drugs: lithium, theophylline, digoxin, and</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 121</p>
