<p>serum therapeutic level of 0.6 to 1.2 mEq/L. Lithium is recommended for use in manic-depressive illness. Toxicity frequently occurs with this drug. Minor toxicity findings are vomiting, diarrhea, poor coordination, fine motor tremors, weakness, and lassitude. Major toxicity findings are coarse tremors, severe thirst, tinnitus, and diluted urine. Adequate fluids are essential during initial therapy of 2 to 3 liters/day and 1 to 2 liters/day during maintenance. Decreased sodium intake with decreased fluid intake may lead to lithium retention and toxicity and visa versa. An effect is usually not seen until the medicine has been taken for 1 to 3 weeks.</p>
<p>antibiotics. Peaks and troughs are done for antibiotics. Recall tip—lithium requires levels.</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Correct answer: b</li>
</ol>
<p>Alcohol and other CNS depressants cause an additive effect. Alcohol should never be mixed with an antipsychotic agent. Alcohol in moderation should definitely not be mixed with the drug. Wine will increase the drug's effectiveness but is not recommended for this reason.</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct answer, cluster the responses into the three that suggest drinking alcohol. Response b is correct, since it falls outside of the cluster.</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Correct answer: b</li>
</ol>
<p>This action of amphetamines in response b increases</p>
<p>Eliminate responses a and c, since these contradict the key word in</p>
<p>122 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<p>alertness and elevates mood. Response <em>a</em> is an incorrect action for amphetamines. Amphetamines are CNS stimulants, not depressants. CNS stimulation is a result of the increase in norepinephrine.</p>
<p>the stem, “stimulates.” Then make an educated guess if these drugs are potent, they would act more generally than just locally on the cerebral cortex. Select option <em>b</em>.</p>
<ol start="9">
<li><strong>Correct answer: b</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>Most of the injection agents inhibit the area of the brain that controls alertness and produce an additive effect with inhalation anesthetics. Some of the injection agents may decrease the severity of the side effects, but they cannot prevent adverse reactions. Most of the injection agents have a short duration, which is an advantage for outpatient surgery. Inhalation offers the most control and precision in producing anesthesia.</p>
<p>Make an educated guess. The injection of a drug into the vein will have rapid results and be an aid to a drug that has been inhaled and has to cross the aveoli to get into the circulation. Select response <em>b</em>, not <em>d</em>, since IV anesthesia would not aid in the control of the depth of anesthesia; this is because once the drug is injected, there is loss of control of the severity of the effects.</p>
<ol start="10">
<li><strong>Correct answer: a</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>The lungs absorb and excrete anesthetic agents; therefore any change in the lung will affect the pharmacokinetics of the agent administered. This agent in option <em>b</em> is not potent enough on its own to produce analgesia, and it is short acting. Short-acting barbiturates are used to lessen the amount of inhalation anesthetics required. Injection</p>
<p>Eliminate responses <em>b</em> and <em>c</em>, since they have the absolutes “always” and “seldom.” Use common sense to eliminate response <em>d</em>. Select response <em>a</em>, which supports your general knowledge of these disease processes.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 123</p>
<p>anesthetics are ideal for outpatient surgeries because of their short duration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="11-correct-answer-c">11. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Amphetamines should only be used to help the client adjust to a new diet and lifestyle. Using amphetamines for weight control is secondary to using diet and lifestyle modification. Short-term treatment of 2 to 3 weeks may be recommended. Long-term treatment is contraindicated because of the side effects. Amphetamines have many side effects, including toxic effects with overdosage, of which findings are excitement, tremors, tachycardia, hallucinations, delirium, convulsions, and circulatory collapse.</p>
<p>If you narrowed the responses to either <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>, reread them. Note that in response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> the statement "can" be used with a weight reduction plan; in response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> the statement "must" be on a weight reduction plan. The stronger term leads to the selection of the correct response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="12-correct-answer-a">12. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These agents are all high in tyramine, which could cause hypertension. Oranges are not contraindicated. Chicken and apples are not contraindicated. Most cheeses, especially aged, are prohibited, but cottage cheese is allowed.</p>
<p>The two foods to remember NOT to eat with MAO inhibitors are beer and aged cheese. If this is all that you can remember, go with what you know and select response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="13-correct-answer-b">13. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The anticholinergic effect slows the GI motility and results in constipation and</p>
<p>Think of the prototype anticholinergic, atropine, which slows the GI and GU peristatsis.</p>
<p>124 ▼ CHAPTER 7 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSYEM</p>
<p>urine retention from the relaxation of the urinary muscles. Response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> is not a side effect of these agents; a decrease in salivation is more likely. Tachycardia, not bradycardia, is a possibility because of the anticholinergic effect. Orthostatic hypotension is a more common side effect; never hypertension.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-correct-answer-b">14. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this situation only mild sedation is needed. Barbiturates can act more as hypnotics. Barbiturates can be short-acting and work as quickly as benzodiazepines. Both of these agents are controlled substances. Tolerance can develop with both agents.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="15-correct-answer-b">15. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#15-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Annie’s serious disease processes can cause severe complications after a general anesthesia. Bobby’s anxiety will be controlled better with a general anesthesia. Brian’s separation anxiety, age, and type of surgery warrant a general anesthesia. A spinal will not anesthetize the arm; spinals are typically used for body surgery below the waist.</p>
<p>The only answer that suggests a result of such action is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Use a true-false approach to select response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>; if you are not sure that one drug is faster than the other, do not select that response. Besides, the stem gives no data to support that a rapid-acting drug is indicated. By general knowledge of drugs, identify that responses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> are false.</p>
<p>Use an educated guess that the youngest and oldest clients listed are at the greatest risk for surgery. Then reread these choices and by common sense conclude that the older client has multisystem threats that the younger client does not; select response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 125</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="16-correct-answer-c">16. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#16-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Safety precautions should be assessed due to the sedating and relaxing properties of the medication. The sedative properties of the drug warrant notifying his supervisor before returning. The client may tolerate the medication without sedation and may be able to work while taking the drug. An injury is highly possible because of the relaxing and sedating properties of this agent.</p>
<p>Response <em>c</em> is the most realistic and reasonable. Response <em>d</em> is incorrect in approach, since he is only to tell if asked. Use the nursing process—select to assess then intervene.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="17-correct-answer-b">17. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#17-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These agents decrease the release of calcium, thereby decreasing the muscle’s ability to contract. This action in response <em>a</em> is not the action of these agents. This action in response <em>c</em> describes the centrally acting skeletal muscle relaxants. These agents do not depress the CNS but work directly on the muscle.</p>
<p>Key words in the stem guide you to the correct response: “direct acting . . . muscle relaxant.” Note that only responses <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> suggest direct muscle action. Then, recall your basic knowledge that with less calcium in the muscle there is less contraction. For relaxing the muscle, it follows that response <em>b</em> is correct.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="18-correct-answer-d">18. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#18-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Muscle spasms respond very well to centrally acting agents. These agents are usually not used for chronic diseases such as cerebral palsy. Spasticity experienced by paraplegics responds therapeutically to direct-acting agents.</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct response, try to cluster responses <em>a</em>, <em>b</em>, and <em>c</em> under “findings of chronic conditions.” Response <em>d</em> is selected; “severe” muscle spasms suggest a more acute situation.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>Drugs Affecting Sleep
CHAPTER 8</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the difference between a sedative and a hypnotic.</li>
<li>Identify the difference between barbiturate and nonbarbiturate agents used as sedatives and hypnotics.</li>
<li>Describe the safety measures necessary for a client taking a sedative or hypnotic.</li>
<li>Identify the side effects and nursing implications of client use of sedatives or hypnotics.</li>
</ul>
<p>127</p>
<p>128 ▼ CHAPTER 8 DRUGS AFFECTING SLEEP</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Antabuse</strong>
A trade name for the alcohol abuse deterrent, disulfiram.</p>
<p><strong>Dependence</strong>
A total psychophysical state of one addicted to drugs or alcohol who must receive an increasing amount of the substance to prevent the onset of abstinence symptoms.</p>
<p><strong>Hypnotics</strong>
A class of drugs often used as sedatives.</p>
<p><strong>Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep</strong>
REM sleep periods, lasting from a few minutes to 30 minutes alternate with nonrapid eye movement (NREM) periods. NREM sleep, with its four stages, represents three-fourths of a period of typical sleep; REM represents one-fourth of that total time. Dreaming occurs during REM time. Infants tend to begin a sleep period with REM sleep, whereas adults usually begin with the four stages of NREM sleep before entering REM sleep.</p>
<p><strong>Rebound insomnia</strong>
The inability to sleep worsens after treatment.</p>
<p><strong>Sedative</strong>
An agent that decreases functional activity, diminishes irritability, and allays excitement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2d776422">I. Sedatives and hypnotics—general considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2d776422" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-differences-between-classifications">A. Differences between classifications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-differences-between-classifications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Sedative: an agent that produces a state of calmness when given in divided doses. In high doses a sedative becomes a hypnotic.</li>
<li>Hypnotic: an agent given at bedtime (h.s.) to induce sleep, usually in a larger dose than a sedative</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-these-agents-alleviate-symptoms-but-do-not-cure-the-cause">B. These agents alleviate symptoms but do not cure the cause<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-these-agents-alleviate-symptoms-but-do-not-cure-the-cause" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-all-have-the-potential-for-producing-dependency">C. All have the potential for producing dependency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-all-have-the-potential-for-producing-dependency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-many-of-these-agents-induce-rest-by-increasing-the-amount-of-sleep-obtained-but-do-not-necessarily-produce-restful-rem-sleep-the-period-of-sleep-needed-for-physical-and-mental-restoration-some-of-these-agents-decrease-rem-sleep-while-others-do-not-affect-rem-at-all">D. Many of these agents induce rest by increasing the amount of sleep obtained, but do not necessarily produce restful REM sleep (the period of sleep needed for physical and mental restoration). Some of these agents decrease REM sleep, while others do not affect REM at all.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-many-of-these-agents-induce-rest-by-increasing-the-amount-of-sleep-obtained-but-do-not-necessarily-produce-restful-rem-sleep-the-period-of-sleep-needed-for-physical-and-mental-restoration-some-of-these-agents-decrease-rem-sleep-while-others-do-not-affect-rem-at-all" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-additional-agents-affecting-sleep-patterns">E. Additional agents affecting sleep patterns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-additional-agents-affecting-sleep-patterns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Antianxiety agents: see Chapter 7 pp. 108-109</li>
<li>Amphetamines: see Chapter 7 pp. 104-105</li>
</ol>
<p>GENERAL INFORMATION: SEDATIVES, HYPNOTICS; BARBITURATES ▼ 129</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Antihistamines</li>
<li>Alcohol</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Clients should not be awakened to receive these drugs unless absolutely necessary. Uninterrupted sleep and rest should be provided as much as possible, preferably in blocks of 4 to 6 hours.</p>
<p>G. Safety measures should be taken and taught to clients receiving these agents</p>
<ol>
<li>Elevate rails, place bed in low position, and document these actions in the nurse's notes</li>
<li>Encourage assistance in ambulating</li>
<li>Caution against driving or operating machinery</li>
<li>Monitor for suicidal tendencies</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-barbiturates">II. Barbiturates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-barbiturates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Action: produce various levels of CNS depression by decreasing the excitability of synaptic membranes in the cerebral cortex</p>
<p>B. Uses: particularly effective when sleep is interrupted early in the morning. Should be used only if nonbarbiturate does not work.</p>
<ol>
<li>Sedative (low dose) and hypnotic (high dose)</li>
<li>Preoperatively and as an anesthetic</li>
<li>Anticonvulsant agent</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Excessive central nervous system depression: drowsiness, dizziness, hangover effect, confusion</li>
<li>CNS excitement: restlessness, delirium, disorientation</li>
<li>Rebound insomnia: the inability to sleep worsens after treatment</li>
<li>Anxiety</li>
<li>Hypersensitivity</li>
<li>Respiratory depression because of the effect on the CNS</li>
<li>Toxicity: pinpoint pupils, sluggish reflexes, irregular and slower pulse, slow respirations</li>
<li>Chronic poisoning: slow thought, incoherent speech, failing memory, weight loss</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Teach safety precautions to clients (see General Considerations p. 128)</li>
<li>Assess level of consciousness (LOC), respiratory status, and effectiveness of the agent</li>
</ol>
<p>130 ▼ CHAPTER 8 DRUGS AFFECTING SLEEP</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Teach clients not to abuse medication, and to monitor their use of the medication</li>
<li>Note that chronic use is contraindicated because the agents lose their effectiveness in 2 to 3 weeks and suppress REM sleep</li>
<li>Hold if respirations &lt;10/min</li>
<li>Instruct clients not to abruptly stop taking the medication</li>
<li>Note that some are controlled substances</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Interactions: additive effect with other CNS depressants (alcohol), increased metabolism of antidepressants and warfarin sodium (Coumadin)</p>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Phenobarbital (Luminal)</li>
<li>Secobarbital (Seconal)</li>
<li>Aprobarbital (Alurate)</li>
<li>Butabarbital sodium (Butisol Sodium)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-benzodiazepines">III. Benzodiazepines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-benzodiazepines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: CNS depression by increasing the GABA neuronal inhibition</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Insomnia</li>
<li>Preoperatively</li>
<li>Anxiety</li>
<li>Sleep induction</li>
<li>Prolonged hypnotic therapy</li>
<li>Withdrawal syndromes</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Drowsiness</li>
<li>Hypotension</li>
<li>Slurred speech, memory impairment</li>
<li>Hangover effect</li>
<li>Dizziness, potential for falls</li>
<li>Respiratory depression: bradypnea, shallow respirations</li>
<li>CNS excitement: nervousness, restlessness, euphoria, excitement, confusion (particularly in older adults)</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Follow safety measures and teach these to client (see general considerations p. 128)</li>
<li>Monitor use, since these are controlled substances</li>
<li>Assess respiratory status</li>
<li>Withdraw drugs slowly after prolonged use</li>
</ol>
<p>BENZODIAZEPINES, NONBARBITURATES, ALCOHOL ▼ 131</p>
<p>E. Contraindicated with other CNS depressants (alcohol).
Interactions: additive effect with CNS depressants, and decreased effectiveness with antacids.</p>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Flurazepam hydrochloride (Dalmane)</li>
<li>Temazepam (Restoril)</li>
<li>Haloperidol (Halcion)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-nonbarbiturates">IV. Nonbarbiturates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-nonbarbiturates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Similar in all ways to barbiturates
B. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Prescription
a. Chloral hydrate (Noctec)
b. Ethchlorvynol (Placidyl)
c. Methyprylon (Noludar)
d. Paraldehyde (Paral)</li>
<li>Nonprescription
a. Unisom
b. Diphenhydramine hydrochloride (Benadryl)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-alcohol">V. Alcohol<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-alcohol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Action: CNS depressant that can produce sedation (low doses) and hypnotic effect or unconsciousness (high doses).
Effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Euphoria</li>
<li>Depressed learned inhibitions</li>
<li>Temporary increase in activity</li>
<li>Decreased fine motor skills</li>
<li>Decreased libido (in high doses)</li>
<li>Diuresis</li>
<li>Appetite stimulation
B. Use: by older-adult patients as a sedative
C. Major side effects</li>
<li>Cardiovascular response: increased pulse and BP</li>
<li>Carcinogenic effects</li>
<li>Toxicity to liver</li>
<li>Hangover effect, blackouts—lapse of memory of current events</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS): a set of congenital psychological, behavioral, cognitive, and physical abnormalities that tends to</li>
</ol>
<p>132 ▼ CHAPTER 8 DRUGS AFFECTING SLEEP</p>
<p>appear in infants whose mothers consumed alcoholic beverages during pregnancy</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Disorientation, slurred speech, decreased motor coordination</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Assess the amount and frequency of alcohol consumption</li>
<li>Emphasize safety precautions if used by older adults. Monitor liver function tests: ALT, AST.</li>
<li>Report any signs of abuse</li>
<li>Use disulfiram (Antabuse) for treatment. Antabuse can cause severe complications within 30 minutes if taken along with alcohol: flushing, diaphoresis, hypoventilation, copious vomiting, confusion, chest pain, difficult breathing. Its use in combination with alcohol can be fatal.</li>
</ol>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 133</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>A client was prescribed a barbiturate, pentobarbital (Nembutal) 100 mg p.o., h.s. to aid in sleeping after an auto accident. She comments that after a month she finds sleep is a problem again. The nurse should recommend which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Stop taking them because they have lost their effectiveness
b. Take them prn and stop the routine every h.s.
c. See your physician, since the pills lose effectiveness after 2 weeks
d. Take the agents with a small glass of wine</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>A client, age 63, is scheduled for open heart surgery in the morning. The physician has ordered secobarbital (Seconal) 100 mg p.o., h.s. After giving the tablet, the nurse should do which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Raise the side rails and instruct him to try to rest
b. Raise the side rails and instruct him not to get out of bed without assistance
c. Instruct him to use the bedside commode for safety
d. Allow the family member to assist him to the bathroom if necessary</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Which side effect would caution a nurse to hold a client's aprobarbital (Alura) at h.s. instead of giving the medicine as ordered?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. BP 110/62
b. P 92/min and regular
c. R 8/min and shallow
d. P 135/min and regular</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>While making rounds, the nurse finds a client confused, scared of her daughter, and unable to remember her name. The nurse should suspect which side effect of triazolam (Halcion)?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. CNS stimulation
b. CNS depression
c. Rebound CNS depression
d. Respiratory excitement</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Nursing implications while a client is taking a hypnotic or sedative would include which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Assess for signs of suicidal intention
b. Assure the client that the hangover effect gets better over time
c. Awaken the client to take the medicine if he/she is asleep
d. Assure the family that sluggish reflexes and slow respirations are normal responses to the agents</p>
<p>CHAPTER 8 DRUGS AFFECTING SLEEP</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Use of these agents longer than 2 to 3 weeks can cause suppression of REM sleep. Clients should never abruptly withdraw from a barbiturate. A daily routine is required to adjust to the level of sedation produced by the agents. Alcohol produces an additive effect and should not be combined with a barbiturate.</td><td>If you have no idea of the correct answer, use common sense. The physician prescribed the medication. If problems occur, refer clients back to the physician.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Side rails should be up at all times, and assistance would be needed for any activity outside of bed. Although this answer a is correct, the safety measures needed for this agent should be strongly enforced. Ambulating without assistance could result in a fall. Assistance should be demanded and enforced, even for a bedside commode. A family member could assist the client to ambulate to the bathroom to prevent an accident. However, of the given responses this is not the best choice.</td><td>Select the most specific answer, which would be b. The others give incomplete information.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Respiratory depression manifested by bradypnea is a concern with these agents.</td><td>Use the ABCs and select a respiratory threat if you have no idea of the correct response.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 135</p>
<p>This is a normal blood pressure and should not prevent the client from taking the agent. An irregular pulse is a sign of toxicity. Tachycardia is not a usual side effect, and other causes should be investigated.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Correct answer: a
Excitement and confusion are signs of CNS stimulation, a side effect often seen in older clients. The action of the drug is depression of the CNS. Rebound CNS depression is not a side effect of this agent. Respiratory depression, not excitement, is the typical side effect.</li>
</ol>
<p>The important factor to identify in the stem is that the client is stimulated, confused, and excited. Of the given responses, only <em>a</em> and <em>d</em> match with stimulation. It is obvious that the stimulation is not of the respiratory system but of the neurological system.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Correct answer: a
Insomnia is often a symptom of depression or serious mental disorders. Suicidal tendencies could trigger the misuse of these agents. Some clients never adjust to the hangover effect and have to try other interventions or medications. As much uninterrupted sleep as possible should be provided to facilitate REM sleep. In response <em>d</em> the two symptoms reported by family are abnormal effects of the agents and should be reported.</li>
</ol>
<p>Use the true-false approach to identify that responses <em>b</em>, <em>c</em>, and <em>d</em> are false.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>137</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-that-relieve-pain-and-inflammation">Drugs That Relieve Pain and Inflammation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-that-relieve-pain-and-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify common groups of drugs used to provide pain relief.</li>
<li>Describe the difference between narcotics, nonnarcotics, and narcotic antagonists.</li>
<li>Identify agents used to decrease inflammation, gout, and manifestations of arthritis.</li>
<li>Describe the major side effects and nursing implications of client use of pain-relieving agents.</li>
</ul>
<p>CHAPTER 9</p>
<p>138 ▼ CHAPTER 9 DRUGS THAT RELIEVE PAIN AND INFLAMMATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Analgesic</strong>
A drug that relieves pain.</p>
<p><strong>Antagonists</strong>
A drug that exerts the opposite action to that of another or competes for the same receptor site.</p>
<p><strong>Inflammation</strong>
A protective response of the tissues of the body to irritation or injury. It may be acute or chronic. Cardinal findings are redness (rubor), heat (calor), swelling (tumor), and pain (dolor), accompanied by loss of function.</p>
<p><strong>Narcotic analgesics</strong>
Acts on the CNS to alter the client’s perception of pain; used for severe pain.</p>
<p><strong>Nonnarcotic analgesics</strong>
Acts at the site of the pain; does not produce tolerance or dependence or alter the client’s perception; used for mild to moderate pain.</p>
<p><strong>NSAID</strong>
Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs—a classification of drugs that decreases prostaglandin synthesis. They are used to treat mild to moderate pain, osteo- and rheumatoid arthritis, and dysmenorrhea (pain associated with menstruation).</p>
<p><strong>Ototoxicity</strong>
Having a harmful effect on the eighth cranial nerve or the organs of hearing or balance from such drugs as aminoglycide antibiotics, aspirin, furosemide, and quinine. Damage may reverse when the drug is stopped.</p>
<p><strong>Tinnitus</strong>
A subjective noise sensation heard in one or both ears. It may occur for no apparent reason; commonly described as “ringing in the ears”; classic finding with too much aspirin or severe lithium toxicity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="analgesics">ANALGESICS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#analgesics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-narcotics">I. Narcotics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-narcotics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Action:</strong> combine with opiate receptors to produce an analgesic effect by altering one’s perception of pain</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Severe pain, chronic pain</li>
<li>Suppression of GI motility</li>
</ol>
<p>ANALGESICS: NARCOTICS ▼ 139</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Dyspnea</li>
<li>Antitussive</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Toxicity: pinpoint pupils, coma</li>
<li>Sedation, confusion, drowsiness</li>
<li>Euphoria</li>
<li>Respiratory depression, hypotension</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Constipation</li>
<li>Tolerance and dependency</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-interactions-additive-effect-with-other-cns-depressants-alcohol-decreased-effect-with-smoking">D. Interactions: additive effect with other CNS depressants (alcohol), decreased effect with smoking<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-interactions-additive-effect-with-other-cns-depressants-alcohol-decreased-effect-with-smoking" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess respiratory status: depth, rate, and rhythm. Hold the medication if the respiratory rate is &lt;10/min.</li>
<li>Assess for hypotension</li>
<li>Monitor bowel elimination, offer stool softener, and fluids, increase dietary fiber, or increase assisted ambulation</li>
<li>Instruct the client to ask for the pain medication before the pain is too severe</li>
<li>Evaluate pain response to the analgesic</li>
<li>Implement and teach the client about safety: put side rails up, and place bed in low position; assist in ambulation; and teach proper safety in operating machinery or driving</li>
<li>Do not administer in clients with head injuries or with increased intracranial pressure (ICP); use only with caution in clients with chronic airway limitations (CAL) or with asthma</li>
<li>Do not abruptly withdraw the medication</li>
<li>Monitor the use of the narcotics and maintain them in a locked area</li>
<li>Teach clients who use a patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) pump how to administer the medicine; in particular, how to push button when they are uncomfortable, without waiting until their pain is severe</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Morphine sulfate (MS)</li>
<li>Meperidine hydrochloride (Demerol)</li>
<li>Codeine sulfate: suppresses cough</li>
<li>Methadone hydrochloride (Dolophine)</li>
<li>Hydromorphone hydrochloride (Dilaudid): for severe pain</li>
<li>Oxycodone terephthalate (Percocet)</li>
</ol>
<p>140 ▼ CHAPTER 9 DRUGS THAT RELIEVE PAIN AND INFLAMMATION</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Propoxyphene hydrochloride (Darvon)</li>
<li>Mixed agents: Brompton’s cocktail (morphine, cocaine, dextroamphetamine, and alcohol)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-mixed-narcotic-agonist-antagonist-agents">II. Mixed narcotic agonist-antagonist agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-mixed-narcotic-agonist-antagonist-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Action:</strong> bind with specific receptors to prevent the opioid from remaining on opioid receptor sites. These agents have no antitussive effects and fewer gastrointestinal effects than agonists do.</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Mild to moderate pain</li>
<li>Respiratory depression</li>
<li>Reduction in the potential for narcotic abuse</li>
<li>Obstetrical analgesia</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Same as for narcotics</li>
<li>Withdrawal findings in clients who are dependent on narcotics</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Same as for narcotics</li>
<li>Should not be given to clients dependent on narcotics</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Butorphanol tartrate (Stadol)</li>
<li>Nalbuphine hydrochloride (Nubain)</li>
<li>Pentazocine hydrochloride (Talwin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-narcotic-antagonists">III. Narcotic antagonists<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-narcotic-antagonists" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Action:</strong> compete with narcotics for receptor sites</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Respiratory depression (particularly drug-induced)</li>
<li>Opioid toxicity</li>
<li>Diagnosis of opioid overdose</li>
<li>Treatment of newborns from addicted mothers</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Withdrawal symptoms in clients dependent on opiates or in infants of mothers addicted to opiates: nervousness, hypertension, palpitations, headache, shortness of breath</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Tachycardia, hypertension</li>
<li>Return of pain or discomfort for which narcotic agonist was given</li>
</ol>
<p>NARCOTICS: AGONIST-ANTAGONIST, ANTAGONISTS; NONNARCOTICS ▼ 141</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Relapse of respiratory depression 15 to 20 minutes after administration of the antagonists, since antagonist is shorter-acting than the agonist</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor the patient closely for return of respiratory depression</li>
<li>Assess and implement interventions for relieving pain</li>
<li>Assess vital signs every 5 minutes: respirations and blood pressure</li>
<li>For acute respiratory depression may repeat dose if needed; usually administered IV push</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Naloxone hydrochloride (Narcan), usually IV</li>
<li>Naltrexone (Trexan), usually p.o.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>IV. Nonnarcotic analgesics</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Actions:</strong> inhibit the enzyme necessary for the synthesis of prostaglandin, treat pain, and act on the hypothalamus to regulate body temperature</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Mild to moderate pain</li>
<li>Fever reduction</li>
<li>In combination with narcotics for an additive effect</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects (rare with therapeutic use)</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Toxicity, which can cause liver and kidney damage</li>
<li>Hypersensitivity</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Assess temperature every 4 hours</li>
<li>Administer acetylcysteine (Mucomyst), by mouth, as the antidote for acetaminophen toxicity, which should be treated immediately; usually given for 3 to 4 days</li>
<li>Evaluate the degree of pain relief obtained</li>
<li>Same nursing implications as those listed under narcotics for those nonnarcotic analgesics that are combined with a narcotic*</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Acetaminophen (Tylenol)</li>
<li>Acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin)</li>
<li>Oxycodone terephthalate (Percocet)*</li>
<li>Oxycodone hydrochloride and acetaminophen (Tylox)*</li>
<li>Hydrocodone bitartrate and acetaminophen (Vicodin)*</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>combination of narcotic and nonnarcotic analgesic</li>
</ul>
<p>142 ▼ CHAPTER 9 DRUGS THAT RELIEVE PAIN AND INFLAMMATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-nonsteroidal-antiinflammatory-drugs-nsaids-are-nonnarcotic-analgesics-but-are-discussed-in-length-under-antiinflammatory-agents">V. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are nonnarcotic analgesics but are discussed in length under antiinflammatory agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-nonsteroidal-antiinflammatory-drugs-nsaids-are-nonnarcotic-analgesics-but-are-discussed-in-length-under-antiinflammatory-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="drugs-used-to-treat-inflammation">DRUGS USED TO TREAT INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-used-to-treat-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="i-antiinflammatory-antipyretic-agents">I. Antiinflammatory/Antipyretic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-antiinflammatory-antipyretic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h5 level="5" id="a-actions-prevent-the-formation-of-prostaglandins-prevent-platelet-aggregation-and-lower-body-temperature">A. Actions: prevent the formation of prostaglandins, prevent platelet aggregation, and lower body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions-prevent-the-formation-of-prostaglandins-prevent-platelet-aggregation-and-lower-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h5></div>
<ol>
<li>Some have combination effects: acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) (ASA) is a nonnarcotic analgesic (reduces pain), antiinflammatory (reducing inflammation), antiplatelet (increases coagulation time), and antipyretic agent (reduces temperature)</li>
<li>Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents (NSAID) inhibit the formation of prostaglandins; these include ibuprofen products</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h5 level="5" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h5></div>
<ol>
<li>Mild to moderate pain</li>
<li>Arthritis</li>
<li>Dysmenorrhea</li>
<li>Fever reduction</li>
<li>Minor postoperative procedures</li>
<li>Decrease of inflammation</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h5 level="5" id="c-interactions-an-increased-chance-of-bleeding-when-drugs-are-used-in-combination-with-diseases-in-which-bleeding-can-occur-ulcers-with-alcohol-consumption-or-with-other-medications-anticoagulants">C. Interactions: an increased chance of bleeding when drugs are used in combination with diseases in which bleeding can occur (ulcers), with alcohol consumption, or with other medications (anticoagulants)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-interactions-an-increased-chance-of-bleeding-when-drugs-are-used-in-combination-with-diseases-in-which-bleeding-can-occur-ulcers-with-alcohol-consumption-or-with-other-medications-anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h5></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="d-major-side-effects">D. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>GI irritation: heartburn, GI bleeding, nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Hematologic: bone marrow depression, anemia, thrombocytopenia</li>
<li>Tinnitus, ototoxicity</li>
<li>Reye’s syndrome with acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) only. Reye’s syndrome can occur in clients 18 years of age or younger.</li>
<li>Toxicity in nonnarcotic agents: respiratory alkalosis, increase in rate and depth of respirations, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, tinnitus, confusion, dizziness</li>
<li>Hypersensitivity to NSAIDs: skin rashes, urticaria, hypotension, dyspnea, and angioedema (also called angioneurotic edema: acute painless swelling of short duration involving the face, neck, lips, larynx, hands, feet, genitalia, or viscera)</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIINFLAMMATORIES, ANTIPYRETICS, ANTIRHEUMATICS ▼ 143</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Give with food or antacids if GI upset occurs</li>
<li>Monitor CBC and stress compliance with frequent visits for blood monitoring. Older-adult clients should be monitored monthly.</li>
<li>Discontinue these products 5 to 7 days before any major procedure or surgery</li>
<li>Instruct mothers not to use ASA in children with high fevers</li>
<li>NSAID products can be alternated with acetaminophen (Tylenol) for extremely high or difficult-to-control temperatures</li>
<li>Teach the clients to report if a temperature does not subside, bleeding occurs, or the swelling and redness do not decrease</li>
<li>Administer with a full glass of water</li>
<li>These agents are highly protein bound. Competition with other agents that are protein bound is possible. Example: digoxin.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Acetylsalicylic acid (Aspirin) (ASA)</li>
<li>Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, Medipren, Nuprin)</li>
<li>Naproxen (Naprosyn, Aleve)</li>
<li>Fenoprofen calcium (Nalfon)</li>
<li>Flurbiprofen sodium (Ansaid)</li>
<li>Indomethacin (Indocin)</li>
<li>Tolmetin sodium (Tolectin)</li>
<li>Sulindac (Clinoril)</li>
<li>Nabumetone (Relafen)</li>
<li>Ketorolac (Toradol)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs-used-to-treat-arthritis">DRUGS USED TO TREAT ARTHRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-used-to-treat-arthritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-antirheumatic-agents">I. Antirheumatic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-antirheumatic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-major-classifications">A. Major classifications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-major-classifications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>NSAID products</li>
<li>Gold compounds</li>
<li>Antimalarial compounds</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-actions-suppress-inflammation-of-synovial-membrane-in-joints-affected-by-arthritis-during-active-stage-of-the-disease-relieve-pain-swelling-and-stiffness-and-can-arrest-the-progression-of-the-disease">B. Actions: suppress inflammation of synovial membrane in joints affected by arthritis during active stage of the disease. Relieve pain, swelling, and stiffness, and can arrest the progression of the disease.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-actions-suppress-inflammation-of-synovial-membrane-in-joints-affected-by-arthritis-during-active-stage-of-the-disease-relieve-pain-swelling-and-stiffness-and-can-arrest-the-progression-of-the-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="c-uses-for-arthritis-and-for-arthritic-clients-who-are-not-responsive-to-nsaid-therapy-alone">C. Uses: for arthritis and for arthritic clients who are not responsive to NSAID therapy alone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-uses-for-arthritis-and-for-arthritic-clients-who-are-not-responsive-to-nsaid-therapy-alone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>144 ▼ CHAPTER 9 DRUGS THAT RELIEVE PAIN AND INFLAMMATION</p>
<p><strong>D. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Toxicity: nephrotoxicity, hepatotoxicity</li>
<li>Metallic taste in mouth, stomatitis, mouth ulcers with gold compounds</li>
<li>Thrombocytopenia, bone marrow depression</li>
<li>Skin changes: rash, dermatitis, changes in pigmentation</li>
<li>Neuropathy, headache, dizziness</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor complete blood count for decreases, BUN, creatinine for elevations</li>
<li>Protect skin from overexposure to sun</li>
<li>Stress compliance with follow-up visits to the physician</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>F. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>NSAID (refer to p. 142)</li>
<li>Gold compounds
a. Gold sodium thiomalate (Myochrysine)
b. Aurothioglycose (Solganal)
c. Auranofin (Ridaura)</li>
<li>Antimalarial medications
a. Chloroquine hydrochloride (Aralen)
b. Hydroxychloroquine sulfate (Plaquenil)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>II. Antigout agents</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Actions</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Control acute inflammation of the attack</li>
<li>Increase excretion of uric acid (uricosuric)</li>
<li>Decrease production of uric acid</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Gouty arthritis, a disease associated with an increased production of, or interference with, the excretion of uric acid</li>
<li>Control uric acid production with antineoplastic drug therapy (*see next page)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Kidney stones</li>
<li>Bone marrow depression, anemia</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Encourage fluid intake of at least 2 to 3 L/day to prevent kidney stone formation</li>
<li>Stress compliance with treatment, and diet of low-purine foods; limit beer, wine, shellfish, and legumes to prevent recurrence</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIGOUT AGENTS, STEROIDAL AGENTS ▼ 145</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Monitor complete blood count (CBC) for decrease in values, agranulocytosis</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Colchicine (Novocolchine)</li>
<li>Probenecid (Benemid)</li>
<li>Sulfinpyrazone (Anturan)</li>
<li>Allopurinol (Zyloprim)*</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-steroidal-antiinflammatory-agents">III. Steroidal antiinflammatory agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-steroidal-antiinflammatory-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: suppress the intensity of the inflammatory response
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Myocarditis: inflammation of the myocardium</li>
<li>Pericarditis: inflammation of the pericardium</li>
<li>Arthritis: inflammation of joints manifested by pain and swelling</li>
<li>Tendinitis: inflammation of tendon</li>
<li>Bursitis: inflammation of bursa (tissue around joint)</li>
<li>Ulcerative colitis: chronic inflammation of the large intestine and rectum</li>
<li>Dermatitis: inflammation of skin, with erythremia, pain, and pruritus</li>
<li>Collagen diseases: extensive disruption of connective tissue (systemic lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects: discussed in Chapter 14 p. 225
D. Nursing implications: discussed in Chapter 14 p. 226
E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Cortisone acetate (Cortistan)</li>
<li>Hydrocortisone (Cortisol, Cortaid)</li>
<li>Prednisone (Apo-Prednisone, Deltasone)</li>
<li>Dexamethasone (Decadron)</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 9 DRUGS THAT RELIEVE PAIN AND INFLAMMATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>A client is postoperative day one from a total abdominal hysterectomy and complains of pain. The nurse should withhold the meperidine hydrochloride (Demerol) based on which of these observations?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. BP 100/72, R 14, P 65
b. BP 98/68, R 8, P 72
c. BP 120/84, R 16, P 90
d. BP 155/98, R 23, P 130</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>A client, age 16, is brought into the emergency room unconscious without any explanation of causation. Narcotic overdose is suspected, and naloxone hydrochloride (Narcan) is administered based on which of these observations?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Dilated pupils, BP 200/98, R 8
b. P 42, R 18, BP 118/62
c. Pinpoint pupils, R 8
d. P 88, R 20, BP 100/65</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>A migraine headache sufferer is seen frequently in the emergency department requesting pain relief. Stadol might be administered instead of meperidine hydrochloride (Demerol) because it is</li>
</ol>
<p>a. An effective analgesic for moderate pain
b. A narcotic antagonist
c. Better and has few side effects
d. A narcotic agonist-antagonist</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Acetylcysteine (Mucomyst) is used as an antidote for</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Aspirin overdose
b. Tylenol overdose
c. Demerol overdose
d. NSAID toxicity</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Upon discharge with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, a client should be taught which of the following for the prevention of side effects with an NSAID product?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Take the NSAID q 4 hours and prn
b. Avoid antacids if the medication causes heartburn
c. Cautiously operate machinery because of the sedative effect
d. Report as requested for a CBC and checkup</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 147</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Respirations &lt;10 should caution the nurse to avoid another dose. Respiratory depression will worsen with subsequent doses. These vital signs in responses <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> are within normal limits.
