These vital signs in response <em>d</em> may indicate that the pain is still present or worsened and that the Demerol could help.</td><td>Use the “vertical approach” to read down each part of the series. Keep in mind the ABCs when vital signs are involved. Response <em>b</em> jumps out with a respiration of 8. Then compare the other answers to confirm that response <em>b</em> is correct.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Both of these findings in response <em>c</em> are indicative of an opioid narcotic overdose. Narcotics cause pinpoint pupils and hypotension. These vital signs in responses <em>d</em> and <em>b</em> are all within normal limits.</td><td>Read each part of the series vertically and eliminate the answers indicating a normal respiratory rate, <em>b</em> and <em>d</em>. Between the remaining two answers, the clue of hypertension makes option <em>a</em> incorrect; select response <em>c</em>.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The agent will relieve pain but prevent the major side effects of narcotics. These agents also have less potential for dependency. The answer in response <em>a</em> is true but not the best reason for substituting the two agents. The correct classification for Stadol is narcotic analgesic. Stadol is not necessarily better with fewer side effects than Demerol.</td><td>If you narrowed the options <em>c</em> and <em>d</em>, reread the question. Note the question is specific; select the more specific option, option <em>d</em>.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>148 ▼ CHAPTER 9 DRUGS THAT RELIEVE PAIN AND INFLAMMATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-correct-answer-b">4. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acetylcysteine (Mucomyst) works by decreasing the buildup of a metabolite that is hepatotoxic in acetaminophen (Tylenol) poisoning. In addition, modifying the pH in the urine with a urinary alkalizer, acetazolamide (Diamox)—acarbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases the reabsorption of sodium bicarbonate in the proximal tubule—can help eliminate acetylsalicylic acid (Aspirin) when the client is overdosed. Naloxone hydrochloride (Narcan) is the recommended agent for meperidine hydrochloride (Demerol) overdose. Eliminating the NSAID will usually relieve symptoms of NSAID toxicity.</p>
<p>Associate acetylcysteine with acetaminophen to recall the treatment for overdosage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-d">5. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anemias are common with these agents, and a regular CBC is needed to avoid or detect any major complications. Response <em>a</em> is the recommended dose and does not eliminate side effects. Heartburn is a common side effect and should be treated with antacids. An NSAID typically does not cause excess sedation.</p>
<p>Key words in the stem are "prevention of side effects." Responses <em>a</em>, <em>b</em>, and <em>c</em> focus on actions to minimize or to deal with side effects.</p>
<p>CHAPTER 10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-cardiovascular-system">Drugs Affecting the Cardiovascular System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-cardiovascular-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the action and use of cardiac glycosides.</li>
<li>Describe nursing implications concerning side effects and prevention of toxicity with cardiac glycosides.</li>
<li>Identify the groups of drugs that relieve angina.</li>
<li>Discuss the nursing implications for the antianginals.</li>
<li>Identify the classifications of drugs used as antihypertensives.</li>
<li>Discuss the stepped-care regimen for treating hypertension.</li>
<li>Describe nursing implications concerning diet and drug therapy to lower blood pressure.</li>
<li>Identify the classifications of drugs used as antidysrhythmics.</li>
<li>Describe nursing implications concerning cardiovascular assessment related to dysrhythmic agents.</li>
</ul>
<p>150 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="afterload">Afterload<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#afterload" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The resistance against which the left ventricle must eject its volume of blood during contraction. The resistance is produced by the volume of blood already in the vascular system plus the diameter of the vessel walls. <strong>Left ventricular afterload</strong>: referred to as peripheral vascular resistance (PVR); <strong>Right ventricular afterload</strong>: referred to as pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antidysrhythmics">Antidysrhythmics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antidysrhythmics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A classification of drugs that prevent, alleviate, or correct an abnormal cardiac rhythm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antilipidemics">Antilipidemics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antilipidemics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Agents that reduce the amount of lipids in the serum: Lovastatin (Mevacor)—interferes with the synthesis of cholesterol. Colestipol (Colestid), Cholestyramine (Questran)—combine with bile acids in the intestine to form an insoluble complex that is excreted in the feces. Clofibrate (Atromid-S)—reduces low-density lipoproteins in the serum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="automaticity">Automaticity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#automaticity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A property of a specialized excitable tissue that allows self-activation through spontaneous development of an action potential, as in most of the cells called pacemaker cells in the heart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="digitalis-toxicity">Digitalis toxicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digitalis-toxicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A result of the cumulative effect of digitalis preparations; earliest findings are typically nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preload">Preload<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preload" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The stretch of the myocardial fiber at end diastole which is related to filling volume.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiac-glycosides-and-similar-drugs">CARDIAC GLYCOSIDES AND SIMILAR DRUGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-glycosides-and-similar-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Actions: a positive inotropic, negative chronotropic, and negative dromotropic effect produced by inhibiting the adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase) enzyme and increasing calcium into the myocardial cytoplasm (Box 10-1)</li>
</ol>
<p>CARDIAC GLYCOSIDES AND SIMILAR AGENTS ▼ 151</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-10-1-effect-of-drugs-on-the-heart">Box 10-1. Effect of Drugs on the Heart<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-10-1-effect-of-drugs-on-the-heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Inotropic</th><th>affects the force of contraction</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Chronotropic</td><td>interferes with the rate of the heart beat</td></tr><tr><td>Dromotropic</td><td>pertains to conduction</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>A. Positive inotropic effect: increases myocardial contraction, which may decrease heart size in clients with cardiomyopathy and CHF, and increases renal blood flow
B. Negative chronotropic effect: decreases heart rate
C. Negative dromotropic effect: slows conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node
D. Overall effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Increased cardiac output without increased oxygen demand in non-myocardial infarction situations</li>
<li>Decreased workload from the effect of decreased heart rate</li>
<li>Mild diuretic effect</li>
<li>Decreased heart size in cardiomyopathy clients</li>
<li>Specific to amrinone lactate (Inocor) as a result of vasodilation
a. Decreased preload: decreased stretch of myocardial fiber at the end of diastole
b. Decreased afterload and end-diastolic volume</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-uses">II. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congestive heart failure (CHF)
B. Atrial dysrhythmias, atrial flutter, supraventricular tachycardia</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-major-side-effects">III. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Digitalis toxicity</p>
<ol>
<li>GI disturbances: nausea, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhea (first signs of adult toxicity), upset stomach (first sign of toxicity in older children)</li>
<li>Neurological symptoms: vertigo, headache, drowsiness, irritability, weakness, convulsions</li>
<li>Ophthalmologic disorders: photophobia, disturbances in color vision (yellow vision), yellow-green halos around objects, flickering lights</li>
<li>Cardiovascular effects: ECG changes, extra beats, bradycardia (first sign of toxicity in older children), heart block, tachycardias (first sign of toxicity in young children)</li>
</ol>
<p>152 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>B. GI disturbances similar to those listed above may occur without toxicity. If not toxic, these disappear with continued therapy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-nursing-implications">IV. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Monitor blood levels and signs of toxicity. Digitalis has a low therapeutic index (0.5 to 2 ng/ml), and toxicity occurs quickly.</p>
<p>B. Because of the long half-life, monitor for associated factors of toxicity</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Hypokalemia (&lt;3.5 mEq/L), hypercalcemia (&gt;10.5 mg/dl), hypomagnesemia (&lt;1.8 mg/dl)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recent myocardial infarction, ventricular tachycardia, or heart block</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Impaired renal function, dehydration, low serum albumin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rapid administration IV</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Carefully monitor the older adults because of the possible interactions with other drugs, diseases, and slower absorption, which may lead to toxicity</p>
<p>D. Assess heart rate by taking an apical pulse for 1 full minute. Hold the drug for heart rates &lt;60 beats/min (adult) and &lt;110 (children); and &gt;120 beats/min (adults) and &gt;140 (children), unless parameters have been set by the physician.</p>
<p>E. Assess use of concurrent medications</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Give separately from antacids (at least 1 to 2 hours apart)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use cautiously with other calcium channel blockers or beta blockers to prevent severe bradycardia or heart block</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Assess renal status, monitor intake and output (I&amp;O)</p>
<p>G. Assess for findings of increasing CHF: weight gain, edema of feet and ankles, or lung congestion, S₃ or S₄ heart sound</p>
<p>H. Usually requires digitalizing dose before beginning a maintenance dose. The preferred routes are IV and PO. These drugs are extremely painful if given IM.</p>
<p>I. Monitor hospitalized clients for electrolytes, ECG changes, creatinine, and BUN</p>
<p>J. Use digoxin immune FAB (Digibind) to treat toxicity if dysrhythmias are life-threatening</p>
<p>K. Teach the client</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Proper dose, time of day to take the medication, and other medications to avoid</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How to count a pulse rate and when to notify the physician of changes</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIANGINAL AGENTS: NITRATES ▼ 153</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>When to report to the physician: extra beats, fast heart rates, signs of toxicity, excess coughing, weight gain—report gain of &gt;2 pounds/week or/day</li>
<li>Information about toxicity and the importance of knowing what dose to take if the physician changes the prescription</li>
</ol>
<p>V. Interactions can occur with prescription and over-the-counter (OTC) medications. Nurses should review the current medication record, and clients should be sure to tell all physicians that they are taking a digitalis preparation. A pharmacist should be consulted before clients take OTC preparations. Interactions have occurred with quinidine, beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, loop diuretics, and thyroid preparations.</p>
<p>VI. Contraindicated in idiopathic hypertrophic subaortic stenosis (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy), Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome, and heart blocks</p>
<p>VII. Common individual drugs</p>
<p>A. Digitalis preparations</p>
<ol>
<li>Digoxin (Lanoxin, Lanoxicaps)</li>
<li>Deslanoxide (Cedilanid-D)—given IV only</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Amrinone lactate (Inocor) is similar to cardiac glycosides but differs in the following ways</p>
<ol>
<li>Does not cause dysrhythmias in large doses</li>
<li>Side effects also include thrombocytopenia and hypotension</li>
<li>Used in CHF when cardiac glycosides fail</li>
<li>Should not be diluted in dextrose products</li>
<li>Should not be given with furosemide (Lasix)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antianginals">ANTIANGINALS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antianginals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. Classifications of drugs used to treat angina
A. Nitrates
B. Beta adrenergic blockers
C. Calcium channel blockers</p>
<p>II. Nitrates</p>
<p>A. Actions</p>
<ol>
<li>Decrease oxygen demand</li>
<li>Decrease preload by dilating veins</li>
</ol>
<p>154 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>In higher doses, dilate all major systemic arteries, which decreases afterload: the resistance against which the left ventricle must eject its volume of blood during contraction</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Uses: first line treatment for immediate and long-term prevention of angina: chest pain due to lack of oxygenated blood supply to the heart</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Headache (most common)</li>
<li>Hypotension</li>
<li>Postural hypotension</li>
<li>Syncope</li>
<li>Flushed feeling</li>
<li>Dizziness</li>
<li>Weakness</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Hypotension can be severe with consumption of alcohol or when taken with beta blockers or calcium channel blockers</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Know how to administer in all available forms: PO, IV, ointment, patch, SL, spray, chewable, inhalation</li>
<li>Assess the frequency and nature of the angina before drug therapy and as relief is obtained</li>
<li>Monitor BP before any dose. BP should be taken before, during, and after therapy. Parameters for administration should be documented by the physician.</li>
<li>Instructions for patches and ointment application</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Use nonhairy area
b. Rotate sites
c. Remove the old patch or ointment immediately before applying a new dose
d. Use gloves to avoid getting ointment on hands
e. Squeeze the prescribed amount of ointment onto the paper and apply to the skin without rubbing. Tape the paper in place or apply a plastic wrap over the paper to increase absorption.
f. Date the patch on the outside</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Instructions for SL and spray preparations</li>
</ol>
<p>a. May take up to 3 SL tablets, 3 to 5 minutes apart to obtain pain relief. If relief is not obtained, seek medical attention.
b. Tablets should be protected from light, heat, and moisture
c. Tablets should always be available. Teach the clients to carry them at all times on their person.</p>
<p>ANTIANGINAL AGENTS: BETA ADRENERGIC BLOCKERS ▼ 155</p>
<p>d. Tablets should be replaced 3 to 6 months after bottle is opened. A burning sensation should occur when taken SL.
e. Spray should be applied directly to the oral mucosa (avoid inhaling)
f. Cotton should be removed from all new bottles, and expiration dates on bottles should be checked</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>
<p>IV nitroglycerin (Tridil) should be mixed with D5W or normal saline in a glass bottle with the manufacturer-supplied tubing. A pump should be used and the dose titrated every 3 to 5 minutes according to pain assessment, blood pressure, and pulse measurements. Do not mix any other drug with IV nitroglycerin (Tridil). IV nitroglycerin (Tridil) interferes with the effects of IV heparin, so IV heparin rates usually need to be increased to obtain a therapeutic effect.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Avoid use in head trauma or cases of increased intracranial pressure, cerebral hemorrhage</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Client teaching
a. Take nitroglycerin (Nitrostat) tablets at the first sign of an anginal attack
b. Nitrates are not habit forming, but tolerance can develop
c. Lie or sit down while taking NTG for an acute attack to prevent falls from potential dizziness from the decreased preload
d. To prevent angina, take agents before stressful physical activity known to cause angina such as exercise, sexual activity
e. Teach the specifics about the form of nitroglycerin prescribed
f. Monitor BP if equipment available at home</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Interactions can occur with alcohol and other vasodilators
G. Common individual drugs: {NTG} nitroglycerin (Nitro-bid, Nitrostat, Tridil, Transderm-Nitro, Nitrodisc, Nitro-dur, Deponit, Minitran)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-beta-adrenergic-blockers">III. Beta adrenergic blockers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-beta-adrenergic-blockers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Actions: block beta receptor sites in the heart, which decreases the force of the contraction and lowers oxygen demand. These actions result in the following</p>
<ol>
<li>Lowered heart rate</li>
<li>Decreased cardiac output</li>
<li>Decreased contractility</li>
<li>Prevention of exercise-induced tachycardia</li>
<li>Decreased dysrhythmias</li>
</ol>
<p>156 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>B. Uses: for long-term prevention of angina. These agents assist chronic angina patients to increase their exercise potential. These agents are not used for acute attacks. Beta blockers are also used after a myocardial infarction (MI) and to prevent a further infarct. (Table 10-1 for other uses)</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Cardiovascular: hypotension, bradycardia</li>
<li>Beta blocker blues: decreased libido, depression</li>
<li>Bronchospasm</li>
<li>Worsening of CHF, heart blocks</li>
<li>Fatigue</li>
<li>Constipation</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor BP and pulse before, during, and after therapy. If the apical pulse is below 60 for a full minute, consult the physician unless other parameters have been given.</li>
<li>Assess other medications the client is taking. Avoid administering at the same time as antacids (wait 1 to 2 hours), calcium channel blockers, or cardiac glycosides.</li>
<li>Use cautiously in clients with chronic airway limitations (CAL), asthma, CHF, heart blocks, and peripheral vascular insufficiency</li>
<li>Monitor the ECG status of the client</li>
<li>Client teaching
a. Do not abruptly withdraw the medication without consulting the physician first; abrupt withdrawal may result in angina
b. Take the medication at the same time each day
c. If a dose is forgotten, do not double the dose; rearrange the schedule to make up the dose
d. Report any side effects to the physician
e. Do not take hot baths, sit in hot tubs, or be exposed to the hot sun for long periods of time
f. Monitor the pulse at the same time daily; count for 1 full minute</li>
<li>Triglyceride and cholesterol level (LDL) may be elevated</li>
<li>Clients exercising or attending cardiac rehabilitation may not experience a rise in HR in response to the activity. Signs and symptoms of the client should be considered in response to the exercise undertaken.</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Interactions: increased potential for bradycardia with concurrent use of cardiac glycosides and calcium channel blockers, and an increased hypotensive effect with diuretics</p>
<p>157</p>
<p>Table 10-1. Clinical Uses for Beta Blockers and Calcium Channel Blockers</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Classification</th><th>Antianginal</th><th>Antihypertensive</th><th>Antidysrhythmic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Beta Blockers</td><td>Relieve pain by</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing HR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing contractility</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing oxygen demand</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ producing negative inotropic effect</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ producing negative chronotropic effect</td><td>Lower BP by</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ blocking sympathetic stimulation</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing cardiac output</td><td>Stop dysrhythmias by</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing ischemia by</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ lowering oxygen demand</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ due to decreasing HR (negative chronotropic effect)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Calcium Channel Blockers</td><td>Relieve pain by</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing intracellular calcium, which decreases myocardial contractility, which then lowers oxygen demand</td><td>Lower BP by</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing peripheral vascular resistance</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing calcium transport across cells</td><td>Stop dysrhythmias by</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ decreasing conduction rate (negative dromotropic effect)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ blocking calcium influx, which decreases irritability</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>158 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p><strong>F. Common drugs</strong>*</p>
<ol>
<li>Propranolol hydrochloride (Inderal)</li>
<li>Nadolol (Corgard)</li>
<li>Metoprolol tartrate (Lopressor)</li>
<li>Atenolol (Tenormin)</li>
<li>Pindolol (Viskin)</li>
<li>Timolol maleate (Blocadren)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Note: these drugs end in “lol”</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>IV. Calcium channel blockers</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Actions</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Decrease myocardial contractility by preventing the influx of calcium ions into the cells</li>
<li>Decrease oxygen demand</li>
<li>Dilate coronary and peripheral arteries</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Uses: see Table 10-1</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Prevention of complications post-MI</li>
<li>Acute and long-term prevention of angina attacks</li>
<li>Angina caused by vasospasm</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Hypotension</li>
<li>Bradycardia</li>
<li>Heart blocks</li>
<li>Dyspnea</li>
<li>Wheezing</li>
<li>Worsening CHF</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor BP and pulse before, during, and after administration. Parameters (high and low) should be set for BP and pulse.</li>
<li>Monitor ECG pattern and avoid giving the medication when existing heart blocks are present</li>
<li>Administer these medications with meals or milk</li>
<li>Monitor renal status: serum creatinine and urine output</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Interactions: increased effects if taken with a beta blocker and increased digoxin level if taken with digoxin products</strong></p>
<p><strong>F. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Diltiazem hydrochloride (Cardizem)</li>
<li>Nicardipine hydrochloride (Cardene)</li>
<li>Nifedipine (Procardia)</li>
<li>Verapamil hydrochloride (Calan, Isoptin)</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIDYSRHYTHMIC AND ANTIHYPERTENSIVE AGENTS ▼ 159</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="antidysrhythmic-agents">ANTIDYSRHYTHMIC AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antidysrhythmic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. Actions: separated into classes I through IV based on the action and type of dysrhythmia the drug treats. A dysrhythmia is a deviation from the normal pattern of the heartbeat. These drugs work by one or more of the following ways</p>
<p>A. Decrease automaticity: decreases the ability of any cell in the myocardium to self-activate through spontaneous development of an action potential. The ability of cells to fire an impulse accounts for many of the dysrhythmias and extra (premature) beats.
B. Decrease reentry phenomena: decreases the reactivation of myocardial tissue for the second or subsequent time by the same impulse
C. Decrease conduction: slows heart rate</p>
<p>II. Specific actions, uses, side effects, and nursing implications for each class are identified in Table 10-2</p>
<p>III. Nursing implications</p>
<p>A. Monitor vital signs before, during, and after treatment
B. Make sure IV forms of dysrhythmic drugs are always on an IV controller
C. Monitor ECG patterns; withhold if heart block occurs
D. Administer around-the-clock, since most require that a therapeutic level be maintained
E. Monitor electrolytes, especially potassium (K) and magnesium values</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="antihypertensives">ANTIHYPERTENSIVES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antihypertensives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. The stepped-care approach (Table 10-3) for the treatment of high blood pressure should begin with lifestyle modification (Step 1) consisting of</p>
<p>A. Exercise
B. Reduction of stress
C. Cessation of smoking
D. Loss of excess weight
E. Restriction of sodium
F. Decrease in alcohol</p>
<p>160
Table 10-2. Antidysrhythmics: Class, Action, Side Effects, and Nursing Implications</p>

BP</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>procainimide</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>hydrochloride (Pronestyl)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>disopyramide speech</td><td>▼ Check allergies to local</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>anesthetics</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>mexiletine hydrochloride</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(Mexitil)</td><td>▼ Used to suppress or</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>prevent sign</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>**severe</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Continued.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th></th><th>Lidocaine toxicity, especially if administered with Tagamet or Inderal Respiratory arrest</th><th>Read labels carefully to be sure of administering correct IV form of drug</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Class I-C</td><td>↓ Interrupts reentry, stabilizes cell membrane, decreases depolarization</td><td>CNS disturbances: dizziness, headache, visual disturbances</td><td>Monitor K levels</td></tr><tr><td>flecainide acetate (Tambocor)</td><td>↓ Used for ventricular dysrhythmias and to prevent sustained ventricular tachycardia</td><td>Dyspnea</td><td>↓ Assess BP</td></tr><tr><td>encainide hydrochloride (Enkaid)</td><td></td><td>Abdominal and leg pain</td><td>↓ Assess for signs of CHF</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Worsen CHF</td><td>↓ Give with food if GI upset occurs</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Exacerbate existing dysrhythmias and create new ones</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Class II (Beta Blockers)</td><td>↓ Decreases ischemia by decreasing oxygen demand and decreasing heat rate (negative chronotropic effect)</td><td>Bradycardia, hypotension syncope, precipitate CHF decreased libido fatigue, lassitude (see beta blockers under antianginals)</td><td>↓ Use cautiously with heart blocks, CHF, COPD</td></tr><tr><td>propranolol hydrochloride (Inderal)</td><td>↓ These actions cause less irritability and less dysrhythmias</td><td></td><td>↓ Withhold if HR&lt;60/min</td></tr><tr><td>acebutolol hydrochloride (Sectral)</td><td></td><td></td><td>↓ Monitor for signs of CHF</td></tr><tr><td>esmolol hydrochloride (Brivibloc)</td><td></td><td></td><td>↓ Do not abruptly withdraw—angina may result</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>162</p>
<p>Table 10-2. Antidysrhythmics: Class, Action, Side Effects, and Nursing Implications—cont'd</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Class/Name</th><th>Action/Use</th><th>Side Effects</th><th>Nursing Implications</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Clue: Drugs ending in “lol” are typically beta blockers</td><td>▼ Used for controlling atrial and ventricular ectopy and sudden atrial or ventricular tachycardia</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Class III</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>amiodarone hydrochloride (Cordarone)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>bretylium tosylate (Bretylol)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>sotalol (Betapace)</td><td>▼ Decreases automaticity, stops reentry, delays repolarization of fast potentials</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ All three can affect the heart in different ways; therefore they are not interchangeable</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Used for life-threatening ventricular dysrhythmias</td><td>Orthostatic hypotension, dizziness, can aggravate existing dysrhythmias, fatigue, malaise</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Sotalol can cause torsades de pointes</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Toxicity and dysrhythmias are increased by hypokalemia: widens QRS, prolongs PR and QT interval</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Photosensitivity</td><td>▼ Monitor BP and pulse</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Monitor EKG for changes</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Teach client to use sunscreens</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Class IV (Calcium Channel Blockers)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>verapamil hydrochloride (Calan, Isoptin)</td><td>▼ Blocks calcium influx across myocardial cell and decreases conduction rate (negative dromotropic effect)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Used for controlling ventricular rate in clients with supraventricular dysrhythmias</td><td>Severe orthostatic hypotension, especially when administered IV</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Sinus and AV blocks</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Worsen CHF</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Flushing, headache, leg and muscle cramps</td><td>▼ Use cautiously with bradycardia, CHF clients, and sick sinus syndrome</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Give IV slowly, over 2 to 3 minutes</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Assess BP</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Assess signs of CHF</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Monitor EKG during IV administration</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>STEPPED-CARE APPROACH FOR HYPERTENSION, DIURETICS ▼ 163</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="table-10-3-stepped-care-approach">Table 10-3. Stepped-Care Approach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-10-3-stepped-care-approach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>|  <strong>Step I</strong>
Sodium restriction
Weight control
Alcohol restriction
Exercise
Cessation of smoking
Stress reduction | <strong>Step II</strong>
Continue Step I
Add one agent:
Diuretic
Calcium channel blocker
ACE inhibitor
Beta adrenergic blocker | <strong>Step III</strong>
Continue Step I
Change or add another agent:
Adrenergic blocking agent | <strong>Step IV</strong>
Continue Step I
Change or add another agent:
Direct Vasodilator  |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |</p>
<p>Summary of the Stepped-Care Approach recommended in the 1993 revised report by the Joint National Committee on Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-classifications-of-drugs-used-beyond-step-1">II. Classifications of drugs used beyond Step 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-classifications-of-drugs-used-beyond-step-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Step 2</p>
<ol>
<li>Diuretics</li>
<li>Calcium channel blockers</li>
<li>Beta adrenergic blockers</li>
<li>Angiotensin antagonists</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Step 3: adrenergic blocking agents
C. Step 4: direct vasodilators</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-diuretics-see-chapter-11-p-182-are-often-tried-first-especially-in-older-adults-as-a-step-2-approach">III. Diuretics (see Chapter 11 p. 182) are often tried first, especially in older adults as a Step 2 approach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-diuretics-see-chapter-11-p-182-are-often-tried-first-especially-in-older-adults-as-a-step-2-approach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions</p>
<p>164 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<ol>
<li>Increase sodium and water excretion</li>
<li>Decrease cardiac output</li>
<li>Directly vasodilate arterioles</li>
<li>Decrease peripheral vascular resistance (PVR): a resistance to the flow of blood determined by the tone of the systemic vascular musculature and the diameter of the blood vessels</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Essential hypertension (HTN): thiazides and loop diuretics</li>
<li>Potassium sparing are often combined with other agents to lower BP</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Refer to Chapter 11, p. 182 for side effects, nursing implications and common drugs</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-beta-adrenergic-blockers">IV. Beta adrenergic blockers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-beta-adrenergic-blockers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit sympathetic stimulation, which lowers HR and decreases cardiac output to lower BP (see Table 10-1)
B. Often used in combination with a diuretic
C. Side effects and nursing implications: see antianginals, p. 153
D. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Atenolol (Tenormin)</li>
<li>Labetalol (Normodyne)</li>
<li>Metoprolol tartrate (Lopressor)</li>
<li>Nadolol (Corgard)</li>
<li>Pindolol (Viskin)</li>
<li>Propranolol hydrochloride (Inderal)</li>
<li>Timolol maleate (Blocadren)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-calcium-channel-blockers">V. Calcium channel blockers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-calcium-channel-blockers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit release of intracellular calcium, which decreases the force of contraction and prevents entry of calcium ions into smooth muscle; this lowers arteriolar constriction, thereby lowering PVR and decreasing BP (see Table 10-1)
B. Uses: mild to moderate HTN alone or in combination with diuretics
C. Side effects and nursing implications: see antianginals, p. 153
D. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Diltiazem hydrochloride (Cardizem)</li>
<li>Felodipine (Plendil)</li>
</ol>
<p>ANGIOTENSION CONVERTING ENZYME (ACE) INHIBITORS ▼ 165</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Nicardipine hydrochloride (Cardene)</li>
<li>Nifedipine (Procardia)</li>
<li>Verapamil hydrochloride (Isoptin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-angiotensin-antagonists-angiotension-converting-enzyme-ace-inhibitors">VI. Angiotensin antagonists (angiotension converting enzyme, ACE) inhibitors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-angiotensin-antagonists-angiotension-converting-enzyme-ace-inhibitors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: interrupt the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system in one of three ways (Box 10-2)</p>
<ol>
<li>Inhibit conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II</li>
<li>Decrease aldosterone secretion</li>
<li>Compete with angiotensin II to block its effect</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Uses: mild to moderate hypertension (HTN)</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Chest pain</li>
<li>Palpitations</li>
<li>Hypotension</li>
<li>Tachycardia</li>
<li>Proteinuria: large quantities of protein in the urine, associated with renal disease, hypertension, heart failure</li>
<li>Rash</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-10-2-three-mechanisms-of-action-from-ace-inhibitors-in-relation-to-normal-physiology">Box 10-2. Three Mechanisms of Action from ACE Inhibitors in Relation to Normal Physiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-10-2-three-mechanisms-of-action-from-ace-inhibitors-in-relation-to-normal-physiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="long-term-regulation-of-blood-pressure">Long-Term Regulation of Blood Pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#long-term-regulation-of-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>With a decrease in BP, stimulation of the kidneys occurs to excrete renin, an
(1) inhibits
enzyme involved in the formation of angiotensin I. Angiotensin I is converted
(3) competes with
to Angiotensin II (potent vasoconstrictor). Angiotensin II produces two
(2) decreases
effects: elevation of BP by potency, or a release in aldosterone, which
decreases the excretion of Na and water and thereby elevates BP.</p>
<p>Key: Mechanism of action</p>
<p>CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Neuroterapia: an abnormal decrease in the number of neutrophils in the blood, associated with leukemia, infection, rheumatoid arthritis</li>
<li>Agranulocytosis: reduction in the number of basophils, eosinophils and neutrophils</li>
<li>Hyperkalemia: potassium &gt;5.0 mEq/L</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor CBC and potassium (K) levels</li>
<li>Assess for signs of infection</li>
<li>Check BP daily and keep a monthly log as needed</li>
<li>Instruct client to</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Inform any new physician about the medication taken
b. Avoid excess intake of foods rich in potassium and potassium supplements. (Box 10-3)
c. Do not abruptly stop taking the medication
d. Avoid OTC medications without approval of the physician</p>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Captopril (Capoten)</li>
<li>Enalapril maleate (Vasotec)</li>
<li>Ramipril (Altace)</li>
<li>Benazepril hydrochloride (Lotensin)</li>
</ol>
<p>*Note: drugs ending in "ril" are typically ACE inhibitor, antihypertensives</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-adrenergic-blocking-agents">VII. Adrenergic blocking agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-adrenergic-blocking-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Groups of drugs within this class</p>
<ol>
<li>Centrally acting adrenergic blocking agents</li>
<li>Ganglionic blockers</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-10-3-dietary-consideration-potassium-sources">Box 10-3. Dietary Consideration: Potassium Sources<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-10-3-dietary-consideration-potassium-sources" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dietary sources of potassium that should be avoided or restricted with ACE inhibitors.</p>
<ul>
<li>Citrus fruits and juices: especially tomato juice</li>
<li>Bananas, watermelon</li>
<li>Other juices: grape, cranberry, apple, pear, apricot</li>
<li>Cereals</li>
<li>Meat, fish, foul</li>
<li>Leafy vegetables</li>
<li>Salt substitutes (read label)</li>
<li>Coffee, tea, cola beverages</li>
<li>Nuts, peanut butter</li>
</ul>
<p>ADRENERGIC BLOCKING AND DIRECT VASODILATING AGENTS ▼ 167</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Alpha adrenergic blocking drugs</li>
<li>Peripherally acting antiadrenergic agents</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Actions: vary depending on the group (see Chapter 5 p. 67). Most inhibit stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system, which causes a drop in BP from peripheral vasodilation or decreased cardiac output.</p>
<p>C. Uses: mild to severe essential hypertension
D. Side effects and nursing implications (see Chapter 5 p. 68)
E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Centrally acting adrenergic agents
a. Methyldopa (Aldomet)
b. Quanfacine (Tenex)
c. Guanabenz acetate (Wytensin)
d. Clonidine hydrochloride (Catapres)</li>
<li>Ganglionic blockers
a. Mecamylamine hydrochloride (Inversine)
b. Trimethaphan camsylate (Arfonad)</li>
<li>Alpha adrenergic blocking drugs
a. Prazosin hydrochloride (Minipress)
b. Phentolamine (Regitine)</li>
<li>Peripherally acting antiadrenergic agents
a. Reserpine (Serpalan)
b. Terazosin (Hytrin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-direct-vasodilating-agents">VIII. Direct vasodilating agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-direct-vasodilating-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: relax arteriolar smooth muscle, dilate arteries, and decrease PVR
B. Uses: moderate to severe hypertension (HTN) and hypertensive crisis
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Headache</li>
<li>Sodium retention</li>
<li>Rebound HTN</li>
<li>Increased workload of heart: tachycardia, palpitations, nausea</li>
<li>Vomiting, abdominal pain
D. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Monitor VS every 5 to 15 minutes, titrate dose to BP, and do not leave patient unmonitored</li>
<li>Monitor I&amp;O, preferably with a foley catheter in critical care setting</li>
<li>Use microdrip tubing and have IV on a controller pump</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Do not mix these drugs with any other drugs</li>
<li>Since sodium nitroprusside (Nipride) must be protected from light, wrap IV bag and tubing with foil</li>
<li>Give hydralazine hydrochloride (Apresoline) slowly IV push</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Sodium nitroprusside (Nipride)</li>
<li>Hydralazine hydrochloride (Apresoline)</li>
<li>Diazoxide (Hyperstat)</li>
<li>Guanethidine sulfate (Ismelin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-general-nursing-implications-for-antihypertensives">IX. General nursing implications for antihypertensives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-general-nursing-implications-for-antihypertensives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Monitor baseline BP and pulse before, during, and after therapy
B. Monitor I and O, renal function by creatinine clearance or serum creatinine levels
C. Encourage lifestyle changes: see Step I
D. Teach the client how to check the BP at home; offer parameters from which to report abnormal values. Explain orthostatic BP and the need to rise slowly from lying or sitting position.
E. Teach the client to report edema, cough, and weight gain of &gt;2 pounds per week
F. Stress need to comply with taking the BP and medication
G. Stress need to avoid all OTC products unless physician has been consulted</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antihyperlipidemia-agents">ANTIHYPERLIPIDEMIA AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antihyperlipidemia-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. Therapy for high cholesterol levels (&gt;200 mg/dl-adult) and triglyceride levels (&gt;160 mg/dl in males and &gt;135 mg/dl in females)</p>
<p>A. First line of therapy: nondrug treatment</p>
<ol>
<li>Diet management</li>
<li>Exercise program</li>
<li>Reduction of other risk factors</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Second line of therapy: treatment with medications</p>
<ol>
<li>Cholesterol-lowering agents</li>
<li>Triglyceride-lowering agents</li>
</ol>
<p>II. Cholesterol-lowering agents</p>
<p>A. Actions</p>
<ol>
<li>Bile-sequestering agents: form insoluble complexes with the bile acids in the GI tract, which causes cholesterol to replace the lost bile acids, thereby lowering the cholesterol level</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIHYPERLIPIDEMICS: CHOLESTEROL &amp; TRIGLYCERIDE-LOWERING AGENTS ▼ 169</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Cholesterol inhibitors: inhibit the synthesis of cholesterol and increase the excretion of cholesterol</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Uses: when dietary management does not lower cholesterol and the lower density level (LDL) cholesterol is high</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Gastrointestinal: constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhea</li>
<li>Headache</li>
<li>Hepatotoxicity</li>
<li>Alteration of prothrombin time</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions: binds with other acid drugs in the GI tract and thereby reducing absorption of fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Instruct the client how to mix the powder or granules in a liquid or food</li>
<li>Monitor prothrombin time (PT) monthly</li>
<li>Assess cholesterol levels frequently (at least monthly)</li>
<li>Monitor for GI distress, especially bowel elimination patterns</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Bile-sequestering agents
a. Cholestyramine (Questran)
b. Colestipol hydrochloride (Colestid)</li>
<li>Cholesterol synthesis inhibitors
a. Probucol (Lorelco)
b. Iovastatin (Mevacor)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-triglyceride-lowering-agents-fibric-acid-derivatives">III. Triglyceride-lowering agents: fibric acid derivatives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-triglyceride-lowering-agents-fibric-acid-derivatives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit the synthesis of cholesterol and increase the excretion of triglycerides</p>
<p>B. Uses: decrease high levels of triglycerides and lower cholesterol</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Gastrointestinal: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea</li>
<li>Cholelithiasis</li>
<li>Benign and malignant liver tumors</li>
<li>Bleeding tendencies</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Use short-term only</li>
<li>Monitor prothrombin time (PT)</li>
<li>Assess for a prior history of gallstones and liver disease</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Clofibrate (Atromid-S)</li>
<li>Gemfibrozil (Lopid)</li>
</ol>
<p>170 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Which side effect of the calcium channel blocker nicardipine hydrochloride (Cardene) would be of concern to the nurse?
a. “My mouth is so dry”
b. “I haven’t had a BM in 4 days”
c. BP 200/100
d. BP 80/50</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What is the <em>initial</em> treatment for a client with essential hypertension?
a. A diuretic agent
b. A diuretic, low-fat diet, and exercise
c. Low-sodium diet, weight reduction, and an exercise program
d. Adrenergic blocking agent and weight reduction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How should the nurse respond when a client asks how a beta blocker lowers his/her BP?
a. “The drug decreases the amount of O₂ demanded by the heart”
b. “The drug dilates veins, which increases the workload of the heart”
c. “You’ll have to discuss this with your doctor”
d. “The drug slows the HR and decreases cardiac output, thereby lowering BP”</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The drugs of choice in reducing triglycerides in clients who do not respond to dietary management are
a. Bile-sequestering agents
b. Febric acid derivatives
c. Cholesterol synthesis inhibitors
d. Bile-sequestering agents and cholesterol synthesis inhibitors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A loading dose of digoxin (Lanoxin) 0.5 mg PO is administered and followed by 0.25 mg PO daily. The positive inotropic and negative chronotropic effect is reflected in which of the following sets of data?
a. BP 150/70, P 92, R 24, decrease in urine output
b. BP 130/80, P 60, R 22, increase in urine output
c. BP 80/50, P 60, R 22, no effect on urine output
d. BP 80/50, P 92, R 24, decrease in urine output</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The nurse should suspect digoxin (Lanoxin) toxicity if a client states
a. “I can’t have a BM”
b. “The lights seem very bright”</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 171</p>
<p>c. "I have no appetite"
d. "My BP has been elevated lately"</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>
<p>Which of the following should alert the nurse to consider digoxin (Lanoxin) toxicity?
a. K level 5.5 mEq/L
b. Na level 146 mEq/L
c. Magnesium level 1.5 mEq/L
d. K level 2.3 mEq/L</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After administering a client his first nitroglycerin (Nitrostat) sublingual (SL), the nurse checks his blood pressure and gets 80/50. He still complains of chest pain. The nurse should
a. Give the SL nitroglycerin (Nitrostat) tablet anyway and notify the physician
b. Hold the SL nitroglycerin (Nitrostat) tablet and notify the physician
c. Apply a nitroglycerin (Transderm-Nitro) transdermal patch instead
d. Wait 5 minutes, recheck the BP, and if elevated give the NTG (Nitrostat)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After application of a nitroglycerin (Nitrodur) patch, which of the following would be considered a common side effect?
a. "My skin itches all over"
b. "I see halos around everything"
c. "My head is pounding"
d. "I feel tired"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client is admitted with ventricular tachycardia in an emergency situation. The physician orders a bolus of lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine) followed by an IV infusion of lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine), Class I-B antidysrhythmic. Which of the following is true about this medication?
a. Lidocaine is the drug of choice for ventricular dysrhythmias
b. It seldom causes drowsiness and/or confusion
c. It is indicated in the above dysrhythmia and heart blocks
d. It can be mixed with epinephrine (Adrenalin) to slow the absorption</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After several bolus doses of lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine), a Class I-B drug, the ventricular tachycardia does not stop. The physician would probably try
a. Class I-C, encainide hydrochloride (Enkaid)
b. Class I-A, quinidine sulfate
c. Class II, esmolal hydrochloride (Brivibloc)
d. Class IV, verapamil hydrochloride (Isoptin)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>172 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="12">
<li>
<p>Which of the following is true of beta blockers?
a. They have adverse effects as orthostatic hypotension
b. They are the drugs of choice in angina
c. They increase the rate and contractility of the heart
d. They are Step 3 drugs in treating hypertension</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If a client who experiences angina abruptly stops taking a beta blocker, which of the following might be experienced?
a. Hypertension
b. Nausea
c. Lethargy
d. Acute myocardial infarction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By interrupting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, ACE inhibitors act in which of the following ways?
a. Inhibit the autonomic nervous system
b. Increase PVR
c. Increase the effect of angiotensin I
d. Decrease aldosterone release</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client on a routine office visit complains of chest pain every time he cuts the grass, yet he refuses to hire someone else to perform this task. The nurse should instruct the client to
a. Stop every 15 minutes while cutting the grass
b. Take a NTG (Nitrostat) if chest pain occurs
c. Take a NTG (Nitrostat) before cutting the grass and rest periodically
d. Take three NTG (Nitrostat) 5 minutes apart and then cut the grass</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 173</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The dilation of coronary and peripheral arteries causes the hypotensive effect. Responses <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> are not known side effects of these agents. The side effect is hypotension.</td><td>Calcium channel blockers act on the vascular system to relax smooth muscle; thus, narrow the response to either <em>c</em> or <em>d</em>. Then reread the question about side effects. With these drugs, hypotension is more of a problem than hypertension.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Diet, weight reduction, and exercise are indicated before drug therapy. The drug in response <em>a</em> is a step II drug, which should be added to step I. Response <em>b</em> is the step II phase. Adrenergic blocking agents are step III agents.</td><td>The key words are “initial treatment.” As with most other therapies a noninvasive or more natural approach is used first. Be cautious not to read too quickly and read over the diuretic in option <em>b</em>, since the other 2 items are correct.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The decrease in cardiac output lowers the BP. In response <em>a</em> the described action is true; it explains the agent’s antianginal and antiarrhythmic effect but not the HTN effect. In response <em>b</em> the description is for the function of the nitrates. Response <em>c</em> is inappropriate.</td><td>If you have narrowed the responses to <em>a</em> or <em>d</em>, reread the question. Note that the client is taking it to decrease the BP; thus response <em>d</em> is the best.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>4. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>These agents lower cholesterol and triglycerides. In responses <em>a</em>, <em>c</em>, and <em>d</em>, the agents only lower cholesterol.</td><td>If you have no idea of the correct answer cluster responses <em>a</em>, <em>c</em>, and <em>d</em> under “having an effect on cholesterol.” The only response left is <em>b</em>.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>174 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-b">5. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pulse rate indicates the negative chronotropic effect, and the increase in urine indicates the positive inotropic effect. Information in option <em>a</em> indicates a negative inotropic and positive chronotropic effect. The positive inotropic effect influences the urine output. Response <em>d</em> represents an effect directly opposite of these agents.</p>
<p>A tip to recall the definitions of inotropic and chronotropic is to identify that the action is the opposite of the beginning letter of <em>Chronotropic</em>—it is not <em>Contraction</em> but rate. Then remember that the other word is the opposite—<em>Inotropic</em> = contraction. Thus response <em>b</em>, with the lower HR, will increase cardiac output, resulting in increased urine output.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-correct-answer-c">6. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anorexia is a first indicator of toxicity. Diarrhea usually indicates toxicity. Halos around objects, disturbances in color vision, a yellow or a yellow-green tint to vision, and flickering lights are symptoms of toxicity. BP is usually not affected in digoxin toxicity.</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct answer, use the approach that most drugs cause problems with the GI tract. Narrow options to <em>a</em> and <em>c</em>. Reread each option and think that anorexia would be more of an earlier finding than constipation. Select option <em>c</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-correct-answer-d">7. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Potassium levels &lt;3.0 usually indicate a risk for toxicity. Hypokalemia is usually evident in digatilis toxicity. Sodium levels are usually not altered in digatilis toxicity. Hypomagnesemia is usually evident, along with a low serum potassium; normal magnesium is 1.5 to 2.5 mEq/L.</p>
<p>The first step to the correct answer is to recall that the electrolyte to associate with digoxin is potassium. Step two is to pick between a high or low potassium; it is the low potassium.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 175</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-correct-answer-b">8. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A form of medication other than NTG can be administered to relieve the pain; the NTG will continue to lower the BP. The second NTG will lower the BP even further. The patch has the same side effects as the SL tablet. Waiting 5 minutes with a cardiac patient with chest pain is contraindicated.</p>
<p>The critical data in the stem is that it was the “first” dose with a drastic physiologic effect, and he still has pain. The reasonable action is described in response b.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9-correct-answer-c">9. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A headache is common because of the vasodilation properties of the drug. The patch could be irritating to the skin directly under the patch, but it is not a common finding. A yellow-green halo in the vision is a sign of digitalis toxicity. Fatigue is not a common side effect of the drug, but rather a first indication of possible heart failure.</p>
<p>The important word in the question is “common” side effect. Eliminate response a because of the words “all over.” Refer to the Rationale.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-correct-answer-a">10. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lidocaine suppresses ventricular irritability and thereby stops ventricular tachycardia. Both of these findings in option b are side effects, particularly in the older adult. Lidocaine is contraindicated in heart block because of the suppressive nature of the</p>
<p>Use the true-false approach to identify the correct response.</p>
<p>176 ▼ CHAPTER 10 DRUGS AFFECTING THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>drug. Heart block could be worsened. IV lidocaine cannot be mixed with epinephrine (Adrenalin). The topical subcutaneous lidocaine injection may have epinephrine in it to cause local vasoconstriction and minimize bleeding during suturing of lacerations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="11-correct-answer-a">11. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Class I-C drugs include flecainide and encainide, which interrupt reentry and stabilize irritable tissue. Class I-A are administered PO except for pronestyl, which can also be given by IV drip. Class II drugs are beta blockers, which are indicated for ventricular dysrhythmias once they are stabilized. Class IV are calcium channel blockers which are used for controlling ventricular “rates.”</p>
<p>This type of question may increase your anxiety. The best approach is to give it your best try and go on to the next question. Expect that you will not be familiar with all the questions on the exam. Do your favorite relaxation exercise after difficult questions like this one.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="12-correct-answer-a">12.
