Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Hypotension can occur because of the decrease in cardiac output, which lowers BP. Nitrates are the drugs of choice in angina. Beta blockers lower the heart rate and are step 2 drugs in treating hypertension.</p>
<p>You may have narrowed the responses to either a or d. Use the approach to go with what you know and select response a rather than d.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="13-correct-answer-d">13. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>If abruptly stopped, the angina could return and cause a heart attack. Hypertension could occur, but this would</p>
<p>The approach here is to go with what you know: angina frequently precedes myocardial infarction. Select response d.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 177</p>
<p>not be the main concern unless the medication were taken for hypertension. In response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> these adverse effects are not common with beta blocker withdrawal. Response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> is not a common withdrawal effect of these agents.</p>
<ol start="14">
<li>Correct answer: d</li>
</ol>
<p>A decrease in aldosterone release causes an increase in the excretion of Na and water and a decrease in preload. The autonomic nervous system is not involved with ACE inhibitors. ACE inhibitors do not directly affect preload. The ACE inhibitors inhibit the effect of angiotensin I.</p>
<p>A close reading reveals that responses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> contradict this information and are thus incorrect. Next make an educated guess that response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> is correct, since this drug has specific target sites and does not involve an entire system. Refer to Box 12-2.</p>
<ol start="15">
<li>Correct answer: c</li>
</ol>
<p>Since NTG is not habit forming, taking the agent to prevent angina could help the client perform the task in combination with appropriately spaced rest periods. Short rest periods in option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> would be advisable but may not by themselves relieve the angina. This action in option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> treats the pain, but prevention of angina is the better action. Three NTG may not be indicated or needed for the prevention of angina. Clients have individual needs established over time.</p>
<p>Cluster options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> as single actions. Select option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> which combines choices from the other selections.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>179</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-renal-system">Drugs Affecting the Renal System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-renal-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Differentiate between the various groups of diuretic agents.</li>
<li>Identify the action and major side effects of diuretic agents.</li>
<li>Discuss nursing implications concerning clients taking diuretic agents.</li>
</ul>
<p>CHAPTER
11</p>
<p>180 ▼ CHAPTER 11 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RENAL SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Diuretic</strong>
A drug that promotes diuresis, the formation and excretion of urine.</p>
<p><strong>Edema</strong>
The abnormal accumulation of fluid in interstitial spaces of tissues.</p>
<p><strong>Pitting edema</strong>—most common bilaterally in the feet and ankles from right-sided heart failure or unilaterally from venous congestion or blockage of lymphatic vessels from malignant diseases.</p>
<p><strong>Anasarca</strong>—a generalized, massive edema often observed with renal disease or low serum albumin levels when fluid retention continues for an extended period of time.</p>
<p><strong>Periorbital edema</strong>—edema located in the area surrounding the socket of the eye, and is most commonly an initial sign in children with nephrosis, also called nephrotic syndrome.</p>
<p><strong>Hyperkalemia</strong>
Serum potassium levels &gt;5.0 mEq/L; a major threat in renal failure or with the diuretic, aldactone, which inhibits the function of aldosterone to reabsorb sodium in the distal renal tubule. Consequently sodium is lost into the urine and potassium is reabsorbed into the blood stream.</p>
<p><strong>Hyperpyrexia</strong>
An extremely high temperature elevation, which can occur in acute infections, especially in the kidney infections of pediatric clients.</p>
<p><strong>Hypochloremic alkalosis</strong>
A metabolic disorder resulting from increased blood bicarbonate secondary to the loss of chloride from the body; not uncommon in diuretic therapy with lasix or bumex.</p>
<p><strong>Hypokalemia</strong>
A serum potassium level &lt;3.5 mEq/L.</p>
<p><strong>Hypomagnesemia</strong>
A serum magnesium level &lt;1.5 mEq/L; both low potassium and magnesium are major threats with thiazide diuretics, Hydrochlorothiazide (Hydrodiuril), or loop diuretics, furosimide (Lasix), bumetanide (Bumex); if client is hypomagnesemic and hypokalemic and on digoxin, an increased risk of digoxin toxicity occurs.</p>
<p><strong>Renal failure</strong>
Inability of the kidneys to excrete wastes, concentrate urine, and conserve electrolytes. The diagnostic test is an elevated serum creatinine level.</p>
<p>DIURETICS: THIAZIDE, THIAZIDE-LIKE AGENTS ▼ 181</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diuretics">DIURETICS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diuretics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-major-classifications">I. Major classifications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-major-classifications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Thiazide and thiazide-like agents
B. Loop diuretics
C. Potassium sparing
D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
E. Osmotic agents</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-thiazide-and-thiazide-like-agents">II. Thiazide and thiazide-like agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-thiazide-and-thiazide-like-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit sodium and chloride reabsorption in the distal tubule and lower peripheral vascular resistance (PVR)</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypertension</li>
<li>Edematous states associated with the following
a. Congestive heart failure (CHF)
b. Pregnancy
c. Kidney failure
d. Liver disease</li>
<li>Decreased urine output in diabetics</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Orthostatic hypotension</li>
<li>Electrolyte imbalance: hypokalemia</li>
<li>Anorexia, nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Glucose intolerance: high glucose levels</li>
<li>Dry mouth, thirst</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions</p>
<ol>
<li>Decreased excretion of lithium, which could cause toxicity</li>
<li>Increased dysrhythmias with digitalis in the presence of hypokalemia</li>
<li>Increased potassium loss with corticosteroids and some penicillins</li>
<li>Orthostatic hypotension if taken with alcohol or other antihypertensives</li>
<li>Hyponatremia and hyperglycemia, which may be caused by oral hypoglycemics and insulin</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>See general nursing implications at the end of this chapter</li>
<li>Check for allergies to sulfonamides</li>
</ol>
<p>182 ▼ CHAPTER 11 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RENAL SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Monitor glucose and potassium levels</li>
<li>Monitor closely in the presence of renal or liver dysfunction</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>F. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Chlorothiazide (Diuril)—clue: remember, <em>Diuril</em> acts in the <em>distal tubule</em></li>
<li>Hydrochlorothiazide (Esidrix, HydroDiuril)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>II. Loop diuretics (potent diuretics)</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Actions:</strong> block the reabsorption of Na in the loop of Henle, the ascending loop where the greatest Na reabsorption normally occurs; also reduce preload and afterload</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Edema: congestive heart failure, renal or hepatic dysfunction</li>
<li>Hypertension (HTN)</li>
<li>Whenever a more potent diuretic is needed</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Increased electrolyte depletion because of potency</li>
<li>Excessive diuresis (urination), which could lead to circulatory collapse</li>
<li>High doses: transient hearing loss, abdominal pain</li>
<li>Leukopenia: abnormal decrease in white blood cells to &lt;5000/cm³</li>
<li>Thrombocytopenia: reduction in platelets to &lt;150,000/mm³</li>
<li>Postural hypotension</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Interactions</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Hypotension with alcohol</li>
<li>Toxicity with lithium</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding with anticoagulants</li>
<li>Toxicity with digitalis</li>
<li>Hyponatremia with oral hypoglycemics</li>
<li>Hypotension with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>See general nursing implications at the end of this chapter</li>
<li>Schedule the last dose early enough to prevent nocturia</li>
<li>Avoid if client becomes anuric</li>
<li>Assess for allergy to sulfonamides</li>
<li>Give IM route by Z-track method because of pain at injection site</li>
<li>Teach the client to do the following
a. Consume K⁺ rich foods (Box 11-1)
b. Report muscle cramps, which are usually in calves of legs (especially at night)
c. Take tablets that change color, since they are still effective</li>
</ol>
<p>DIURETICS: LOOP, POTASSIUM SPARING ▼ 183</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Assess for signs of dehydration, especially in older adults</li>
<li>Caution client about switching brands without physician consent; this may change bioavailability and the clinical effects</li>
</ol>
<p>F. <strong>Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Furosemide (Lasix); clue: <em>Lasix—remember loop diuretic and the way it acts in ascending loop</em></li>
<li>Ethacrylate sodium (Edecrin)</li>
<li>Bumetanide (Bumex)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-potassium-sparing-agents">IV. Potassium sparing agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-potassium-sparing-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit the pump mechanism that normally exchanges potassium for sodium in the distal convoluted tubule. Spironolactone (Aldactone) antagonizes aldosterone, which mediates Na⁺ and K⁺ exchange. This mechanism reduces Na reabsorption while retaining K⁺. The other drugs within this class produce the same effects as spironolactone (Aldactone) but do not depend on aldosterone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-11-1-dietary-consideration-potassium-sources">Box 11-1. Dietary Consideration: Potassium Sources<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-11-1-dietary-consideration-potassium-sources" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some drugs, especially the loop and thiazide diuretics, steroids, amphotericin B, cause excessive loss of potassium, resulting in hypokalemia which may go unnoticed but in severe cases may contribute to toxicity from other drugs, as well as cardiac toxicity. Good dietary sources of Potassium include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Citrus fruits and juices</li>
<li>Bananas, watermelon</li>
<li>Grape, cranberry, apple, pear, and apricot juices</li>
<li>Cereals</li>
<li>Leafy vegetables</li>
<li>Meat, fish, and fowl</li>
<li>Salt substitutes (read label)</li>
<li>Coffee, tea, and cola beverages</li>
<li>Nuts and Peanut butter</li>
</ul>
<p>Some sources of potassium may be contraindicated in persons who must also limit sodium intake. Licorice can cause potassium excretion and should be avoided by patients experiencing hypokalemia.</p>
<p>Clark J, Queener, S, &amp; Karb V: <em>Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice</em>, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.</p>
<p>184 ▼ CHAPTER 11 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RENAL SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Edema</li>
<li>Diuretic-induced hypokalemia</li>
<li>Hyperaldosteronism: hypersecretion of aldosterone</li>
<li>Steroid-induced edema</li>
<li>In combination with other potassium-losing diuretics</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Hyperkalemia if used alone and with high-potassium diet or potassium supplements</li>
<li>Hypotension</li>
<li>GI upset: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramps</li>
<li>Weakness, fatigue</li>
<li>Paresthesia of hands and feet; numbness or tingling</li>
<li>Megaloblastic anemia</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-interactions">D. Interactions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-interactions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Hyperkalemia with K⁺ supplements</li>
<li>Toxicity with lithium</li>
<li>Nephrotoxicity with indocin</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>See general nursing implications at the end of this chapter</li>
<li>Teach that high-potassium diet is contraindicated</li>
<li>Monitor other medications for potassium sources</li>
<li>Frequently monitor complete blood count (CBC)</li>
<li>Teach the client the symptoms of hyperkalemia and to report these as soon as noticed</li>
<li>Keep tablets stored in a dark container</li>
<li>Assess K⁺ levels closely if patient is receiving blood. Blood can contain &gt;30 mEq of K⁺/liter when stored.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Spironolactone (Aldactone)</li>
<li>Amiloride hydrochloride (Midamor)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-carbonic-anhydrase-inhibitors-weak-diuretics">V. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (weak diuretics)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-carbonic-anhydrase-inhibitors-weak-diuretics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="13fed927">A. Actions: inhibit the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which prevents the secretion of hydrogen ions and causes an alkaline urine. The Na⁺ is excreted along with the bicarbonate.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13fed927" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Glaucoma: lower intraocular pressure (internal pressure of the eye)</li>
<li>Edema</li>
<li>Premenstrual control</li>
<li>To alkalinize the urine in overdose</li>
<li>As anticonvulsant</li>
</ol>
<p>DIURETICS: CARBONIC ANHYDRASE INHIBITORS, OSMOTICS ▼ 185</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Electrolyte imbalance</li>
<li>Hemolytic anemia</li>
<li>Frequent moderate headaches</li>
<li>Nervousness, depression, malaise</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting, anorexia</li>
<li>Hyperglycemia</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-interactions-are-limited-but-include-increased-effect-of-amphetamines-and-toxicity-of-salicylates">D. Interactions are limited but include increased effect of amphetamines and toxicity of salicylates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-interactions-are-limited-but-include-increased-effect-of-amphetamines-and-toxicity-of-salicylates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>See general nursing implications at the end of this chapter</li>
<li>Assess for allergy to sulfonamides</li>
<li>Monitor glucose, electrolytes, and CBC levels</li>
<li>Do not mix with fruit juices; use honey or syrup to disguise the bitter taste</li>
<li>Avoid IM due to pain</li>
<li>Administer with antacids to lower GI distress</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="f-common-drug-acetazolamide-diamox">F. Common drug: acetazolamide (Diamox)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drug-acetazolamide-diamox" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-osmotics">VI. Osmotics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-osmotics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-action-increase-osmotic-pressure-which-decreases-water-reabsorption">A. Action: increase osmotic pressure, which decreases water reabsorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-increase-osmotic-pressure-which-decreases-water-reabsorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Prevent oliguria in acute renal failure</li>
<li>Lower intracranial pressure in Cerebral edema</li>
<li>Lower intraocular pressure</li>
<li>Lower pressure in cerebral spinal fluid</li>
<li>Treat certain drug intoxications</li>
<li>Emergency management of any of the above</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Transient expansion of plasma volume, which can lead to circulatory overload; increased blood volume, which can lead to heart failure or pulmonary edema</li>
<li>Rebound intracranial pressure 8 to 12 hours after initial diuresis</li>
<li>Irritation at IV site, including sloughing of tissue</li>
<li>Headache (cerebral dehydration)</li>
<li>Thrombophlebitis: inflammation of a vein</li>
<li>Electrolyte imbalance</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Contraindication with acute renal failure, CHF, intracranial hemorrhage, pregnancy, or severe dehydration</li>
<li>Monitor urinary output closely: should be &gt;50 ml/hr with therapy</li>
<li>Monitor electrolytes and blood urea nitrogen (BUN)</li>
</ol>
<p>186 ▼ CHAPTER 11 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RENAL SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Assess IV site frequently during administration; avoid extravasation</li>
<li>Warm mannitol (Osmitrol) vial or bottle under hot water and shake vigorously if crystallized</li>
<li>Do not mix with blood products or other drugs</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Mannitol (Osmitrol)</li>
<li>Isosorbide (Ismotic)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="vii-general-nursing-implications-for-all-diuretics">VII. General nursing implications for all diuretics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-general-nursing-implications-for-all-diuretics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Assess weight (gain or loss) at the same time each day in the same clothes
B. Monitor I&amp;O carefully
C. Monitor food consumption and offer instructions according to K⁺ rich or K⁺ sparing foods (see Box 11-1)
D. Avoid all alcohol products because of diuretic effect and lowering of BP
E. Assess for findings of hypokalemia and hyperkalemia. Monitor electrolyte levels.
F. Administer early in the day to avoid nocturia (9 A.M. and 5 P.M. if ordered BID)
G. Limit Na⁺ if used for hypertension
H. Monitor pulse and BP; caution client about rising too abruptly to avoid orthostatic hypotension
I. Instruct the client in the signs of decreasing effectiveness: weight gain, edema, coughing
J. Instruct client to take with or after meals if GI distress occurs. Caution the client that nausea and vomiting may be indicative of electrolyte disturbance.
K. Diuretics are sometimes abused by overweight clients
L. Older adults may need lower doses and dietary counseling, as well as accurate assessment of BP and electrolytes</p>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 187</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Administering furosemide (Lasix), a loop diuretic, too fast IVP could result in which of the following?
a. Hypertension
b. Permanent hearing loss
c. Transient hearing loss
d. Hyperkalemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>While on a potassium sparing diuretic—spironolactone (Aldactone)—a client should be instructed to avoid which foods?
a. Bananas, meat, peanut butter
b. Fish, red beans, bread
c. Carrots, green beans, apple juice
d. Tomato juice, potatoes, beets</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When a client received a daily Aldactone and 3 units of packed red blood cells (RBC), the nurse would be most concerned with which of the following?
a. Potassium level of 2.3 mEq/L
b. Magnesium level of 1.5 mEq/L
c. Sodium level of 145 mEq/L
d. Potassium level of 5.8 mEq/L</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client, age 39, is diagnosed with glaucoma and can no longer drive his eighteen wheeler. His physician would most likely place him on which of the following diuretics?
a. Thiazide: hydrochlorothiazide (Hydrodiuril)
b. Loop: bumetanide (Bumex)
c. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor: acetazolamide (Diamox)
d. Potassium sparing: spironolactone (Aldactone)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When preparing to give mannitol (Osmotrol), the nurse notices crystals in the ampule. The nurse should
a. Return the ampule to the pharmacy
b. Hold the ampule under cold tap water
c. Hold the ampule under warm tap water
d. Shake vigorously</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>188 ▼ CHAPTER 11 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RENAL SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Temporary hearing loss may be experienced. Hearing loss is a temporary side effect and may be due to a high dose or if administered too fast. Postural hypotension is a side effect. Hypokalemia is a side effect.</td><td>An approach is to cluster responses <em>a</em> and <em>d</em> under “Hyper” and eliminate. Then decide between responses <em>b</em> and <em>c</em>. Select response <em>c</em> based on knowledge that effects of drugs are more commonly transient than permanent.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: a</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>All these foods are high in potassium. In response <em>b</em> only fish is high in potassium. In response <em>c</em> only apple juice is high in potassium. Tomato juice is high in sodium and potassium.</td><td><em>Go with what you know.</em> If you only identified that bananas and peanut butter are high in potassium, select that response. It is not advisable to select a response you do not know much about.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Potassium is not lost while a client is on a potassium-sparing diuretic, and stored blood can be high in potassium. Both the drug and the blood would raise the potassium level; aldactone is the potassium-sparing diuretic. Magnesium level should not be affected. Sodium level should not be affected.</td><td><em>Go with what you know:</em> the more units of blood given, the higher the risk of increasing potassium. Add to that the type of medication, and there is double jeopardy for the client.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>4. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are used primarily to lower intraocular pressure in</td><td>An approach is to cluster responses <em>a</em>, <em>b</em>, and <em>d</em> under “common diuretics for heart failure or fluid</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 189</p>
<p>glaucoma. Thiazides are not recommended for glaucoma. Loop diuretics are extremely potent and not recommended for glaucoma. Aldactone is not recommended for glaucoma.</p>
<p>overload”; the one left, option c, must be used for the eyes.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Correct answer: c</li>
</ol>
<p>Warm tap water will dissolve the crystals so the drug can be used. Crystals form in the syringe while the drug is stored. The nurse can easily prepare the medicine. Cold water will not dissolve the crystals. Shaking the syringe will not dissolve the crystals.</p>
<p>An approach is to use common sense as to what dissolves substances. If in an emergency situation, get another ampule without crystals from pharmacy. Returning the ampule to pharmacy is an incomplete answer. Avoid reading into the response that option a also means to obtain a new ampule.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>191</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-hematologic-system">Drugs Affecting the Hematologic System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-hematologic-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the groups of drugs that affect coagulation and anemia.</li>
<li>Describe specific actions of anticoagulants and thrombolytics.</li>
<li>Describe nursing implications for safe administration of these agents.</li>
<li>Identify hematinic agents used to treat anemia.</li>
</ul>
<p>192 ▼ CHAPTER 12 DRUGS AFFECTING THE HEMATOLOGIC SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (APTT)</strong>
A test for detecting coagulation defects of the intrinsic system; used to monitor <strong>heparin</strong> activity.</p>
<p><strong>Anticoagulant</strong>
A substance that prevents or delays coagulation of the blood, such as Heparin. Heparin interferes with: (1) the formation of thromboplastin, the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin and (2) the formation of fibrin from fibrinogen. Coumarin—a Vitamin K antagonist, inhibits the formation of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.</p>
<p><strong>Hematuria</strong>
The abnormal presence of blood in the urine, which may occur with too high of doses of anticoagulants.</p>
<p><strong>Hemophilia</strong>
A group of hereditary bleeding disorders in which there is a deficiency in one of the factors necessary for coagulation of blood. Hemophilia A (classic) is a deficiency or absence of factor VIII; Hemophilia B (Christmas disease) is a deficiency of the thromboplastin component.</p>
<p><strong>Hemorrhage</strong>
Loss of a large amount of blood in a short period of time, either internal or external, and from arterial, venous, or capillary sites.</p>
<p><strong>Hemostatic</strong>
Pertaining to a procedure or substance that arrests the flow of blood.</p>
<p><strong>Prothrombin Time (PT)</strong>
A test for detecting plasma coagulation defects caused by a deficiency of factors V, VII, and X; used to monitor <strong>coumarin</strong> activity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="anticoagulants">ANTICOAGULANTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-oral-anticoagulants">I. Oral anticoagulants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-oral-anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit blood clotting by depressing synthesis of factors VII, IX, X, thereby preventing utilization of vitamin K by the liver</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Slow down or prevent the extension of a blood clot
a. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
b. Pulmonary embolism</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTICOAGULANTS: ORAL ▼ 193</p>
<p>c. Coronary artery disease (CAD)
d. Atrial fibrillation
e. Cardiovascular thrombosis</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Rheumatic heart disease</li>
<li>Prophylactically
a. Major surgery
b. Periods of prolonged immobilization when coagulation complications are possible</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Greater incidence of bleeding than with parenteral anticoagulants
a. Hematuria: blood in the urine
b. Epistaxis: nose bleed
c. Ecchymosis: bruising
d. Tarry stools: black, sticky
e. Bleeding gums</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Leukopenia, agranulocytosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypersensitivity</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>GI upset: diarrhea, nausea, vomiting</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions</p>
<ol>
<li>Increased effect with glucocorticoids, acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin), alcohol, and antibiotics</li>
<li>Decreased effect with barbiturates, estrogens, and oral contraceptives</li>
<li>Contraindicated in pregnancy or conditions in which hemorrhage is possible</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Assess for bleeding</li>
<li>Monitor the prothrombin time (PT), which is normally 11 to 12.5 seconds. The PT can be maintained at 1.5 to 2.0 times the control for a therapeutic effect; for example, a range from 18 to 26 seconds is therapeutic. A physician may adjust the dose to maintain the PT at 2.0 to 2.5 times the control to reach the desired results of the agent. Careful monitoring for bleeding is necessary when the PT values are greater than 2.0 times the control. Note that each laboratory has established controls.</li>
<li>Give by mouth only; may be started while parenteral form is infusing. Use extreme caution to monitor for bleeding. Takes 2 to 3 days to reach therapeutic levels.</li>
<li>Instruct the clients to do the following
a. Protect themselves from excessive bruising or cuts. Use an electric razor and a soft toothbrush.</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 12 DRUGS AFFECTING THE HEMATOLOGIC SYSTEM</p>
<p>b. Wear a medical alert bracelet
c. Consult a physician before taking any OTC drugs
d. Avoid foods high in vitamin K such as green leafy vegetables, tomatoes, fish, liver, cheese, egg yolks, and red meats. A food-to-drug interaction could occur and increase the coagulation due to a decrease in the drug's effectiveness.
e. Avoid acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin and aspirin products)
f. Report any excess bruising, red urine, tarry stools
g. Take bleeding precautions for 9 to 10 days after the last dose of the drug</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Have vitamin K (AquaMephyton) available as an antidote. Vitamin K activates the precursors in the liver needed for clotting.</li>
<li>Monitor the client's medication record sheet for the following
a. Acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) and aspirin products. Pay particular attention to pain relievers.
b. Avoid IM injections if possible. If used, hold pressure for several minutes after the injection.</li>
<li>Since anticoagulants are highly protein bound, if a therapeutic effect is not seen, closely observe the other medications prescribed or the client's protein level</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Warfarin sodium (Coumadin)</li>
<li>Dicumarol (Bishydroxycoumarin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-parenteral-anticoagulants">II. Parenteral anticoagulants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-parenteral-anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Action: combine with antithrombin III to retard thrombin activity
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Short-term or emergency treatment</li>
<li>All of the situations listed for oral anticoagulants</li>
<li>Myocardial infarction (MI)</li>
<li>Postcoronary artery bypass surgery</li>
<li>Hemodialysis</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Hemorrhage (same as with oral products)</li>
<li>Heparin-induced thrombosis: white clot syndrome</li>
<li>Thrombocytopenia: decreased platelets &lt;150,000/mm³</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions</p>
<ol>
<li>Increased effect with acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin), alcohol, antibiotics</li>
<li>Decreased effect with nitroglycerin products, digoxin (Lanoxin), antihistamines</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTICOAGULANTS: PARENTERAL; THROMBOLYTICS ▼ 195</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Contraindicated in ulcers or situations threatening hemorrhage, liver, and renal disease</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Assess for bleeding</li>
<li>Know proper application for SC or IV route</li>
<li>Always keep continuous IV administration on a controller pump</li>
<li>Monitor the activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), which is normally 30 to 40 seconds. Should be maintained at 1.5 to 2.0 times the control for a therapeutic effect; for example, a therapeutic range is from 60 to 80.</li>
<li>Rotate sites for SC; do not rub the injection site</li>
<li>Let other disciplines know that patient is taking heparin</li>
<li>Have protamine sulfate available as an antidote</li>
<li>Instruct the client to avoid falls or abrasions to the skin, and to use caution with sharp utensils while eating. The physician should be consulted concerning the use of razors. Usually electric or battery-operated razors are preferred.</li>
<li>Monitor the medication record (same as with oral products)</li>
<li>Monitor the complete blood count (CBC)</li>
<li>Instruct the patient to report any signs of bleeding</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drug: heparin sodium (Liquaemin)</p>
<p>THROMBOLYTIC AGENTS</p>
<p>I. Thrombolytic agents
A. Actions: dissolve the clot by converting plasminogen to plasmin, which lyses the thrombi and fibrinogen
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Acute thromboembolic disorders</li>
<li>Pulmonary embolus</li>
<li>Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)</li>
<li>Myocardial infarction (MI)</li>
<li>Arterial or coronary thrombosis</li>
<li>Thrombi in parenteral cannulas
C. Major side effects</li>
<li>Hemorrhage</li>
<li>Allergic reaction: usually with streptokinase only</li>
<li>Febrile reaction</li>
<li>Dysrhythmias and chest pain</li>
<li>Reocclusion: occlusion of a vessel that had been opened
D. Interactions: increased tendency to bleed with any drug that alters coagulation or platelets. Contraindicated in</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 12 DRUGS AFFECTING THE HEMATOLOGIC SYSTEM</p>
<p>hemophilia, intracranial disorders, recent gastrointestinal bleeds, uncontrolled hypertension, high-risk situations for hemorrhage, or clients who bruise easily.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Monitor bleeding closely, especially during the loading dose period</li>
<li>Know how to mix properly for IV administration. Many of these agents are expensive. IV bags that are mixed should be used within 24 hours. Carefully calculate the dosage.</li>
<li>Administer with a controller pump, minidrip, and filter</li>
<li>Alert all other disciplines that these agents were infused; post sign on client door, on chart, or over bed if possible</li>
<li>Check with physician about all acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) and aspirin products</li>
<li>Monitor the PT, APTT, and CBC</li>
<li>Assess the client for reperfusion dysrhythmias; reoccurrence of angina may indicate reocclusion</li>
<li>Hold excess pressure for 5 to 10 minutes on all discontinued IV sites</li>
<li>Have the antifibrinoltic agent—aminocaproic acid (Amicar)—available as an antidote</li>
<li>Follow same safety measures for the client as with anticoagulants</li>
<li>Monitor the client carefully for hemorrhage for 24 to 48 hours. These agents have a short half-life, but bleeding risk may persist for 24 hours after infusion.</li>
<li>Know that Benadryl or Solu-Cortef may be given before streptokinase to prevent allergic reactions</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Streptokinase (Streptase)</li>
<li>Alteplase (Activase), known as t-PA</li>
<li>Urokinase (Abbokinase)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-agents">OTHER AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-antiplatelet-agents">I. Antiplatelet agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-antiplatelet-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Actions: interfere or inhibit the adherence of platelets to exposed collagen at sites of vascular injury; hinders platelet aggregation</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Cerebral vascular accidents (CVA)</li>
<li>Myocardial infarction</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Side effects differ and are specific to the drug</p>
<p>ANTIPLATELET, HEMOSTATIC, AND HEMATINIC (IRON PRODUCTS) AGENTS ▼ 197</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-common-drugs">D. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Acetylsalicylic acid (Aspirin)</li>
<li>Dipyridamole (Persantine)</li>
<li>Ticlopidine (Ticlid)</li>
<li>Sulfinpyrazone (Anturane)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-hemostatic-agents">II. Hemostatic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-hemostatic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-actions-hasten-clotting-of-blood-by-inhibiting-the-substances-that-activate-plasminogen-and-inhibit-plasmin">A. Actions: hasten clotting of blood by inhibiting the substances that activate plasminogen and inhibit plasmin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions-hasten-clotting-of-blood-by-inhibiting-the-substances-that-activate-plasminogen-and-inhibit-plasmin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Stop bleeding during surgery</li>
<li>Stop bleeding in emergencies</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects-minimal-and-depend-on-whether-used-topically-or-systemically-hypotension-is-the-most-common">C. Major side effects: minimal and depend on whether used topically or systemically. Hypotension is the most common.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects-minimal-and-depend-on-whether-used-topically-or-systemically-hypotension-is-the-most-common" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-nursing-implications-depend-on-the-agent">D. Nursing implications: depend on the agent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications-depend-on-the-agent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Know how to administer or mix the drug</li>
<li>Assess for cessation of bleeding</li>
<li>Some agents may be left in the wound (Gelfoam) and are self-absorbing. Others will not absorb (oxidized cellulose).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Vitamin K (AquaMephyton)</li>
<li>Aminocaproic acid (Amicar)</li>
<li>Gelfoam, Gelfilm: absorbable gelatin sponge or film</li>
<li>Thrombin (Thrombostat)</li>
<li>Oxidized cellulose (Surgicel)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hematinic-agents">HEMATINIC AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hematinic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-iron-products">I. Iron products<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-iron-products" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-actions-replace-the-depleted-iron-stores-and-raise-the-iron-in-hemoglobin">A. Actions: replace the depleted iron stores and raise the iron in hemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions-replace-the-depleted-iron-stores-and-raise-the-iron-in-hemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Iron deficiency anemia</li>
<li>Premature infants</li>
<li>Pregnant females</li>
<li>Lactating females</li>
<li>Bleeding disorders</li>
<li>Menses with heavy blood loss</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>GI upset (most common): anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation</li>
<li>Dark, tarry stools—black or dark-green</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 12 DRUGS AFFECTING THE HEMATOLOGIC SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Potential for staining of the teeth and the skin with administration</li>
<li>Iron poisoning in children: vomiting, bloody diarrhea, cyanosis, gastric and intestinal pain</li>
<li>Pain and soreness if given IM</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions</p>
<ol>
<li>Increased absorption with ascorbic acid (vitamin C)</li>
<li>Decreased absorption with antacids, tetracyclines, milk</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>If given IM, use Z-track method. Intramuscular injections can stain the skin and be extremely painful.</li>
<li>Take PO form before or after eating</li>
<li>Instruct client on foods high in iron. Refer to nursing implications under vitamin  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>12</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_{12}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">12</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Sip iron liquids through a straw to prevent staining teeth</li>
<li>Instruct client about bloody stools, which are abnormal. Darker, tarry stools are normal.</li>
<li>Monitor a complete blood count (CBC)</li>
<li>Teach clients the symptoms of accidental poisoning: lethargy, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, convulsions, pallor, or cyanosis</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Ferrous sulfate (Feosol, Fer-Iron)</li>
<li>Ferrous gluconate (Fergon)</li>
<li>Iron dextran (Imferon)</li>
<li>Ferrous fumarate (Feostat)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3171e7c3">II. Hydroxocobalamin (vitamin  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>12</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_{12}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">12</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> )<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3171e7c3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: replaces  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>12</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_{12}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">12</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  not found in diet. Essential for cell growth and the nervous system.
B. Uses: treats megaloblastic anemia—a hemolytic disorder characterized by the production and peripheral proliferation of immature, large, dysfunctional erythrocytes; these megaloblasts are usually associated with severe pernicious anemia or folic acid deficiency anemia
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypersensitivity</li>
<li>Hematologic reactions</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Available in injectable form only because gastrointestinal absorption depends on an intrinsic factor in the gastric mucosa</li>
<li>Monitor folate levels; large doses mask folate deficiency</li>
</ol>
<p>HEMATINICS: VITAMIN B₁₂ AND B₉ (FOLIC ACID) ▼ 199</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Stress compliance: monthly injections are usually required for life</li>
<li>Dietary teaching
a. Consume foods high in iron if intrinsic factor available from parietal cells in stomach: egg yolks, wheat germ, fish, fowl, cereal grains, beans, and green leafy vegetables
b. Avoid foods low in iron: milk, vegetables that are not green and leafy</li>
<li>Should be used cautiously in pregnant and lactating females</li>
<li>Cimetidine (Tagamet) impairs absorption</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="52704e58">III. Folic acid (vitamin B₆)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#52704e58" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: required for normal erythrocyte production and growth
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Folic acid anemia (megaloblastic anemia)</li>
<li>Prophylactically
a. Pregnancy
b. Alcoholism
c. Renal disease
d. Liver disease
C. Major side effect: allergic responses
D. Interactions: decreased metabolism with anticonvulsants or contraceptives
E. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Dietary teaching</li>
<li>Monitoring for B₁₂ deficiency, which may be masked</li>
</ol>
<p>200 ♥ CHAPTER 12 DRUGS AFFECTING THE HEMATOLOGIC SYSTEM</p>
