<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A client is on warfarin sodium (Coumadin) every day at 9 A.M. Her laboratory work comes back with her PT four times the control. The nurse notices that the client's laboratory work was within normal limits the day before. The nurse's first action would be to
a. Call the physician
b. Call the physician and prepare vitamin K
c. Check when the laboratory work was drawn
d. Call the laboratory to draw another level</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client has heparin sodium (Liquaemin) infusing IV for a deep vein thrombosis. The physician orders the dose to be lowered and starts him on warfarin sodium (Coumadin) 5 mg PO q day. Why should the nurse be concerned about bleeding?
a. Heparin sodium (Liquaemin) is a potent anticoagulant, and bleeding potential is high
b. Warfarin sodium (Coumadin) has a greater risk of bleeding than heparin sodium (Liquaemin) does
c. The warfarin sodium (Coumadin) dose is too high
d. Heparin sodium (Liquaemin) has a short half-life, but the bleeding tendencies last beyond the half-life</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At 4 A.M., a client, who is on a heparin drip and has the initial dose of Coumadin given at 5 P.M. the previous day, notices oozing of blood from the IV site and at the site where the lab drew blood at 7 A.M. the previous day. The nurse would expect the physician to order which of the following?
a. Aminocaproic acid (Amicar)
b. Protamine sulfate
c. Vitamin K (AquaMephyton)
d. Hydroxocobalamin (vitamin B₁₂)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client is diagnosed with a coronary thrombosis after a heart catheterization. The physician plans to infuse alteplase (t-PA) to prevent a myocardial infarction. This medicine exerts its fibrinolytic action by
a. Preventing the utilization of vitamin K
b. Retarding the extension of the clot
c. Using hemostatic action
d. Retarding thrombin formation and lysing the clot</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 201</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Discharge instructions for a client going home on warfarin sodium (Coumadin) 10 mg PO q day would be which of the following?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Eat plenty of foods rich in vitamin K
b. If bruising is noted, stop taking the medicine and call the physician
c. Wear a medical alert bracelet and use caution with sharp instruments
d. Report to the physician as ordered for a CBC</p>
<p>CHAPTER 12 DRUGS AFFECTING THE HEMATOLOGIC SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The lab work could have been drawn after the 9 A.M. dose, especially since the value for the previous day was normal. A registered nurse would be expected to investigate the time the lab work was drawn. The physician would need to be notified if this value was drawn at the proper time. Vitamin K would be needed if bleeding were to occur. The nurse would first need to check with the physician prior to any medication change.</td><td>An approach to the evaluation of serum levels after medication administration is to investigate when the blood sample was drawn in relation to when the medication was given. Select response c.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Coumadin does have a greater potential for bleeding than heparin. Also, the coumadin dose will be increased while the heparin dose is decreased. Response a is correct; however, note that the heparin dose is being lowered. In response c the dose is correct. Response d's statement is correct for thrombolytic agents, not anticoagulants.</td><td>Key information in the stem is that the heparin dose has been lowered; eliminate response a. Response d is false for heparin. In deciding between responses b and c, if you are not certain about the dose of coumadin, go with response b, which seems reasonable.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>This is the antidote for heparin therapy, which he has been</td><td>Make an educated guess. The heparin has been given the</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 203</p>
<p>on for a longer period of time. Both agents would probably be stopped for a period of time. Response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> is the antidote for thrombolytic agents. Only 1 dose has been given of the coumadin, which has peak action from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\frac{1}{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span> to 3 days. It's too early for Coumadin to have peaked. In response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> this agent does not correct bleeding tendencies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-correct-answer-d">4. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Thrombolytics dissolve or lyse clots. Response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> is the action of oral anticoagulants. Response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> is the action of parenteral anticoagulants. Hemostatic agents hasten the clotting of blood.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-c">5. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A medic-alert bracelet is needed in case of an emergency. Cuts could cause bleeding problems and safety is needed. In option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>, a food-to-drug interaction could occur, as could increased clotting. The client should notify the physician before completely stopping the agent. A reduced dose may be all that is necessary. A visit to the physician would probably be for a PT or APTT.</p>
<p>longest, so select the antidote for it, response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Refer to the Rationale. Also, use the approach go with what you know—for coronary thrombosis the lysing of the clot is most important; select option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Narrow the options to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> by the true-false approach to eliminate options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>. Reread options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>. Note the key words “stop taking the medicine” in option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>; physicians should be notified prior to “stopping medicine.” Select option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>Drugs Affecting the Immune System
CHAPTER 13</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the difference between agents that offer passive and active immunity.</li>
<li>Describe the clinical application of various immunity agents.</li>
<li>Identify assessments needed in administering immunizations.</li>
<li>Identify immunosuppressive and immunomodulating agents.</li>
</ul>
<p>205</p>
<p>CHAPTER 13 DRUGS AFFECTING THE IMMUNE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Antitoxins
A subgroup of antisera such as botulism, tetanus, and diphtheria antitoxins; injected they confer passive immunity.</p>
<p>Antivenin
A suspension of venom-neutralizing antibodies that confers passive immunity and is given as part of emergency first aid for various snake and insect bites.</p>
<p>Attenuated vaccine
A vaccine made from a strain of virus whose virulence has been lowered by a physical or chemical process. It is used to prevent tuberculosis, small pox, measles, mumps, rubella, polio, and yellow fever. DTP (Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis); MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) vaccine; OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine).</p>
<p>HBV (hepatitis B vaccine)
A genetically engineered vaccine produced in yeast cells by recombinant DNA technology.</p>
<p>Hib (haemophilus influenzae) vaccine
A vaccine given to children at 24 months. Hib is a gram-negative bacterium found in the throats of 30% of normal, healthy people, yet it can cause bacterial meningitis, pneumonia, joint or bone infections, and throat inflammations in children through age 5 and older adults.</p>
<p>Immune globulin
Also called immune gamma globulin—passive immunizing agents obtained from pooled human plasma.</p>
<p>Immunity
The quality of being insusceptible to or unaffected by a particular disease or condition.</p>
<p>Immunosuppressive
A substance or procedure that lessens or prevents an immune response.</p>
<p>Vaccines
A suspension of attenuated or killed microorganisms administered PO, IM, IV, or intradermal to induce active immunity to infectious diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="immunological-agents">IMMUNOLOGICAL AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunological-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="i-general-considerations">I. General considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-general-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>A. Immunity can be innate or acquired; natural or artificial (Table 13-1)</p>
<p>207</p>
<p>Table 13-1. Sources of Immunity</p>
<p>|  Natural Resistance |   | One's innate abilities to resist antigens
Influenced by rest, nutrition, stress, exercise
Beyond our natural resistance, immunity must be acquired  |   |   |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  Natural Immunity |   | Artificial Immunity  |   |   |
|  Passively Acquired | Actively Acquired | Passively Acquired | Actively Acquired |   |
|  Antibodies obtained passively by transfer via placenta or from breast milk | Protection obtained by actually contracting the disease | Temporary prophylactic immunity acquired by direct injection of antibodies, serums; immune globulin | Immunization with a live or attenuated organism (vaccine) or toxins from organisms (toxoids) so that antibodies are produced by the body |   |</p>
<p>208 ▼ CHAPTER 13 DRUGS AFFECTING THE IMMUNE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-scheduling-box-13-1">B. Scheduling (Box 13-1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-scheduling-box-13-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Children must have a current schedule to attend school</li>
<li>Schedule should be followed as closely as possible. Schedules should be altered or exemptions granted for the following
a. An ill, febrile child
b. Immunosuppressed child
c. Use of certain medications or other recent immunizations</li>
<li>Instruct parents to keep the immunization schedule in a safe place</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-public-emphasis-provide-pamphlets-use-local-health-units-as-resources-critical-ages-are-between-2-and-5-years-of-age">C. Public emphasis: provide pamphlets; use local health units as resources. Critical ages are between 2 and 5 years of age.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-public-emphasis-provide-pamphlets-use-local-health-units-as-resources-critical-ages-are-between-2-and-5-years-of-age" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-high-risk-groups">D. High risk groups<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-high-risk-groups" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Unimmunized parents</li>
<li>Refugees/immigrants</li>
<li>Healthcare providers</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-side-effects">E. Side Effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Common, should be taught to child’s care provider
a. Low-grade fever
b. Soreness at site
c. Joint pain
d. Minor rash
e. Malaise: fatigue</li>
</ol>
<p>Box 13-1. Immunization Schedule for Birth to 16 Years</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>HBV</th><th>DTP</th><th>OPV</th><th>Hib</th><th>MMR</th><th>Other</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>In Hospital</td><td>#1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2 months</td><td>#2</td><td>#1</td><td>#1</td><td>#1</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4 months</td><td></td><td>#2</td><td>#2</td><td>#2</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>6 months</td><td>#3</td><td>#3</td><td></td><td>#3</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>12 months</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Td</td></tr><tr><td>15 months</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>#4</td><td>#1</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>18 months</td><td></td><td>#4</td><td>#3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4-5 years</td><td></td><td>#5</td><td>#4</td><td></td><td>#2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>13-16 years</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Td</td></tr><tr><td>HBV</td><td>Hepatitis B Vaccine</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DTP</td><td>Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>OPV</td><td>Oral Polio Virus</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Hib</td><td>Hemophilus influenzae</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>MMR</td><td>Measles, Mumps, Rubella</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Td</td><td>Tetanus Diphtheria</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>IMMUNOLOGICS: GENERAL INFORMATION, ADMINISTRATION SCHEDULE ▼ 209</p>
<p>f. Raised red area at site
g. Symptoms of the disease</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Uncommon but more severe; report immediately
a. Convulsions
b. Anaphylaxis: an exaggerated, life-threatening hypersensitivity reaction
c. Encephalitis: an inflammatory condition of the brain
d. Serum sickness: an immunological disorder that may occur 2 to 3 weeks after the administration of an antiserum
e. Allergic response
f. Guillain-Barré syndrome: an idiopathic, peripheral polyneuritis occurring between 1 and 3 weeks after a mild episode of fever associated with a viral infection or with immunization; characterized by an ascending paralysis from the feet up</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Role of the nurse</p>
<ol>
<li>Know proper administration dose, route, and site</li>
<li>Conduct a history interview, assessing for the following
a. Allergies to eggs or egg products
b. Current acute or febrile illness
c. Immunosuppressive therapy in progress
d. Recent injection of an immune globulin or a blood transfusion
e. History of malignancies, chemotherapy
f. Possibility of pregnancy</li>
<li>Check expiration date on all vials</li>
<li>Properly store immunization vials in the refrigerator or freezer, but not in the doors of the appliances</li>
<li>Change needles after drawing up the injection and always aspirate</li>
<li>Observe the child for 30 minutes after immunization is given</li>
<li>Properly restrain the child and be truthful about pain</li>
<li>Report abnormal or severe reactions with the lot number and the symptoms experienced to the Center for Disease Control (CDC)</li>
</ol>
<p>G. Parent teaching</p>
<ol>
<li>Expected and unexpected side effects, and when to call the physician</li>
<li>How to use antipyretics for side effects</li>
<li>Closely observing the child for the first 24 hours</li>
<li>Encouraging the child to rest for the first 24 hours</li>
<li>Answer any questions about the injections and relieve any fears about harmful side effects</li>
</ol>
<p>210 ▼ CHAPTER 13 DRUGS AFFECTING THE IMMUNE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-passive-immunity-agents">II. Passive immunity agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-passive-immunity-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Source: serums obtained from humans or animals in which antibodies have been formed against a pathogenic organism
B. Action: provide temporary immunity
C. Uses: prevent infectious disease from occurring or relieve symptoms of the disease after suspected or actual exposure
D. Common agents with their use</p>
<ol>
<li>Immune globulin—exposure to hepatitis A, immunodeficiency syndromes</li>
<li>Agents with known antibodies
a. Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG)—exposure to hepatitis B
b. Tetanus immune globulin (Hyper-Tet)—treatment of tetanus, prophylaxis after exposure—may be given in emergency rooms for severe massive trauma or for burn clients
c. Varicella-Zoster immune globulin (VZIG)—prevention or treatment of varicella, chickenpox
d. RhoD immune globulin (RhoGAM)—for Rh negative pregnant women or women who deliver an Rh positive baby</li>
<li>Antitoxins and antivenins
a. Antitoxin: an agent prepared from the serum of horses immunized against a particular toxin-producing organism
(1) Diphtheria antitoxin—treatment of diphtheria
(2) Tetanus antitoxin—treatment of tetanus when immune globulin not available
b. Antivenin: a suspension of venom-neutralizing antibodies prepared from the serum of immunized horses
(1) Rabies immune globulin—exposure to rabies
(2) Antivenin for snake and spider bites</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-active-immunity-agents">III. Active immunity agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-active-immunity-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Vaccines: biologic agents that stimulate antibodies to be produced in the body. Clue: remember the <em>a</em> in vaccine refers to active immunity; the body acts to produce antibodies and it takes awhile: about 2 to 3 weeks.</p>
<ol>
<li>Live vaccine: live microorganisms that are altered but will still multiply in the body over time and cause a reaction
a. Measles, mumps, rubella (MMR)
b. Poliovirus (Sabin, OPV)
c. Yellow fever</li>
</ol>
<p>PASSIVE AND ACTIVE IMMUNITY; IMMUNOSUPPRESSIVE AGENTS ▼ 211</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Attenuated: microorganisms that are killed, inactivated, or altered in such a way that their virulence is reduced
a. Hemophilus influenzae (Hib)
b. Hepatitis B (Heptavax)
c. Poliovirus (Salk)
d. Influenza vaccine
e. Rabies vaccine
f. Cholera vaccine
g. Typhoid vaccine
h. Rubella vaccine—instruct female to wait at least 3 months before attempting pregnancy
i. Havrix vaccine—for Hepatitis A</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Toxoids: toxins that have been treated to eliminate the toxic properties but retain the ability to stimulate antibodies</p>
<ol>
<li>Tetanus toxoid—administer every 10 years</li>
<li>Diphtheria toxoid</li>
<li>Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (DTP)</li>
<li>Diphtheria and tetanus (Td)—recommended for 7 year olds and adults</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="immunosuppressive-and-immunomodulating-agents">IMMUNOSUPPRESSIVE AND IMMUNOMODULATING AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunosuppressive-and-immunomodulating-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-immunosuppressive-agents">I. Immunosuppressive agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-immunosuppressive-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Groups of drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Corticosteroids</li>
<li>Antimetabolites</li>
<li>Cytotoxic agents</li>
<li>Certain antibiotics</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Action: lessen or prevent an immune response</p>
<p>C. Uses: organ transplantation and autoimmune diseases</p>
<p>D. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Infections</li>
<li>Cancer</li>
<li>Lymphomas</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal (GI) upset</li>
<li>Anemias</li>
<li>Leukopenia</li>
<li>Thrombocytopenia</li>
<li>Serum sickness</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Contraindications: live vaccines, combination immunosuppressive therapy</p>
<p>CHAPTER 13 DRUGS AFFECTING THE IMMUNE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-nursing-implications">F. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Monitor complete blood count and liver enzymes</li>
<li>Assess for transplant rejection and signs of infection</li>
<li>Give oral forms with food or milk to reduce GI upset</li>
<li>Monitor IV site carefully; avoid extravasation</li>
<li>Frequently assess major body systems including oral cavity</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="g-common-drugs">G. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#g-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Azathioprine (Imuran)</li>
<li>Lymphocyte immune globulin (ATG, Atgam)</li>
<li>Muromonab-CD3 (Orthoclone OKT3)</li>
<li>Cyclosporine (Sandimmune)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-immunomodulating-agents">II. Immunomodulating agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-immunomodulating-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-action-bind-to-the-cells-infected-with-the-human-immunodeficiency-virus-hiv">A. Action: bind to the cells infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-bind-to-the-cells-infected-with-the-human-immunodeficiency-virus-hiv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses-clients-seroconverted-to-hiv-or-exposed-to-occupational-hiv">B. Uses: clients seroconverted to HIV or exposed to occupational HIV<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses-clients-seroconverted-to-hiv-or-exposed-to-occupational-hiv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Neurological symptoms: insomnia, confusion, seizures, peripheral neuropathies</li>
<li>Bone marrow depression, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia</li>
<li>Pancreatitis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Obtain a thorough history of previous bone marrow depression, blood dyscrasias, anemias</li>
<li>Encourage good hydration and oral care</li>
<li>Encourage antipruritics and sedatives as needed</li>
<li>Institute seizure precautions</li>
<li>Monitor complete blood count (CBC)</li>
<li>Reorient as needed</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Zidovudine (Azidothymidine, AZT, Retrovir)</li>
<li>Didanosine (ddl, Videx)</li>
<li>Zalcitabine (Hivid)</li>
</ol>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 213</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>A frantic mother calls the nurse at the physician’s office. She states that her child is very sleepy, has a temperature of 100.4° F, and has a raised red area on his leg where he recently received the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) injection. What should the nurse tell her?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. That these side effects are serious, so the child needs to be brought in to see the physician
b. That these side effects are common, and she should call if the temperature is &gt;102° F or if she cannot arouse the child
c. That she is overreacting and should not panic
d. That these side effects are common, so she should not be concerned at all</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>A client, age 22, accidentally falls into a hay bailer while working on a farm. He has multiple deep wounds and requires surgery. A tetanus toxoid would be given based on which of these responses in reference to the last tetanous shot?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. “I can’t remember, but it was less than 5 years”
b. “I can’t remember, but it was less than 10 years”
c. “I know I am up-to-date; I had an injection in 1993”
d. “I think it was 3 years ago”</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>A client plans to become pregnant and wants to plan everything just right. She receives the rubella as a prevention and calls the public health nurse to ask when she should begin trying to get pregnant. The nurse should suggest trying</li>
</ol>
<p>a. No sooner than 3 months
b. Whenever you feel like it
c. No sooner than 2 months
d. No sooner than 6 months</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Blood work on a 17-year-old client who has a stillbirth returns normal, and she is Rh negative. The autopsy reveals the baby was Rh positive. Which of the following should she receive?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG)
b. Haemophilus influenzae vaccine (Hib)
c. Rh₀ (D) immune globulin (RhoGam)
d. Hepatitis B vaccine (Heptavax)</p>
<p>214 ▼ CHAPTER 13 DRUGS AFFECTING THE IMMUNE SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>A client is concerned about having her current immunization schedule for her 13-month-old daughter. She calls the nurse at the health unit and asks which “shots” her daughter should have received by this time. What is the nurse’s best answer?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. 3 DTP, 1 MMR, Tb, 3 HBV
b. 2 DTP, Tb, 2 OPV, 3 HBV
c. 3 DTP, 3 Hib, 2 OPV, 2 HBV
d. 3 DTP, 3 Hib, Td, 2 OPV, 3 HBV</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 215</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>These are common effects. Acetaminophen (Tylenol), rest, and normal movement of the leg are the best treatment. The items in option <em>a</em> are not serious enough to panic an already frantic mother. Simple instructions would work best. Never tell a worried mother that she is overreacting. Concern is always warranted, but panic is unnecessary at this time.</td><td>Refer to the Rationale. Note that responses <em>b</em> and <em>d</em> are similar. If trying to decide between the two responses, be alerted to the key words in response <em>d</em>: “not be concerned . . . at all.” This absolute leads you to response <em>b</em>.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>With a serious wound an interval of more than 5 years usually requires another injection for prophylactic reasons. Injections given within 5 years are usually sufficient for accidents. An unknown or questionable date usually requires an injection for prophylactic reasons.</td><td>Select the longest time, 10 years.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: a</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>A 3-month wait is recommended in the literature to prevent any complications to the fetus. Pregnancy too soon after injection could cause abnormalities in the pregnancy or baby. A 2-month wait is not long enough. A 6-month wait is too long.</td><td>Use the number approach if you have no idea of a correct answer. Throw out the smallest and largest numbers, 2 and 6; select 3 in response <em>a</em>.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>216 ▼ CHAPTER 13 DRUGS AFFECTING THE IMMUNE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-correct-answer-c">4. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>RhoGam provides temporary immunity from antibodies received from the child, and it protects the mother and the next baby from the incompatibility of the blood; it is passive-acquired immunity. In option <em>a</em> HBIG is to provide temporary immunity if there is contact with hepatitis B; it is passive-acquired immunity—the direct injection of antibodies in the form of an “immune globulin.” Hib is to prevent infection from haemophilus influenzae, which is serious in children and older adults; it is active-acquired immunity—the body has to actively produce its own antibodies within 2 to 3 weeks. Heptavax provides active-acquired immunity against hepatitis B. It is a series of 3 injections: the initial, at 3 months, and at 6 months.</p>
<p>Use common sense after rereading the stem. There is no problem with hepatitis or the flu, so the only possible answer is <em>c</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-d">5. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This schedule in response <em>d</em> is correct according to age. The schedule in option <em>a</em> is incorrect for the child’s age; the MMR is scheduled too soon. In option <em>b</em> for the child’s age there should have been 3 DTP and 3 HIB injections. In option <em>c</em> for the child’s age the HBV should be complete to a total of 3; the Td is also needed.</p>
<p>The easiest way to remember this is to list the numbers 3, 3, 3, 2, 1, then place the tests alphabetically DTP, HBV, HIB, OPV, and Td. These shots total 12 in number (add them up for yourself) and relate that a 12 month old should have completed this group of injections.</p>
<p>217
CHAPTER 14</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-endocrine-system">Drugs Affecting the Endocrine System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-endocrine-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the anterior and posterior pituitary hormones and the names of the replacement agents.</li>
<li>Identify the parathyroid and thyroid hormones and the replacement agents.</li>
<li>Describe corticosteroids and mineralcorticoids and their uses.</li>
<li>Identify hypoglycemic and hyperglycemic agents.</li>
<li>Describe the difference between short-acting, intermediate-acting, and long-acting insulin.</li>
<li>Describe nursing implications for clients on insulin therapy.</li>
</ul>
<p>218 ▼ CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Corticotropin</strong>
Also called <strong>adrenocorticotropic (ACTH) hormone</strong>; secreted from the anterior pituitary gland which in turn stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete other hormones such as cortisol in times of stress, fever, or acute hypoglycemia.</p>
<p><strong>Dawn phenomenon</strong>
Hyperglycemia only in the early morning, without a prior hypoglycemia, results from an increased plasma glucose concentration (and related to the growth hormone); treated with an extra dose of insulin.</p>
<p><strong>Hyperfunction of the endocrine system</strong>
Thyrotoxicosis, Hyperglycemia, Hyperthyroidism, also called <strong>Grave’s Disease</strong>, Hyperparathyroidism.</p>
<p><strong>Hypofunction of the endocrine system</strong>
Addison’s Disease, Cretinism, Hypoparathyroidism, Hypoglycemia, Hypothyroidism.</p>
<p><strong>Iodism</strong>
A condition produced from excessive amounts of iodine in the body, with findings of lacrimation, salivation, rhinitis, weakness, and a typical skin eruption.</p>
<p><strong>Myxedema</strong>
The severest form of hypothyroidism, characterized by swelling of the hands, face, feet, and the periorbital tissues, at which stage coma may result.</p>
<p><strong>Somogyi effect</strong>
Hypoglycemia in the evening results in a rebound hyperglycemia in the early morning. The low blood sugar drawn around 3 A.M. usually pinpoints the problem.</p>
<p><strong>T₃ (Thyroxine)</strong>
Thyroid hormone that influences metabolism.</p>
<p><strong>T₄ (Triiodothyronine)</strong>
Thyroid hormone produced mainly from the metabolism of thyroxine in the peripheral tissues, but also made by and stored in the thyroid gland. It helps regulate growth and development, control metabolism and body temperature, and by negative-feedback loop inhibit the secretion of thyrotropin, a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) by the pituitary.</p>
<p><strong>Thyroid storm</strong>
Also called <strong>thyrotoxic crisis</strong>—a life-threatening situation in uncontrolled hyperthyroidism with characteristic findings: fever as high as 106°F, sweating, tachycardia, extreme nervous excitability, and acute respiratory distress.</p>
<p>PITUITARY HORMONES: ANTERIOR ▼ 219</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pituitary-hormones">PITUITARY HORMONES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pituitary-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-anterior-pituitary-hormones-box-14-1">I. Anterior pituitary hormones (Box 14-1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-anterior-pituitary-hormones-box-14-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-growth-hormone">A. Growth hormone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-growth-hormone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Action: increases cellular size and rate of growth</li>
<li>Use: pituitary dwarfism</li>
<li>Major side effects
a. Development of antibodies
b. Gigantism, too rapid growth
c. Hyperglycemia (diabetogenic effect)
d. Soft-tissue hypertrophy</li>
<li>Nursing implications
a. Monitor effects of the drug
b. Give by injection only and mix with sterile water
c. Assess glucose level</li>
<li>Common drugs
a. Somatrem (Protropin)
b. Somatropin (Humatrope)
c. Octreotide acetate (Sandostatin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="c6d0893b">B. Corticotropin—ACTH (Acthar)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c6d0893b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Actions: controls cortisol release and assists in dealing with stress</li>
<li>Uses
a. Diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency
b. Myasthenia gravis
c. Rheumatic disease
d. Multiple sclerosis</li>
<li>Major side effects
a. Allergic reactions
b. Acne</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="box-14-1-anterior-pituitary-hormones">Box 14-1. Anterior Pituitary Hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-14-1-anterior-pituitary-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Somatotropin or growth hormone (GH)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Thyrotropin or thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)</td></tr><tr><td>Corticotropin or adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)</td></tr><tr><td>Gonadotropins: Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)</td></tr><tr><td>Luteinizing hormone (LH)</td></tr><tr><td>also called interstitial-stimulating hormone (ICSH)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>220 ▼ CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<p>c. Mood swings
d. Sodium retention, potassium loss, glucose elevated
e. Cushing’s syndrome (from excess hormone)
f. Depression of immune system</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Nursing implications
a. Monitor for allergic response
b. Promptly treat any signs of infection
c. Monitor electrolytes and glucose</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-thyroid-stimulating-hormone-tsh">C. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-thyroid-stimulating-hormone-tsh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Actions
a. Controls functional activity of the thyroid gland
b. Increases production and release of the thyroid hormone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use: diagnosing hypothyroidism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Major side effects
a. Cardiac arrhythmias: particularly atrial fibrillation because thyroid hormones increase the cardiac contractility and heart rate
b. Anaphylactic reactions because of the cardiostimulant effect</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nursing implications
a. Monitor cardiac status
b. Assess for allergic reaction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Common drug: thyrotropin (Thytropar)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-posterior-pituitary-hormone-box-14-2">II. Posterior pituitary hormone (Box 14-2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-posterior-pituitary-hormone-box-14-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="56b7a8ed">A. Oxytocics—oxytocin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#56b7a8ed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Actions
a. Cause vasopressor activity
b. Decrease urine output
c. Increase water absorption</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Uses
a. Diabetes insipidus
b. Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeds
c. Induction of labor for term babies
d. Promotion of milk letdown and uterine involution</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="box-14-2-posterior-pituitary-hormones">Box 14-2. Posterior Pituitary Hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-14-2-posterior-pituitary-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Vasopressin or antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
Oxytocin</p>
<p>PITUITARY HORMONES: POSTERIOR ▼ 221</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Major side effects
a. Hypertension
b. Water intoxication
c. Anaphylaxis
d. Nausea, vomiting</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nursing implications
a. Monitor fetal activity: fetal heart tones (FHT), contractions, vital signs (especially BP)
b. Monitor fluid status, I&amp;O</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Common drugs
a. Oxytocin (Pitocin, Syntocinon)
b. Oxytocin citrate (Pitocin Citrate)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Oxytocics—ergot alkaloids</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Actions
a. Contract smooth muscle, primarily on the uterus and blood vessels, with the greatest effect at term and postpartum
b. Peripheral vasoconstriction
c. Antihypertensive effect
d. Alpha-adrenergic blockade</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Uses
a. Production of uterine contractions
b. Postpartal bleeding
c. Migraine headaches
d. Hypertension</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Major side effects
a. Nausea, vomiting
b. Dry mouth due to increased urinary output
c. Increased BP
d. Ergotism: cerebrospinal findings of spasms, cramps, dry gangrene</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nursing implications: same as for oxytocins</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Common drugs
a. Ergonovine maleate (Ergotrate Maleate)
b. Ergotamine tartraye (Ergostat)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Vasopressin: (antidiuretic hormone [ADH])</p>
<ol>
<li>Action: maintains normal osmotic pressure and volume in the ECF by regulating the amount of water absorbed in the renal distal tubule</li>
<li>Uses
a. Hormone replacement in diabetics
b. Hemorrhage control
c. Increase BP</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<p>d. Diagnosis to determine the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine
e. Replacement therapy after head injury with diabetes insipidus</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Major side effects</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Irritation to tissue
b. Nasal congestion and inflammation
c. Nausea, vomiting, headache
d. Flushing, pallor</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Nursing implications</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Contraindicated in cardiac disease
b. Monitor vital signs, I&amp;O
c. Assess weight changes
d. Monitor ECG
e. Assess for signs of water intoxication—hyponatremia and decreased urine output</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Common drugs</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Desmopressin acetate (DDAVP)—usually nasally
b. Vasopressin (Pitressin)—maybe IM or IV</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thyroid-and-parathyroid-hormones">THYROID AND PARATHYROID HORMONES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thyroid-and-parathyroid-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-parathyroid-hormone-box-14-3">I. Parathyroid hormone (Box 14-3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-parathyroid-hormone-box-14-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: maintains calcium (Ca) levels in the blood by affecting the absorption of Ca from the gut and bone. The serum phosphate level changes in the opposite direction of the Ca level.
B. Agents for hypoparathyroid</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypoparathyroidism: a deficiency of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that causes a low calcium level and high phosphate level (tetany, cardiac arrhythmias, neuromuscular irritability)</li>
<li>Uses: to treat hypocalcemia, raise the calcium level, and decrease the phosphate level</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-14-3-hormones-influencing-overall-function">Box 14-3. Hormones Influencing Overall Function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-14-3-hormones-influencing-overall-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Gland</th><th>Hormones</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Thyroid</td><td>Thyroxine (T₃), Triiodothyronine (T₄), Calcitonin</td></tr><tr><td>Parathyroid</td><td>Parathormone (PTH)</td></tr><tr><td>Pancreas</td><td>Insulin, Glucagon</td></tr><tr><td>Adrenals</td><td>Mineralocorticoids, Glucocorticoids</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>PARATHYROID AND THYROID HORMONES ▼ 223</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Major side effects
a. Azotemia: excess nitrogenous waste in the blood with elevated serum BUN
b. Renal failure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Common drugs
a. Calcium chloride
b. Calcium gluconate (Kalcinate)
c. Ergocalciferol (vitamin D)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Agents for hyperparathyroid</p>
<ol>
<li>Hyperparathyroidism: excess of parathyroid hormone, which causes a high calcium level and low phosphate level</li>
<li>Uses: to treat hypercalcemia, lower the calcium level, and raise the phosphate level</li>
<li>Major side effects
a. Flushing of the face
b. Inflammation if injected
c. Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Common drugs
a. Calcitonin (Cibacalcin)
b. Etidronate disodium (Didronel)</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications for both groups</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor for signs of hypocalcemia and hypercalcemia</li>
<li>Give PO form of medication 1 to 1½ hour after eating</li>
<li>Closely monitor IV forms to prevent extravasation</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs and ECG</li>
</ol>
<p>II. Thyroid hormones (see Box 14-3)</p>
<p>A. Thyroid agents</p>
<ol>
<li>Action: replace missing thyroid hormones, synthetic or natural preparations of T₃ or T₄. Thyroid hormone is necessary for all cell metabolism.</li>
<li>Uses: hypothyroidism or decreased activity of the thyroid gland
a. Myxedema (greater in adults over 50 years of age)
b. Cretinism (congenital hypothyroidism)</li>
<li>Major side effects
a. Cardiovascular: palpitations, tachycardia, angina
b. Central nervous system: nervousness, irritability
c. Weight loss
d. Insomnia
e. Thyrotoxicosis: extreme hyperthyroidism or the sudden secretion of thyroid hormone in greater-than-normal amounts</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Nursing implications</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Give dose carefully, usually small amounts in micrograms
b. Encourage compliance with a single morning dose at breakfast
c. Teach signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism
d. Hold if HR &gt;100 taken for a full minute; take apical pulse</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Interactions: a decrease in antidiabetic agents, increase in oral anticoagulants</li>
<li>Common drugs</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Levothyroxine sodium (Synthroid)
b. Thyroglobulin (Proloid)
c. Liotrix (Euthroid)</p>
<p>B. Antithyroid drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Actions: lower the thyroid level by three mechanisms</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Interfere with the hormone production: iodine must be present in the body for thyroid hormone synthesis. A high dose of iodine has a suppressant effect and causes a decrease in the production of thyroid hormone.
b. Modify the response to the hormone by blocking the synthesis of thyroid hormone
c. Destroy the gland: radioactive preparations destroy the thyroid tissue, thereby decreasing the production of thyroid hormone</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Use: hyperthyroidism (Grave's disease or thyrotoxicosis)</li>
<li>Major side effects</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Granulocytopenia: decrease in granulocytes in blood
b. Hypersensitivity
c. Iodism: excess iodine in the body manifested by increased thirst; burning, brassy taste in the mouth
d. Myxedema coma: severe hypothyroidism leading to coma or death
e. Hypothyroidism</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Nursing implications</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Dilute liquid iodine preparations in water and encourage use of a straw to prevent staining teeth
b. Teach the client about hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism. Thyroid storm exhibited by fever, tachycardia, CHF, and CNS changes.
c. Monitor vital signs and weight
d. Contraindicated if client is pregnant
e. Avoid over-the-counter medications because they may contain iodine</p>
<p>ADRENAL HORMONES: STEROIDS ▼ 225</p>
<p>f. Teach client follow-up is needed to evaluate for hypothyroidism</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Common drugs
a. Antithyroid drugs: taken about 3 weeks for a desired response
(1) Methimazole (Tapazole)
(2) Propylthiouracil (PTU)
b. Iodides
(1) Strong iodine solution (Lugol’s solution)
(2) Potassium iodide solution (SSKI)
c. Radioactive iodine (Sodium Iodide-131)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-hormones">ADRENAL HORMONES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-glucocorticoids-see-box-14-3">I. Glucocorticoids (see Box 14-3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-glucocorticoids-see-box-14-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-actions">A. Actions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Increase carbohydrate, protein, and fat metabolism</li>
<li>Exhibit antiinflammatory properties</li>
<li>Suppress the normal immune response</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Topical and systemic inflammation</li>
<li>Allergic disorders</li>
<li>Collagen diseases</li>
<li>Fractures, impaired healing</li>
<li>Shock</li>
<li>Replacement in adrenal cortical insufficiency, Addison’s disease</li>
<li>Eye diseases</li>
<li>Rheumatic disorders</li>
<li>Asthma</li>
<li>Acute leukemia</li>
<li>Cerebral edema</li>
<li>Skin disorders</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Buffalo hump—accumulation of fat on the back of the neck due to prolonged use of steroids</li>
<li>Moon face—rounded, puffy face due to prolonged use of steroids</li>
<li>Immunosuppressant effect: inability of the immune system to respond to antigenic stimulation by inhibiting cellular and humoral immunity</li>
<li>Growth retardation, muscle wasting</li>
<li>Hyperglycemia: blood sugar &gt;100 mg/dl</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>Hypertension: blood pressure &gt;140/90</li>
<li>Mood swings</li>
<li>Sterility</li>
<li>Cardiac dysrhythmias: tachycardia most common</li>
<li>Cushingoid signs and symptoms: having the habitus and facies characteristic of Cushing's disease, which involves excess cortisol</li>
<li>Hypokalemia</li>
<li>Inhibited protein synthesis</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually recommended for short-term use only; stress the severe side effects from long-term use</li>
<li>Know and teach that they should not be abruptly withdrawn; taper off slowly</li>
<li>Encourage a diet rich in protein and potassium</li>
<li>Draw steroid levels at 7 A.M. and/or 4 P.M. to determine hypofunction or hyperfunction of adrenal gland's production of steroids</li>
<li>Monitor daily weight and teach patient to weigh at home because of the action of the drug. Report weight gain &gt;5 pounds.</li>
<li>Advise client to wear a medical alert tag</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Interactions: increased need for insulin or oral hypoglycemics. Contraindicated in clients with TB or peptic ulcers (may worsen the disease).</p>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Hydrocortisone (Cortef, Hydrocortone)</li>
<li>Hydrocortisone sodium succinate (Solu-Cortef)</li>
<li>Cortisone acetate (Cortone)</li>
<li>Prednisone (Deltasone, Orasone)</li>
<li>Triamcinolone (Aristocort)</li>
<li>Betamethasone (Celestone)</li>
<li>Dexamethasone (Decadron)</li>
</ol>
<p>II. Mineralcorticoids
A. Actions: conserve sodium stores in the body and affect fluid and electrolyte balance, thereby causing reabsorption of sodium (Na) and excretion of potassium (K)
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Addison's disease: a life-threatening condition caused by partial or complete failure of adrenocortical function</li>
<li>Adrenocortical insufficiency</li>
</ol>
<p>MINERALCORTICOIDS, HYPOGLYCEMICS ▼ 227</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypokalemia</li>
<li>Hypernatremia</li>
<li>Edema</li>
<li>Hypertension</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
