<li>Weigh client daily</li>
<li>Monitor BP</li>
<li>Encourage a diet rich in potassium</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drug: fludrocortisone acetate (Florinef Acetate)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs-used-in-diabetes">DRUGS USED IN DIABETES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-used-in-diabetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-hypoglycemic-agents-see-box-14-3">I. Hypoglycemic agents (see Box 14-3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-hypoglycemic-agents-see-box-14-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Actions: control carbohydrate (CHO) metabolism and decrease glucose levels</p>
<ol>
<li>Oral agents stimulate the pancreas to secrete more insulin; not given in children, type I diabetics, since pancreatic β cells are not functioning</li>
<li>Insulin aids glucose across the cell</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Uses: diabetes mellitus (DM), ketoacidosis, and coma associated with DM</p>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Somogyi effect: hypoglycemia in the evening or night with rebound hyperglycemia in the early morning. The blood sugar provides a good evaluation of the problem when drawn around 3 A.M.; it is typically low.</li>
<li>Hypoglycemia: weakness, hunger, sweating, nausea, BS &lt;50</li>
<li>Local allergic reaction: itching, redness at the site</li>
<li>Dawn phenomenon: hyperglycemia only in the early morning without a prior hypoglycemia; increased plasma glucose concentration and related to the growth hormone; treated by giving an extra dose of insulin</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Insulin is available in various forms (Table 14-1) for SQ or IV administration. The GI tract digests insulin if given orally.</li>
<li>Schedule snacks around insulin’s peak action time: the greatest hypoglycemic time</li>
<li>Give insulin SQ on a rotating basis; various SQ sites have different absorption times</li>
<li>May need to teach the client or family member how to give an injection</li>
</ol>
<p>228</p>
<p>Table 14-1. Insulin Preparations</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Generic Name</th><th>Classification</th><th>Description</th><th>Pharmacokinetics</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Onset</td><td>Peak</td><td>Duration</td></tr><tr><td>Insulin injection (Regular)</td><td>Rapid-acting</td><td>Clear solution containing no zinc or modifying agents; IV only or subcutaneous injection</td><td>SQ: ½ to 1 hr</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IV: 10 to 30 min</td><td>2 to 4 hr</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>15 to 30 min</td><td>6 to 8 hr</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>30 to 60 min</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prompt insulin zinc suspension (Semilente)</td><td>Rapid-acting</td><td>Cloudy suspension of amorphous insulin precipitated with zinc to slow absorption; subcutaneous only</td><td>1 to 2 hr</td><td>4 to 7 hr</td><td>12 to 16 hr</td></tr><tr><td>Isophane insulin suspension (NPH)</td><td>Intermediate-acting</td><td>Cloudy suspension of insulin complexed with protamine to slow absorption; subcutaneous only</td><td>2 to 4 hr</td><td>10 to 16 hr</td><td>18 to 30 hr</td></tr><tr><td>Insulin zinc suspension (Lente)</td><td>Intermediate-acting</td><td>Cloudy suspension containing 30% semilente insulin and 70% ultralente insulin; subcutaneous only</td><td>1 to 2 hr</td><td>10 to 16 hr</td><td>18 to 30 hr</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th>Protamine zinc insulin suspension (PZI)</th><th>Long-acting</th><th>Cloudy when well mixed; suspension of insulin complexed with more protamine than NPH insulin; subcutaneous only</th><th>6 to 8 hr</th><th>14 to 24 hr</th><th>24 to 36 hr or longer</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Extended insulin zinc suspension (Ultralente)</td><td>Long-acting</td><td>Cloudy when well mixed; large complexes of insulin with zinc to slow absorption; no protein modifiers; subcutaneous only</td><td>5 to 8 hr</td><td>16 to 24 hr</td><td>24 to 36 hr or longer</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Teach about foot care, exercise, and diet. Stress that exercise decreases the need for supplemental insulin, while most other factors increase the need for supplemental insulin.</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Hypoglycemia (BS &lt; 50): too much insulin, too little food, too much exercise
b. Hyperglycemia (BS &gt; 120): too little insulin, too much food, too little exercise</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>Assess for allergies to sulfa; oral agents contraindicated if sulfa allergies because they are chemically related</li>
<li>Encourage compliance</li>
<li>Teach how to self-monitor glucose level with the appropriate equipment</li>
<li>Know the onset and peak time for the type of insulin given</li>
<li>Insulin ordered to sliding scale is usually regular. Sliding scale is additional insulin given intermittently for high blood glucose levels.</li>
<li>Do not shake, but gently rotate insulin bottle in the hand</li>
<li>Draw up regular insulin first when mixing agents</li>
<li>Only regular insulin can be given IV</li>
<li>Double-check dose with another nurse since dosages are minute</li>
<li>Encourage the use of a medical alert tag</li>
<li>The open vial can be stored at room temperature. Once refrigerated, however, the vial should be placed in the refrigerator.</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>See Table 14-1 for insulins</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Short-acting: regular, Humulin-R
b. Intermediate-acting: NPH, Humulin-N
c. Long-acting: Protamine Zinc, Ultralente</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Oral agents</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Chlorpropamide (Diabinese)
b. Tolazamide (Tolinase)
c. Tolbutamide (Orinase)
d. Glipizide (Glucotrol)
e. Glyburide (Micronase)</p>
<p>II. Hyperglycemic agents (see Box 14-3)</p>
<p>A. Action: stimulate glucose synthesis to raise the glucose level
B. Use: severe hypoglycemic states
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Hyperglycemia: polydipsia, polyuria, polyphagia</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Coma</li>
</ol>
<p>HYPERGLYCEMICS ▼ 231</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Consciousness should return within 15 to 20 minutes; may repeat dose with dextrose-50% by IV route</li>
<li>Client and family, should be taught how to use at home and have available at all times</li>
<li>Glucagon should be used as soon as concentrated and given SQ, IM, or IV</li>
<li>Patients not losing complete consciousness can be offered 4 ounces of soda (not diet) instead of or in addition to glucagon. A syrup base is absorbed more rapidly than a juice base.</li>
<li>Dextrose-50% by IV slow push is the drug of choice for unconscious clients</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Glucagon</li>
<li>Dextrose-50%</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>In preparing to administer regular and NPH insulin, why would the nurse draw up the regular first?
a. It is easier to see the correct dose
b. It avoids contamination of the solution in the regular insulin vial
c. It avoids contamination of the solution in the NPH vial
d. It is not as thick and therefore easier to draw up</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client is given her usual 7:30 A.M. dose of NPH insulin along with an added amount of regular insulin to scale because her glucose is 329. When would the first signs of insulin action be expected to occur?
a. 10:30 A.M.
b. 8:00 A.M.
c. 9:00 A.M.
d. 9:30 A.M.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client self-monitors her glucose at home and reports that every morning the level is extremely high. The glucose is within normal limits the rest of the day. The nurse would explain that this is called the
a. Somogyi effect
b. Peak time
c. Dawn phenomenon
d. Onset time</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client, age 16, is having difficulty giving herself insulin injections. She wants to take the insulin in an oral form. How should the nurse respond?
a. Insulin is better than the oral agents
b. Oral agents are more expensive than insulin
c. Insulin is not available orally because the gastrointestinal tract would destroy it
d. Oral agents can be destroyed by the gastrointestinal tract</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A patient diagnosed with hyperthyroidism would most likely be prescribed
a. Levothyroxine sodium (Synthroid)
b. Thyroglobulin (Proloid)
c. Calcitonin-human (Cibacalcin)
d. Strong iodine solution (Lugol's solution)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The danger for a client with hypothyroidism in suddenly stopping the thyroid medication would be</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 233</p>
<p>a. Thyrotoxicosis
b. Addison's disease
c. Thyroid storm
d. Myxedema coma</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>
<p>A client, age 15, has made the varsity football team and wants to gain weight. He asks the nurse about taking steroids to "pump up." How should the nurse reply?
a. Steroids do not really increase weight, and they carry many dangerous side effects
b. Steroids can "pump you up" but should only be taken in extreme cases
c. Steroids cannot "pump you up" and should never be used
d. Steroids are safe and effective but could make you lose weight</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The drug of choice for a client with Grave's disease would be
a. Thyroid agent
b. Parathyroid hormone
c. Antithyroid agent
d. Anterior pituitary agent</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The NPH insulin is modified with a protein that can alter the regular insulin, which is unmodified and thereby contaminates the regular insulin solution. The dose should be correct no matter which agent is drawn up first. The regular insulin would not harm the NPH vial. The thickness of the solution is basically the same for both types of insulin.</td><td>Identify that the sequence of drawing up the medication is to prevent contamination. Then, to select between responses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>, stop and think of how the sequence follows; your common sense will guide you to response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The onset time is 30 minutes to 1 hour for regular insulin; therefore the regular insulin, which should onset first, could be between 8 and 8:30 A.M. Option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> would be too long of a time for the onset of regular insulin. Option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> would be the onset time for NPH, which is 2 to 4 hours, but the regular insulin would have an onset first.</td><td>Read carefully to note that the question is asking about “the first sign of insulin action,” not the peak, which has typically been asked throughout your educational process.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The dawn phenomenon exhibits normally controlled glucose throughout the day except in early morning when it is high. The Somogyi effect would exhibit findings of hypoglycemia in the evening or early morning, 2 to 3 A.M.</td><td>A helpful way to remember somogyi effect is a slump then elevation in glucose levels. Dawn phenomenon only does a peak.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 235</p>
<p>The client might report waking up sweating in the middle of the night. Rebound hyperglycemia would then occur in the morning. For this problem, therapy may be directed at a decrease in the NPH dosage. In option b, the peak time would cause hypoglycemia and would not likely be only in the early morning. In option d, the onset time could be early morning, depending on the time the insulin is given, but the client would exhibit findings of hypoglycemia.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Correct answer: c
Insulin is not available orally, as explained in the answer. Neither agent is necessarily better than the other. Not all diabetics need insulin. The point in option b is not necessarily true and is irrelevant. Oral agents such as Micronase are not destroyed by the GI tract.</li>
</ol>
<p>Careful reading is a must for questions like this. Note that the client asks about “insulin in an oral form.” The only response that directly answers THE question is option c. Options a, b, and d can be clustered with the terms “oral agents” and eliminated as the correct answer.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Correct answer: d
Response d is an antithyroid agent used to lower thyroid levels. Responses a and b are thyroid agents used for hypothyroidism. The agent in option c is used to treat hyperparathyroidism; it increases calcium deposited into the bone.</li>
</ol>
<p>Eliminate responses a and b, using common sense; each has a medication with “thyro” in it. This hints that these drugs may supplement the hormone. Eliminate option c when calcitonin is associated with calcium which is unrelated to thyroid therapy. Use the above approach if you have no idea of a correct answer.</p>
<p>236 ▼ CHAPTER 14 DRUGS AFFECTING THE ENDOCRINE SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-correct-answer-d">6. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Myxedema coma, severe hypothyroidism, may occur if the agent is suddenly stopped. Responses <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> could be side effects of the medication. Addison’s disease is treated with mineralocorticoids and steroids.</p>
<p>Use an educated approach to match up ideas: a client with hypothyroidism who stops the medicine will be severely hypothyroid, which results in very slow metabolism. Select the response that suggests a slow metabolism—<em>d</em>, coma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-correct-answer-a">7. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The side effects of steroids offset the short-term weight gain sought by weight lifters. Steroids should never be used just to increase one’s weight. Steroids can cause weight gain, but chronic use can cause weight loss. These agents must be monitored by a physician.</p>
<p><em>Go with what you know.</em> These drugs have dangerous side effects, so select response <em>a</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-correct-answer-c">8. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The agents in response <em>c</em> are used in hyperthyroidism, called Graves’ disease. The agents in response <em>a</em> are effective for clients with hypothyroidism. The agents in response <em>c</em> affect the absorption of calcium. Anterior pituitary drugs, as in response <em>d</em>, are not used for thyroid conditions.</p>
<p>Associate in Graves disease that the body is gassed-up to go at a great metabolism. Or recall that alphabetically <em>h</em> follows <em>g</em>; remember Graves is a high metabolic rate.</p>
<p>237
CHAPTER 15</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-respiratory-system">Drugs Affecting the Respiratory System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the difference between mucolytics, bronchodilators, antitussives, and antihistamines.</li>
<li>Identify common side effects of agents used to treat respiratory conditions.</li>
<li>Explain the proper application of inhalers.</li>
<li>Identify the use of respiratory stimulants versus depressants.</li>
</ul>
<p>CHAPTER 15 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Antihistamine</strong>
Any substance capable of reducing the physiologic and pharmacologic effects of histamine.</p>
<p><strong>Antitussive</strong>
Any of a large group of narcotic and nonnarcotic drugs that act on the CNS and peripheral nervous system to suppress the cough reflex. Examples: codeine and hydrocodone, which are potent narcotic antitussives.</p>
<p><strong>Decongestant</strong>
A substance that eliminates or reduces congestion or swelling, especially in the mucous membranes.</p>
<p><strong>Expectorant</strong>
An agent that promotes expectoration by reducing the viscosity of pulmonary secretions or by decreasing the tenacity with which exudates adhere to the lower respiratory tract.</p>
<p><strong>Histamine</strong>
A compound found in cells and released in allergic, inflammatory reactions with resultant dilation of capillaries, decreased BP, increased gastric secretions and constriction of the smooth muscles of the bronchi and uterus. Anaphylactic shock may result when massive amounts are released.</p>
<p><strong>Mucolytic</strong>
Any agent such as Mucomyst that dissolves or destroys mucus.</p>
<p><strong>Xanthine derivative</strong>
Any of the closely related alkaloids, caffeine, theobromine, and theophylline. Their pharmacologic properties stimulate the CNS, produce diuresis, relax smooth muscle; most importantly they dilate the bronchials.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="bronchodilators">BRONCHODILATORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchodilators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>I. Groups of drugs</strong>
A. Sympathomimetics
B. Xanthine derivatives</p>
<p><strong>II. Sympathomimetics</strong>
A. Action: stimulate the production of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (CAMP), which relaxes smooth muscle</p>
<p>BRONCHODILATORS, METERED-DOSE INHALER USE ▼ 239</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Bronchospasms</li>
<li>Chronic pulmonary diseases</li>
<li>Asthma</li>
<li>Airway obstruction</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Anxiety</li>
<li>Restlessness, insomnia</li>
<li>Tremors</li>
<li>Palpitations, dysrhythmias</li>
<li>Headache</li>
<li>Rebound bronchospasm</li>
<li>Urinary retention</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-contraindicated-in-patients-with-hypertension-dysrhythmias-increased-cardiac-effects-with-theophylline-preparations">D. Contraindicated in patients with hypertension, dysrhythmias; increased cardiac effects with theophylline preparations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-contraindicated-in-patients-with-hypertension-dysrhythmias-increased-cardiac-effects-with-theophylline-preparations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess respiratory status and arterial blood gases</li>
<li>Instruct patient on how to use an inhaler or respiratory apparatus at home (Figure 15-1)</li>
<li>Monitor ECG and cardiac status</li>
<li>Administer with meals if gastrointestinal (GI) upset occurs</li>
<li>Emphasize compliance with dosage and schedule</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Epinephrine (Adrenalin)</li>
<li>Isoproterenol hydrochloride (Isuprel)</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-65d674d9.jpeg" alt="img-14.jpeg">
Figure 15-1. Metered-Dose Inhaler. A, Cannister without a spacer. B, Cannister with a spacer for clients with coordination difficulty. Spacer improves drug delivery deep into lungs. (From Clark J, Queener S, &amp; Karb V: Pharmacologic basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-369297dc.jpeg" alt="img-15.jpeg"></p>
<p>240 ▼ CHAPTER 15 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Isoetharine hydrochloride (Bronkosol)</li>
<li>Albuterol (Ventolin)</li>
<li>Metaproterenol sulfate (Alupent)</li>
<li>Terbutaline sulfate (Brethine)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-xanthine-derivatives-methylxanthines">III. Xanthine derivatives: methylxanthines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-xanthine-derivatives-methylxanthines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Actions:</strong> inhibit phosphodiesterase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down CAMP. Because this enzyme is inhibited, more CAMP is available for bronchodilation. These agents also stimulate cardiac muscle and the central nervous system (CNS), increase cardiac output, produce diuresis, and decrease peripheral vascular resistance (PVR).</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Bronchospasm</li>
<li>Asthma</li>
<li>Wheezing and dyspnea associated with pulmonary diseases</li>
<li>Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or chronic airway limitations (CAL)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>CNS stimulation: “tremors” (later sign of toxicity), nervousness, insomnia, agitation, convulsions</li>
<li>Cardiac stimulation: tachydysrhythmias, tachycardia, angina, hypotension</li>
<li>GI distress: “nausea” (first sign of toxicity), vomiting, anorexia</li>
<li>Toxicity</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Interactions</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Increased side effects with high intake of caffeine</li>
<li>Altered cardiac status with most of the cardiac agents</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Give during the daytime to prevent insomnia</li>
<li>Monitor blood levels for toxicity: therapeutic blood level is 10 to 20 ug/ml; toxicity may occur with small increases &gt;20 ug/ml</li>
<li>Instruct client as follows
a. Be compliant with dosing, schedule, and blood work
b. Do not crush or alter the dosage form
c. Take with milk or food if GI distress occurs
d. Avoid smoking because it increases metabolism of these agents</li>
<li>Monitor for side effects and report the first sign of cardiac disturbances. The event of tachycardia does not warrant discontinuing the drug; instead, the dosage may be decreased.</li>
</ol>
<p>XANTHINE DERIVATIVES, DECONGESTANTS, ANTIHISTAMINES ▼ 241</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Aminophylline (Aminophyllin, Somophyllin)—IV only</li>
<li>Oxtriphylline (Choledyl)</li>
<li>Theophylline (Theolair)</li>
<li>Anhydrous theophylline (Theodur)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="upper-respiratory-drugs">UPPER RESPIRATORY DRUGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#upper-respiratory-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-decongestants">I. Decongestants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-decongestants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: shrink nasal membranes by a vasoconstrictive mechanism
B. Uses: upper respiratory infections (URI), sinusitis
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>CNS stimulation: nervousness, restlessness, insomnia</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Palpitations, hypertension</li>
<li>Rebound engorgement: swelling and congestion of the nasal mucosa when the parasympathetic nervous system tries to equalize the effects of the sympathomimetic decongestant drugs</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Instruct the client not to overuse the agent because it may be habit forming. Limit the number of days used.</li>
<li>Limit caffeine intake</li>
<li>Maintain sitting position when taking these drugs</li>
<li>Consult pharmacist before taking these products with diet pills</li>
<li>Consult physician before use if hypertension is present</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Oxymetazoline (Afrin, Dristan)</li>
<li>Phenylephrine (NeoSynephrine)</li>
<li>Pseudoephedrine + chlorpheniramine + dextromethorphan + acetaminophen (Comtrex)</li>
<li>Pseudoephedrine hydrochloride (Sinutab, Sudafed)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-antihistamines">II. Antihistamines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-antihistamines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: compete for H₁ receptor sites
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Rhinitis: inflammation of the mucous membranes of the nose accompanied by swelling of the mucosa and nasal discharge</li>
<li>Common cold</li>
<li>Allergic responses: itchy, watery eyes</li>
<li>Sinusitis</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 15 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Headache</li>
<li>Anticholinergic effects: dry mouth, urinary retention, dilated pupils, tachycardia, decreased GI motility</li>
<li>CNS: sedation, dizziness; antihistamines cross the blood-brain barrier</li>
<li>Hypotension, palpitations</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Take at bedtime if possible to avoid sedation during the day</li>
<li>If taken during the day, caution the client about safety measures with driving, operating machinery, and ambulating. Sedation usually decreases with repeated doses.</li>
<li>Caution older adults in particular about sedative effects</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Diphenhydramine hydrochloride (Benadryl)</li>
<li>Terfenadine (Seldane)</li>
<li>Brompheniramine maleate (Dimetane)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs-affecting-cough">DRUGS AFFECTING COUGH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-cough" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-diluents">I. Diluents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-diluents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-sterile-water">A. Sterile water<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-sterile-water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Action: liquefies mucus, which facilitates removal of secretions</li>
<li>Uses
a. Helps remove secretions
b. Decreases mucus plug formation
c. Diluent given by ultrasonic nebulization</li>
<li>Nursing implications
a. Taken systemically, tap water acts as an expectorant
b. Consume 2 to 3 quarts of tap water per day to help eliminate secretions unless contraindicated by presence of congestive heart failure (CHF) or fluid restrictions</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-sterile-normal-saline-sodium-chloride">B. Sterile normal saline (sodium chloride)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-sterile-normal-saline-sodium-chloride" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Action: exerts osmotic pressure on plasma fluids, which results in hydration of respiratory secretions</li>
<li>Nursing implications: caution use by clients with cardiac problems or when edematous states exist</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-mucolytic-drugs">II. Mucolytic drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-mucolytic-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-actions-work-directly-on-mucus-to-reduce-thickness-and-make-secretions-less-tenacious-alters-metabolism-of-acetaminophen-to-decrease-injury-to-the-liver-in-overdose">A. Actions: work directly on mucus to reduce thickness and make secretions less tenacious. Alters metabolism of acetaminophen to decrease injury to the liver in overdose.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions-work-directly-on-mucus-to-reduce-thickness-and-make-secretions-less-tenacious-alters-metabolism-of-acetaminophen-to-decrease-injury-to-the-liver-in-overdose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>DILUENTS, MUCOLYTICS, EXPECTORANTS ▼ 243</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Inhalation
a. Respiratory conditions with thick mucus
b. Cystic fibrosis</li>
<li>Orally: acetaminophen overdose</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Nausea, vomiting (may be due to rotten egg odor)</li>
<li>Bronchospasm</li>
<li>Burning in back of throat</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>May be given by nebulization, IV, orally, or instilled in endotracheal tube</li>
<li>Dilute with sterile water to ensure that all of drug is given</li>
<li>Use cautiously in older adults or individuals with severe respiratory insufficiency (may cause bronchospasm)</li>
<li>Offer face cloth after inhalation (leaves sticky coating)</li>
<li>Suction and encourage coughing after administration</li>
<li>Assess lung sounds and respiratory status</li>
<li>Administer by mouth mixed with iced liquid, about 17 doses over a 4-day period in acetaminophen overdose</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-common-drug-acetylcysteine-mucomyst">E. Common drug: acetylcysteine (Mucomyst)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drug-acetylcysteine-mucomyst" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-expectorants">III. Expectorants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-expectorants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-actions">A. Actions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>remove viscid secretions by reducing adhesiveness and surface tension. Iodide preparations act directly on bronchial tissue to increase the secretion of respiratory fluids and decrease the viscosity of mucus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Respiratory difficulty in children</li>
<li>Bronchitis</li>
<li>Persistent coughs</li>
<li>Mucus plugs</li>
<li>Influenza</li>
<li>Common cold</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects-rare-may-include-gi-upset">C. Major side effects: rare, may include GI upset<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects-rare-may-include-gi-upset" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess lung sounds and secretions: color, consistency, amount</li>
<li>Offer 2 to 3 quarts of fluid per day unless contraindicated</li>
<li>Administer potassium iodide solution (SSKI) with juices to disguise taste; have client use a straw to decrease taste</li>
<li>Do not offer water before or after expectorant agents except for SSKI</li>
</ol>
<p>244 ▼ CHAPTER 15 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Potassium iodide solution (SSKI)</li>
<li>Guaifenesin (Robitussin, Glycotuss)</li>
<li>Dextromethorphan hydrobromide + benzocaine (Formula 44D, Vicks Cough Syrup)</li>
<li>Dextromethorphan hydrobromide + guaifenesin + phenylpropanolamine HCL (Naldecon)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iv-antitussives">IV. Antitussives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-antitussives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Actions: suppress the cough reflex center in the medulla. Some are peripherally acting and some are centrally acting.
B. Uses: suppress nonproductive cough and/or assist in nighttime sleep in children with productive cough. Can be combined with a narcotic or nonnarcotic agents.
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Dry secretions</li>
<li>Drowsiness without respiratory depression</li>
<li>Constipation</li>
<li>Narcotic abuse</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Wait 15 to 20 minutes after taking the syrup before drinking any liquid</li>
<li>Monitor use because these are controlled substances</li>
<li>Take at bedtime</li>
<li>Monitor bowel elimination</li>
<li>Humidify air during sleep time to improve effectiveness</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Interactions: a synergistic effect with alcohol and CNS depressants</p>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Nonnarcotic</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Benzonatate (Tessalon)
b. Diphenhydramine hydrochloride (Benylin)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Narcotic</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Codeine sulfate
b. Hydrocodone bitartrate (Hycodan)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-respiratory-agents">OTHER RESPIRATORY AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-respiratory-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-prophylactic-asthmatic-drugs">I. Prophylactic asthmatic drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-prophylactic-asthmatic-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: prevent the release of histamine
B. Use: prevent acute attacks in asthma</p>
<p>ANTITUSSIVES, PROPHYLACTIC ASTHMATIC DRUGS, CORTICOSTEROIDS ▼ 245</p>
<p>C. <strong>Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Headache</li>
<li>Bronchospasm</li>
<li>Dry throat</li>
</ol>
<p>D. <strong>Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Teach client how to use inhaler</li>
<li>Do not mix with bronchodilators given by inhalation</li>
<li>Assess breath sounds</li>
<li>Give by inhalation, since it is absorbed poorly from oral route</li>
</ol>
<p>E. <strong>Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Cromolyn sodium (Intal)</li>
<li>Pirbuterol (Maxair)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-antiinflammatory-agents-corticosteroids">II. Antiinflammatory agents: corticosteroids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-antiinflammatory-agents-corticosteroids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. <strong>Actions</strong>: inhibit bronchodilation; decrease activity of inflammatory cells in the respiratory tract</p>
<p>B. <strong>Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Asthma</li>
<li>Withdrawal from systemic corticosteroids</li>
<li>Exacerbation of COPD or CAL</li>
</ol>
<p>C. <strong>Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Oral and nasal irritation</li>
<li>Fungal infections</li>
<li>Death due to adrenal insufficiency</li>
</ol>
<p>D. <strong>Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Carefully monitor client during stressful situations or when acute asthma attacks occur</li>
<li>Assess oral cavity, encourage drinking of water after each inhalation</li>
<li>Allow 1 to 2 minutes between inhalations</li>
</ol>
<p>E. <strong>Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Beclomethasone dipropionate (Vanceril)</li>
<li>Beclomethasone dipropionate (Beclovent)</li>
<li>Dexamethasone sodium phosphate (Decadron Phosphate)</li>
<li>Flunisolide (AerobBid)</li>
</ol>
<p>246 ▼ CHAPTER 15 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>A client, age 4, with bronchitis, is producing a thick, yellow sputum, is febrile, and is not sleeping well at night. He is prescribed dextromethorphan hydrobromide (Naldecon), 1 tsp tid during waking hours and dextromethorphan hydrobromide + guaifenesin + phenylpropanolamine + codeine (Naldecon CX), 1 tsp at night. What would the nurse explain to the client's mother?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. The Naldecon is better and therefore given more often
b. There is no difference between the two; they both help him bring up the secretions
c. The Naldecon helps him bring up the secretions during the day, and the other suppresses the cough at night
d. The Naldecon CX is more potent in bringing up secretions</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>The active ingredient in most antitussives that makes them controlled substances is</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Codeine sulfate
b. Phenobarbital sodium
c. Meperidine hydrochloride (Demerol)
d. Morphine sulfate</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>While making early morning rounds, the nurse notices a client's hands trembling. This client with CAL receiving aminophylline (Aminophyllin) through a continuous drip. The client says he feels fine, but could not sleep last night. The nurse would be concerned about</li>
</ol>
<p>a. CNS depression sometimes accompanying xanthine derivatives
b. CNS stimulation often accompanying xanthine derivatives
c. Anticholinergic effects of Theophylline
d. Cardiovascular depression accompanying aminophylline agents</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>During assessment for sinusitis and influenza, the client uses oxymetazoline (Afrin) nasal spray twice. When asked about the use of the Afrin, she replies, “I can’t seem to get my nose open no matter how much I use this stuff.” The nurse would suspect</li>
</ol>
<p>a. CNS stimulation
b. Improper administration
c. Rebound engorgement
d. Oxymetazoline toxicity</p>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 247</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Instructions for a client with asthma who is learning to use an inhaler would be as follows
a. Hold the inhaler between the lips, activate the inhaler, and take a deep breath
b. Shake the inhaler while holding it between two fingers, exhale completely, activate the inhaler for as many puffs as the physician ordered as you inhale slowly and deeply, and hold breath for approximately 5 to 10 seconds
c. Hold the inhaler between two fingers, take a deep breath as you activate the inhaler for as many puffs as the physician ordered, and continue inhaling for 5 seconds
d. Shake the inhaler, then take several deep breaths while activating the inhaler</li>
</ol>
<p>248 ▼ CHAPTER 15 DRUGS AFFECTING THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The Naldecon helps to bring up the secretions during waking hours, and the codeine in the CX form helps to suppress the cough. The Naldecon is not better but serves a different purpose during the day. Option <em>b</em> is partially true, but the difference is that the CX (with codeine) helps to suppress the cough. There is no truth to the statement in option <em>d</em>.</td><td>Remember that <em>codiene</em> controls the cough to allow for rest. Note it doesn’t <em>eliminate</em> the cough reflex; It suppresses the cough reflex.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: a</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Codeine is used in many prescription cough agents to suppress the cough. The agent in option <em>b</em> is not used in respiratory agents because of the CNS depressant effect. Demerol would decrease respiration rate and depth, which could worsen most respiratory problems. Morphine is not used for respiratory problems; it is used, however, in acute pulmonary edema—not to impact the lung or decrease pain, but to decrease severe anxiety.</td><td>Make an educated guess and eliminate answers <em>b</em>, <em>c</em>, and <em>d</em>. That leaves <em>a</em>. If you had no idea of the correct response, cluster <em>c</em> and <em>d</em> since they are in the same classification and eliminate them. Then “go with what you know”—phenobarbital is more commonly used for seizure activity. Select option <em>a</em>.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Stimulation of the CNS creates nervousness and trembling</td><td>Match the clue in the stem, “could not sleep,” with “stimulation” in</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 249</p>
<p>and is common with xanthine derivatives. Theophylline products do not have anticholinergic effects.</p>
<p><strong>4. Correct answer: c</strong></p>
<p>Frequent administration of Afrin can cause rebound engorgement. The complaints by the client in option <em>a</em> are not explained by CNS stimulation. Administration, even if improper, would not cause these symptoms in option <em>b</em>. Toxicity is not a side effect of this medication.</p>
<p><strong>5. Correct answer: b</strong></p>
<p>This is the best explanation of the length of inhalation after activation of the inhaler; if a second dose is needed the client should wait 1 to 2 minutes. The explanation in option <em>a</em> is true but not clear enough. The client should exhale before activating the inhaler and taking a deep breath. Activation of the inhaler should be slightly after initial inhalation.</p>
<p>response <em>b</em>. The other responses in <em>a</em> and <em>d</em> suggest a slowing.</p>
<p>Match ideas: “can’t get my nose open” suggests “engorgement.”</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct response, select the one that gives the most detail or information, <em>b</em>.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>251
CHAPTER 16</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-used-to-treat-cancer">Drugs Used to Treat Cancer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-used-to-treat-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the major groups of drugs used to treat cancer.</li>
<li>Identify the most common side effects of antineoplastic agents.</li>
<li>Describe nursing implications for these agents.</li>
</ul>
<p>252 ▼ CHAPTER 16 DRUGS USED TO TREAT CANCER</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Alopecia</strong>
Partial or complete lack or loss of hair.</p>
<p><strong>Bone marrow depression</strong>
A suppression of the manufacture and maturation of red blood cells.</p>
<p><strong>Cell-cycle nonspecific</strong>
The action of an agent without regard to the stage of cell division.</p>
<p><strong>Cell-cycle specific</strong>
The action of an agent at a specified stage of cell division.</p>
<p><strong>Chemotherapeutic agent</strong>
The treatment of infections and other diseases with chemical agents. In <em>modern usage</em>, it usually refers to the use of chemicals to <em>destroy cancer cells</em> on a selective basis; not to kill the cells but to impair their ability to replicate. Agents are termed cytotoxic.</p>
<p><strong>Non-vesicant</strong>
A drug incapable of causing tissue necrosis when extravasated.</p>
<p><strong>Stomatitis</strong>
Any inflammatory condition in the mouth.</p>
<p><strong>Vesicant</strong>
A drug capable of causing tissue necrosis when extravasated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antineoplastics">ANTINEOPLASTICS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antineoplastics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-general-considerations">I. General considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-general-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Goals of treatment are to kill cancer cells and to conserve normal cells by interfering with cancer cell reproduction. These agents are used to do the following</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Cure</li>
<li>Relieve symptoms</li>
<li>Prevent complications</li>
<li>Reduce tumor size before surgery</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Two types of agents</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Cell-cycle specific: respond during a specific cycle of the cell. Usually work best in multiple, repeated doses.</li>
<li>Cell-cycle nonspecific: respond during any phase, sometimes in more than one phase at a time. These agents are dose-dependent.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Growth fraction: the number of proliferating cells in the system. Because the bone marrow, hair follicles, and cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract have the highest growth fraction, these areas suffer the greatest toxicity.</strong></p>
<p>ANTINEOPLASTICS ▼ 253</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-principles-of-chemotherapy">D. Principles of chemotherapy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-principles-of-chemotherapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Timing of dose around the cell cycle and in relation to other drugs is critical</li>
<li>Combination therapy is often more effective</li>
<li>Effectiveness of the drug relies on the number of cells in division</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-recovery-periods-are-needed-to-allow-normal-cells-to-regenerate-therefore-chemotherapy-may-be-given-for-several-months-and-then-stopped-for-a-period-of-time">E. Recovery periods are needed to allow normal cells to regenerate. Therefore chemotherapy may be given for several months and then stopped for a period of time.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-recovery-periods-are-needed-to-allow-normal-cells-to-regenerate-therefore-chemotherapy-may-be-given-for-several-months-and-then-stopped-for-a-period-of-time" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="f-agents-are-classified-according-to-tissue-response-if-infiltration-occurs">F. Agents are classified according to tissue response if infiltration occurs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-agents-are-classified-according-to-tissue-response-if-infiltration-occurs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Vesicant: causing blisters, tissue sloughing, necrosis</li>
<li>Nonvesicant: usually administered first, no severe tissue destruction</li>
<li>Irritant: causing cellulitis, thrombophlebitis, possible necrosis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-preparation-and-administration">II. Preparation and administration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-preparation-and-administration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-handling-of-chemotherapeutic-agents">A.
