Handling of chemotherapeutic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-handling-of-chemotherapeutic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Use gloves, protective garment, mask</li>
<li>Use laminar flow hood for preparation</li>
<li>Prime the intravenous (IV) line with normal saline, then hang the chemotherapeutic agent. The IV line can also be primed under a laminar flow hood.</li>
<li>Dispose all materials used in preparation and administration in a container labeled “Hazardous Waste”</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-management-during-administration">B. Management during administration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-management-during-administration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>After drawing up the medication, change the needle</li>
<li>Check that the client has been informed of benefits and risks</li>
<li>Choose appropriate site (start distal and move to proximal sites; avoid sites over joints)</li>
<li>Know drug compatibilities</li>
<li>Consider sequence, delivery, vesicant properties</li>
<li>Check for blood return in IV according to agency policy</li>
<li>Avoid extravasation of IV; stabilize with splint if necessary</li>
<li>Know the characteristics of the individual drug being administered</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-major-side-effects-and-nursing-implications">III. Major side effects and nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-major-side-effects-and-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-bone-marrow-depression">A. Bone marrow depression<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-bone-marrow-depression" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Leukopenia: a decrease in the number of white blood cells. Assess for infection. A temperature of 99° F in the leukopenic client is a concern.</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 16 DRUGS USED TO TREAT CANCER</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Thrombocytopenia: a decrease in the number of platelets. Assess for bleeding such as petechiae (typically on the chest or upper arms).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anemia: a decrease in hemoglobin; monitor hemoglobin and hematocrit (H&amp;H). Assess H&amp;H and for clinical findings—pallor of skin, increased fatigue, or shortness of breath especially with activity.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Nausea and vomiting (N/V): give antiemetics before symptoms develop and before therapy begins</p>
<ol>
<li>Chemotherapy agents stimulate the chemoreceptor trigger zone</li>
<li>N/V may be psychogenic or anticipatory</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Stomatitis: inflammation of the mouth; offer good mouth care and topical antibiotics or analgesics
D. Alopecia: loss of hair; may be most distressing for clients</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-classification-of-agents-table-16-1">IV. Classification of agents (Table 16-1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-classification-of-agents-table-16-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Alkylating agents
B. Antimetabolites
C. Antibiotics
D. Hormonal agents
E. Radioactive agents
F. Miscellaneous individual agents</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-general-nursing-implications">V. General nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-general-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Recommend use of body surface area (BSA) to determine correct dosage
B. Avoid contact with skin or inhalation
C. Know hospital protocol for administering agents
D. Monitor blood counts
E. Assess condition of skin, IV site, bowel habits, signs of dehydration, bleeding, infection
F. Offer oral hygiene and assess oral cavity
G. Offer small, frequent meals
H. Do not handle or administer if you are pregnant or breast feeding</p>
<p>I. What to teach the client</p>
<ol>
<li>Signs of infection, bleeding, dehydration</li>
<li>To avoid over-the-counter medications</li>
<li>The need for compliance</li>
<li>That relief of nausea is maximized with antiemetics before the next chemotherapy visit</li>
</ol>
<p>255
Continued.</p>
<p>Table 16-1. Antineoplastic Agents: Classifications, Actions, Side Effects, Uses, and Considerations</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Classification/Action</th><th>Side Effects</th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>S</td><td>NS</td><td>BD</td><td>N-V</td><td>Alo</td><td>Sto</td><td>Uses</td><td>Considerations</td></tr><tr><td>Alkylating Agents</td><td></td><td>*</td><td>++</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td></td><td>Leukemia; Hodgkin's; lymphoma; cancers of the breast, ovaries, testes, prostate</td><td>Cause infertility problems</td></tr><tr><td>Busulfan (Myleran)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Mustard is a vesicant</td></tr><tr><td>Chlorambucil (Leukeran)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Cisplatin is an irritant</td></tr><tr><td>Cisplatin (Platinol)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Mechlorethamine (Mustard)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Disrupt structure of DNA</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Antimetabolites</td><td>*</td><td></td><td>++</td><td></td><td></td><td>+</td><td>Leukemia; cancers of the breast, GI tract, neck, cervix</td><td>Can cause nephrotoxicity and liver dysfunction</td></tr><tr><td>Cytarabine (Cytosar-U)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Effective in rapidly proliferating cancers</td><td>Monitor BUN, creatinine</td></tr><tr><td>Floxuridine (FUDR)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Encourage fluids</td></tr><tr><td>Fluorouracil (5-FU)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Taking folic acid may increase protection of normal cells</td></tr><tr><td>Mercaptopurine (6-MP)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Some are irritants</td></tr><tr><td>Methotrexate (MTX)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>▼ Inhibit DNA and RNA synthesis</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Hormonal Antineoplastic Agents</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td></td><td>Cancers of prostate, breast, endometrium, renal system</td><td>Mostly palliative</td></tr><tr><td>Androgens, estrogens, progesterones, corticosteroids</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Teach about characteristics of opposite sex, decreased libido, and breast tenderness</td></tr><tr><td>▼ Cytostatic; alter hormonal environment of tumor</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>S = Cell-cycle specific</td><td>N-V = Nausea/vomiting</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>+ = Frequently occurs</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>NS = Cell-cycle nonspecific</td><td>Alo = Alopecia</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>++ = Severe side affect</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>BD = Bone marrow depression</td><td>Sto = Stomatitis</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>▼ = Action of agents in classification</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 16-1. Antineoplastic Agents: Classifications, Actions, Side Effects, Uses, and Considerations—cont'd</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Classification/Action</th><th>Side Effects</th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th>Uses</th><th>Considerations</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>S</td><td>NS</td><td>BD</td><td>N-V</td><td>Alo</td><td>Sto</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Radioactive Drugs</td><td>*</td><td></td><td>++</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Leukemia, thyroid cancer</td><td>Require protective isolation to prevent radiation contamination</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium radioiodine (Iodotope)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>May cause radiation sickness</td></tr><tr><td>Sodium radiophosphate (P 32) Radiogold (150Au)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Emit radiation to destroy specific tissue</td><td></td><td>*</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Antibiotics</td><td>*</td><td>*</td><td>++</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td></td><td>Hodgkin's, testicular carcinoma, breast and bladder cancers</td><td>All are vesicants except bleomycin is an irritant</td></tr><tr><td>Doxorubicin (Adriamycin)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Severe tissue damage if extravasate</td></tr><tr><td>Bleomycin (Blenoxane)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>Teach signs of infection</td></tr><tr><td>Plicamycin (Mithracin)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Bind with DNA; cytotoxic effect; antimicrobial activity</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>S = Cell-cycle specific</td><td>N-V = Nausea/vomiting</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>+ = Frequently occurs</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>NS = Cell-cycle nonspecific</td><td>Alo = Alopecia</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>++ = Severe side affect</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>BD = Bone marrow depression</td><td>Sto = Stomatitis</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>▼ = Action of agents in classification</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 257</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A client diagnosed with cancer of the testes is receiving an antibiotic antineoplastic agent. The nurse would teach him to
a. Eat six small meals instead of three large ones
b. Report a temperature of 101° F, chills, and any discomfort
c. Drink 2400 cc of fluids to prevent constipation
d. Report signs of nephrotoxicity</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following might occur because of the high growth fraction in response to chemotherapeutic agents?
a. Headache
b. Hypernatremia
c. Diarrhea
d. Constipation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Antimetabolites cause which additional severe side effect?
a. Liver complications
b. Infertility
c. Differences in sex characteristics
d. Ototoxicity</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Before giving parenteral a chemotherapeutic agent, the nurse would perform which nursing assessment?
a. Assess bowel sounds
b. Check the last complete blood count for a high white count
c. Assess for stomatitis
d. Check for adequate blood return from the IV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client is experiencing the signs of bone marrow depression—thrombocytopenia. The nurse would teach him to observe daily for
a. Infection
b. Stomatitis
c. Petechiae
d. Diarrhea</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Two chemotherapeutic agents are ordered to be given: one is a vesicant, the other a nonvesicant. In what order would the nurse give them?
a. Give the nonvesicant first because the vesicant may irritate the IV site
b. Give the vesicant to get the most difficult one infused first
c. It should not matter
d. Administer the agents together</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>258 ▼ CHAPTER 16 DRUGS USED TO TREAT CANCER</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Bone marrow depression is the prime side effect and could cause leukopenia. <em>If</em> nausea is a problem, six small meals could help. Constipation and nephrotoxicity are not common side effects.</td><td>Make an educated guess: most chemotherapy for cancer has side effects of bone marrow depression. This results in a decreased white count with increased risk of infection. Thus response <em>b</em> is best.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Diarrhea is common because the cells of the GI tract multiply rapidly. High-growth fraction does not affect the brain, causing headaches. A high-growth fraction does not cause an elevated sodium level. Constipation is not a common side effect.</td><td>Figure that “high-growth fraction” attracts the medication for a toxic effect and irritability. Of the given responses, only <em>c</em> suggests irritability.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: a</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Hepatotoxicity is a common side effect of these agents. Option <em>a</em> is not a side effect with these drugs. Option <em>c</em> is a major side effect of the hormonal antineoplastic agents. Complications in hearing are not common with chemotherapeutic agents.</td><td>The important word in the stem is “severe.” It leads to response <em>a</em>, since, of the given responses, this option would be the most severe side effect in any situation.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>4. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Many of the agents are irritating if extravasation occurs; a healthy IV line with adequate blood flow is necessary to prevent vascular complications.</td><td>Use common knowledge that before administration of an IV medication, the line needs to be patent, especially if the agent is caustic to the vein.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 259</p>
<p>Assessing bowel sounds may be advisable if nausea and diarrhea are present, but not before administering the agent. Response <em>b</em> is not a necessary nursing action before giving the agents; since many of the agents lower the white count, high counts are not as common. Stomatitis is usually a side effect of the agents.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="5-correct-answer-c">5. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Bleeding is possible with thrombocytopenia because of a decrease in platelets. Petechiae, especially on the anterior chest or upper arms, is an early sign of low platelets. Infection would be a concern if leukopenia were present. Stomatitis is not a complication arising from bone marrow depression. Response <em>d</em> is not a side effect of bone marrow depression.</p>
<p>Cluster responses <em>a</em>, <em>b</em>, and <em>d</em> under “involvement with inflammation.” The only response left is <em>c</em>. Use this if you have no clue to the correct answer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="6-correct-answer-a">6. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>If the vesicant were given first and caused irritation, the non-vesicant would not be administered unless a new line were started. The most irritating should be given last in case complications arise. Because of the possible complications, it does make a difference which is given first. Two agents should never be given at the same time because of the possible side effects and complications.</p>
<p>Use common sense to conclude that the nonirritating agent is to be given first.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>261
CHAPTER 17</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-used-to-treat-infections">Drugs Used to Treat Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-used-to-treat-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the difference between narrow-spectrum and broad-spectrum antimicrobial agents.</li>
<li>Describe the major classifications of agents used: penicillins, cephalosporins, tetracyclines, sulfonamides, aminoglycosides, macrolides, quinolones.</li>
<li>Describe the agents and uses of antifungal, antiviral, antitubercular, antihelmintic, and antimalarial agents.</li>
<li>Identify the major side effects and nursing implications for each of the classifications.</li>
</ul>
<p>262 ▼ CHAPTER 17 DRUGS USED TO TREAT INFECTIONS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Peak and trough</strong>
Test obtained to establish the peak, the highest concentration of a drug, may be measured immediately after the drug has been administered; and the trough, the lowest concentration of a drug, may be measured immediately before the drug is administered.</p>
<p><strong>Resistance</strong>
A situation when an organism is not affected or only minimally affected by antimicrobial drugs.</p>
<p><strong>Sensitivity</strong>
A situation when an organism is affected by low concentrations of antimicrobial drugs.</p>
<p><strong>Superinfection</strong>
An infection occurring during antimicrobial treatment for another infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibiotics">ANTIBIOTICS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibiotics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-general-information">I. General information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-general-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Agent classifications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Narrow-spectrum: treat relatively limited number of organisms; less likely to disrupt the normal flora; used when an organism has been identified by a culture</li>
<li>Extended-spectrum: treat multiple organisms; more likely to disrupt the normal flora; used often when a specific causative organism is unknown</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. General side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Hypersensitivity</li>
<li>Toxicity to various organs: kidney, liver, skin, bone marrow</li>
<li>Superinfection based on the disruption of the normal flora of the body: black, furry tongue; thrush; vaginal discharge</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Many microorganisms have become resistant to antibiotics. A culture and sensitivity (C&amp;S) or gram stain is preferred to specify the exact organism.</strong></p>
<p><strong>D. General nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Assess for the results of the C&amp;S or ensure that the culture has been completed before starting a new antibiotic</li>
<li>What to instruct the client
a. Take all of the medication, even after symptoms subside, to prevent recurrence of the infection</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIBIOTICS: GENERAL INFORMATION, PENICILLINS ▼ 263</p>
<p>b. Use another type of contraceptive if the client is taking birth control pills. Many of the antibiotics will decrease the effectiveness of birth control pills.
c. Immediately report any signs of allergic reaction</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Monitor blood levels
a. Peak: time of maximum effect
b. Trough: level prior to the next dose; should be drawn 30 minutes before the next dose is given</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Monitor the complete blood count (CBC), especially the white blood count (WBC) and the differential to evaluate the effectiveness of the antibiotic; expect WBC to decrease</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If severe diarrhea occurs, instruct the client to take buttermilk or yogurt to replace the normal intestinal flora</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Know the difference
a. Bacteriostatic: tending to restrain the development of the reproduction bacteria
b. Bactericidal: tending to kill bacteria</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-penicillins">II. Penicillins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-penicillins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: interfere with cell wall synthesis and division of bacteria</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Gram-positive cocci, rods, and anaerobic bacteria</li>
<li>Pharyngitis: inflammation of the pharynx</li>
<li>Endocarditis: an abnormal, infectious condition that affects the endocardium and heart valves</li>
<li>Pneumonia</li>
<li>Meningitis</li>
<li>Syphilis, gonorrhea</li>
<li>Shigella: gram-negative organism causing gastroenteritis and bacterial dysentery</li>
<li>Salmonella: gram-negative, rod-shaped bacteria; affects the GI tract</li>
<li>Upper respiratory infections (URI)</li>
<li>Urinary tract infections (UTI)</li>
<li>Otitis media</li>
<li>Sinusitis</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Rash on abdomen, scalp, or arms—usually the first finding of allergic reaction</li>
<li>Anaphylaxis</li>
<li>Serum sickness: an immunologic disorder that may occur 2 to 3 weeks after the administration of an antiserum</li>
</ol>
<p>264 ▼ CHAPTER 17 DRUGS USED TO TREAT INFECTIONS</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Hematologic reactions: decreased hemoglobin, prolonged bleeding</li>
<li>Diarrhea</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Assess for known previous allergies</li>
<li>Discontinue immediately if signs of allergic reactions occur. Benadryl may be given for mild reactions.</li>
<li>Monitor for seizures in clients with renal disease</li>
<li>Penicillin G (Pentids) should be given with food</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Categories</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Natural penicillins
a. Penicillin G (Pentids)
b. Penicillin VK (V-Cilin K)</li>
<li>Penicillinase-resistant penicillins
a. Methicillin (Staphcillin)
b. Nafcillin (Unipen)</li>
<li>Aminopenicillins
a. Amoxicillin (Amoxil) ☑
b. Ampicillin (Polycillin)</li>
<li>Extended-spectrum penicillins
a. Piperacillin (Pipracil)
b. Carbenicillin (Geopen)
c. Ticarcillin (Ticar)</li>
<li>Combination products
a. Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid (Augmentin) ☑
b. Ampicillin + sulbactam (Unasyn) ☑
c. Ticarcillin + clavulanic acid (Timentin)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>III. Cephalosporins</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Actions:</strong> inhibit cell wall synthesis, thereby resembling penicillin action. Work especially well on rapidly growing organisms; they are bacteriostatic and bacteriocidal.</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Upper respiratory infection</li>
<li>Urinary tract infection</li>
<li>MRSA (methicillin-resistant staphylococci)</li>
<li>Beta-hemolytic streptococci</li>
<li>Klebsiella infections</li>
<li>Surgical prophylaxis</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Superinfections</li>
</ol>
<p>CEPHALOSPORINS, TETRACYCLINES ▼ 265</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>More resistance to gram-positive organisms as spectrum broadens (third generation)</li>
<li>False-positive glucose values</li>
<li>Nephrotoxicity: toxicity to the kidney</li>
<li>Pain at injection site</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Assess for allergies; if allergic to penicillin, client may not be able to take these agents either</li>
<li>Monitor renal status: I&amp;O, serum creatinine</li>
<li>Assess for superinfection with teaching clients about the use of buttermilk and yogurt</li>
<li>Monitor IV infusion closely for pain and irritation</li>
<li>Monitor glucose level if client is a diabetic</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Generations according to spectrum</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>First generation: work best against gram-positive bacteria; ☐ often used in clients allergic to penicillin
a. Uses: E. coli, klebsiella, proteus, salmonella, shigella
b. Common drugs
(1) Cephalothin (Keflin)
(2) Cephalexin (Kefzol)
(3) Cephapirin (Cefadyl) ☑
(4) Cephradine (Anspor) ☑
(5) Cefadroxil (Duricef) ☑</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Second generation: work best against gram-negative bacteria
a. Uses: proteus, E. cloacae, hemophilus influenza
b. Common drugs
(1) Cefamandole (Mandol) ☑
(2) Cefoxitin (Mefoxin)
(3) Cefaclor (Ceclor)
(4) Cefonocid (Monocid)
(5) Cefotetan (Cefotan)
(6) Ioracarbef (Lorabid)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Third generation: work best against gram-negative bacteria
a. Uses: serratia, pseudomonas aeruginosa
b. Common drugs
(1) Cefotaxime (Claforan)
(2) Cefoperazone (Cefobid)
(3) Ceftriaxone (Rocephin) ☑</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>IV. Tetracyclines (broad-spectrum)</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Actions:</strong> inhibit protein synthesis in the bacterial cell; bacteriostatic</p>
<p>266 ▼ CHAPTER 17 DRUGS USED TO TREAT INFECTIONS</p>
<p><strong>AB. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria</li>
<li>Aerobic and anaerobic bacteria</li>
<li>Lyme’s disease</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Superinfection</li>
<li>Interfere with normal calcification and may cause gray teeth</li>
<li>Photosensitivity: sunscreens do not seem to decrease photosensitivity</li>
<li>GI disturbances: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea</li>
<li>Hepatotoxicity: toxicity to the liver</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Contraindicated for use in children under 8 years of age due to staining of teeth. Decreased absorption if taken with iron, milk, and antacids.</strong></p>
<p><strong>E. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Take on an empty stomach (better absorption) unless GI disturbances occur. Can be taken with food but may decrease absorption.</li>
<li>Use protection in direct sunlight; clothing rather than sunscreen</li>
<li>Assess for signs of superinfection: oral cavity, vaginal discharge</li>
<li>Administer with full glass of water</li>
<li>Inform patient that stools may be yellow or green</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>F. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Doxycycline (Vibramycin)</li>
<li>Minocycline (Minocin)</li>
<li>Oxytetracycline (Terramycin)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>V. Aminoglycosides</strong>
<strong>A. Actions:</strong> inhibit protein synthesis; bacteriostatic (low doses) and bacteriocidal (high doses)
<strong>B. Use:</strong> primarily for gram-negative bacilli
<strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Ototoxicity: toxic to nerves or organs of hearing; results in a hearing loss</li>
<li>Nephrotoxicity</li>
<li>Dizziness, vertigo, ataxia</li>
<li>Neuromuscular blockade: the inhibition of a muscular contraction activated by the nervous system, resulting in weakness or paralysis</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Interactions:</strong> inactivation when mixed with extended-spectrum penicillins</p>
<p>AMINOGLYCOSIDES, MACROLIDES, SULFONAMIDES ▼ 267</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Do not give at the same time as extended-spectrum penicillin; separate by at least 2 hours</li>
<li>Use cautiously with anesthetics and muscle relaxants</li>
<li>Monitor renal function: creatinine, I&amp;O</li>
<li>Monitor peak and trough levels</li>
<li>Assess for hearing loss</li>
<li>Give with a large amount of fluids</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Gentamicin (Garamycin)</li>
<li>Amikacin (Amikin)</li>
<li>Tobramycin (Nebcin, Tobrex)</li>
<li>Streptomycin</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="vi-macrolides">VI. Macrolides<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-macrolides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-actions-bind-to-ribosomes-to-inhibit-protein-synthesis-bacteriostatic-action">A. Actions: bind to ribosomes to inhibit protein synthesis; bacteriostatic action<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions-bind-to-ribosomes-to-inhibit-protein-synthesis-bacteriostatic-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Gram-negative and gram-positive organisms</li>
<li>Staph Aureus infections</li>
<li>Pneumonia</li>
<li>Patients allergic to penicillin</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>GI disturbances: diarrhea, nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Hepatotoxicity</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess for frequent diarrhea and monitor weight loss, especially in children</li>
<li>Monitor for signs of hepatotoxicity (increase in ALT, AST)</li>
<li>Give with a full glass of water</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Erythromycin ethylsuccinate (EES)</li>
<li>Clarithromycin (Biaxin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="vii-sulfonamides-broad-spectrum">VII. Sulfonamides (broad-spectrum)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-sulfonamides-broad-spectrum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-action-interfere-with-paba-to-decrease-synthesis-of-folic-acid-which-is-needed-for-bacteria-survival">A. Action: interfere with PABA to decrease synthesis of folic acid, which is needed for bacteria survival<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-interfere-with-paba-to-decrease-synthesis-of-folic-acid-which-is-needed-for-bacteria-survival" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Gram-negative and gram-positive organisms</li>
<li>Urinary tract infection</li>
<li>Otitis media</li>
<li>Vaginal infections</li>
<li>Prostatitis: inflammation of the prostate gland</li>
</ol>
<p>268 ▼ CHAPTER 17 DRUGS USED TO TREAT INFECTIONS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Renal calculi</li>
<li>Hypersensitivity</li>
<li>Nephrotoxicity</li>
<li>Hematologic: decrease in WBC</li>
<li>Photosensitivity</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Encourage fluids up to 1500 cc/day</li>
<li>Monitor I&amp;O, creatinine</li>
<li>Monitor CBC, WBC</li>
<li>Protect against sunlight with clothing</li>
<li>Take on an empty stomach (better absorption) unless GI disturbance occurs; then take with small amount of food</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Trimethoprim + sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim, Septra)</li>
<li>Sulfadiazine</li>
<li>Sulfisoxazole (Gantrisin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="viii-quinolones">VIII. Quinolones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-quinolones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-action-interrupt-dna-synthesis">A. Action: interrupt DNA synthesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-interrupt-dna-synthesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Infection from E. coli</li>
<li>Gram-negative organisms</li>
<li>Urinary tract infection</li>
<li>Bronchitis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="c-common-side-effects">C. Common side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-common-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Photosensitivity</li>
<li>GI irritation: nausea</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Protect against sunlight</li>
<li>Inform the client that urine may be brown or bright orange</li>
<li>Monitor renal status (offer 1 to 2 L/day of fluids), I&amp;O, serum creatinine for an increase</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Ciprofloxacin (Cipro)</li>
<li>Norfloxacin (Noroxin)</li>
<li>Ofloxacin (Floxin)</li>
<li>Enoxacin (Penetrex)</li>
<li>Nitrofurantoin (Furadantin)</li>
<li>Phenazopyridine hydrochloride (Pyridium)</li>
</ol>
<p>QUINOLONES, ANTITUBERCULAR, ANTIVIRALS ▼ 269</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="antitubercular-agents">ANTITUBERCULAR AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antitubercular-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. Actions: exert either a tuberculostatic or tuberculocidal effect by inhibiting mycolic acid, a necessary metabolite of the organism</p>
<p>II. Uses</p>
<p>A. Prevent or treat tuberculosis
B. Treat Hansen’s disease: leprosy
C. Treat persons with positive TB tests or known exposure</p>
<p>III. Major side effects</p>
<p>A. Hepatotoxicity
B. Headache, vertigo
☑ C. Neuritis: inflammation of a nerve from B₆ deficiency
D. Jaundice</p>
<p>IV. Nursing implications</p>
<p>A. Administer on empty stomach
B. Recommended for extended periods (&gt;6 months) because the organism may lie dormant in an individual
C. Stress compliance in completing the prescription
D. Monitor liver status for elevated serum ALT, AST and jaundice
E. Stress avoidance of alcohol because of the hepatotoxic effect and possible further impairment of the liver</p>
<p>V. Common drugs</p>
<p>A. Tuberculosis
☑ 1. Isoniazid (INH)
2. Rifampin (Rifadin)
☑ 3. Streptomycin
B. Hansen’s disease—dapsone (DDS)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-agents">OTHER AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. Antivirals</p>
<p>A. Action: interfere with DNA replication of virus. This interference also can occur in the host cell.
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Herpes simplex</li>
<li>Influenza A and B</li>
<li>AIDS</li>
</ol>
<p>270 ▼ CHAPTER 17 DRUGS USED TO TREAT INFECTIONS</p>
<p>C. <strong>Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Diarrhea</li>
<li>Renal toxicity</li>
</ol>
<p>D. <strong>Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Use gloves, as some of the lesions are contagious</li>
<li>Monitor IV use carefully; prevent phlebitis</li>
</ol>
<p>E. <strong>Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Herpes: acyclovir (Zovirax)</li>
<li>Respiratory syncytial virus: ribavirin (Virazole)</li>
<li>AIDS
a. Didanosine (Videx)
b. Zidovudine (AZT)</li>
<li>☑ Influenza A: amantadine hydrochloride (Symmetrel)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-antifungals">II. Antifungals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-antifungals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. <strong>Action:</strong> alter the permeability of the cell membrane</p>
<p>B. <strong>Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>☑ Systemic and topical fungal infections</li>
<li><strong>Histoplasmosis:</strong> an infection caused by inhalation of spores of the fungus histoplasma capsulatum</li>
<li>☑ Thrush: candidiasis of the tissue of the mouth</li>
</ol>
<p>C. <strong>Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Nephrotoxicity</li>
<li>Fever, chills</li>
<li>Thrombophlebitis</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting</li>
<li>Hypokalemia: low potassium (&lt;3.5 mEq/L)</li>
<li>Hypomagnesemia: low magnesium (&lt;1.5 mEq/L)</li>
</ol>
<p>D. <strong>Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>☑ Monitor electrolytes, BUN, creatinine, CBC</li>
<li>Monitor I&amp;O due to the nephrotoxicity</li>
<li>Assess vital signs and treat fever with acetaminophen</li>
<li>Instruct client to report any abnormal symptoms</li>
<li>Instruct client to swish Mycostatin around the mouth and then swallow</li>
</ol>
<p>E. <strong>Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Amphotericin B (Fungizone)</li>
<li>Miconazole (Monistat)</li>
<li>Ketoconazole (Nizoral)</li>
<li>☑ Nystatin (Mycostatin)</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIFUNGALS, ANTIHELMINTICS, ANTIMALARIALS ▼ 271</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-antihelmintic-agents">III. Antihelmintic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-antihelmintic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: destroy parasitic helminths (worms) by affecting the nervous system
B. Uses: treat roundworms, tapeworms, flatworms, and flukes
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Toxicity: medicine kills the helminth, which spills out its toxin</li>
<li>GI distress: nausea, anorexia</li>
<li>Dehydration, anemia
D. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Assess for proper identification of the type of worm</li>
<li>Stress good handwashing, gloving, and proper disposing of feces and urine</li>
<li>Suggest treating all members of the family to prevent recurrence</li>
<li>Encourage washing bed linen with hot water to destroy the parasites</li>
<li>Instruct patient to take the entire recommended dose
E. Common drugs
☑ 1. For amebiasis: metronidazole (Flagyl)
☑ 2. For roundworm/hookworm: mebendazole (Vermox)
☑ 3. For pinworm: pyrantel pamoate (Antiminth)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iv-antimalarial-agents">IV. Antimalarial agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-antimalarial-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: kill the parasite
B. Use: malaria
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>GI distress: nausea</li>
<li>Agranulocytosis</li>
<li>Headache, agitation
D. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Complete the entire course of therapy</li>
<li>May begin taking 1 to 2 weeks before traveling to an endemic area</li>
<li>Give with food to minimize GI distress
E. Common drugs</li>
<li>Chloroquine (Aralen)</li>
<li>Hydroxychloroquine sulfate (Plaquenil)</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 17 DRUGS USED TO TREAT INFECTIONS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity are <strong>major side effects</strong> with which of the following?
a. Penicillin
b. Sulfonamides
c. Erythromycin
d. Aminoglycosides</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nursing implications for clients on antibiotics for an <strong>extended period</strong> would include which of the following?
a. Take with a full glass of water or food
b. Take buttermilk or yogurt if diarrhea occurs
c. Watch for a decrease in urine production
d. Watch for an increase in urine production</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A <strong>serious and dangerous side effect</strong> of penicillin is
a. Anaphylaxis
b. Nephrotoxicity
c. Hepatotoxicity
d. Neuromuscular blockade</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The best antibiotic for a urinary tract infection is which of these groups?
a. Penicillin G (Pentids)
b. Tobramycin sulfate (Tobrex)
c. Trimethoprim + sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim)
d. Erythromycin ethylsuccinate (EES)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Since a client's annual tuberculosis test was reported as positive, the client should be placed on which agent prophylactically?
a. Cloroquine (Aralene)
b. Mebendazole (Vermox)
c. Isoniazid (INH)
d. No agent; obtain a chest x-ray</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which is the best agent for amebiasis?
a. Mebendazole (Vermox)
b. Metronidazole (Flagyl)
c. Pyrantel pamoate (Antiminth)
d. Chloroquine (Aralen)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 273</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Both of these are major side effects of the aminoglycosides and should be monitored carefully. The key word is “major” side effects. The aminoglycosides, garamycin, kanamycin, and streptomycin, can be thought of as the “mycin” family, which has affects on a few major body functions. A major side effect of penicillins is rash, initially found on the abdomen. Renal calculi from crystals is a major side effect of sulfonamides, especially if sufficient fluids are not taken during therapy. GI disturbance, especially diarrhea, is a major side effect of erythromycin.</td><td>Refer to the rationale.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>All antibiotics can destroy the normal flora in the intestines, and diarrhea can occur. Yeast, buttermilk, or yogurt can replace the bacteria. Some of the agents require hydration because of the effect on the kidneys. Not all antibiotic agents are nephrotoxic. None of the antibiotic agents result in an increase in urine output.</td><td>The key word in the stem is “extended” period. Think of superinfections or secondary infections as the result of the suppression of normal flora. In short-term therapy this may be less likely.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>274 ▼ CHAPTER 17 DRUGS USED TO TREAT INFECTIONS</p>
<ol start="3">
<li><strong>Correct answer: a</strong>
Severe allergic response such as anaphylaxis is more common with the penicillin group.
Aminoglycosides are particularly nephrotoxic.
Tetracyclines are hepatotoxic.
Aminoglycosides can produce neuromuscular blockade.</li>
</ol>
<p>The important words in the stem are “serious” and “dangerous.” These guide you to response <em>a</em>.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li><strong>Correct answer: c</strong>
Sulfonamides are broad spectrum and work well on urinary tract infections. Penicillins work best on gram-positive bacteria. Aminoglycosides work best on gram-negative bacilli. Macrolides work best on pneumonia or staph aureus infections.</li>
</ol>
<p>Remember <em>Bactrim</em> is used for bladder infections.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li><strong>Correct answer: c</strong>
INH is the recommended drug to treat positive TB skin test or the active disease. The agent in option <em>a</em> is recommended for malaria. The agent in option <em>b</em> is recommended for roundworms. The most current recommendation is to treat any positive TB test with 6 months of INH, whether the chest x-ray is positive or not.</li>
</ol>
<p>Eliminate option <em>d</em> since it does not answer THE question of which agent. Then approach your choice with a “go with what you know”; most likely INH is a more familiar drug than the drugs in options <em>a</em> and <em>b</em>. Select option <em>c</em>.</p>
<ol start="6">
<li><strong>Correct answer: b</strong>
Option <em>b</em> is the drug of choice for amebiasisa. Option <em>a</em> is the drug of choice for roundworms. Option <em>c</em> is the drug of choice for pinworms. Option <em>d</em> is the drug of choice for malaria.</li>
</ol>
<p>For this type of difficult question, select an answer and go on. Keep your emotional reaction to a minimum so you can think about the remaining questions. This would be a good time for a few deep breaths with your eyes closed.</p>
<p>275
CHAPTER 18</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dermatological-agents">Dermatological Agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dermatological-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify agents used to treat various skin disorders.</li>
<li>Describe side effects, nursing implications, and uses for the different groups of drugs.</li>
<li>Discuss the medications administered to burn patients.</li>
</ul>
<p>276 ▼ CHAPTER 18 DERMATOLOGICAL AGENTS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Antiparasitic</strong>
A substance that kills parasites or inhibits their growth or reproduction such as amebicides, anthelmintics, and antimalarials.</p>
<p><strong>Antiseptic</strong>
A substance that inhibits the growth and reproduction of microorganisms.</p>
<p><strong>Astringent</strong>
A substance that causes contraction of tissues upon application, usually locally or in a bath such as alum or tannic acid.</p>
<p><strong>Debriding agent</strong>
A substance that removes damaged tissue or cellular debris from a wound to prevent infection and promote healing.</p>
<p><strong>Disinfectant</strong>
A chemical that can be applied to objects to destroy microorganisms.</p>
<p><strong>Emollient</strong>
A substance that softens tissue particularly the skin and mucous membranes.</p>
<p><strong>Keratolytics</strong>
A substance that loosens or causes shedding of the outer layer of skin.</p>
<p><strong>Liniments</strong>
A preparation, usually containing an alcoholic, oily, or soapy vehicle, that is rubbed into the skin as a counterirritant.</p>
<p><strong>PABA</strong>
Paraaminobenzoic acid, a topical sunscreen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-antiseptics-and-disinfectants">I. Antiseptics and disinfectants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-antiseptics-and-disinfectants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-actions-denature-protein-reduce-surface-tension-or-interfere-with-the-metabolic-processes-of-cell-growth">A. Actions: denature protein, reduce surface tension, or interfere with the metabolic processes of cell growth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions-denature-protein-reduce-surface-tension-or-interfere-with-the-metabolic-processes-of-cell-growth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Slowing microorganisms that cause infection</li>
<li>Cleaning wounds</li>
<li>Douches</li>
<li>Irrigants</li>
<li>Preparing skin for treatment</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Hypersensitivity</li>
<li>Teratogenic effects on fetus</li>
<li>Nephrotoxicity</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Know the proper use of the agent; some can be used to pack wounds and some cannot</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTISEPTICS, DISINFECTANTS, BATHS, CLEANSERS ▼ 277</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Watch for signs of hypersensitivity: rash, itching, redness, drying of skin</li>
<li>Use gloves to apply</li>
<li>Know the proper dilution if required</li>
<li>Know the organism on the skin and the agent sensitive to that organism. Some of these agents are not effective against spores.</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Chlorhexidine gluconate (Hibiclens)</li>
<li>Sodium hydrochloride</li>
<li>Hydrogen peroxide</li>
<li>Acetic acid</li>
<li>Alcohol</li>
<li>Hexachlorophene (PhisoHex)</li>
</ol>
<p>II. Baths
A. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Cleanse</li>
<li>Soothe puritis</li>
<li>Medicate</li>
<li>Reduce temperature</li>
<li>Lubricate skin
B. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Can cause drying of the skin</li>
<li>Use only tepid water, without alcohol, to lower temperature
C. Common drugs</li>
<li>Oatmeal (Aveeno)</li>
<li>Starch</li>
<li>Gelatin</li>
<li>Alpha-Keri lotion</li>
</ol>
<p>III. Soaps and cleansers
A. Soaps</p>
<ol>
<li>Uses: for cleaning the skin and for enemas; are antimicrobial</li>
<li>Nursing implications
a. Soaps may irritate mucous membranes
b. May have glycerin or medication added</li>
<li>Common soaps
a. Safeguard
b. Zest
c. Dial
d. Lifebuoy
e. Castile</li>
</ol>
<p>278 ▼ CHAPTER 18 DERMATOLOGICAL AGENTS</p>
<p>B. Cleansers: soap-free or modified soap products; may include an emollient</p>
<ol>
<li>Uses: persons with sensitive or irritated skin or those with previous reactions to soap products; are not antimicrobial</li>
<li>Common cleansers
a. Phisoderm
b. Oatmeal (Aveeno bar)
c. Dove
d. Acne Aide
e. Caress
f. Neutrogena</li>
</ol>
<p>IV. Emollients
A. Actions: fatty or oily substances that soften or soothe irritated skin and mucous membranes; often used as vehicles for other medications
B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Treating diaper rash</li>
<li>Lubricating</li>
<li>Soothing</li>
<li>Inserting tubes and catheters
C. Common emollients</li>
<li>Petrolatum (Vaseline)</li>
<li>Vitamin A&amp;D ointment (Clocream, Desitin)</li>
<li>Lubriderm</li>
<li>Nivea skin</li>
<li>Lanolin products</li>
<li>Glycerin (Corn Husker’s Solution)</li>
<li>K-Y Jelly</li>
</ol>
<p>V. Solutions and lotions
A. Actions</p>
<ol>
<li>Treat inflammation</li>
<li>Protect and heal skin</li>
<li>Decrease itching
B. Uses</li>
<li>Insect bites</li>
<li>Diaper rash</li>
<li>Prickly heat</li>
<li>Poison ivy</li>
<li>Acne</li>
<li>Chicken pox</li>
</ol>
<p>EMOLLIENTS, SOLUTIONS, ASTRINGENTS, SKIN PROTECTANTS ▼ 279</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Infections</li>
<li>Wet dressings</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Calamine lotion: shake well before application; good to relieve itching</li>
<li>Diphenhydramine hydrochloride (Benadryl)</li>
<li>Boric acid solution</li>
<li>Aluminum acetate solution (Burrow’s Solution)</li>
<li>Aluminum sulfate (Domeboro)</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Calamine + diphenhydramine hydrochloride (Caladryl) is not recommended for children with chicken pox. It will slow the recovery. Use oatmeal baths to minimize itching.</p>
<p>VI. Astringents
A. Actions: provide comfort because of tightening properties and ability to decrease inflammation and exudate
B. Uses: acne, hemorrhoids
C. Common agents</p>
<ol>
<li>Aluminum sulfate (Domeborro)</li>
<li>Tucks</li>
</ol>
<p>VII. Skin protectants
A. Actions: protect or coat minor skin irritations
B. Uses: ulcers, wounds, protection of skin
C. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Physical sunscreens are thick and offer the best protection. Must be applied heavily.</li>
<li>Chemical sunscreens are absorbing and the most appealing</li>
<li>Sun protection factor (SPF) ranges from 2 to 45 and should be chosen depending on the climate and type of skin. The higher the number, the greater the protection.
D. Common drugs</li>
<li>Benzoin</li>
<li>Kerodex</li>
<li>PABA (suntan products)</li>
<li>Liquid petrolatum (mineral oil)</li>
</ol>
<p>VIII. Rubs and liniments
A. Actions</p>
<ol>
<li>Analgesic</li>
<li>Antiinflammatory</li>
</ol>
<p>280 ▼ CHAPTER 18 DERMATOLOGICAL AGENTS</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Local anesthetic</li>
<li>Antiseptic</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Muscle aches</li>
<li>Neuralgia</li>
<li>Rheumatoid arthritis</li>
<li>Sprains</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>BenGay</li>
<li>Vaporub</li>
<li>Aspercreme</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>IX. Protectives</strong>
<strong>A.</strong> Actions: soothe, cool, and form film on skin. The film aids in healing and in decreasing odors.
<strong>B.</strong> Uses: wounds or minor abrasions
<strong>C.</strong> Nursing implication: may have to be peeled off because the powders stick to wet surfaces only
<strong>D. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Collodion</li>
<li>Zinc oxide</li>
<li>Talcum powder</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>X. Topical antiinfectives</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Antibacterials</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Actions: inhibit or destroy microorganisms by interfering with metabolic activity; also retard growth of bacteria</li>
<li>Uses
a. Wounds, minor abrasions
b. Acne
c. Burns
d. <em>Streptococcus</em> and <em>staphylococcus</em></li>
<li>Special considerations for silver sulfadiazine (Silvadene)
a. Stains clothing or skin a gray color
b. Hypersensitivity: can cause burning, itching, blistering
c. Can be absorbed systemically; monitor for renal insufficiency
d. Use gloves to apply</li>
<li>Common drugs
a. Bacitracin (Baciguent)
b. Neomycin sulfate (Myciguent)
c. Silver sulfadiazine (Silvadene Cream)
d. Mupirocin (Bactroban)</li>
</ol>
<p>PROTECTIVES, TOPICAL ANTIINFECTIVES, ANTIINFLAMMATORIES ▼ 281</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-antivirals">B. Antivirals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-antivirals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Actions: inhibit viral replication, decrease pain, and increase healing of skin lesions</li>
<li>Uses: treat herpes simplex, varicella zoster</li>
<li>Common drugs
a. Acyclovir (Zovirax)
b. Amantadine (Symmetrel)
c. Zidovudine (Retrovir)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-antifungals">C. Antifungals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-antifungals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Actions: offer fungistatic and fungicidal properties</li>
<li>Uses
a. Superficial fungal infections
b. Athlete’s foot
c. Jock itch
d. Ringworm
e. Candida albicans
f. Candidiasis</li>
<li>Common drugs
a. Clotrimazole (Lotrimin)
b. Toinaftate (Tinactin)
c. Nystatin (Mycostatin)
d. Amphotericin B (Fungizone)
e. Ketoconazole (Nizoral)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xi-antiinflammatory-agents">XI.
