Antiinflammatory agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xi-antiinflammatory-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-actions">A. Actions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Alleviate inflammation response</li>
<li>Antipruritic</li>
<li>Vasoconstrictive</li>
<li>Reduce itching, redness, and swelling associated with an allergic response</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Psoriasis</li>
<li>Dermatitis</li>
<li>Minor skin irritations</li>
<li>Allergic responses</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-nursing-implications">C. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Do not use with an antifungal</li>
<li>Do not use on broken skin (increased absorption results)</li>
<li>Applying a dressing will increase absorption on thick lesions</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Common drugs 1. Hydrocortisone (Cortaid) 2. Betamethasone valerate (Valisone) 3. Desoximetasone (Topicort) 4. Fluocinonide (Lidex) 5. Flurandrenolide (Cordran)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xii-antiparasitic-agents">XII. Antiparasitic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xii-antiparasitic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Groups 1. Scabicides: eradicate scabies 2. Pediculicides: eradicate lice</p>
<p>B. Actions: cause paralysis and death of parasites by blocking nerve impulse transmission</p>
<p>C. Major side effects 1. Systemic effect, which can cause toxicity to kidneys, heart, and CNS 2. Seizures 3. Renal complications 4. Drying out of hair and skin 5. Irritation to skin: itching, stinging</p>
<p>D. Nursing implications 1. Encourage client to read the instructions well on the medication 2. Instructions vary concerning application a. Some call for repeating the application in 7 to 10 days b. Shampoos are left on 4 to 10 minutes. Instructions depend on whether hair is shampooed wet or dry. c. Lotion may need to be applied again in 24 hours, followed by a shower d. Gloves should be used if medication is applied by the nurse e. Bedding and clothing should be washed with hot water and bleached if possible f. The whole family may need to be treated</p>
<p>E. Common drugs 1. Lindane (Kwell) 2. Pyrethrins with piperonyl butoxide (RID) 3. Lindane shampoo (Kwell) 4. Permethrin (NIX)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xiii-keratolytics">XIII. Keratolytics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xiii-keratolytics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: soften and loosen the outer, horny layer of thickened skin by removing excess keratin</p>
<p>ANTIPARASITICS, KERATOLYTICS, DEBRIDING AGENTS ▼ 283</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Acne</li>
<li>Warts</li>
<li>Psoriasis</li>
<li>Corns</li>
<li>Calluses</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-nursing-implications-repeat-application-and-apply-dressings">C. Nursing implications: repeat application and apply dressings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-nursing-implications-repeat-application-and-apply-dressings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-common-drugs">D. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Salicylic acid (Occlusal)</li>
<li>Sulfur (Sebulex)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xiv-debriding-agents">XIV. Debriding agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xiv-debriding-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-proteolytic-preps">A. Proteolytic preps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-proteolytic-preps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Actions: digest or liquefy necrotic tissue and purulent exudate</li>
<li>Uses: debride decubitus, burns, severe wounds</li>
<li>Major side effects
a. Allergic response
b. Pain at the site
c. Bleeding at the site</li>
<li>Nursing implications
a. Use a tongue depressor to apply
b. Avoid excess heat
c. Protect the healthy skin
d. Clean the area if needed before application</li>
<li>Common drugs
a. Fibrinolysin + desoxyribonuclease (Elase)
b. Trypsin + Peru balsam + castor oil (Granulex)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-nonenzyme-forms">B. Nonenzyme forms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-nonenzyme-forms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Absorptive beads: debrisan is poured into the wound and acts by physical absorption of wound</li>
<li>Duoderm or op site: dressings used for decubitus and stasis ulcers. Duoderm has moisture-reactive particles that create a soft gel over the wound. Liquefied material resembling pus will be evident when the duoderm is removed. Both should be changed every 7 days.</li>
</ol>
<p>284 ▼ CHAPTER 18 DERMATOLOGICAL AGENTS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A common side effect of silver sulfadiazine (Silvadene) cream used on burns is
a. Hives
b. Drying of the skin
c. Graying of the skin
d. Burning on the skin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client, age 32, is suffering from athlete's foot with itching and discomfort. The nurse would recommend which of these products?
a. Acyclovir (Zovirax)
b. Hydrocortisone
c. Clotrimazole (Lotrimin)
d. Ketoconazole (Nizoral)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A frantic mother calls because her infant has excessively dry skin that is beginning to look cracked. The mother states that she has been washing it with Irish Spring soap. The nurse might recommend
a. Safe Guard
b. Oatmeal (Aveeno) cleansing bar
c. Calamine lotion after the bath
d. Dove</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The nurses' aid reports that a client has red, bleeding, irritated buttocks from frequent diarrhea stools. The nurse should begin to use which preparation for protection of the skin?
a. Lubriderm
b. Zinc oxide
c. Glycerine (Corn Husker's Solution)
d. Silver sulfadiazine (Silvadene)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Instructions for a mother for treating her child's chicken pox would be to use
a. Oatmeal (Aveeno) baths for soothing and calamine lotion
b. Oatmeal (Aveeno) baths for healing and diphenhydramine hydrochloride + calamine (Caladryl Lotion)
c. Oatmeal (Aveeno) cleansing bar and calamine lotion
d. Alpha-Keri lotion in her bath water</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 285</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The ingredients in the agent cause graying of clothing and skin. Silver sulfadiazine (Silvadene) does not commonly result in irritation and hives; it dries the wound but not the skin; it treats burns, and does not cause a burning or stinging sensation unless an allergic reaction has occured.</td><td>Use an educated guess to eliminate options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>, which tend to be findings of reactions to a substance. Reread the question; it asks for a “common side effect.” Select option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> since a desired effect would be to dry a wound.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>This is an antifungal and used to treat athlete’s foot. Acyclovir (Zovirax) is used primarily for herpes virus such as fever blisters. Hydrocortisone is used primarily for inflammation. Ketoconazole (Nizoral) is used for seborrheic dermatitis.</td><td>On these types of questions when you may have no idea of the correct answer, make a selection. Go to the next question only after you have done a relaxation exercise such as a few slow, deep breaths. Keep your tiredness or tenseness to a minimum so you can better answer the remaining questions. Remember you will have a few questions that will be unfamiliar content.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Dove is gentle and does not dry the skin. Safegard, an antibacterial or antimicrobial soap, is harsh for an infant and will dry the skin. The oatmeal could sooth but the continued use of Irish Spring would continue to dry the skin. A deodorant soap is antimicrobial and therefore</td><td>The best approach is to use your common knowledge of soaps.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>286 ▼ CHAPTER 18 DERMATOLOGICAL AGENTS</p>
<p>dries the skin out. Calamine lotion would further dry the skin.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li><strong>Correct answer: b</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>Zinc protects the skin to assist in healing. Lubriderm would not heal broken, irritated skin. Glycerine would soften skin and may irritate open, broken skin. Silvadene does heal the skin, but in this case the priority is protection from the diarrhea.</p>
<p>The key idea in the stem is to “protect” the skin. Of the given substances, associate that zinc oxide is used in the summertime as a skin protectant from the sun—recall those white-nosed children on the beach. Thus, select response <em>b</em> in this situation.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li><strong>Correct answer: a</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>These agents in option <em>a</em> together offer the most relief from itching. Caladryl should not be used because it prolongs the healing time and dries the skin. The approach in option <em>c</em> is not inappropriate, but rubbing the skin with a washcloth in using the oatmeal bar soap may not be tolerated by the child. Alpha-Keri would not soothe the itching.</p>
<p>It is important to identify the difference between “calamine” and “Caladryl”; remember that Caladryl has a <em>d</em> in it and has a significant <em>d</em>rying effect.</p>
<p>287
CHAPTER 19</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-gastrointestinal-system">Drugs Affecting the Gastrointestinal System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-gastrointestinal-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify those drugs commonly used to treat peptic ulcer disease and hyperacidity.</li>
<li>Describe the difference between emetics and antiemetics.</li>
<li>Identify the groups of drugs commonly used as digestants, antidiarrheals, and laxatives.</li>
<li>Describe the use and action of activated charcoal.</li>
<li>Describe the side effects and nursing implications of the drugs used to treat the gastrointestinal system.</li>
</ul>
<p>288 ▼ CHAPTER 19 DRUGS AFFECTING THE GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Antispasmodics</strong>
A drug or other agent such as belladonna and dicyclomine hydrochloride (Antispas) that prevents smooth muscle spasms, as in the uterus, digestive system, or urinary tract.</p>
<p><strong>Cathartic</strong>
Also called <em>laxative</em> or <em>coprogogue</em>, a substance that promotes bowel evacuation by stimulating peristalsis, increasing the fluidity or bulk of intestinal contents, softening the stool, or lubricating the intestinal wall.</p>
<p><strong>Emetics</strong>
A substance such as syrup of ipecac that causes vomiting used in the emergency treatment of overdosage or in certain cases poisoning; it can be cardiotoxic if absorbed and not vomited.</p>
<p><strong>Malabsorption syndrome</strong>
A complex of symptoms resulting from disorders in the intestinal absorption of nutrients, characterized by anorexia, weight loss, bloating of the abdomen, muscle cramps, bone pain, and steatorrhea. Anemia, weakness and fatigue occur because iron, folic acid, and vitamin B₁₂ are not absorbed in sufficient quantities. Examples: gastric or small bowel resection, celiac disease, cystic fibrosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs-used-to-treat-peptic-ulcer-disease-and-gastric-hyperacidity">DRUGS USED TO TREAT PEPTIC ULCER DISEASE AND GASTRIC HYPERACIDITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-used-to-treat-peptic-ulcer-disease-and-gastric-hyperacidity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-antacids">I. Antacids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-antacids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Actions:</strong> neutralize gastric acid and raise the pH of the stomach, thereby relieving heartburn and the pain associated with gastric disorders</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Indigestion</li>
<li>Reflux esophagitis: esophageal irritation and inflammation resulting from reflux of the stomach contents into the esophagus</li>
<li>Peptic ulcers</li>
<li>Ulcer prevention</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Rebound hyperacidity: an excessive amount of acidity in the stomach</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTACIDS, H₃ HISTAMINE RECEPTOR ANTAGONISTS ▼ 289</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Sodium retention</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal (GI) disturbances
a. Constipation (aluminum and calcium)
b. Diarrhea (magnesium)</li>
<li>Electrolyte disturbances
a. Hypermagnesemia: hypotension, nausea, vomiting, ECG changes (magnesium-containing antacids)
b. Hypophosphatemia: anorexia, malaise, muscle weakness (aluminum-containing antacids)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Assess the effectiveness of the medication</li>
<li>Avoid other medications that lower the stomach pH or increase hyperacidity, such as caffeine and acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin)</li>
<li>Take 1 hour after eating and do not take other medications within 1 to 2 hours of taking the antacid</li>
<li>Shake most liquids well and follow with a full glass of water</li>
<li>Instruct clients to inquire about interactions with any new medications and over-the-counter (OTC) preparations</li>
<li>Inform clients that they may experience better relief from liquids than tablets</li>
<li>Monitor for constipation and diarrhea. Medication or dose may need to be changed.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Interactions are too numerous to name within this text. Of special importance is the decrease in absorption of medications when these agents are given with digoxin and antibiotics.</strong></p>
<p><strong>F. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Aluminum hydroxide (AlternaGel, Amphojel)</li>
<li>Magnesium hydroxide (Milk of Magnesia)</li>
<li>Calcium carbonate (Alka-Mints, Tums)</li>
<li>Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃)</li>
<li>Aluminum-magnesium complex (Maalox, Riopan, Riopan Plus)</li>
<li>Magnesium-hydroxide + aluminum hydroxide with simethicone (Maalox TC, Mylanta II)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>II. H₃ histamine receptor antagonists</strong></p>
<p><strong>A. Actions:</strong> inhibits the release of histamine at histamine H₂ receptor sites and decreases gastric acidity</p>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Treatment of ulcers</li>
<li>Prevention of stress ulcers</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 19 DRUGS AFFECTING THE GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Hyperacidity</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal (GI) bleed</li>
<li>Prevention of allergic responses</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Confusion</li>
<li>Nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain</li>
<li>Anemia, blood dyscrasias</li>
<li>Severe bradycardia after IV administration</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions: increased action of many of the cardiac drugs and anticoagulants</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Instruct client to limit caffeine intake</li>
<li>Should administer before meals (AC) and at bedtime (HS)</li>
<li>Do not administer at the same time as antacids</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Cimetidine (Tagamet)</li>
<li>Ranitidine (Zantac)</li>
<li>Famotidine (Pepcid)</li>
<li>Nizatidine (Axid)</li>
<li>Other agents—gastric mucosa protectants
a. Sucralfate (Carafate) forms a barrier at the ulcer site, prevents NSAID-induced gastric ulcers and absorbs pepsin. It must be taken on an empty stomach for the best effect.
b. Misoprostol (Cytotec) is used with peptic ulcers. Uterine contractions are common and can cause miscarriages.</li>
</ol>
<p>III. Anticholinergic agents (antispasmodics)</p>
<p>A. Actions</p>
<ol>
<li>Reduce gastric acid secretion</li>
<li>Decrease smooth muscle motility</li>
<li>Delay gastric emptying time</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Adjuncts to peptic ulcer disease</li>
<li>Spasms and cramping associated with irritable bowel syndrome</li>
<li>Colic in children</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Tachycardia</li>
<li>Dry mouth</li>
<li>Constipation</li>
<li>Urinary retention</li>
<li>Sedation (may be preferred)</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTICHOLINERGICS, DIGESTANTS, ANTIFLATULENT AGENTS ▼ 291</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Many of these agents come from belladonna plants and are termed belladonna alkaloids. Many others contain atropine sulfate (prototype).</li>
<li>Monitor bowel elimination</li>
<li>Treat side effects per physician orders</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Atropine sulfate</li>
<li>Belladonna alkaloids</li>
<li>Hyoscyamine sulfate (Levsin, Anaspaz)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-gastrointestinal-agents">OTHER GASTROINTESTINAL AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-gastrointestinal-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-digestants">I. Digestants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-digestants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: work in various ways to aid in digestion by replacing missing substances that naturally digest food</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Malabsorptive syndromes: a complex of symptoms resulting from disorders in the intestinal absorption of nutrients</li>
<li>Achlorhydria: absence of hydrochloric acid in the gastric juice</li>
<li>Hypochlorhydria: a deficiency of hydrochloric acid in the stomach's gastric juice</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects: vary with each drug and are limited</p>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Take with or immediately after meals</li>
<li>Drink a full glass of water with each dose</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Hydrochloric acid</li>
<li>Pancreatin (Dizymes)</li>
<li>Famotidine (Pepsin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-antiflatulent-agents">II. Antiflatulent agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-antiflatulent-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: aids in breaking up gas bubbles trapped in the intestines</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Postoperatively</li>
<li>Children with colic</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effect: constipation</p>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Drink plenty of water</li>
<li>Treat the constipation</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common drug: simethicone (Mylicon)</p>
<p>CHAPTER 19 DRUGS AFFECTING THE GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-antiemetics">III. Antiemetics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-antiemetics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-drug-groups">A. Drug groups<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-drug-groups" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Phenothiazines</li>
<li>Antihistamines</li>
<li>Anticholinergics</li>
<li>Other individual drugs</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-actions-depends-on-the-group-used">B. Actions: depends on the group used<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-actions-depends-on-the-group-used" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Phenothiazines decrease the response of the chemoreceptor trigger zone by inhibiting the dopaminergic receptors</li>
<li>Antihistamines block the H₁ receptors</li>
<li>Anticholinergics prevent motion sickness by decreasing GI motility and secretions</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-uses">C. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Severe nausea</li>
<li>Vomiting</li>
<li>Before or after chemotherapy</li>
<li>Motion sickness</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-major-side-effects-are-group-related">D. Major side effects: are group related<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-major-side-effects-are-group-related" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Anticholinergic effects: dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, tachycardia</li>
<li>Drowsiness</li>
<li>Extrapyramidal findings with phenothiazines: tardive dyskinesia, chorea, athetosis, Parkinson's disease symptoms</li>
<li>Hypersensitivity</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Motion sickness: take 30 minutes to 1 hour before the activity that causes nausea</li>
<li>Caution the client about the sedative properties</li>
<li>Give Vistaril Z-track</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Chlorpromazine hydrochloride (Thorazine)</li>
<li>Promethazine (Phenergan)</li>
<li>Prochlorperazine maleate (Compazine)</li>
<li>Metoclopramide hydrochloride (Reglan)</li>
<li>Scopolamine (Triptone)</li>
<li>Dimenhydrinate (Dramamine)</li>
<li>Hydroxyzine pamoate (Vistaril)</li>
<li>Diphenhydramine hydrochloride (Benadryl)</li>
<li>Meclizine hydrochloride (Antivert)</li>
<li>Trimethobenzamide hydrochloride (Tigan)</li>
</ol>
<p>ANTIEMETICS, EMETICS, LAXATIVES ▼ 293</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-emetics">IV. Emetics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-emetics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: irritate the stomach and stimulate the vomiting center in the brain</p>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Overdose</li>
<li>Accidental poisoning</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Toxicity</li>
<li>Abuse by bulemic patients</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Interactions with alcohol and central nervous system depressants</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Instruct clients to have a bottle of ipecac at home in case of accidental ingestion especially with children. Note expiration date.</li>
<li>Never administer to semicomatose or comatose patients</li>
<li>Can be very messy and difficult for a child to ingest</li>
<li>Administer dosage for ipecac of 10 ml followed by a glass of water in children &lt;1 year of age; 15 ml followed by water for children &gt;1 year; 15 to 30 ml followed by several glasses of water for adults</li>
<li>May repeat ipecac dose in 30 minutes if first dose does not produce emesis</li>
<li>Never give with or after activated charcoal. If needed, give before the activated charcoal.</li>
<li>Never give to clients who are unconscious or who accidentally ingest a caustic substance</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Ipecac syrup</li>
<li>Apomorphine hydrochloride</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-laxatives-cathartic">V. Laxatives (cathartic)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-laxatives-cathartic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: specific to the group (Table 19-1)</p>
<p>B. Major side effects: dehydration, straining</p>
<p>C. General nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor the client for misuse of these agents; can be habit forming</li>
<li>Monitor electrolytes</li>
<li>Assess bowel elimination pattern, GI discomforts</li>
<li>Discontinue if diarrhea persists; do not give if obstruction is suspected</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 19 DRUGS AFFECTING THE GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM</p>
<p>Table 19-1. Laxative Types</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Name</th><th>Mechanism of Action</th><th>Nursing Considerations</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Stimulants</strong></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Senna (Senokot)</td><td>Irritant to bowel; peristalsis is stimulated</td><td>Not recommended for children</td></tr><tr><td>Phenolphthalein (Ex-Lax)</td><td>Used in preparation for surgery, acute constipation</td><td>Avoid in pregnancy</td></tr><tr><td>Cascara sagrada (Cascara)</td><td></td><td>Should obtain results in 6 to 12 hours</td></tr><tr><td>Castor oil</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>Salines/Osmotics</strong></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Normal saline solution</td><td>Act by drawing water into the bowel and increasing peristalsis</td><td>Electrolyte imbalance and dehydration can occur</td></tr><tr><td>Magnesium citrate (Citrate of Magnesia)</td><td>Used for elimination of poisons; before procedures; removal of parasites</td><td>Fleets are given and rectally come in an oil-retention form that is good for older clients</td></tr><tr><td>Epsom salts</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Magnesium salts (MOM)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Sodium biphosphate (Fleets)</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>Bulk-Forming</strong></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Psyllium hydrophilic muclloid (Metamucil)</td><td>Act by forming a soft, bulky mass from absorbing water</td><td>May take up to 72 hours to work</td></tr><tr><td>Methylcellulose (Maltsupex, Citrucel)</td><td>Used for chronic constipation, in infants suffering from continuous constipation, in pregnant females</td><td>Monitor elimination</td></tr><tr><td>Polycarbophil (Fibercon)</td><td></td><td>Take with a full glass of water</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Emollients/Fecal Softeners</strong></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Mineral oil</td><td>Coat the fecal mass with oil to help lubricate for easier elimination; reduce surface tension of feces</td><td>Assess electrolytes</td></tr><tr><td>Haley’s M-O</td><td></td><td>Offer candy or juice to disguise the taste</td></tr><tr><td>Docusate sodium (Colace)</td><td></td><td>Monitor electrolytes</td></tr><tr><td>Docusate calcium (Surfak)</td><td>Used in older adults when straining is prohibited (MI, eye surgery)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Docusate potassium (Dialose)</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>LAXATIVE TYPES, ANTIDIARRHEALS ▼ 295</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Teach clients the proper diet and exercise to aid in elimination</li>
<li>Clients who should avoid straining may benefit from a lubricant laxative. Mineral oil enemas work well without causing severe strain in clients who had a recent heart attack, clients with increased intracranial pressure, or older clients with fecal impaction; they also work well when saline is contraindicated.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-antidiarrheals">VI. Antidiarrheals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-antidiarrheals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Groups</p>
<ol>
<li>Absorbents</li>
<li>Opiates</li>
<li>Anticholinergics</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Actions: relieve symptoms or work against the cause of the diarrhea. Absorbents bind with bacteria or toxins.</p>
<p>C. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Short-term diarrhea</li>
<li>Irritable bowel syndrome</li>
<li>Overdose</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Constipation</li>
<li>Abuse potential</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Know how to administer properly. Some of the agents can be given after each diarrhea stool.</li>
<li>Instruct client that the agents relieve symptoms but do not cure; notify physician if diarrhea persists longer than 48 hours</li>
<li>Assess elimination, dehydration, and the results obtained</li>
<li>Activated charcoal is a powder that must be mixed with water to administer; it is also used for overdose of caustic chemicals</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Absorbents
a. Bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol)
b. Activated charcoal (Charcocaps)</li>
<li>Opiates
a. Paregoric (camphorated opium tincture)
b. Synthetic opiates
(1) Diphenoxylate hydrochloride + atropine sulfate (Lomotil)
(2) Loperamide (Imodium)</li>
<li>Anticholinergics: alcohol + kaolin + atropine + hyoscyamine sulfate + scopolamine hydrobromide (Donnagel suspension)</li>
</ol>
<p>296 ▼ CHAPTER 19 DRUGS AFFECTING THE GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="vii-flora-modifiers">VII. Flora modifiers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-flora-modifiers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: replace normal flora
B. Use: excessive diarrhea, usually from antibiotic use
C. Major side effects: overgrowth, since preparation contains lactobacillus organisms
D. Common drug: Lactinex</p>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 297</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>With an aluminum antacid, which of the following symptoms would be expected?
a. Hyperkalemia
b. Hyponatremia
c. Hypophosphatemia
d. Hypercalcemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client is taking an antacid 1 hr PC and HS and a tetracycline q 6 hours. The best times to schedule each is as follows
a. Antacid 9-1-5-9, tetracycline 8-2-8-2
b. Antacid 8-12-4-9, tetracycline 9-4-9-4
c. Schedule both together
d. Antacid 7:30-11-4-9, tetracycline 8-2-8-2</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An over-the-counter medication that mothers can use for infants with excess flatus is
a. Hyoscyamine sulfate (Levsin)
b. Simethicone (Mylicon)
c. Famotidine (Pepcid)
d. Diphenoxylate hydrochloride + atropine sulfate (Lomotil)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In preparing for a jet flight to Hawaii, Susan plans to take a dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) to relieve her motion sickness. When should she take it?
a. Once the plane has taken off
b. At least 2 hours before departure
c. When she becomes nauseated
d. About 30 minutes before boarding</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The best laxative for a client, age 63, diagnosed with a heart attack (MI) and severe constipation would be
a. 1000 cc normal saline with Castile soap
b. Psyllium hydrophilic muciloid (Metamucil), 1 tsp TID
c. Oil Retention Fleets, holding for 15 to 30 minutes if possible
d. Senna (Senokot), 2 tsp BID</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The best absorbent for accidental poisoning with a caustic substance would be
a. Bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol)
b. Syrup of ipecac
c. Activated charcoal
d. Dimercaprol (BAL)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>298 ▼ CHAPTER 19 DRUGS AFFECTING THE GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Low phosphorous is common with the aluminum-containing antacids. Thus, these antacids are used in renal failure to decrease the high phosphate levels. Antacids usually do not affect the potassium level. Sodium level may be raised with antacids. High calcium levels may be evident in calcium-containing antacids.</td><td>Remember that the two major categories for antacids are magnesium and aluminum. The two electrolytes effected are magnesium and phosphorus. Match magnesium antacid with magnesium and the other, aluminum, binds phosphorus to lower its levels.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: a</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>This schedule separates the antacid and tetracycline by one hour and follows the usual mealtimes for the antacid. The antacid is ordered 1 hour after meals. Medications should not be scheduled at the same time as antacids, since the absorption can be changed.</td><td>Remember that with most medications and antacids, the time apart for each administration is about 1 hour.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Mylicon, available without a prescription, relieves excess gas associated with colic. Levsin will decrease flatus but must be prescribed by the physician. The agent in option c are used to treat ulcers and hyperacidity. Option d is an antidiarrheal agent.</td><td>Associate that Simethicone takes away the smell of flatus, since it decreases the production of the flatus.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 299</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-correct-answer-d">4. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This allows for absorption of the agent and a peak effect during the flight. Recall the basic knowledge of drug administration by route and time of effect: PO = 30 minutes; IM = 15 minutes; IV = within 5 minutes; rectal suppository = 15 minutes; SL = within 5 to 10 minutes. The Dramamine may not be absorbed enough to relieve the motion sickness if the plane has already taken off. Two hours before would be too long, and the agent may not relieve the motion sickness. Option c would involve too long of a wait.</p>
<p>Recall the time medication taken by mouth would begin to work—in 30 to 45 minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-c">5. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An oil retention enema would provide the relief needed without the strain on the cardiac system. Saline is not recommended for a cardiac client. Metamucil may not provide the immediate relief needed but would probably be a good preventive approach. Senna would not provide the immediate relief needed.</p>
<p>Recall that when the client is already this constipated, the need is to help the stool slip out without straining. Thus the oil retention enema is the best choice.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-correct-answer-c">6. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Activated charcoal binds with the caustic agent to decrease the effects on the body. Pepto-Bismol would not be effective enough for a caustic agent. Vomiting is</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct response, “go with what you know”—that activated charcoal is used to absorb.</p>
<p>300 ♥ CHAPTER 19 DRUGS AFFECTING THE GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM</p>
<p>not recommended for a caustic substance. BAL is an antidote for heavy metal poisoning. It is given deep IM, since it is an oil-based medication. It is also used in arsenic, gold, mercury, and lead poisoning; administration is frequent, with the initial series of doses usually given daily for up to 10 days.</p>
<p>CHAPTER 20</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-the-ear-and-eye">Drugs Affecting the Ear and Eye<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-the-ear-and-eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the difference between mydriatics and cycloplegics.</li>
<li>Identify drugs that lower intraocular pressure.</li>
<li>Identify agents that decrease and increase aqueous humor.</li>
<li>Describe the role of antiinfective, antiinflammatory, and anesthetic agents used in the ear and eye.</li>
<li>Define ceruminolytics.</li>
<li>Describe major side effects and nursing implications for these agents.</li>
</ul>
<p>301</p>
<p>302 ▼ CHAPTER 20 DRUGS AFFECTING THE EAR AND EYE</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Ceruminolytic</strong>
Pertaining to a drug or other agent that loosens or dissolves cerumen (earwax) to allow for removal.</p>
<p><strong>Cycloplegic</strong>
An agent that causes paralysis with relaxation of the ciliary or ocular muscles of accommodation.</p>
<p><strong>Miotic</strong>
An agent such as pilocarpine that causes constriction of the pupil; used to treat glaucoma.</p>
<p><strong>Mydriatic</strong>
An agent that causes dilation of the pupil from the contraction dilator muscle of the iris. Such drugs as atropine, homatropine, and scopolamine are both mydriatics and cycloplegics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="agents-used-in-the-eye">AGENTS USED IN THE EYE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#agents-used-in-the-eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-mydriatics-and-cycloplegics">I. Mydriatics and cycloplegics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-mydriatics-and-cycloplegics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Actions</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Mydriatics exert a sympathetic nervous system response, causing dilation of the pupil by contraction of the pupil’s dilator muscle</li>
<li>Cycloplegics paralyze the fine-focusing muscle (accommodative muscle) by blocking cholinergic stimulation of the muscle of the iris</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Groups of drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Sympathomimetic</li>
<li>Anticholinergic acting</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Intraocular exams</li>
<li>Pre- and post-eye surgery</li>
<li>Iris refraction in children</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Local irritation</li>
<li>Burning</li>
<li>Blurred near vision; photophobia</li>
<li>Systemic reactions: tachycardia and dry mucous membranes</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Instruct the client to wear dark sunglasses until clear vision resumes</li>
</ol>
<p>EYE: MYDRIATICS, CYCLOPLEGICS, MIOTICS ▼ 303</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Teach the client proper instillation (Figure 20-1)</li>
<li>Hold pressure on lacrimal sac 1 to 2 minutes</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Contraindicated in closed-angle glaucoma if use is prolonged. Some of these agents can increase intraocular pressure with resulting ocular congestion.</p>
<p>G. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Sympathomimetic
a. Epinephrine hydrochloride (Epifrin)
b. Naphazoline hydrochloride (Naphcon)
c. OcuClear
d. Phenylephrine hydrochloride (Neo-synephrine)
e. Tetrahydrozoline hydrochloride (Murine Plus)</li>
<li>Anticholinergic acting
a. Atropine sulfate (Isopto Atropine)
b. Cyclopentolate hydrochloride (Cyclogyl)
c. Scopolamine hydrobromide (Isopto Hyoscine)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-miotics">II. Miotics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-miotics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: exert a parasympathetic response resulting in constriction of the pupil, contraction of the accommodative muscle, and decrease resistance to outflow of aqueous humor</p>
<ol>
<li>Decrease intraocular pressure: the internal pressure of the eye, regulated by resistance to the flow of aqueous humor</li>
<li>Increase outflow of aqueous humor</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Groups of drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Direct-acting cholinergics</li>
<li>Anticholinesterase agents</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Uses: treatment of glaucoma and esotropia (cross-eyed)</p>
<p>D. Major side effects: blurred vision and local irritation</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Administer at bedtime to decrease blurring of vision</li>
<li>Avoid if inflammation is present</li>
<li>Teach the client how to administer</li>
<li>Hold pressure at the lacrimal sac for 1 to 2 minutes to decrease systemic absorption</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Direct-acting cholinergics
a. Pilocarpine hydrochloride (Pilocar)
b. Carbachol (Isopto Carbachol)</li>
<li>Anticholinesterase agents
a. Demecarium bromide (Humorsol)
b. Isoflurophate (Floropryl)
c. Physostigmine salicylate (Isopto Eserine)</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-75e8f536.jpeg" alt="img-16.jpeg">
C</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-07a8b454.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg">
B</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-c2a4c6d6.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg">
A
Figure 20-1. Eye medication administration. Eye drops. A, With tissue or cotton resting below lower lid, gently press downward with thumb or forefinger against bony orbit. Ask client to look at ceiling. B, Instill eye drops while explaining steps to client. With dominant hand resting on client's forehead, hold filled medication eye dropper approximately 1 to 2 cm (½ to ¾ inch) above conjunctival sac. Drop prescribed number of medication drops into conjunctival sac. Instill eye ointment. C, Holding ointment applicator above lid margin, apply thin stream of ointment evenly along inside edge of lower eyelid on conjunctiva from the center outward. Ask client to look down. Apply thin stream of ointment along upper lid margin on inner conjunctiva. Have client close eye and rub lid lightly in circular motion with cotton ball, if rubbing is not contraindicated. (From Perry A, Potter P: Clinical Nursing Skills and Techniques, ed 3, St Louis, 1994, Mosby.)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-d0ed52aa.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg"></p>
<p>EYE DRUG ADMINISTRATION, GLAUCOMA DRUGS ▼ 305</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-other-drugs-used-to-lower-intraocular-pressure-iop">III. Other drugs used to lower intraocular pressure (IOP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-other-drugs-used-to-lower-intraocular-pressure-iop" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-actions">A. Actions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAI) reduce the amount of aqueous humor produced and thereby lower intraocular pressure (IOP)</li>
<li>Beta-adrenergic blocking agents are not quite understood; similar to CAI</li>
<li>Osmotic agents increase plasma osmolarity and thereby lower IOP</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-use">B. Use<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-use" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Open- and closed-angle glaucoma</li>
<li>Pre- and post-eye surgery</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Bradycardia</li>
<li>Headache</li>
<li>Fatigue</li>
<li>Stinging when administered</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="d-nursing-implications">D. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>CAI and osmotics are diuretics and will increase urine production. Monitor electrolytes and advise client to take early in the morning.</li>
<li>Beta blockers: monitor vital signs especially HR</li>
<li>Teach client how to administer</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="e-common-drugs">E. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>CAI
a. Acetazolamide (Diamox)
b. Dichlorphenamide (Daranide)
c. Methazolamide (Neptazane)</li>
<li>Osmotics
a. Glycerin, anhydrous (Opthalgan)
b. Isosorbide (Ismotic)
c. Mannitol (Osmitrol)</li>
<li>Beta blockers
a. Timolol maleate (Timoptic)
b. Levobunolol hydrochloride (Betagan)
c. Carteolol hydrochloride (Ocupress)
d. Betaxolol hydrochloride (Betoptic)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iv-anesthetic-agents">IV. Anesthetic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-anesthetic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-action-anesthetize-the-corneal-surface">A. Action: anesthetize the corneal surface<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-action-anesthetize-the-corneal-surface" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>An aid to instruments that measure intraocular pressure or remove foreign bodies</li>
</ol>
<p>306 ▼ CHAPTER 20 DRUGS AFFECTING THE EAR AND EYE</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Suture removal</li>
<li>Conjunctival scraping</li>
<li>Manipulation of lacrimal canal</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>C. Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Stimulation of the central nervous system: syncope, nausea, seizures</li>
<li>Hypotension</li>
<li>Transient eye pain, blurred vision, redness</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>D. Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Provide protective eye patch while eye is anesthetized</li>
<li>Instruct client not to rub the eye to prevent corneal abrasions</li>
<li>Apply pressure to the lacrimal sac for 1 to 2 minutes to prevent systemic absorption</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>E. Common drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Proparacaine hydrochloride (Alcaine)</li>
<li>Tetracaine hydrochloride (Pontocaine Hydrochloride)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>V. Antiinflammatory agents</strong>
<strong>A. Actions:</strong> decrease edema, redness, scarring, and exudate
<strong>B. Groups of drugs</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Corticosteroids</li>
<li>Nonsteroidal agents
<strong>C. Uses:</strong> inflammatory disorders, hypersensitivity conditions
<strong>D. Major side effects</strong></li>
<li>Increased intraocular pressure</li>
<li>Optic nerve damage</li>
<li>Decreased visual activity</li>
<li>Cataracts
<strong>E. Nursing implications</strong></li>
<li>Instruct in proper administration</li>
<li>Use on short-term basis only</li>
<li>Instruct client not to rub eye
<strong>F. Common drugs</strong></li>
<li>Dexamethasone (Maxidex)</li>
<li>Prednisolone sodium phosphate (Ak-Pred)</li>
<li>Diclofenac sodium (Voltaren)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>VI. Antiinfectives</strong>
<strong>A. Actions:</strong> interfere or destroy microorganisms that cause these infections: staphylococcus, streptococcus, pseudomonas, klebsiella, escherichia coli, neisseria gonorrhea</p>
<p>EYE ANESTHETICS, ANTIINFLAMMATORIES; EYE &amp; EAR ANTIINFECTIVES ▼ 307</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-groups-of-drugs">B. Groups of drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-groups-of-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Antibiotics</li>
<li>Antifungals</li>
<li>Antivirals</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-uses">C. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Infections: bacterial, fungal, viral</li>
<li>Pinkeye</li>
<li>Herpes simplex I</li>
<li>Conjunctivitis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-major-side-effects">D. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Local irritation</li>
<li>Overgrowth of microorganism</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-nursing-implications">E. Nursing implications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-nursing-implications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Teach proper administration</li>
<li>Instruct client to notify physician if edema, redness, or pain do not decrease</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f-common-drugs">F. Common drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-common-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Antibiotics
a. Bacitracin ophthalmia (AK-Tracin)
b. Gentamicin sulfate (Garamycin Ophthalmic)
c. Tobramycin (Tobrex)
d. Sulfacetamide sodium 15% (Sulfair-15 Ophthalmic)</li>
<li>Antifungal: natamycin (Natacyn)</li>
<li>Antiviral: trifluridine (Viroptic)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="agents-used-in-the-ear">AGENTS USED IN THE EAR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#agents-used-in-the-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-antiinfective-agents">I.
