Antiinfective agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-antiinfective-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit or destroy gram-negative or gram-positive microorganisms that cause infection in the ear
B. Uses: treat external auditory canal infections (otitis externa) and middle ear infections (otitis media)
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Superinfections</li>
<li>Hypersensitivity
D. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Assess for hypersensitivity</li>
<li>Assess for culture and sensitivity before administering</li>
<li>Teach the client how to instill the drops (Figure 20-2)</li>
<li>Teach the client to report ringing of the ear and any decrease in hearing</li>
<li>Instruct the client to take all the medication prescribed</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-21ab19b3.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg">
C</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-9dea69ad.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg">
B</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251221-ac242449.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg">
A
Figure 20-2. Ear medication administration. Have client assume side-lying position with ear to be treated facing up, or client may sit in chair or at the bedside. Straighten ear canal by pulling auricle down and back (children) or upward and outward (adult). A, If cerumen or drainage occludes outermost portion of ear canal, wipe out gently with cotton-tipped applicator. Do not force wax inward to block or occlude canal. B, Instill prescribed drops holding dropper 1 cm (½ inch) above ear canal. C, Ask client to remain in side-lying position 2 to 3 minutes. Apply gentle massage or pressure to tragus of ear with finger. At times physician orders insertion of portion of cotton ball into outermost part of canal. Do not press cotton into canal. Remove cotton after 15 minutes. (From Perry A, Potter P: Clinical Nursing Skills and Techniques, ed 3, St Louis, 1994, Mosby.)</p>
<p>EAR MEDS: ADMINISTRATION, ANTIINFLAMMATORIES, CERUMINOLYTICS ▼ 309</p>
<p>E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Topical
a. Chloramphenicol (Chloromycetin Otic)
b. Neosporin</li>
<li>Oral
a. Ampicillin (Polycillin)
b. Trimethoprim + sulfamethoxazole (Septra)
c. Penicillin VK (V-Cillin K)
d. Amoxicillin (Amoxil)
e. Cefaclor (Ceclor)
f. Amphotericin B (Fungizone)
g. Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid (Augmentin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-antiinflammatory-agents">II. Antiinflammatory agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-antiinflammatory-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: inhibit edema and fibrin deposition to decrease inflammation of the ear
B. Use: decrease inflammation in the external ear canal
C. Major side effects: mask underlying otic infections
D. Nursing implications: do not administer if tympanic membrane is ruptured
E. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Dexamethasone sodium phosphate (Ak-dex)</li>
<li>Hydrocortisone acetate (Coly-Mycin S Otic)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-anesthetic-agents">III. Anesthetic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-anesthetic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Action: block nerve conduction
B. Use: relieve ear pain temporarily
C. Common drug: benzocaine (Auralgan Otic)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-ceruminolytic-agents">IV. Ceruminolytic agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-ceruminolytic-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Actions: emulsify hardened or impacted cerumen or prevent accumulation of cerumen
B. Major side effects: local irritation
C. Nursing implications: instruct the client to irrigate the ear for 15 minutes after use and not to use cotton swabs
D. Common drugs</p>
<ol>
<li>Carbamide peroxide (Debrox)</li>
<li>Triethanolamine polypeptide oleate-condensate (Cerumenex)</li>
</ol>
<p>310 ▼ CHAPTER 20 DRUGS AFFECTING THE EAR AND EYE</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Instructions to a mother for instilling drops in a 2-year-old would be as follows
a. Pull the auricle downward and slightly backward
b. Pull the auricle upward and backward
c. Pull the auricle downward and slightly forward
d. Lay the child flat and do not pull the ear in any direction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After an eye examination, the nurse would instruct the client to
a. Expect burning and itching
b. Wear sunglasses and avoid driving
c. Expect blurred vision for several days
d. Avoid reading for several days</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If given with Timoptic drops, which of the following medications would warrant careful monitoring of the cardiovascular system?
a. Dexamethasone
b. Neptazane
c. Diamox
d. Digoxin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To prevent systemic absorption of eye medications, the nurse should
a. Put pressure on the tragus
b. Hold slight pressure on the lacrimal sac for 5 minutes
c. Hold slight pressure on the lacrimal sac for 1 to 3 minutes
d. Gently rub the eye for 1 to 2 minutes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Medications such as carbonic anhydrase inhibitors work in glaucoma by
a. Increasing the formation of aqueous humor
b. Decreasing the formation of aqueous humor
c. Increasing the outflow of aqueous humor
d. Decreasing the outflow of aqueous humor</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 311</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: a</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>This action helps straighten the ear canal in children. The action in response <em>a</em> applies to adults. The action in response <em>c</em> does not assist with ear drops. A flat position may be helpful, but the auricle must be slightly down and back.</td><td>Remember that adults grow “up”; therefore the instillation of ear drops is pull back and “up.” The child is the opposite—pull back and down.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The eyes are often dilated for an examination; also, the sunlight makes vision difficult, since the dilated pupil results in photophobia. Driving could be dangerous if the vision is blurred due to the dilation. Burning and itching may signal an allergic reaction to any agent used. The blurred vision should subside within a few hours after the examination and should be reported if still present 24 hours later. Reading may be difficult if the vision is blurred, but only for a few hours.</td><td>Cluster responses <em>c</em> and <em>d</em> with the time frame of “several days” and eliminate them as not reasonable. Between the remaining responses, use basic knowledge that instilling a substance into the eye to result in burning is inappropriate; select response <em>b</em>.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: d</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Both these agents have the potential for lowering the heart rate; therefore vital signs should be monitored closely. Timoptic has similar properties to the by-mouth</td><td>Go with what you know: the most familiar drug listed is digoxin, and the question is asking about cardiovascular effects. Select response <em>d</em>.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>312 ▼ CHAPTER 20 DRUGS AFFECTING THE EAR AND EYE</p>
<p>beta blockers. The agents in options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> do not interact with Timoptic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-correct-answer-c">4. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is to avoid pressure on the tear duct and to prevent the medication from entering the sinuses. Pressure on the ear, option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>, does not affect eye drops. Option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> is too long a time. Rubbing and excessive blinking should be avoided after application of drops or ointment.</p>
<p>“Go with what you know” if you have no clue of the correct answer. Eliminate option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>, which have nothing to do with systemic absorption. In deciding between options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>, use common sense to select less time of 1 to 3 minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="5-correct-answer-b">5. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Decreasing the aqueous humor is necessary in glaucoma to decrease the intraocular pressure. Options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> would worsen the glaucoma. The formation, not the outflow, of aqueous humor is affected.</p>
<p>Miotic drops constrict the pupil and facilitate the outflow of the aqueous humor from the eye. In carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, the key word to remember is “inhibitors,” which can be associated with a decrease in humor production.</p>
<p>313
CHAPTER 21</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drugs-affecting-sexuality-and-reproduction">Drugs Affecting Sexuality and Reproduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-affecting-sexuality-and-reproduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="study-outcomes">STUDY OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#study-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After completing this chapter, the reader will be able to do the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the uses of agents containing estrogen and progesterone.</li>
<li>Describe the differences between oral contraceptives.</li>
<li>Identify agents and the uses of ovulation stimulants, uterine stimulants, uterine relaxants, and lactation suppressants.</li>
<li>Describe side effects and nursing implications of these agents.</li>
</ul>
<p>314 ▼ CHAPTER 21 DRUGS AFFECTING SEXUALITY AND REPRODUCTION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)</strong>
Also called <strong>menotropin</strong>—a gonadotropin that stimulates the growth and maturation of the graafian follicles in the ovaries in females, and promotes spermatogenesis in males.</p>
<p><strong>Infertility</strong>
Inability to produce offspring.</p>
<p><strong>Luteinizing hormone (LH)</strong>
A glycoprotein. In females LH works together with FSH to stimulate the ovaries to secrete estrogen in which high concentrations stimulate the release of a surge of LH, which stimulates ovulation. In men it induces the secretion of testosterone, which together with FSH stimulates the production of sperm.</p>
<p><strong>Premenstrual syndrome</strong>
A syndrome of nervous tension, irritability, weight gain, edema, headache, mastalgia, dysphoria, and lack of coordination that occurs during the last few days of the menstrual cycle before the onset of menstruation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="content-review">CONTENT REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="female-and-male-sex-hormones">FEMALE AND MALE SEX HORMONES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#female-and-male-sex-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-estrogens">I. Estrogens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-estrogens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>A. Actions:</strong> bind with receptors to produce the same effect as naturally occurring estrogen. Estrogen is needed for the following</p>
<ol>
<li>Female reproductive organs</li>
<li>Secondary sex characteristics
a. Fullness of breasts
b. Appropriate distribution of body fat
c. Soft skin texture
d. Growth and distribution of body hair
e. Female voice</li>
<li>Maintenance of menstrual cycle</li>
<li>Growth of the ducts and nipples of the mammary glands</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>B. Uses</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Menopausal symptoms: hot flashes, night sweats, somatic complaints, fatigue, nervousness, headache, memory loss</li>
<li>Osteoporosis</li>
<li>Menstrual disturbances: abnormal uterine bleeding, premenstrual symptoms, dysmenorrhea</li>
</ol>
<p>ESTROGENS, PROGESTINS ▼ 315</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Prostate cancer and female breast cancer</li>
<li>Oral contraceptives</li>
<li>Postcoital contraception</li>
<li>Lactation suppressant</li>
<li>Acne in females</li>
<li>Prostate cancer treatment in men</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite</li>
<li>Salt and water retention, weight gain</li>
<li>Breast tenderness</li>
<li>Headache</li>
<li>Thromboembolic disorders</li>
<li>Hypertension</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor BP because of hypertension potential</li>
<li>Instruct client to report any breakthrough bleeding—bleeding between cycles of regular menses</li>
<li>Inform male clients receiving estrogen therapy that the female characteristics usually disappear when the therapy is complete and the drug discontinued</li>
<li>Offer instruction on how to use the form ordered: oral, intravaginal, transdermal</li>
<li>Warn against cigarette smoking; side effects are increased in women over 35</li>
<li>Estrogens may alter certain laboratory tests</li>
<li>Monitor weight gain</li>
<li>Emphasize compliance</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Interactions: occur with antidiabetic and anticoagulant drugs (increased dose may be needed)</p>
<p>F. Common agents</p>
<ol>
<li>Chlorotrianisene (Tace)</li>
<li>Conjugated estrogenic substances (Premarin)</li>
<li>Diethylstilbestrol (DES)</li>
<li>Esterified estrogens (Estrace)</li>
<li>Estropipate (Ogen)</li>
</ol>
<p>II. Progestins</p>
<p>A. Actions: replace the missing progesterone by modifying the progesterone molecule from inactivation by the liver. Needed for the following</p>
<ol>
<li>Preparation of the uterus for pregnancy</li>
<li>Development of mammary gland duct during pregnancy</li>
<li>Reduction of spontaneous contractions</li>
</ol>
<p>CHAPTER 21 DRUGS AFFECTING SEXUALITY AND REPRODUCTION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-uses">B. Uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Dysmenorrhea: pain associated with menstruation</li>
<li>Endometriosis: ectopic growth and function of endometrial tissue</li>
<li>Functional uterine bleeding</li>
<li>Prevention of abortion</li>
<li>Premenstrual syndrome (PMS)</li>
<li>Infertility: inability or difficulty in becoming pregnant</li>
<li>Contraception</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Nausea</li>
<li>Weight gain</li>
<li>Dizziness, headache</li>
<li>Decreased libido</li>
<li>Thrombolytic disease</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-contraindicated-in-patients-with-epilepsy-migraine-headaches-cardiac-disorders-and-asthma">D. Contraindicated in patients with epilepsy, migraine headaches, cardiac disorders, and asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-contraindicated-in-patients-with-epilepsy-migraine-headaches-cardiac-disorders-and-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-common-agents">E. Common agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-common-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Provera)</li>
<li>Progesterone (Progestasert)</li>
<li>Norethindrone (Norlutin)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-oral-contraceptives-birth-control-pills">III. Oral contraceptives: birth control pills<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-oral-contraceptives-birth-control-pills" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-actions-block-fsh-and-lh-which-decreases-the-release-of-the-ovum-and-alters-the-viscosity-of-the-mucus-of-the-cervix-thereby-hindering-the-fertilized-ovum-from-implanting-properly">A. Actions: block FSH and LH, which decreases the release of the ovum and alters the viscosity of the mucus of the cervix, thereby hindering the fertilized ovum from implanting properly<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actions-block-fsh-and-lh-which-decreases-the-release-of-the-ovum-and-alters-the-viscosity-of-the-mucus-of-the-cervix-thereby-hindering-the-fertilized-ovum-from-implanting-properly" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-combinations">B. Combinations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-combinations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Fixed dose of estrogen and progestin</li>
<li>Fixed estrogen dose, varying progestin dose (low, then high level in cycle)</li>
<li>Varying amounts of progestin and estrogen</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-major-side-effects">C. Major side effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-major-side-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Early signs of pregnancy: nausea, breast fullness, weight gain, dizziness, fatigue, depression, irregular bleeding</li>
<li>Amenorrhea: the absence of menstruation</li>
<li>Thromboembolic disorders</li>
<li>Carcinogenesis and tumors</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="d-interactions-are-numerous-antibiotics-anticonvulsants-anticoagulants-antihypertensive-agents-caffeine-corticosteroids-analgesics">D. Interactions are numerous: antibiotics, anticonvulsants, anticoagulants, antihypertensive agents, caffeine, corticosteroids, analgesics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-interactions-are-numerous-antibiotics-anticonvulsants-anticoagulants-antihypertensive-agents-caffeine-corticosteroids-analgesics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>CONTRACEPTIVES: ORAL AND OTHER; ANDROGENS ▼ 317</p>
<p>E. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Teach the client how to take the medications: begin on day 5 of the cycle and take 1 pill every day until day 21; then take the 7 pills containing no hormones during the menstrual cycle</li>
<li>Instruct the client that missing a dose could result in pregnancy</li>
<li>Instruct the client to do breasts exams monthly</li>
</ol>
<p>F. Common agents (Table 21-1)</p>
<p>IV. Contraceptives: other devices
A. Spermicides: creams, gels, and foams, which are applied vaginally before penetration and ejaculation. Instruct clients not to douche for 6 to 8 hours afterwards.
B. Contraceptive sponge: contains a spermicide that absorbs the semen
C. Intrauterine devices (IUD): contains a reservoir of progesterone, which must be replaced every year
D. Subdermal implant: the Norplant system, which slowly releases progestin over 5 years
E. Morning-after pill (the estrogen hormone DES): used in rape, incest, or pregnancy when it threatens the woman's mental well-being. Must be taken within 72 hours of intercourse.</p>
<p>V. Androgens
A. Action: replacement therapy of testosterone given orally, subcutaneously, or intramuscularly. Testosterone is needed for the following</p>
<ol>
<li>Male sex characteristics</li>
<li>Normal development of male sex organs and structures (penis, prostate, seminal vesicles)</li>
<li>Synthesis of sperm</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Uses</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypogonadism: a deficiency in the secretory activity of the ovary or testis</li>
<li>Delayed puberty</li>
<li>Palliative management of metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women</li>
<li>Endometriosis</li>
<li>Impotence: inability to achieve penile erection</li>
<li>Oligospermia: insufficient spermatozoa in the semen</li>
</ol>
<p>318</p>
<p>Table 21-1. Oral Contraceptives</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Progestin</th><th>Estrogen</th><th>Progestin: Estrogen Ratio</th><th>Trade Name</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ethynodiol diacetate</td><td>Ethinyl estradiol</td><td>1.0 mg:50 <p>All oral contraceptives are FDA Pregnancy Category X.</p>
<ul>
<li>Available in Canada and United States.
† Triphasic preparation—0.05 mg:30 μg pills are taken the first 6 days of the cycle, 0.075 mg:40 μg pills the next 5 days, and 0.125 mg:30 μg pills the next 10 days of the cycle, followed by a week of no medication or placebo.
‡ Biphasic preparation—0.5 mg:35 μg pills are taken the first 10 days of the cycle, and 1.0 mg:35 μg pills the next 11 days of the cycle, followed by a week of no medication or placebo.
§ Triphasic preparation—0.5 mg:35 μg pills are taken the first 7 days of the cycle, 0.75 mg:35 μg pills the next 7 days, and 1.0 mg:35 μg the next 7 days, followed by a week of no medication or placebo.
¶ Triphasic preparation—0.5 mg:35 μg pills are taken the first 7 days of the cycle, 1.0 mg:35 μg pills the next 9 days, and 0.5 mg:35 μg pills the next 3 days of the cycle, followed by a week of no medication or placebo.
From Clark J, Queener S, Karb V: Pharmacological basis of nursing practice, ed 4, St Louis, 1993, Mosby.</li>
</ul>
<p>320 ▼ CHAPTER 21 DRUGS AFFECTING SEXUALITY AND REPRODUCTION</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Cryptorchidism: failure of one or both testicles to descend</li>
<li>Weight gain in debilitated patients: anabolic steroids, which are closely related to testosterone, increase weight. They are often misused by athletes and weight builders.</li>
</ol>
<p>C. <strong>Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Signs of masculinization in females: hirsutism, acne, deepening of the voice, clitoral enlargement, menstrual irregularities, regression of the breasts</li>
<li>Water and sodium retention, edema</li>
<li>Increased libido</li>
</ol>
<p>D. <strong>Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor weight gain</li>
<li>Emphasize compliance</li>
<li>Teach the female client about potential side effects</li>
<li>Recommend use of nonhormonal contraception</li>
</ol>
<p>E. <strong>Common agents</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Fluoxymesterone (Halotestin)</li>
<li>Testosterone (Testoject)</li>
<li>Testosterone cypionate (Depo-Testosterone)</li>
<li>Danazol (Danocrine)</li>
<li>Anabolic steroids
a. Nandrolone phenopropionate (Durabolin)
b. Nandrolone deconoate (Deca-Durabolin)
c. Oxymetholone (Anadrol)</li>
</ol>
<p>VI. <strong>Ovulation stimulants</strong>
A. <strong>Actions</strong>: stimulate the growth and maturation of ovum and increase the release of gonadotropins
B. <strong>Use</strong>: infertility
C. <strong>Major side effects</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Multiple births</li>
<li>Cyst on ovaries</li>
<li>Breast tenderness</li>
<li>Hot flashes, sweating</li>
</ol>
<p>D. <strong>Nursing implications</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Careful monitoring and compliance with follow-up visits to the physician are necessary</li>
<li>Instruct the client to report any symptoms</li>
<li>After three months, clients usually do not continue medication</li>
</ol>
<p>E. <strong>Common agents</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Clomiphene citrate (Clomid): first choice</li>
<li>Menotropins (Pergonal)</li>
</ol>
<p>OVULATION AND UTERINE STIMULANTS, UTERINE DEPRESSANTS ▼ 321</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Bromocriptine mesylate (Parlodel)</li>
<li>Danazol (Danocrine)</li>
<li>Progesterone (Progestaject)</li>
<li>Chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs-used-during-pregnancy">DRUGS USED DURING PREGNANCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs-used-during-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-uterine-stimulants">I. Uterine stimulants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-uterine-stimulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: stimulate the uterine smooth muscle
B. Groups</p>
<ol>
<li>Oxytocin</li>
<li>Ergot derivatives</li>
<li>Prostaglandins
C. Uses</li>
<li>Inducing more rapid deliveries</li>
<li>Hemorrhages</li>
<li>Post-cesarean section</li>
<li>Abortions
D. Major side effects</li>
<li>Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea</li>
<li>Postpartal hemorrhage</li>
<li>Hypertension
E. Nursing implications</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs</li>
<li>Assess uterine contractions, hemorrhage</li>
<li>Live birth from abortion is possible
F. Common agents</li>
<li>Oxytocin (Pitocin)</li>
<li>Ergot alkaloids
a. Ergonovine maleate (Ergotrate)
b. Methylergonovine maleate (Methergine)</li>
<li>Prostaglandins: dinoprostone (PGF₂)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-uterine-depressants">II. Uterine depressants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-uterine-depressants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. Action: most act on the beta₂ adrenergic receptors to inhibit uterine contractions by relaxation of smooth muscles in the uterus
B. Uses: uncomplicated premature labor, threatened miscarriage
C. Major side effects</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypertension and tachycardia in the mother</li>
<li>Hyperglycemia</li>
<li>Pulmonary edema in the mother</li>
</ol>
<p>322 ▼ CHAPTER 21 DRUGS AFFECTING SEXUALITY AND REPRODUCTION</p>
<p>D. Nursing implications</p>
<ol>
<li>Monitor the VS in the mother and fetal heart tones in the neonate</li>
<li>Place client on her left side</li>
<li>Monitor IV closely on a pump</li>
<li>Stop if complications occur</li>
</ol>
<p>E. Common agents</p>
<ol>
<li>Ritodrine hydrochloride (Yutopar)</li>
<li>Magnesium sulfate</li>
<li>Terbutaline sulfate (Brethine)</li>
</ol>
<p>III. Lactation suppressants
A. Action: prohibit prolactin secretion
B. Use: suppress lactation postdelivery
C. Major side effects: rare
D. Nursing implications: give the agent 1 to 5 days postdelivery
E. Common agents: bromocriptine mesylate (Parlodel)</p>
<p>REVIEW QUESTIONS ▼ 323</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-questions">REVIEW QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A client placed on tetracycline for her bronchitis asks the nurse about continuing with her birth control pills. She is in college and does not want to become pregnant. What should the nurse tell her?
a. Continue taking the birth control pills prescribed
b. Take a double dose for it to be effective
c. Use an additional form of protection such as a spermicide
d. Continue the birth control pills because they will remain effective</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client, age 57, is exhibiting hot flashes, irritability, and extreme fatigue. The doctor determines that she is having menopausal symptoms and would probably recommend a(an)
a. Androgen
b. Estrogen
c. Progesterone
d. Testosterone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When a client enters the hospital, why should the nurse ask about estrogen therapy during the nursing history?
a. It could be useful information
b. Estrogen therapy affects many lab tests
c. Clients on estrogen should be monitored for hypotension
d. Estrogen therapy should not be abruptly withdrawn</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client trying to get pregnant has had no success for the past year. If she is diagnosed with infertility, the first drug of choice would be
a. Clomid
b. Pergonal
c. Parlodel
d. Danocrine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client's husband is transferred to the United States from France during her seventh month of pregnancy. During the stress of moving and a 10-hour flight, she begins to have severe labor pains. Upon arriving, she would most likely be placed on an IV of
a. Parlodel
b. Ergotrate
c. Yutopar
d. Clomid</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>324 ▼ CHAPTER 21 DRUGS AFFECTING SEXUALITY AND REPRODUCTION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: c</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>An additional contraceptive such as a spermicide or condom is recommended. The antibiotic can cause the birth control pills to be less effective. There is no interaction between the two agents. There is a possibility, however, that the birth control pills will be less effective. Doubling the dose may not help and is not advisable. Extra protection by another form of contraception is recommended. There is no guarantee that the birth control pills will remain effective.</td><td>Eliminate responses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> since they are similar. Reread options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>; select <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> since it makes the most sense. Doubling a dose of medication is rarely a correct action. Use the above approach if you have no idea of the correct answer.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>2. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Estrogens act by exerting the same effect as naturally occurring estrogen, which is decreased and responsible for the symptoms during menopause. Androgens are not recommended for menopausal symptoms. Progesterones are more commonly used for menstrual and pre-menstrual symptoms. Testosterone’s action is the same as androgen’s.</td><td>Think of menopause as Early older age and that Estrogen needs to be replaced.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>3. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Laboratory tests, as listed in the text, can be altered. All home</td><td>If you have no idea of the correct answer, try the cluster approach.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 325</p>
<p>medications should be documented upon the client’s entrance into the hospital, but this is not the <em>best</em> answer. Hypertension is a common side effect, partly from the water retention and weight gain. There is no severe complication of stopping the therapy.</p>
<p>Responses <em>a</em>, <em>c</em>, and <em>d</em> are more specific than response <em>b</em>, which talks in general about lab tests. Select response <em>b</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-correct-answer-a">4. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clomid is usually tried first for infertility problems. Pergonal is used for infertility but only after successive tries with Clomid. Parlodel is an ovulation stimulant but is not the first line of choice. Danocrine is usually not the first-line drug.</p>
<p>Remember that Clomid is first alphabetically, so associate that it is a first drug of choice for infertility.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-c">5. Correct answer: c.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Yutopar inhibits uterine contractions and could decrease the chances of premature labor. Parlodel would not stop the possible premature labor. Ergotrate is a uterine stimulant and could induce premature labor. Clomid does not stop premature labor.</p>
<p>For these type of questions that you have no idea of the correct answer, select a response and go on to the next question. Keep your emotional reaction, your tiredness, to a minimum by taking three slow deep breaths. Do this before reading the next question so you will have your clearest perception and thinking ability. Remember that you will have some questions with unfamiliar content area.</p>
<p>^{}[]</p>
<p>Comprehensive Exam
327</p>
<p>328 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="comprehensive-exam-questions">COMPREHENSIVE EXAM QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#comprehensive-exam-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Mrs. Smith is brought into the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. She is experiencing extreme pain in her right arm and an inability to bend her elbow. Stat blood work reveals hypoglycemia and an alcohol level of 250 mg/dl. She has been taking the antidepressant paroxetine hydrochloride (Paxil) once a day. The nurse should be concerned about which of the following effects if the pain medication meperidine (Demerol) is given as ordered?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Extrapyramidal
b. Additive
c. Synergistic
d. Idiosyncracy</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>The nurse would be most concerned about metabolism of drugs in which of the following situations?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Sally, 6 years old, going to surgery for a tonsillectomy
b. Bobby, 43 years old, experiencing a myocardial infarction
c. Fred, 65 years old, admitted with cirrhosis of the liver and diabetes
d. Morgan, 16 years old, recovering from hip surgery following a motor vehicle accident</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Mrs. Moller, age 65, is receiving heparin sodium (Liquaemin Sodium) SQ BID. Which of the following is the correct method to administer the medication?</li>
</ol>
<p>a. 22 gauge, 1 inch needle; 90 degree angle, 0.2 cc airlock, using the vastus lateralis
b. 25 gauge, ½ inch needle; 45 degree angle, no airlock, using the abdomen
c. 25 gauge, 1 inch needle; 45 degree angle, no airlock, using the ventral gluteal
d. 22 gauge, 1 inch needle; 90 degree angle, 0.5 cc airlock, Z-track, using the abdomen</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Mrs. Carter received hydroxyzine hydrochloride (Vistaril), 75 mg as ordered IM q 4 hr PRN for pain. The correct charting entry for administering this injection would be</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Vistaril, 75 mg IM in the deltoid muscle as needed for pain
b. Vistaril, 75 mg deep IM in the hip for complaint of pain
c. Vistaril, 75 mg, IM, Z-track, in the dorsal gluteal for complain of pain
d. Vistaril, 75 mg, IM, Z-track, in the dorsal gluteal for complaint of radiating, constant pain in the hip</p>
<p>COMPREHENSIVE EXAM ▼ 329</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>
<p>The physician orders the following nasogastric feeding for Mrs. James. Order: Ensure Plus 75 cc/hr with no more than 2 L of fluid for 24 hours. How many cc of water will Mrs. James be able to have if water is given every 4 hours and is part of the 2 liters?
a. 30 cc
b. 33 cc
c. 35 cc
d. 40 cc</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Theophylline ethylenediamide (Aminophylline) is being administered per pump to Mr. Jacobs at 35 gtt/min with a minidrip tubing. The bag is mixed with 2 g/500 cc. How many mg is he receiving per hour?
a. 100 mg/hr
b. 140 mg/hr
c. 200 mg/hr
d. 240 mg/hr</p>
</li>
<li>

b. Administer the medication before meals
c. Administer the drug in a suppository dosage form

</li>

</li>

a. 3-HBV, 5-DTP, 4-OPV, 4-HIB, 2-MMR
b. 3-HBV, 4-DTP, 3-OPV, 3-HIB, 1-MMR

<p>A pregnant client presents in labor to the OB floor. The baby is at term and the mother is placed on oxytocin (Pitocin). The nurse should monitor for which side effect? a. Increased uterine blood flow b. Dehydration c. Fetal heart tones of 160 d. Blood pressure of 189/98</p>

<p>A newly diagnosed 16-year-old diabetic asks the nurse what the insulin shots do for her diabetes. Which of the answers listed would be the least correct? a. Insulin transports glucose across the cell membrane b. Insulin promotes conversion of glycogen to glucose c. Insulin increases the absorption of dietary glucose d. Insulin enhances protein synthesis</p>
</li>

<p>Mrs. Hill, a 35-year-old insulin-dependent diabetic, is found unconscious on a nurse's rounds at 4:00 p.m. Because the cause is unknown, the best action would be treatment for a. Ketoacidosis b. Somogyi effect c. Insulin reaction d. Dawn phenomenon</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Joey, an 8-year-old with chronic asthma, is experiencing severe dyspnea. The child is placed on aminophylline because it will a. Produce bronchoconstriction b. Produce bronchodilation c. Increase the oxygen consumption d. Decrease the respiratory rate</p>
</li>

</li>

<p>COMPREHENSIVE EXAM ▼ 337</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips">ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answers-rationales-and-test-taking-tips" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Rationales</th><th>Test-Taking Tips</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>1. Correct answer: b</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>The combination of the alcohol and the antidepressant could produce a greater sum effect. The term in option <em>a</em> means a client exhibits movement disorders similar to those of Parkinson’s disease. The term in option <em>c</em> means agents do not add to the activity of the other. This term in option <em>d</em> means an inherited sensitivity.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>2. Correct answer: c</strong>
The liver is the primary organ for metabolizing drugs. Metabolism should be sufficient in a client age 6 for such a short surgery in option <em>a</em>. The condition in option <em>b</em> should not cause a metabolism problem. The age in option <em>d</em> should not present a metabolism problem.</p>
<p><strong>3. Correct answer: b</strong>
For SC medications no airlock is required, and the abdomen is the preferred site for the quickest absorption. In option <em>a</em> the needle length and gauge are too big, and the site is inappropriate. Note that the angle would be appropriate only if the client were obese. In option <em>c</em> the needle is too long, and the | The strategy here is to go with what you know—more drugs have additive effects than any of the other items given as choices. Avoid selection of unfamiliar terms or concepts.</p>
<p>The key words in the question are “the metabolism of drugs”; avoid focusing on the words “most concerned,” for you may then select the youngest person. Given the age of the clients, the oldest person has the greatest decrease in the metabolic rate. Recall that with aging most body functions decline.</p>
<p>Use the vertical technique to read the responses for the best clarity and quickest understanding. The vertical technique, step 1: read down the first series—the gauge. Immediately eliminate responses <em>a</em> and <em>d</em>, since this size is too large. Of the remaining responses, it seems that response <em>c</em> is incorrect, since 1 inch is typically too long; however, read through the other  |</p>
<p>338 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<p>site is incorrect for SC injections. In option <em>d</em> the length and gauge of the needle are too big; Z-track and an airlock are not required for SC injections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-correct-answer-d">4. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Z-track is identified, and a complete description of the pain is given. Z-track is not identified, and the description of pain is incomplete in options <em>b</em> and <em>c</em>; these are incomplete descriptions. Option <em>c</em> has no description of the pain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-correct-answer-c">5. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>75 cc × 24 hr = 1800 cc
2 L = 2000 cc
2000 cc – 1800 cc = 200 cc. If water is given every 4 hours: 24 hours divided by 4 = 6 times a day or every 6 hours for water.
200 cc divided by 6 times = 33 cc each time water is given. In responses <em>a</em>, <em>b</em>, and <em>d</em> the calculations are incorrect.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-correct-answer-b">6. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>60</mn><mtext>&nbsp;min</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;hr</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>35</mn><mtext>&nbsp;gtt</mtext></mrow><mtext>min</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;cc</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>60</mn><mtext>&nbsp;gtt</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext>&nbsp;g</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>500</mn><mtext>&nbsp;cc</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1000</mn><mtext>&nbsp;mg</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>16</mn><mtext>&nbsp;m</mtext></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>140</mn><mtext>&nbsp;mg/hr</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{60 \text{ min}}{1 \text{ hr}} \times \frac{35 \text{ gtt}}{\text{min}} \times \frac{1 \text{ cc}}{60 \text{ gtt}} \times \frac{2 \text{ g}}{500 \text{ cc}} \times \frac{1000 \text{ mg}}{16 \text{ m}} = 140 \text{ mg/hr}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0309em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3449em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;hr</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;min</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em;
