<p>In options <em>a</em>, <em>c</em>, and <em>d</em> the calculations are incorrect.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-correct-answer-a">7. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Drugs are more readily absorbed in liquid form.</p>
<p>items in that line and note that the site is for an IM injection. Thus select response <em>b</em>.</p>
<p>Select the most comprehensive and specific response as an example of correct documentation.</p>
<p>If you have no idea how to calculate the correct answer, try the numbers strategy. First, eliminate the highest and lowest numbers, responses <em>a</em> and <em>d</em>. Then note that the choices left are 33 and 35 cc; take a conservative approach to select the smaller number—33 cc. Remember to use this approach ONLY when you have no idea how to calculate the answer.</p>
<p>If you have no idea how to calculate the answer try the numbers strategy—eliminate the highest and lowest numbers, responses <em>a</em> and <em>d</em>. With the remaining responses be conservative and select the smaller number, <em>b</em>.</p>
<p>The key words in the question are “an absorption difficulty.” The</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 339</p>
<p>Obtaining the liquid form needs no new order; simply notify the pharmacy to change the medication to a liquid form. There is not enough information to determine this as a need in option b. The rectal route is sometimes unreliable in the elderly. Frequency may not be the problem.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-correct-answer-b">8. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Narcan counteracts the effects of narcotics such as Demerol, but the duration of action is short and the findings of the overdose may return quickly. The usual dose of 1 mg IV push can be repeated without adverse effects. BAL is recommended for heavy metals like gold, lead, copper, mercury, and arsenic; it binds with these substances to form a water-soluble complex that is removed by the kidneys. It is given deep IM. Mucomyst is used for Tylenol overdose. It is typically mixed with iced juice or soda, given by mouth QID for 4 days. Activated charcoal, given by mouth or nasogastric tube, is used to bind with caustic agents.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9-correct-answer-c">9. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All three of these symptoms are common, depending on the type and frequency of the narcotic used. Beta blockers do not cause cough suppression but can cause common sense approach leads to response a (change the medication to a liquid form).</p>
<p>Cluster responses c and d under "given by mouth." BAL is given IM; eliminate it as a choice, since it takes 15 to 20 minutes for effectiveness. Select Narcan; it is given IV, and with a narcotic overdose the route with the most immediate effect is the best choice. Remember for Narcotics give Narcan to negate the action of this group of medications.</p>
<p>Remember that beta blockers (BB) have the most common side effects of BB—bronchospasm and bradycardia. Cholinergic agents such as reglan and urecholine may cause intestinal cramps or bladder</p>
<p>340 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<p>constipation and bradypnea. Anticonvulsants do not typically cause these reactions. Cholinergic agents cause the opposite effects.</p>
<ol start="10">
<li><strong>Correct answer: d</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>MS is chosen because it is most effective and rapid acting to eliminate cardiac pain. It is typically given IV, with the dose titrated, until the client is pain free. Dilaudid can be used for MI because it is a morphine type of drug; a side effect however, is severe respiratory depression, which may not be desirable with cardiac clients. Dilaudid is the drug of choice for clients with severe pain from terminal diseases. Darvon is too weak for the rapid relief needed with an MI. Tylenol no. 3 is an effective pain medication but is not typically used for MI, since it is given by mouth and would take too long to have the desired and rapid effect.</p>
<ol start="11">
<li><strong>Correct answer: c</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>Aspirin should be avoided in children, especially those with viral infections, which are possible in this situation because the antibiotic has not produced any response. The complication from aspirin in children is Reye’s syndrome. Ibuprofen is effective in spasms. Anticonvulsants typically cause a side effect of drowsiness.</p>
<p>Remember that morphine is the drug of choice for cardiac pain, even if the blood pressure has dropped from other therapy. The nurse would probably adjust the nitroglycerine drip and medicate the client with morphine.</p>
<p>If you found this question to be easy, smile, take a deep breath, and relax. There will be similar easy questions on the exam. Use them to help you relax and think more clearly on the different questions.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 341</p>
<p>lowering temperature and can be alternated with Tylenol. Tylenol is preferred in children. Tepid baths will effectively relieve temperature in children.</p>
<ol start="12">
<li><strong>Correct answer: b</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>Ergostat constricts smooth muscle in peripheral and cranial blood vessels, yet relaxes uterine muscles. It is typically used by sublingual route for vascular headaches from migraines or histamine release. Ibuprofen is too weak for the vascular response of a migraine. Benadryl has been used at bedtime to provide some clients with relief from headaches. It is ineffective in acute attacks and typically causes sedation. Option <em>d</em> could produce sedation without relief of severe pain.</p>
<p>Migraine headaches are thought to be the result of cerebral vasodilation. The best drugs are those that have a vasoconstriction effect, such as ergotamine tartrate.</p>
<ol start="13">
<li><strong>Correct answer: b</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>Jitters, nervousness, and tachycardia are common with therapeutic doses of aminophylline. Tachycardia is expected and usually controlled by adjusting the aminophylline drip if the client exhibits other symptoms. Tremors are findings of toxicity, when serum theophylline levels &gt;20 mEq.</p>
<p>Remember that any of the bronchodilators may have findings similar to sympathetic effect—bronchodilation, tachycardia, and nervousness. In addition, the urine output of a client on aminophylline may increase, since it has a slight diuretic effect.</p>
<p>342 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-correct-answer-a">14. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are typical reactions to anticholinergic agents such as atropine. The opposite effects of those in option <em>b</em> can be seen from anticholinesterase agents such as Mestinon, except for the dry mouth and flushed skin. These effects in option <em>c</em> are not seen with adrenergic blocking agents. These side effects in option <em>d</em> are not seen with noncatecholamines.</p>
<p>Remember that the Cholinergic or parasympathetic system is the Common system used daily for normal bodily functions—moist mouth, urine output, regular heart rate, and bowel movements. The Adrenergic or sympathetic system is used only for an Adventure of new experiences (the fight or flight response)—dilated pupils, dry mouth, increased heart rate, and dilated bronchials.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="15-correct-answer-c">15. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#15-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The positive inotropic effect increases blood to the kidneys and polyuria; the negative chronotropic effect decreases HR. No respiratory response such as bradypnea should be seen. Option <em>d</em> presents opposite effects.</p>
<p>Responses <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> can be eliminated; the heart and lungs work together, in that both will be tachy or brady. As in these responses, if tachycardia is with bradypnea or visa versa, the response is incorrect. In deciding between responses <em>c</em> and <em>d</em>, remember that “inotropic” starts with an “i,” yet it means contractility; “chronotropic” begins with a “c,” yet it means rate. Think in inverse terms for these two words. Positive Inotropic is increased Contractility. Negative Chronotropic is decreased heart rate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="16-correct-answer-a">16. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#16-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the symptoms return before the next dose, it is called end-of-dose deterioration. With the on-off phenomenon, symptoms return at any time despite the continuous medication schedule. In option <em>c</em> it is unlikely to be</p>
<p>To make the correct selection, simply think of the description of when the medication is given in contrast to when the symptoms occur. The medication is given at 9 A.M. and 1 P.M. and 5 P.M., with the symptoms at 12 noon and 4 P.M.—both of these times are 1 hour before the next dose.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 343</p>
<p>both. Toxicity findings would be sustained and not decreased between doses.</p>
<ol start="17">
<li>Correct answer: b
A slow improvement should be noted with each administration of the agent. The sedation does not suddenly disappear. Severe sedation is not desirable for safety reasons, and a different medication should be tried. The sedation should not worsen unless the dose is increased.</li>
</ol>
<p>The key word in response a that makes it incorrect is “suddenly.” Eliminate response c, since it reflects a rote or slang type of answer. Eliminate response d, since it reads, “this side effect may get worse but still control the seizure.” The side effect does not control the seizure; the medication effects control the seizure.</p>
<ol start="18">
<li>Correct answer: d
Benzodiazepine (Valium) works most effectively in status epilepticus. Ativan can also be used and may be preferred, since it has less of a sedating effect than Valium. Dilantin can be used but is usually not the drug of choice. Phenobarbital can be used but is also not the drug of choice mainly because of the sedating properties. Option c is recommended for petit mal seizure activity.</li>
</ol>
<p>The key term in the stem is “status epilepticus,” not epilepsy.</p>
<ol start="19">
<li>Correct answer: c
Hypertension is the most common and serious side effect of combining foods containing tyramine with MAO inhibitors. In option a the opposite effect is noted. Heart rate is unaffected.</li>
</ol>
<p>Recall that a MAO inhibitor results in hypertension if foods with tyramine are eaten.</p>
<p>344 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="20-correct-answer-d">20. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#20-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Antipsychotic agents are usually major tranquilizers that can cause extrapyramidal effects such as these. Cogentin and Artane are given to counteract these side effects. Sedation is the most common side effect with options <em>a</em> and <em>b</em>. Hypertension is the common side effect with option <em>c</em>.</p>
<p>Remember that Tranquilizers result in Tardive dyskinesia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="21-correct-answer-a">21. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#21-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An additive effect can occur with alcohol (CNS depressant), which is in any elixir. Aspirin may improve the condition due to its antiinflammatory properties. No noticeable effect is documented with option <em>c</em>. Aldomet is used for hypertension and should not cause severe interactions.</p>
<p>Associate the factor of relaxants and match up the muscle relaxant with the benylin elixir that relaxes the cough reflex. Remember that alcohol commonly results in an additive effect when it is combined with medications that depress the nervous system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="22-correct-answer-a">22. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#22-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Epinephrine prolongs the effect of the local agent and decreases bleeding as a result of the local vasoconstrictive effects. Option <em>b</em> would not help the suturing process or procedure. Option <em>c</em> would be used for bleeding disorders. The client should be assessed for the last tetanus to have been within the prior 10 years, but this will not aid the suturing time.</p>
<p>The key term in the stem is “local anesthetic,” which is typically given subcutaneously. A need during any laceration is to control bleeding by vasoconstriction, and the only drug in the responses that vasoconstricts is epinephrine.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 345</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="23-correct-answer-b">23. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#23-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Both agents decrease blood pressure. Narcotics cause pinpoint pupils. Both agents are CNS depressants and would not increase the BP. Effects on the heart rate should not necessarily be seen.</p>
<p>Recall that narcotics and anesthetics both depress the body functions. Use common sense to select response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>, hypotension.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="24-correct-answer-a">24. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#24-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Drugs that alter urinary status should be avoided. Renal toxicity is a typical problem of clients on lithium. There is no interaction between a high-sodium diet and this drug. An antacid could be taken with this agent without any effects. Milk products should not interfere with this drug.</p>
<p>Think of the responses in more general terms: a renal drug, a special diet, a GI drug, and dairy products. Use an educated approach and determine which of these factors warrants the most concern. Of course the renal system would have the highest priority—select response <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="25-correct-answer-a">25. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#25-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Taking Elavil at bedtime is best for offering a good night's sleep and decreasing the sedative effect during waking hours. Elavil given as early as in option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> may cause drowsiness too early in the evening. The times in options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> would cause too much sedation for early morning and afternoon.</p>
<p>If the medication's effect is unknown and the data given are nonspecific, select bedtime to give medication.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="26-correct-answer-b">26. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#26-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Safety measures should be taken with any sedative. The nurse should document that</p>
<p>If in doubt put the rails up, no matter what the age or the condition, especially if the</p>
<p>346 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<p>the rails were raised and that the client received and agreed with the instruction to keep the rails up. Option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> is an unsafe action from a legal view. If the client refuses, this should be noted in the nurse's notes. He should not have a choice for side rail position because he has received a sedative. All side rails are raised for safety.</p>
<ol start="27">
<li><strong>Correct answer: a</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>The negative chronotropic effect of Lanoxin decreases the HR. In options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> the fast rate and irregular rhythm would both warrant using Lanoxin. In option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>, the Lanoxin is maintaining the rate within normal ranges and a regular rhythm.</p>
<ol start="28">
<li><strong>Correct answer: d</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>A low serum potassium from the loop diuretic, plus the cardiac glycoside, increase the possibility of toxicity. Options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> are incorrect; these drugs should not cause interactions.</p>
<ol start="29">
<li><strong>Correct answer: b</strong></li>
</ol>
<p>Hypotension is a common and possibly serious side effect requiring close monitoring during administration. The client has been given a sedative.</p>
<p>Remember that Lanoxin is to be held if the heart rate is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '&amp;' at position 1: &amp;̲lt;60" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">&amp;lt;60</span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '&amp;' at position 1: &amp;̲gt;120" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">&amp;gt;120</span></span> and the rhythm is irregular. Remember 60 and then double it to get the maximum rate. Also note that of the given heart rates, the nurse would be most concerned about either the 45 or the 150 heart rate. Then think—digoxin is given for fast rates, so the correct answer must be <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Think of the responses in more general terms: antiinflammatories in responses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>, antihypertensives, and a renal drug. If you have no idea of a correct response, select the renal drug, since the renal system is a priority system.</p>
<p>Of the given responses, the low blood pressure is a priority. Note that this is related to the cardiovascular system, which</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 347</p>
<p>opposite effect occurs in option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>. GI effects are not common side effects. Option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> is not a common side effect. <p>takes precedent over the GI system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="30-correct-answer-c">30. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#30-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients learn to tolerate and to use medication before or right after the nitroglycerin dose for the relief of pain. Preventing the headache entirely may be impossible, but something can be taken to decrease the severity and to relieve the pain. Option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> is a common side effect with the normal dose. Usually a nonnarcotic drug such as Tylenol is effective.</p>
<p>Eliminate options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span> since neither make sense and are a correct approach. Between options <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>, eliminate option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span> because of the words “must tolerate” and “nothing . . . stop . . . pain.” These absolutes give a clue this is an incorrect answer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="31-correct-answer-a">31. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#31-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Inderal is used for chronic, not acute, cardiac pain. It is used to prevent angina. If the drug is stopped suddenly, the client may experience rebound, severe angina. The IV form of NTG is often given after the SL nitroglycerin is tried. The SL form of Isordil is used effectively for angina. In option <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>, procardia is a capsule that contains liquid that can be squirted under the tongue, may provide for quick relief of acute pain or hypertensive episodes.</p>
<p>Be very cautious in reading this question. If you missed the word “least,” you probably answered it incorrectly. Cluster the responses by usual route: Inderal—PO, Tridil—IV drip, Isordil—SL, and Procardia—PO or SL. Note that the PO medication would take the longest to be effective, so it is the least likely to be administered.</p>
<p>348 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="32-correct-answer-c">32. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#32-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Beta blockers can worsen COPD due to the side effects on the respiratory system. Nitroglycerin is safe with COPD clients. Calcium channel blockers are usually safe to administer. Calan is also a calcium channel blocker.</p>
<p>Remember that Inderal is a <em>Beta Blocker</em>. Major side effects: Bradycardia and Bronchospasm—<em>BB</em> = <em>BB</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="33-correct-answer-a">33. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#33-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Thiazides are potassium-loosing, and this potassium level is below normal. Option <em>b</em> is a normal level for potassium. The diuretic should not alter the glucose. Option <em>d</em> is a normal level for sodium.</p>
<p>An approach to this question is to identify the lab value that is the farthest from normal values and at a dangerous level. The glucose is elevated but not to a dangerous level. The potassium is low and at a dangerous level. With serum potassium levels, a small variation from the normal values, 3.5 to 5.0 mEq/L, is quite dangerous.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="34-correct-answer-a">34. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#34-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>OTC cold and cough preparations tend to increase the BP in hypertensive clients. The label warning clearly indicates not to use if taking medication for hypertension. Sedation could occur due to the type of product used, but this should not interfere with the BP. No effect should be seen on heart rate. The opposite effect from option <em>d</em> is seen.</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct answer, use a combination approach of education and common sense. The question is about a client with hypertension; select a response with BP in it, either <em>a</em> or <em>d</em>. Then select the high pressure, since this is the more common problem for hypertensives than low pressure is.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="35-correct-answer-b">35. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#35-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Both of these agents can cause ototoxicity. Usually with the loop diuretic it is from an IV</p>
<p>The most important approach is to read the question carefully. The question is asking about “both”</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 349</p>
<p>administration that was too rapidly injected, &gt;10 mg/minute. Option <em>a</em> is a normal potassium level. The diuretic could drop the level but not necessarily in combination with the antibiotic. Some of the antibiotics in this classification in option <em>c</em> carry this side effect, but the Lasix does not. The diuretic may have this side effect in option <em>d</em> due to potassium loss.</p>
<p><strong>36. Correct answer: c</strong></p>
<p>The loop diuretics are fast acting and extremely potent. Responses <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> would not be the diuretics of choice. Response <em>d</em> is used for hypertension.</p>
<p><strong>37. Correct answer: d</strong></p>
<p>The most common and severe complication from anticoagulation is hemorrhage. Not enough information is given to know if pulmonary embolus is a concern. Urticaria is common but would have occurred early, the first day after the initial medication was given. Option <em>c</em> is not a side effect of an anticoagulant.</p>
<p><strong>38. Correct answer: c</strong></p>
<p>Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation. Hemostatic effects stop bleeding. Option <em>b</em> would correct free drugs—not just one. Note that response <em>d</em>, muscle cramps, is an effect of loop diuretics when the serum potassium levels drop. Response <em>c</em>, nephrotoxicity, is a side effect of the aminoglycosides. Since the K level is normal in response <em>a</em>, the only answer left is <em>b</em>.</p>
<p>Try the approach of going with what you know—Lasix is a potent diuretic, used most commonly in acute situations. Avoid selecting a drug with which you are not familiar.</p>
<p>Another approach is to cluster responses <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> under “allergic type of responses.” Since these would have occurred earlier, eliminate them. Between the remaining responses, the renal system problem takes precedent over a sore throat.</p>
<p>Note that ASA has many effects: antipyretic, antiinflammatory, antiplatelet or anticoagulant, and analgesic.</p>
<p>350 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<p>bleeding for a client with hemophilia. Thrombolytic effects dissolve clots such as with streptokinase.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="39-correct-answer-c">39. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#39-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Parent education should emphasize that the illnesses are far worse than the side effects of the immunizations. This response in option <em>a</em> would only scare the mother further. Written information must be given to the parent from the office or physician, but option <em>b</em> is not the best response. The killed forms can be chosen at most offices, but these forms do not offer the best immunization.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="40-correct-answer-a">40. Correct answer: a<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#40-correct-answer-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is the most complete schedule for a child entering school. The second MMR may not be required in some states. Option <em>b</em> is an incomplete series of DTP, OPV, and HIB. In option <em>c</em> the HBV series should be completed. Option <em>d</em> has an incomplete series of DTP.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="41-correct-answer-d">41. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#41-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The medication must be diluted. It is typically used as a temporary treatment for hyperthyroid conditions. SSKI is a similar medication. Both of these inhibit the release of the thyroid</p>
<p>Response <em>a</em> describes the effects as “severe,” which is unlikely. Response <em>b</em> has the absolute “all” in it; quite unlikely that the physician will tell “all” the information. Of the two responses left, response <em>c</em> is more complete.</p>
<p>Try to remember the series as a countdown, as well as somewhat alphabetical with a switch in the middle between HIB and HBV:
5 DPT
4 HIB, 4 OPV
3 HBV
2 MMR (think 2 Ms)</p>
<p>Try an educated guess and match the solution in the question with response <em>d</em>, which is the only one that presents information about a liquid.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 351</p>
<p>hormones. Bedtime dosing is not required. Vital signs are not necessary before administration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="42-correct-answer-d">42. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#42-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hypertension is a side effect and should be monitored during administration. The side effect is a decreased uterine blood flow. Water intoxication or overhydration, not dehydration, is a side effect. FHT should be monitored, but this value is within normal limits.</p>
<p>If you have no idea of the correct response, try to go with what you know—select response d, the high blood pressure, which is obviously too high.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="43-correct-answer-c">43. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#43-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the least correct answer because it is not true. Options a, b, and d are normal actions of insulin.</p>
<p>Note the key word “least.” Response c is the least correct answer because of the key words “absorption” and “dietary glucose.” These words suggest that insulin has an effect in the GI tract. It does not, since it is destroyed if taken orally; besides, insulin is always given parenterally.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="44-correct-answer-b">44. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#44-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The physician should be called because of the route. Only rapid-acting, regular insulin is given IV. The nurse would be taking responsibility for her action if the medication were given as ordered. Option c could be an appropriate action, but the nurse should know that only regular insulin is given IV. A nurse cannot change the route without notifying the physician.</p>
<p>If you narrow the responses to b and c, select b, since there is not enough information in the stem for the action of consulting another nurse. It just states “about the order”—what about the order? the route? the dose? More specific information is needed in the stem or the response.</p>
<p>352 ▼ COMPREHENSIVE EXAM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="45-correct-answer-c">45. Correct answer: c<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#45-correct-answer-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most likely cause if A.M. NPH insulin were given; an insulin reaction is anticipated at this time of the day. A STAT glucose should be obtained. Option <em>a</em> is not the most likely response if the client received insulin in the A.M. Given the client’s history, NPH insulin was most likely given that morning. The somogyi effect is a rebound effect of hypoglycemia from 3 to 4 A.M. Not enough information is given for selection of this response. The dawn phenomenon usually manifests a high glucose early in the morning.</p>
<p>Note the clues in the stem—“insulin dependent” and “found unconscious”—think insulin reaction or acute hypoglycemia. If the glucose is low, 50% glucose would be given IV push. If the glucose is high, IV regular insulin would be given.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="46-correct-answer-b">46. Correct answer: b<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#46-correct-answer-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bronchodilation is the main action that assists asthmatics. Option <em>a</em> is the opposite effect and would worsen the dyspnea. The drug itself does not increase the oxygen consumption; this will be caused by the bronchodilation then delivery of oxygen to the tissues. The relief obtained from the bronchodilation could lower the respiratory rate; however, the rate may not be fast, only labored.</p>
<p>The stem gives no information on the respiratory rate; response <em>d</em> is not appropriate. Eliminate response <em>c</em>, since medications are not routinely given to increase oxygen use, especially if the client is having difficulty breathing. Then, common sense guides the selection of response <em>b</em>, bronchodilation. Bronchoconstriction is inappropriate for any client in respiratory distress or otherwise.</p>
<p>ANSWERS, RATIONALES, AND TEST-TAKING TIPS ▼ 353</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="47-correct-answer-d">47. Correct answer: d<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#47-correct-answer-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Relief is obtained temporarily; the rebound congestion can increase the frequency of use. Option <em>a</em> is not a typical side effect of nasal sprays. A drying effect, not inflammation or nasal drip, should occur as an action of the agent. Option <em>c</em> is not a typical side effect of nasal sprays.</p>
<p>The clue in the stem is “excessive” use. Think of these sprays as having local effects of vasoconstriction and decreased congestion in the nasal membranes. Thus frequent use will result in rebound effects opposite of the therapeutic effect.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b">B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>Bronchodilators, 238-241
classification, 238
methylxanthines, 240-241
sympathomimetics, 238-240

<p>Instructions for Disk Start-Up</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dos-version">DOS Version<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dos-version" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="system-requirements">System Requirements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#system-requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A computer with at least 324K of RAM (Random Access Memory) available is needed for this program. This computer must be IBM PC or 100% compatible.</p>
<p>For these examples we assume that your A drive is your floppy drive, and your C drive is your hard drive. Please substitute the letter of your floppy drive for A if your floppy drive letter is different. Substitute the letter of your hard drive for C if your hard drive letter is different.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="start-up-floppy-drive">Start-up (floppy drive):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#start-up-floppy-drive" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Turn your computer on</li>
<li>At the prompt, insert the disk into your A drive</li>
<li>Type A: and press &lt;enter&gt;</li>
<li>Type MOSBY and press &lt;enter&gt;</li>
<li>Follow the instructions on the screen</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="start-up-hard-disk">Start-up (hard disk):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#start-up-hard-disk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Turn your computer on</li>
<li>At the prompt, insert the disk into your A drive</li>
<li>Type C: and press &lt;enter&gt;</li>
<li>Type MD\MOSBY and press &lt;enter&gt;</li>
<li>Type CD\MOSBY and press &lt;enter&gt;</li>
<li>Type COPY A:<em>.</em> and press &lt;enter&gt;</li>
</ol>
<p>The software is now installed on your hard drive. Once the software is installed, start the software by following these directions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Type CD\MOSBY and press &lt;enter&gt;</li>
<li>Type MOSBY and press &lt;enter&gt;</li>
<li>Follow the directions on the screen</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mac-version">MAC Version<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mac-version" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="system-requirements">System Requirements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#system-requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Mac 68XXX or Power Mac with a total of at least 1 MB of RAM is needed for this program.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="start-up">Start-up:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#start-up" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Create a new folder on your hard disk called MOSBY.</li>
<li>Insert the disk into your floppy drive and open it.</li>
<li>Drag all items from the disk to the new folder.</li>
</ol>
<p>The software is now installed on your hard drive. Once the software is installed, start the software by following these directions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Open the MOSBY folder.</li>
<li>Select the MOSBY program.</li>
<li>Follow the directions on the screen.</li>
</ol>
<p>WRITE DOWN THE PASSWORD THAT YOU HAVE SELECTED. YOUR DISK WILL BE BRANDED WITH THIS INITIAL ENTRY.&lt;/enter&gt;&lt;/enter&gt;&lt;/enter&gt;&lt;/enter&gt;&lt;/enter&gt;&lt;/enter&gt;&lt;/enter&gt;&lt;/enter&gt;&lt;/enter&gt;</p>
